    proxy statement will be filed under the Securities Exchange Act
    of 1934 within 120&#160;days of the end of US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.&#146;s fiscal year ended December&#160;31, 2006, are
    incorporated by reference into Part&#160;III of this Annual
    Report on
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Form&#160;10-K.</FONT>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 3%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    America West Airlines, Inc. meets the conditions set forth in
    General Instruction&#160;I(1)(a) and (b)&#160;and is therefore
    filing this form with reduced disclosure format pursuant to
    General Instruction&#160;I(2).
</DIV>

<DIV align="right" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I><FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(Continued on following
    page)</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 8pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    This combined Annual Report on
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Form&#160;10-K</FONT>
    is filed by US&#160;Airways Group, Inc. (&#147;US&#160;Airways
    Group&#148;) and its direct and indirect wholly owned
    subsidiaries US&#160;Airways, Inc. (&#147;US&#160;Airways&#148;)
    and America West Airlines, Inc. (&#147;AWA&#148;). AWA is a
    wholly owned subsidiary of America West Holdings Corporation
    (&#147;America West Holdings&#148;), which is a wholly owned
    subsidiary of US&#160;Airways Group. References in this
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Form&#160;10-K</FONT>
    to &#147;we,&#148; &#147;us,&#148; &#147;our&#148; and the
    &#147;Company&#148; refer to US&#160;Airways Group and its
    consolidated subsidiaries.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Note&#160;Concerning
    Forward-Looking Statements</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Certain of the statements contained in this report should be
    considered &#147;forward-looking statements&#148; within the
    meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
    These forward-looking statements may be identified by words such
    as &#147;may,&#148; &#147;will,&#148; &#147;expect,&#148;
    &#147;intend,&#148; &#147;anticipate,&#148; &#147;believe,&#148;
    &#147;estimate,&#148; &#147;plan,&#148; &#147;project,&#148;
    &#147;could,&#148; &#147;should,&#148; and &#147;continue&#148;
    and similar terms used in connection with statements regarding
    our outlook, expected fuel costs, the revenue environment, and
    our expected financial performance. These statements include,
    but are not limited to, statements about the benefits of the
    business combination transaction involving America West Holdings
    and US&#160;Airways Group, including future financial and
    operating results, our plans, objectives, expectations and
    intentions and other statements that are not historical facts.
    These statements are based upon the current beliefs and
    expectations of management and are subject to significant risks
    and uncertainties that could cause our actual results and
    financial position to differ materially from these statements.
    These risks and uncertainties include, but are not limited to,
    those described below under Item&#160;1A. &#147;Risk
    Factors&#148; and the following:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    the impact of high fuel costs, significant disruptions in the
    supply of aircraft fuel and further significant increases to
    fuel prices;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    our high level of fixed obligations and our ability to obtain
    and maintain financing for operations and other purposes;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    our ability to achieve the synergies anticipated as a result of
    the merger and to achieve those synergies in a timely manner;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    our ability to integrate the management, operations and labor
    groups of US&#160;Airways Group and America West Holdings;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TD>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    the impact of global instability, including the current
    instability in the Middle East, the continuing impact of the
    military presence in Iraq and Afghanistan, the terrorist attacks
    of September&#160;11, 2001 and the potential impact of future
    hostilities, terrorist attacks, infectious disease outbreaks or
    other global events that affect travel behavior;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->
<A name='101'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">PART&#160;I</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<A name='102'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Item&#160;1.<I>&#160;&#160;</I></FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Business</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Overview</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group, a Delaware corporation, is a holding
    company formed in 1982 and whose origins trace back to the
    formation of All American Aviation in 1939. US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s principal executive offices are located at
    111&#160;West Rio Salado Parkway, Tempe, Arizona 85281.
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s telephone number is
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">(480)&#160;693-0800,</FONT>
    and its internet address is <I>www.usairways.com.</I>
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s primary business activity is the
    operation of a major network air carrier, through its ownership
    of the common stock of America West Holdings and its wholly
    owned subsidiary AWA; US&#160;Airways; Piedmont Airlines, Inc.
    (&#147;Piedmont&#148;); PSA Airlines, Inc. (&#147;PSA&#148;);
    Material Services Company, Inc. (&#147;MSC&#148;); and Airways
    Assurance Limited. On September&#160;12, 2004, US&#160;Airways
    Group and its domestic subsidiaries, US&#160;Airways, Piedmont,
    PSA and MSC (collectively, the &#147;Reorganized Debtors&#148;),
    which at the time accounted for substantially all of the
    operations of US&#160;Airways Group, filed voluntary petitions
    for relief under Chapter&#160;11 of the U.S.&#160;Bankruptcy
    Code in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern
    District of Virginia, Alexandria Division. On May&#160;19, 2005,
    US&#160;Airways Group signed a merger agreement, subsequently
    amended on July&#160;7, 2005, with America West Holdings
    pursuant to which America West Holdings merged with a wholly
    owned subsidiary of US&#160;Airways Group. The plan of
    reorganization of US&#160;Airways Group and its domestic
    subsidiaries was confirmed by the Bankruptcy Court on
    September&#160;16, 2005. The merger became effective upon
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s emergence from bankruptcy on
    September&#160;27, 2005. Following the merger, America West
    Holdings continued as a wholly owned subsidiary of
    US&#160;Airways Group.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Since the merger, US&#160;Airways Group has been moving toward
    operating under the single brand name of
    &#147;US&#160;Airways&#148; through its two principal
    subsidiaries US&#160;Airways and AWA. We expect to complete the
    integration of our two principal subsidiaries into one operation
    during 2007. As a result of the merger, through our two
    principal operating subsidiaries, we operate the fifth largest
    airline in the United States as measured by domestic revenue
    passenger miles (&#147;RPMs&#148;) and available seat miles
    (&#147;ASMs&#148;). For the years ended December&#160;31, 2006,
    2005 and 2004, passenger revenues accounted for approximately
    93%, 92% and 93%, respectively, of our operating revenues. Cargo
    revenues and other sources accounted for 7%, 8% and 7% of our
    operating revenues in 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. We have
    primary hubs in Charlotte, Philadelphia and Phoenix and
    secondary hubs/focus cities in Pittsburgh, Las Vegas, New York,
    Washington,&#160;D.C. and Boston. We are a low-cost carrier
    offering scheduled passenger service on approximately 4,000
    flights daily to 240 communities in the U.S., Canada, the
    Caribbean, Latin America and Europe, making us the only
    U.S.&#160;based low-cost carrier with a significant
    international route presence. We are also the only low-cost
    carrier with an established East Coast route network, including
    the US&#160;Airways Shuttle service, with substantial presence
    at capacity constrained airports including New York&#146;s
    LaGuardia Airport and the Washington,&#160;D.C. area&#146;s
    Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport. Starting in December
    2005, we expanded our route network to include Hawaii. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, our two principal subsidiaries operated
    359 mainline jets and are supported by our regional airline
    subsidiaries and affiliates operating as US&#160;Airways
    Express, which operate approximately 240 regional jets and 104
    turboprops.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways had approximately 36&#160;million passengers
    boarding its planes in 2006. As of December&#160;31, 2006,
    US&#160;Airways operated 226 jet aircraft. During 2006,
    US&#160;Airways provided regularly scheduled service or seasonal
    service at 85 airports in the continental United States, Canada,
    the Caribbean, Latin America and Europe. As of December&#160;31,
    2006, the US&#160;Airways Express network served 133 airports in
    the United States, Canada and the Bahamas, including
    approximately 40 airports also served by US&#160;Airways. During
    2006, US&#160;Airways Express air carriers had approximately
    20&#160;million passengers boarding their planes. Passenger
    revenues accounted for approximately 90% of
    US&#160;Airways&#146; operating revenues in each of the three
    years ended December&#160;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004. Cargo
    revenues and other sources accounted for approximately 10% of
    US&#160;Airways&#146; operating revenues in 2006, 2005 and 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA had approximately 21&#160;million passengers boarding its
    planes in 2006. As of December&#160;31, 2006, AWA operated 133
    jet aircraft. During 2006, AWA provided regularly scheduled
    service or seasonal service at 67 airports in the continental
    United States, Hawaii, Alaska, Canada and Latin America. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, the AWA Express network served 62
    airports in the United States, Canada and Latin America,
    including approximately 31
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    4
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    airports also served by AWA. During 2006, AWA&#146;s Express air
    carrier had approximately 7&#160;million passengers boarding its
    planes. For the years ended December&#160;31, 2006, 2005 and
    2004, passenger revenues accounted for approximately 94%, 93%
    and 93%, respectively, of AWA&#146;s operating revenues. Cargo
    revenues and other sources accounted for approximately 6%, 7%
    and 7% of AWA&#146;s operating revenues in 2006, 2005 and 2004,
    respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For information regarding operating revenue in US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s and US&#160;Airways&#146; principal geographic
    areas, see notes&#160;15 and 13 to the respective financial
    statements included in Items&#160;8A and 8C of this
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Form&#160;10-K.</FONT>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our results are seasonal. Operating results are typically
    highest in the second and third quarters due to greater demand
    for air and leisure travel during the summer months and
    US&#160;Airways&#146; and AWA&#146;s combination of business
    traffic and North-South leisure traffic in the eastern and
    western United States during those periods.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Material Services Company and Airways Assurance Limited operate
    in support of our airline subsidiaries in areas such as the
    procurement of aviation fuel and insurance.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    You may read and copy any materials US&#160;Airways Group, AWA
    or US&#160;Airways files with the Securities and Exchange
    Commission (&#147;SEC&#148;) at the SEC&#146;s Public Reference
    Room at 100 F Street, NE, Washington, DC 20549. You may obtain
    information on the operation of the Public Reference Room by
    calling the SEC at
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">1-800-SEC-0330.</FONT>
    A copy of this Annual Report on
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Form&#160;10-K,</FONT>
    as well as other Annual Reports on
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Form&#160;10-K,</FONT>
    Quarterly Reports on
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Form&#160;10-Q,</FONT>
    Current Reports on
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Form&#160;8-K</FONT>
    and amendments to those reports are accessible free of charge at
    <I>www.usairways.com </I>and at the SEC&#146;s website at
    <I>www.sec.gov </I>as soon as reasonably possible after the
    report is filed with or furnished to the SEC.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Airline
    Industry</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Despite high fuel costs throughout the year, the airline
    industry is expected to report an annual profit in 2006,
    excluding special items and bankruptcy-related costs, for the
    first time since the terrorist attacks on September&#160;11,
    2001. While the industry continued to focus on structural
    changes through cost containment and fleet rationalization,
    airlines were able to pass some of the fuel price cost increase
    on to passengers through higher fares.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    A number of structural changes in the industry have taken shape
    including restructuring through the Chapter&#160;11 process by
    four legacy carriers, including US Airways. While all carriers
    are focusing on lowering costs and increasing revenues,
    traditional legacy carriers and some newer carriers have reduced
    domestic capacity and redeployed aircraft to international
    markets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Regional jets continue to play a large and growing role within
    the U.S.&#160;airline industry. The more recent trend is toward
    larger 70- and 90-plus seat regional jets rather than the
    50-seat and smaller jets that had dominated the marketplace in
    prior years. As carriers use the bankruptcy laws to restructure
    and reduce their mainline fleets, replacement aircraft
    frequently are larger regional aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    While fares have increased over the prior year due to the rising
    cost of fuel, they still remain at historically low levels on an
    inflation-adjusted basis. While domestic capacity continues to
    rationalize through fleet reductions and the redeployment of
    aircraft to international markets, whether demand can remain at
    historically high levels in the face of rising fares is unclear.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Airline
    Operations</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Prior to the merger, AWA operated its route system through a
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">hub-and-spoke</FONT>
    network centered in its Phoenix and Las Vegas hubs.
    US&#160;Airways&#146; major connecting hubs prior to the merger
    were at airports in Charlotte and Philadelphia. US&#160;Airways
    also had substantial operations at Logan International Airport
    in Boston, New York&#146;s LaGuardia Airport, Pittsburgh
    International Airport, and Ronald Reagan Washington National
    Airport. Following the merger, the combined company has primary
    hubs in Charlotte, Philadelphia and Phoenix and secondary
    hubs/focus cities in Pittsburgh, Las Vegas, New York,
    Washington,&#160;D.C. and Boston.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Despite operating fewer aircraft than in the previous year, both
    AWA and US&#160;Airways were able to increase service in certain
    markets. In 2006, AWA launched service to Hawaii between Las
    Vegas-Maui, Phoenix-Kauai and Phoenix-Kona with
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">extended-over-water-equipped</FONT>
    Boeing 757 Aircraft. US&#160;Airways added new transatlantic
    service from Philadelphia to Milan, Italy; Stockholm, Sweden;
    and Lisbon, Portugal. US&#160;Airways also added
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    5
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    service from Philadelphia to Portland, Oregon using AWA aircraft
    and crew, thus further realizing the synergies from our merger
    by easily adding service from the former east coast route
    network to the west coast route network.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition, US&#160;Airways continued to enhance its fleet mix
    in 2006. We announced an agreement with Embraer for the firm
    order of twenty five 99-seat Embraer 190 aircraft. The aircraft
    began regularly scheduled flights in February 2007. Also,
    through an agreement with our regional airline partner Republic
    Airways Holdings (&#147;Republic&#148;), we added thirty 86-seat
    Embraer 175 aircraft, which replaced twenty 50-seat Embraer 145
    aircraft. The remaining ten aircraft can be used for either
    replacement or growth purposes in 2008. Finally, we announced
    that we have restructured and increased our existing order with
    Airbus for seven new A321 Aircraft. This brings the total
    aircraft on order with Airbus to 37, with fifteen A321 aircraft
    to be delivered between 2008 and 2010.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    To modernize our international product and improve the
    efficiency of our international network, we were scheduled to
    begin accepting deliveries of A350 aircraft in 2011 pursuant to
    an Airbus A350 Purchase Agreement that US Airways Group, US
    Airways and AWA entered into in September 2005 with Airbus. US
    Airways Group has been notified that the A350 will be undergoing
    significant design changes and will be delivered several years
    beyond the originally scheduled delivery dates. We are currently
    evaluating the revised technical and commercial aspects of the
    A350 program.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Express
    Operations</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Express Network</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Certain air carriers have code share arrangements with
    US&#160;Airways to operate under the trade name
    &#147;US&#160;Airways Express&#148;. Typically, under a code
    share arrangement, one air carrier places its designator code
    and sells tickets on the flights of another air carrier, which
    is referred to generically as its code share partner.
    US&#160;Airways Express carriers are an integral component of
    our operating network. US&#160;Airways relies heavily on feeder
    traffic from its US&#160;Airways Express partners, which carry
    passengers from low-density markets that are uneconomical for
    US&#160;Airways to serve with large jets to
    US&#160;Airways&#146; hubs. In addition, US&#160;Airways Express
    operators offer complementary service in existing
    US&#160;Airways mainline markets by operating flights during
    off-peak periods between US&#160;Airways mainline flights. As of
    December 2006, the US&#160;Airways Express network served 133
    airports in the continental United States, Canada and the
    Caribbean, including 40 airports also served by US&#160;Airways.
    During 2006, approximately 20&#160;million passengers boarded
    US&#160;Airways Express air carriers&#146; planes, approximately
    42% of whom connected to US&#160;Airways&#146; flights. Of these
    20&#160;million passengers, approximately 8&#160;million were
    enplaned by our wholly owned regional airlines Piedmont and PSA,
    approximately 1&#160;million were enplaned by
    US&#160;Airways&#146; former MidAtlantic division, approximately
    10&#160;million were enplaned by third-party carriers operating
    under capacity purchase agreements and approximately
    1&#160;million were enplaned by carriers operating under prorate
    agreements, as described below.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The US&#160;Airways Express code share arrangements are either
    in the form of capacity purchase or prorate agreements. The
    capacity purchase agreements provide that all revenues,
    including passenger, mail and freight revenues, go to
    US&#160;Airways. In return, US&#160;Airways agrees to pay
    predetermined fees to these airlines for operating an
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">agreed-upon</FONT>
    number of aircraft, without regard to the number of passengers
    on board. In addition, these agreements provide that certain
    variable costs, such as fuel and airport landing fees, will be
    reimbursed 100% by US&#160;Airways. US&#160;Airways controls
    marketing, scheduling, ticketing, pricing and seat inventories.
    Under the prorate agreements, the prorate carriers pay certain
    service fees to US&#160;Airways and receive a prorated share of
    ticket revenue paid for connecting customers. US&#160;Airways is
    responsible for the pricing and marketing of connecting services
    to and from the prorate carrier. The prorate carrier is
    responsible for pricing and marketing the local, point to point
    markets, and is responsible for all costs incurred operating the
    aircraft. All US&#160;Airways Express carriers use
    US&#160;Airways&#146; reservation systems, and have logos,
    service marks, aircraft paint schemes and uniforms similar to
    those of US&#160;Airways.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    6
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    PSA and Piedmont are wholly owned subsidiaries of
    US&#160;Airways Group.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In April 2004, MidAtlantic, US&#160;Airways&#146; former
    regional jet division, began operating as part of the
    US&#160;Airways Express network. As of December&#160;31, 2005,
    MidAtlantic operated 18 Embraer ERJ-170 regional jets with
    72&#160;seats. MidAtlantic served approximately 2&#160;million
    passengers in 2005. On June&#160;23, 2005, US&#160;Airways
    exercised its option under its agreement with Republic and
    Wexford Capital LLC to sell certain assets used by MidAtlantic,
    including the regional jets, a flight simulator and certain
    commuter slots at Reagan National and LaGuardia. Under the terms
    of the agreement, Republic purchased ten regional jets owned by
    US&#160;Airways and leased the ten purchased aircraft back to
    US&#160;Airways subject to their future transfer to Republic.
    Republic also assumed the leases of 15 additional regional jets.
    Republic entered into a regional jet service agreement that
    continues the operation of the aircraft as a US&#160;Airways
    Express carrier under a ten-year capacity purchase agreement. In
    addition to the aircraft, Republic purchased commuter slots at
    Reagan National and LaGuardia and leases the slots back to
    US&#160;Airways. Effective May&#160;27, 2006, the transfer of
    assets to Republic discussed above was complete and MidAtlantic
    ceased to operate. In December 2006, US&#160;Airways satisfied
    the financial terms of the agreement concerning the LaGuardia
    slots. Republic and US&#160;Airways then modified additional
    terms of the agreement to conform with subsequent regulatory
    changes at LaGuardia, and the slots were returned to
    US&#160;Airways. The need for a subsequent modification was
    fully contemplated in the original agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Express</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA has a regional airline code share agreement with Mesa
    Airlines (&#147;Mesa&#148;). Mesa, operating regional jets and
    large turboprop aircraft as America West Express, provides
    regional feeder service to and from Phoenix, Charlotte and Las
    Vegas to destinations in the continental United States, Canada
    and northern Mexico. AWA collects the revenue and income
    generated from the services provided by Mesa, and in return
    (1)&#160;reimburses Mesa for actual non-controllable costs and
    costs incurred at stations maintained and operated by Mesa,
    (2)&#160;pays Mesa for actual controllable non-maintenance
    costs, subject to a cap, and controllable maintenance costs at
    fixed rates, and (3)&#160;shares with Mesa a percentage of the
    revenue allocated to the flight segments flown by Mesa. Through
    this arrangement with Mesa, AWA offered America West Express
    service to an additional 31 destinations as of December&#160;31,
    2006. As of December&#160;31, 2006, the America West Express
    fleet included 62 aircraft comprised of 38&#160;86-seat CRJ
    900s, 18 50-seat CRJ 200s and six 37-seat Dash 8 turboprop
    aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Marketing
    and Alliance Agreements with Other Airlines</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA and US&#160;Airways maintain alliance agreements with each
    other and with several leading domestic and international
    carriers to give customers a greater choice of destinations.
    Airline alliance agreements provide an array of benefits that
    vary by partner. By code sharing, each airline is able to offer
    additional destinations to its customers under its flight
    designator code without materially increasing operating expenses
    and capital expenditures. Frequent flyer arrangements provide
    members with extended networks for earning and redeeming miles
    on partner carriers. Our US&#160;Airways Club members also have
    access to certain partner carriers&#146; airport lounges. We
    also benefit from the distribution strengths of each of the
    partner carriers.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    7
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">AWA</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA and US&#160;Airways entered into a broad system-wide code
    share program that started soon after the merger. This program
    permits passengers to travel throughout the combined route
    networks of both carriers. The code share program is fully
    implemented except in a few international markets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA also has several code share agreements with different
    carriers. Among international carriers, AWA has code share
    relations with ALIA/Royal Jordanian, EVA Airways and Virgin
    Atlantic Airways. The code share agreements primarily funnel
    international traffic onto AWA&#146;s domestic flights.
    Domestically, AWA code shares with Hawaiian Airlines on
    intra-Hawaii flights and with Big Sky Airlines to smaller
    markets in Idaho, Montana and Washington state.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition to the broad code share agreement with AWA,
    US&#160;Airways has entered into a number of bilateral and
    multilateral alliances with other airlines. In May 2004,
    US&#160;Airways joined the Star Alliance, the world&#146;s
    largest airline alliance, with 17 member airlines serving
    approximately 855 destinations in 155 countries. Two additional
    international carriers based in China are scheduled to join in
    2007. Membership in the Star Alliance further enhances the value
    of US&#160;Airways&#146; domestic and international route
    network by allowing customers wide access to the global
    marketplace. Expanded benefits for customers include network
    expansion through code share service, Dividend Miles benefits,
    airport lounge access, convenient single-ticket pricing,
    one-stop check-in and coordinated baggage handling.
    US&#160;Airways also has bilateral marketing/code sharing
    agreements with Lufthansa, Spanair, bmi, TAP Portugal, and
    Italy&#146;s Air One, as well as several smaller regional
    carriers in the Caribbean that operate collectively as the
    &#147;GoCaribbean&#148; network.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition, US&#160;Airways has comprehensive marketing
    agreements with United Airlines, a member of the Star Alliance,
    which began in July 2002. United, as well as its parent company,
    UAL Corporation, and certain of its affiliates, filed for
    protection under Chapter&#160;11 of the Bankruptcy Code on
    December&#160;9, 2002 and emerged on February&#160;1, 2006.
    United assumed these marketing agreements in its bankruptcy
    proceedings. On March&#160;3, 2006, US&#160;Airways filed a
    motion with the Bankruptcy Court to assume revised agreements
    with United; however, we are continuing to negotiate with United
    concerning revisions to the existing agreements. In the event we
    are unable to reach agreement with United, our code share
    relationship with United and membership in Star Alliance could
    be terminated.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Competition
    in the Airline Industry</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Most of the markets in which we operate are highly competitive.
    Price competition occurs on a
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">market-by-market</FONT>
    basis through price discounts, changes in pricing structures,
    fare matching, target promotions and frequent flyer initiatives.
    Airlines typically use discount fares and other promotions to
    stimulate traffic during normally slack travel periods to
    generate cash flow and to maximize revenue per ASM. Discount and
    promotional fares are generally non-refundable and may be
    subject to various restrictions such as minimum stay
    requirements, advance ticketing, limited seating and change
    fees. We have often elected to match discount or promotional
    fares initiated by other air carriers in certain markets in
    order to compete in those markets. Most airlines will quickly
    match price reductions in a particular market. Our ability to
    compete on the basis of price is limited by our fixed costs and
    depends on our ability to maintain our operating costs.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We also compete on the basis of scheduling (frequency and flight
    times), availability of nonstop flights, on-time performance,
    type of equipment, cabin configuration, amenities provided to
    passengers, frequent flyer programs, the automation of travel
    agent reservation systems, on-board products, markets served and
    other services. We compete with both major full service airlines
    and low-cost airlines throughout our network of hubs and focus
    cities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We believe the growth of low-fare low-cost competition will
    continue. Recent years have seen the entrance and growth of
    low-fare low-cost competitors in many of the markets in which we
    operate. These competitors include Southwest Airlines Co., which
    has steadily increased East Coast operations, AirTran Airways,
    Inc., Frontier
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    8
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Airlines, Inc. and JetBlue Airways. Some of these low cost
    carriers have lower operating cost structures than we have.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition, with its significant activity in the eastern United
    States, US&#160;Airways&#146; average trip distance, or stage
    length, is shorter than those of other major airlines. This
    makes US&#160;Airways more susceptible than other major airlines
    to competition from surface transportation such as automobiles
    and trains.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Industry
    Regulation and Airport Access</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our airline subsidiaries operate under certificates of public
    convenience and necessity or certificates of commuter authority,
    both of which are issued by the Department of Transportation
    (the &#147;DOT&#148;). These certificates may be altered,
    amended, modified or suspended by the DOT if the public
    convenience and necessity so require, or may be revoked for
    failure to comply with the terms and conditions of the
    certificates. US&#160;Airways and AWA currently operate under
    separate certificates, and are in the process of obtaining DOT
    approval to combine the certificates. Approval is expected
    during 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Airlines are also regulated by the U.S.&#160;Federal Aviation
    Administration (the &#147;FAA&#148;), primarily in the areas of
    flight operations, maintenance, ground facilities and other
    operational and safety areas. Pursuant to these regulations, our
    airline subsidiaries have FAA-approved maintenance programs for
    each type of aircraft they operate. The programs provide for the
    ongoing maintenance of such aircraft, ranging from periodic
    routine inspections to major overhauls. From time to time, the
    FAA issues airworthiness directives and other regulations
    affecting our airline subsidiaries or one or more of the
    aircraft types they operate. In recent years, for example, the
    FAA has issued or proposed mandates relating to, among other
    things, enhanced ground proximity warning systems, fuselage
    pressure bulkhead reinforcement, fuselage lap joint inspection
    rework, increased inspections and maintenance procedures to be
    conducted on certain aircraft, increased cockpit security, fuel
    tank flammability reductions and domestic reduced vertical
    separation. Regulations of this sort tend to enhance safety and
    increase operating costs.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The DOT allows local airport authorities to implement procedures
    designed to abate special noise problems, provided such
    procedures do not unreasonably interfere with interstate or
    foreign commerce or the national transportation system. Certain
    locales, including Boston, Washington,&#160;D.C., Chicago,
    San&#160;Diego and San&#160;Francisco, among others, have
    established airport restrictions to limit noise, including
    restrictions on aircraft types to be used and limits on the
    number of hourly or daily operations or the time of these
    operations. In some instances these restrictions have caused
    curtailments in services or increases in operating costs, and
    these restrictions could limit the ability of our airline
    subsidiaries to expand their operations at the affected
    airports. Authorities at other airports may consider adopting
    similar noise regulations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The airline industry is also subject to increasingly stringent
    federal, state and local laws aimed at protecting the
    environment. Future regulatory developments and actions could
    affect operations and increase operating costs for the airline
    industry, including our airline subsidiaries.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our airline subsidiaries are obligated to collect a federal
    excise tax, commonly referred to as the &#147;ticket tax,&#148;
    on domestic and international air transportation. Our airline
    subsidiaries collect the ticket tax, along with certain other
    U.S. and foreign taxes and user fees on air transportation, and
    pass along the collected amounts to the appropriate governmental
    agencies. Although these taxes are not operating expenses of the
    Company, they represent an additional cost to our customers.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Aviation and Transportation Security Act (the &#147;Aviation
    Security Act&#148;) was enacted in November 2001. Under the
    Aviation Security Act, substantially all aspects of civil
    aviation security screening were federalized, and a new
    Transportation Security Administration (the &#147;TSA&#148;)
    under the DOT was created. TSA was then transferred to the
    Department of Homeland Security pursuant to the Homeland
    Security Act of 2002. The Aviation Security Act, among other
    matters, mandates improved flight deck security; carriage at no
    charge of federal air marshals; enhanced security screening of
    passengers, baggage, cargo, mail, employees and vendors;
    enhanced security training; fingerprint-based background checks
    of all employees and vendor employees with access to secure
    areas of airports pursuant to regulations issued in connection
    with the Aviation Security Act; and the provision of passenger
    data to U.S.&#160;Customs and Border Protection.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    9
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Funding for TSA is provided by a combination of air-carrier
    fees, passenger fees, and taxpayer monies. The air-carrier fee,
    or Aviation Security Infrastructure Fee (&#147;ASIF&#148;), has
    an annual cap equivalent to the amount that an individual air
    carrier paid in calendar year 2000 for the screening of
    passengers and property. TSA may lift this cap at any time and
    set a new higher fee for air carriers. In 2005, TSA assessed
    additional ASIF liability on 43 air carriers, including AWA,
    US&#160;Airways, Piedmont, PSA and non-owned affiliates for whom
    AWA and US&#160;Airways pay ASIF. The passenger fee, which is
    collected by air carriers from their passengers, is currently
    set at $2.50&#160;per flight segment but not more than
    $10.00&#160;per round trip.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2006, we incurred expenses of $56&#160;million for the ASIF,
    including amounts related to regional carriers. US&#160;Airways
    incurred expenses of $44&#160;million including amounts paid by
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned regional subsidiaries.
    AWA incurred expenses of $12&#160;million including amounts
    related to regional carriers. Our expenses will further increase
    for amounts assessed to non-owned regional affiliates who can
    pass through their increased ASIF to US&#160;Airways.
    Implementation of the requirements of the Aviation Security Act
    have resulted and will continue to result in increased costs for
    us and our passengers and has and will likely continue to result
    in service disruptions and delays. As a result of competitive
    pressure, AWA, US&#160;Airways and other airlines may be unable
    to recover all of these additional security costs from
    passengers through increased fares. In addition, we cannot
    forecast what new security and safety requirements may be
    imposed in the future or the costs or financial impact of
    complying with any such requirements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Most major U.S.&#160;airports impose passenger facility charges.
    The ability of airlines to contest increases in these charges is
    restricted by federal legislation, DOT regulations and judicial
    decisions. With certain exceptions, air carriers pass these
    charges on to passengers. However, our ability to pass through
    passenger facility charges to our customers is subject to
    various factors, including market conditions and competitive
    factors.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At John F. Kennedy International Airport, LaGuardia and Reagan
    National, which are designated &#147;High Density Airports&#148;
    by the FAA, there are restrictions that limit the number of
    departure and arrival slots available to air carriers during
    peak hours. In April 2000, legislation was enacted that
    eliminated slot restrictions in January 2007 at LaGuardia and
    Kennedy. On December&#160;20, 2006, the FAA implemented an
    interim rule to maintain the number of hourly operations at
    LaGuardia until a final rule is adopted. The FAA proposed a
    comprehensive final rule for LaGuardia in August 2006. The
    proposed rule would require a minimum number of seats on all
    operations to/from LaGuardia except for those expressly
    exempted. Failure to comply with the average seat per departure
    requirement would lead to the withdrawal of operating authority
    until compliance is achieved. The proposed rule also introduces
    a finite lifespan for &#147;operating authorizations&#148; of no
    more than ten years. The FAA intends to seek Congressional
    approval for the introduction of market based mechanisms for
    allocating expiring operating authorizations. We have filed
    extensive comments with the FAA in December 2006 detailing the
    numerous concerns we have with the proposed rule. Given the need
    for Congressional legislation to implement a portion of the
    proposed rule, we do not believe final action on a new rule is
    likely before late 2007 at the earliest.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In the future, takeoff and landing time restrictions and other
    restrictions on the use of various airports and their facilities
    may result in further curtailment of services by, and increased
    operating costs for, individual airlines, including our airline
    subsidiaries, particularly in light of the increase in the
    number of airlines operating at these airports. In general, FAA
    rules relating to allocated slots at High Density Airports
    contain provisions requiring the relinquishment of slots for
    non-use and permit carriers, under certain circumstances, to
    sell, lease or trade their slots to other carriers. Each slot
    must be used on at least 80% of the dates during each two-month
    reporting period. Failure to satisfy the use rate will result in
    loss of the slot and reversion of the slot to the FAA for
    reassignment through a lottery arrangement. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways and AWA exceeded the
    minimum use rate.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Where the FAA has seen congestion and delay increases, it has
    generally stepped in and worked with the carriers to freeze
    operations at current or somewhat reduced levels. Specifically,
    incumbent carriers, including US&#160;Airways and AWA, are not
    permitted to increase operations at Chicago O&#146;Hare
    International Airport as a result of an agreement reached
    between the FAA and these airlines in August 2004. A final rule
    memorializing many of the terms of the August 2004 agreement was
    released in August 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The availability of international routes to domestic air
    carriers is regulated by agreements between the U.S. and foreign
    governments. Changes in U.S.&#160;or foreign government aviation
    policy could result in the alteration or termination of these
    agreements and affect our international operations.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    10
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The DOT has proposed far-reaching changes to the regulations
    that define what constitutes a U.S.&#160;airline. The proposed
    rule was withdrawn in 2006, after facing widespread opposition
    from various industry stakeholders. As a result of the failure
    of the United States to liberalize its foreign ownership
    regulations, the European Union and United States did not
    implement a new liberalized transatlantic air service agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Employees
    and Labor Relations</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our businesses are labor intensive. In 2006, wages, salaries and
    benefits represented approximately 19% of US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s operating expenses, 20% of AWA&#146;s operating
    expenses and 18% of US&#160;Airways&#146; operating expenses. As
    of December&#160;31, 2006, we employed approximately 37,000
    active full-time equivalent employees. As of December&#160;31,
    2006, AWA employed approximately 12,400 active full-time
    equivalent employees including approximately 1,700 pilots, 2,500
    flight attendants, 2,600 passenger service personnel, 2,000
    fleet service personnel, 700 maintenance personnel and 2,900
    personnel in administrative and various other job categories. As
    of December&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways employed
    approximately 19,400 active full-time equivalent employees
    including approximately 2,600 pilots, 4,600 flight attendants,
    2,800 passenger service personnel, 3,700 fleet service
    personnel, 2,600 maintenance personnel and 3,100 personnel in
    administrative and various other job categories. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s remaining
    subsidiaries employed approximately 5,200 active full-time
    equivalent employees including approximately 900 pilots, 600
    flight attendants, 2,200 customer service personnel, 400
    maintenance personnel and 1,100 personnel in administrative and
    various other job categories.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    A large majority of the employees of the major airlines in the
    United States are represented by labor unions. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, approximately 81% of our active
    employees were represented by various labor unions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Since the merger, we have been in the process of integrating the
    labor agreements of our two principal airline subsidiaries. The
    status of AWA&#146;s and US&#160;Airways&#146; labor agreements
    with their major domestic employee groups is as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row -->

    <B>Contract<BR>
    </B>
</TD>

<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom" align="center">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
<DIV style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000; width: 1%; padding-bottom: 1px">
    <B>Union</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD colspan="2" nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    11

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Approximate number of active full-time equivalent employees
    covered by the contract as of December&#160;31, 2006.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (2) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In negotiations for a single labor agreement applicable to both
    AWA and US&#160;Airways.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (3) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In negotiations for a single labor agreement applicable to both
    AWA and US&#160;Airways. On December&#160;15, 2005, the National
    Mediation Board recessed AFA&#146;s separate contract
    negotiations with AWA indefinitely.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (4) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In negotiations to transition to the US&#160;Airways-IAM
    mechanic and related labor agreement.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (5) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In negotiations to transition to the US&#160;Airways-IAM fleet
    service labor agreement.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (6) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In December 2006, US&#160;Airways, AWA and TWU reached a
    transition agreement to transition the AWA dispatchers to the
    US&#160;Airways-TWU dispatcher labor agreement.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (7) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    On June&#160;1, 2006, US&#160;Airways, AWA and the Association
    reached a final transition agreement to transition the AWA
    passenger service employees to the US&#160;Airways passenger
    service labor agreement.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    There are few remaining employee groups that could engage in
    organization efforts. We cannot predict the outcome of any
    future efforts to organize those remaining employees or the
    terms of any future labor agreements or the effect, if any, on
    US&#160;Airways&#146; or AWA&#146;s operations or financial
    performance. For more discussion, see Item&#160;1A. &#147;Risk
    Factors, Risk Factors Relating to the Company and Industry
    Related Risks&#160;&#151; <I>Union disputes, employee strikes
    and other labor-related disruptions may adversely affect our
    operations.</I>&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Aviation
    Fuel</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2006 and 2005, aviation fuel was our largest expense. The
    combined average cost of a gallon of aviation fuel for AWA and
    US&#160;Airways increased 17% from 2005 to 2006 after increasing
    47% from 2004 to 2005. Because the operations of the airlines
    are dependent upon aviation fuel, increases in aviation fuel
    costs could materially and adversely affect liquidity, results
    of operations and financial condition.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We maintain an active fuel hedging program. All fuel hedges are
    placed by AWA and therefore are recorded on AWA&#146;s financial
    statements. As part of our fuel hedging program, AWA has
    periodically entered into certain fixed price swaps, collar
    structures and other similar derivative contracts. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, we had entered into hedging transactions
    using costless collars, which establish an upper and lower limit
    on heating oil futures prices. These transactions are in place
    with respect to approximately 29% of our 2007 fuel requirements.
    During 2006, 2005 and 2004, AWA recognized a net loss of
    $79&#160;million, a net gain of $75&#160;million and a net gain
    of $24&#160;million, respectively, related to hedging activities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table shows annual aircraft fuel consumption and
    costs for US&#160;Airways mainline for 2004 through 2006
    (gallons and aircraft fuel expense in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
