<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    22
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    reorganizations, including the termination of four defined
    benefit pension plans pursuant to agreements with the Pension
    Benefit Guaranty Corporation (the &#147;PBGC&#148;). While the
    PBGC retains the authority to restore some or all of the
    terminated plans, we believe that its ability to do so is
    limited given our emergence from bankruptcy and discharge from
    prior debts.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group could experience significant operating losses in the
    future.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Although US&#160;Airways Group reported an operating profit in
    2006, there is no guarantee of future profitability. There are
    several reasons, including those addressed in these risk
    factors, why US&#160;Airways Group might fail to achieve
    profitability and might in fact experience significant losses.
    For example, the condition of the national economy has an impact
    on our revenue performance.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Since early 2001, the U.S.&#160;airline industry&#146;s revenue
    performance has fallen short of what would have been expected
    based on historical growth trends. This shortfall has been
    caused by a number of factors discussed in these risk factors.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Risks
    Related to Our Common Stock</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Our
    common stock has limited trading history and its market price
    may be volatile.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our common stock began trading on the NYSE on September&#160;27,
    2005 upon the effectiveness of our merger. The market price of
    our common stock may fluctuate substantially due to a variety of
    factors, many of which are beyond our control, including:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    our operating results failing to meet the expectations of
    securities analysts or investors;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    changes in financial estimates or recommendations by securities
    analysts;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    material announcements by us or our competitors;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    movements in fuel prices;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    new regulatory pronouncements and changes in regulatory
    guidelines;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    general and industry-specific economic conditions;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    public sales of a substantial number of shares of our common
    stock;&#160;and
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    general market conditions.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Conversion
    of our convertible notes will dilute the ownership interest of
    existing stockholders and could adversely affect the market
    price of our common stock.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The conversion of some or all of the US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s 7%&#160;senior convertible notes due 2020 will
    dilute the ownership interests of existing shareholders. Any
    sales in the public market of the common stock issuable upon
    such conversion could adversely affect prevailing market prices
    of our common stock. In addition, the existence of the notes may
    encourage short selling by market participants because the
    conversion of the notes could depress the price of our common
    stock.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">A
    small number of stockholders beneficially own a substantial
    amount of our common stock.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    A significant portion of US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s common
    stock is beneficially owned by a relatively small number of
    equity investors. As a result, until these stockholders sell a
    substantial portion of their shares, they will have a greater
    percentage vote in matters that may be presented for a vote to
    stockholders than most other stockholders. This may make it more
    difficult for other stockholders to influence votes on matters
    that may come before stockholders of US&#160;Airways Group. In
    addition, sales of these shares into the market could cause the
    market price of our common stock to drop significantly, even if
    our business is doing well.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    23
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Certain
    provisions of the amended and restated certificate of
    incorporation and amended and restated bylaws of US&#160;Airways
    Group make it difficult for stockholders to change the
    composition of our board of directors and may discourage
    takeover attempts that some of our stockholders might consider
    beneficial.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Certain provisions of the amended and restated certificate of
    incorporation and amended and restated bylaws of US&#160;Airways
    Group may have the effect of delaying or preventing changes in
    control if our board of directors determines that such changes
    in control are not in the best interests of US&#160;Airways
    Group and its stockholders. These provisions include, among
    other things, the following:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    a classified board of directors with three-year staggered terms;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    advance notice procedures for stockholder proposals to be
    considered at stockholders&#146; meetings;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    the ability of US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s board of directors
    to fill vacancies on the board;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    a prohibition against stockholders taking action by written
    consent;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    a prohibition against stockholders calling special meetings of
    stockholders;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    a requirement that holders of at least 80% of the voting power
    of the shares entitled to vote in the election of directors
    approve amendment of the amended and restated bylaws;&#160;and
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    super-majority voting requirements to modify or amend specified
    provisions of US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s amended and restated
    certificate of incorporation.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    These provisions are not intended to prevent a takeover, but are
    intended to protect and maximize the value of US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s stockholders&#146; interests. While these
    provisions have the effect of encouraging persons seeking to
    acquire control of our company to negotiate with our board of
    directors, they could enable our board of directors to prevent a
    transaction that some, or a majority, of our stockholders might
    believe to be in their best interests and, in that case, may
    prevent or discourage attempts to remove and replace incumbent
    directors. In addition, US&#160;Airways Group is subject to the
    provisions of Section&#160;203 of the Delaware General
    Corporation Law, which prohibits business combinations with
    interested stockholders. Interested stockholders do not include
    stockholders, such as our new equity investors, whose
    acquisition of US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s securities is
    approved by the board of directors prior to the investment under
    Section&#160;203.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Our
    charter documents include provisions limiting voting and
    ownership by foreign owners.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our amended and restated certificate of incorporation provides
    that shares of capital stock may not be voted by or at the
    direction of persons who are not citizens of the United States
    if the number of shares held by such persons would exceed 24.9%
    of the voting stock of our company. In addition, any attempt to
    transfer equity securities to a
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">non-U.S.&#160;citizen</FONT>
    in excess of 49.9% of our outstanding equity securities will be
    void and of no effect.
</DIV>
<A name='104'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Item&#160;1B.<I>&#160;&#160;</I></FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Unresolved
    Staff Comments</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    None.
</DIV>
<A name='105'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Item&#160;2.<I>&#160;&#160;</I></FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Properties</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Flight
    Equipment</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with the merger, US&#160;Airways Group negotiated
    reductions to its existing fleet so that the fleet of the
    combined company better matches aircraft size with consumer
    demand. US&#160;Airways Group operated a mainline fleet of
    359&#160;aircraft at the end of 2006 (supported by approximately
    240&#160;regional jets and approximately 104&#160;turboprops
    that provide passenger feed into the mainline system), down from
    a total of 373&#160;mainline aircraft operated by the airlines
    at the end of 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2006, US&#160;Airways Group removed 21&#160;aircraft and
    added seven aircraft to the mainline fleet. In 2006, AWA removed
    eight Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300,</FONT> one
    Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">757-200,</FONT> and
    one Airbus A320 aircraft, while US&#160;Airways removed eleven
    Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300</FONT>
    aircraft. During the year, AWA took delivery of two Airbus A319
    aircraft with leases ending in 2018, while US&#160;Airways took
    delivery of three Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">757-200</FONT> and
    two Embraer ERJ190 aircraft.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    24
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2006, AWA also renewed the leases on eleven Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300</FONT>
    aircraft for three years and one Airbus A320 aircraft for six
    years, and US&#160;Airways renewed leases on twelve Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">757-200</FONT>
    aircraft for periods ranging from five to six years. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, AWA and US&#160;Airways had 28 and
    86&#160;aircraft, respectively, that have lease expirations
    prior to the end of 2009. In 2007 and 2008, US&#160;Airways
    expects to take delivery of an additional 23&#160;Embraer ERJ190
    aircraft. Between 2008 and 2010, US&#160;Airways Group expects
    to take delivery of 37&#160;Airbus aircraft. To modernize our
    international product and improve the efficiency of our
    international network, we were scheduled to begin accepting
    deliveries of Airbus A350 aircraft in 2011 pursuant to a
    purchase agreement that US&#160;Airways Group, US&#160;Airways
    and AWA entered into in September 2005 with Airbus.
    US&#160;Airways Group has been notified that the Airbus A350
    will be undergoing significant design changes and will be
    delivered several years beyond the originally scheduled delivery
    dates. We are currently evaluating the revised technical and
    commercial aspects of the Airbus A350 program.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group had the
    following jet and regional jet aircraft:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">AWA</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TD colspan="2" nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    All owned aircraft are pledged as collateral for various secured
    financing agreements.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (2) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The terms of the leases expire between 2007 and 2024.</TD>
</TR>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    25
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The terms of the leases expire between 2007 and 2022.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As discussed in Item&#160;1.&#160;&#147;Business&#160;&#151;
    US&#160;Airways Express Network&#148;, AWA and US&#160;Airways
    have code share agreements with certain regional jet affiliate
    operators. Collectively, wholly owned regional airline
    subsidiaries and affiliate operators flew 233 regional jet
    aircraft and 61 turboprop aircraft (excluding affiliate carriers
    operating under pro-rate agreements) as part of America West
    Express and US&#160;Airways Express as of December&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group maintains inventories of spare engines,
    spare parts, accessories and other maintenance supplies
    sufficient to meet its current operating requirements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table illustrates US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s
    committed orders, scheduled lease expirations, and lessor call
    and put options as of December&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="right" valign="bottom">
    5
</TD>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    See notes&#160;10, 7 and&#160;8, &#147;Commitments and
    Contingencies&#148; in Part&#160;II, Items&#160;8A, 8B and 8C,
    respectively, for additional information on aircraft purchase
    commitments.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group owned the
    following aircraft that was not considered part of its operating
    fleet presented in the tables above. This aircraft was parked at
    a storage facility.

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA and US&#160;Airways are participants in the Civil Reserve
    Air Fleet, a voluntary program administered by the U.S.&#160;Air
    Force Air Mobility Command. The General Services Administration
    of the U.S.&#160;Government requires that airlines participate
    in Civil Reserve Air Fleet, if activated, in order to receive
    U.S.&#160;Government business. AWA and US&#160;Airways are
    reimbursed at compensatory rates when aircraft are activated
    under Civil Reserve Air Fleet or when participating in
    Department of Defense business.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Ground
    Facilities</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company leases the majority of its ground facilities,
    including:
</DIV>

<DIV style="text-indent: -9pt; margin-left: 9pt">
    <FONT style="font-size: 9pt">Training facility&#160;&#151;
    Charlotte, NC
    </FONT>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>

    <FONT style="font-size: 9pt">Classroom training facilities and
    ten full flight simulator bays
    </FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 9pt">159,000
    </FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;

    <FONT style="font-size: 9pt">Facilities and land leased from the
    City of Charlotte. Lease expires June 2017.
    </FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="background: #CCEEFF">

    Operations Control Center, Phoenix, AZ
    </FONT>
</DIV>
</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition, America West Holdings and AWA have leased an
    aggregate of approximately 207,000&#160;square feet of data
    center, office and warehouse space in Tempe and Phoenix.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    27
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Space for ticket counters, gates and back offices has been
    obtained at each of the other airports operated by AWA and
    US&#160;Airways, either by lease from the airport operator or by
    sublease or handling agreement from another airline.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Terminal
    Construction Projects</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group uses public airports for its flight
    operations under lease arrangements with the government entities
    that own or control these airports. Airport authorities
    frequently require airlines to execute long-term leases to
    assist in obtaining financing for terminal and facility
    construction. Any future requirements for new or improved
    airport facilities and passenger terminals at airports in which
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s airline subsidiaries operate could
    result in additional occupancy costs and long-term commitments.
</DIV>
<A name='106'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Item&#160;3.<I>&#160;&#160;</I></FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Legal
    Proceedings</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On September&#160;12, 2004, US&#160;Airways Group and its
    domestic subsidiaries filed voluntary petitions for relief under
    Chapter&#160;11 of the Bankruptcy Code in the United States
    Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern District of Virginia,
    Alexandria Division (Case Nos.
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">04-13819-SSM</FONT>
    through
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">03-13823-SSM)</FONT>
    (the &#147;2004 Bankruptcy&#148;). On September&#160;16, 2005,
    the Bankruptcy Court issued an order confirming the plan of
    reorganization submitted by the Reorganized Debtors and on
    September&#160;27, 2005, the Reorganized Debtors emerged from
    the 2004 Bankruptcy. The Bankruptcy Court&#146;s order
    confirming the plan included a provision called the plan
    injunction, which forever bars other parties from pursuing most
    claims against the Reorganized Debtors that arose prior to
    September&#160;27, 2005 in any forum other than the Bankruptcy
    Court. The great majority of these claims are pre-petition
    claims that, if paid out at all, will be paid out in common
    stock of the post-bankruptcy US&#160;Airways Group at a fraction
    of the actual claim amount.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On February&#160;26, 2004, a company called I.A.P. Intermodal,
    LLC filed suit against US&#160;Airways Group and its wholly
    owned airline subsidiaries in the United States District Court
    for the Eastern District of Texas alleging that the
    defendants&#146; computer scheduling system infringes upon three
    patents held by plaintiffs, all of which patents are entitled,
    &#147;Method to Schedule a Vehicle in Real-Time to Transport
    Freight and Passengers.&#148; Plaintiff seeks various injunctive
    relief as well as costs, fees and treble damages.
    US&#160;Airways Group and its subsidiaries were formally served
    with the complaint on June&#160;21, 2004. On the same date, the
    same plaintiff filed what US&#160;Airways Group believes to be
    substantially similar cases against nine other major airlines,
    including British Airways, Northwest Airlines Corporation,
    Korean Airlines Co., Ltd., Deutsche Lufthansa AG, Air France,
    Air Canada, Singapore Airlines Ltd., Delta Air Lines and
    Continental Airlines, Inc., and had filed a suit against AMR
    Group, Inc., the parent company of American Airlines, along with
    its airline subsidiaries, in December 2003. This action has been
    stayed as to US&#160;Airways Group and its wholly owned
    subsidiaries as a result of the 2004 Bankruptcy. In the
    meantime, several foreign airline defendants were dismissed from
    the case for reasons unique to their status as foreign
    operators, and the remaining defendants in September 2005
    obtained a ruling that there had been no infringement of any of
    I.A.P.&#146;s patents. In October 2005, I.A.P. entered into
    consent judgments with several defendants. I.A.P. appealed the
    judgment in favor of Continental Airlines and the AMR Group
    defendants, but the trial court&#146;s ruling was affirmed on
    November&#160;13, 2006. No further appeals have been taken.
    I.A.P. did not file any claims against US&#160;Airways Group or
    any of its subsidiaries in the 2004 Bankruptcy.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On January&#160;7, 2003, the Internal Revenue Service issued a
    notice of proposed adjustment to US&#160;Airways Group proposing
    to disallow $573&#160;million of capital losses that
    US&#160;Airways Group sustained in the tax year 1999 on the sale
    of stock of USLM Corporation (the &#147;USLM matter&#148;). On
    February&#160;5, 2003, the IRS filed a proof of claim with the
    Bankruptcy Court in connection with the bankruptcy case filed on
    August&#160;11, 2002 (the &#147;2002 Bankruptcy&#148;) asserting
    the following claims against US&#160;Airways with respect to the
    USLM matter: (1)&#160;secured claims for U.S.&#160;federal
    income tax and interest of $1&#160;million; (2)&#160;unsecured
    priority claims for U.S.&#160;federal income tax of
    $68&#160;million and interest of $14&#160;million; and
    (3)&#160;an unsecured general claim for penalties of
    $25&#160;million. On May&#160;8, 2003, US&#160;Airways Group
    reached a tentative agreement with the IRS on the amount of
    U.S.&#160;federal income taxes, interest and penalties due
    subject to final approval from the Joint Committee on Taxation.
    By letter dated September&#160;11, 2003, US&#160;Airways Group
    was notified that the Joint Committee on Taxation had accepted
    the tentative agreement with the IRS, including a settlement of
    all federal income taxes through the end of 2002. Due to the
    2004 Bankruptcy filing, which suspended payment of prepetition
    liabilities, final payment terms under the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    28
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    agreement have not been submitted to the Bankruptcy Court for
    approval. The IRS has submitted a proof of claim relating to the
    USLM matter in the 2004 Bankruptcy in the amount of
    approximately $31&#160;million, and on August&#160;2, 2005 the
    IRS filed a motion for relief from the automatic stay seeking
    setoff against approximately $4&#160;million of tax refunds due
    to the Reorganized Debtors. On October&#160;20, 2005, the IRS
    filed an amended proof of claim reducing its claim in the USLM
    matter to $11&#160;million. On November&#160;3, 2005, the IRS
    filed an amended motion continuing to seek relief for the
    $4&#160;million setoff. US&#160;Airways and the IRS have reached
    an agreement to settle the USLM matter whereby the IRS would
    setoff approximately $4.5&#160;million of tax refunds and the
    IRS would be allowed an unsecured priority claim in the amount
    of approximately $6.5&#160;million, payable within 30&#160;days
    after the agreement is filed with the Bankruptcy Court. The
    agreement was filed with the Bankruptcy Court on
    February&#160;18, 2007 and the matter is now closed.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On February&#160;8, 2006, 103 flight attendants employed by the
    former MidAtlantic division of US&#160;Airways filed a complaint
    against the Association of Flight Attendants (&#147;AFA&#148;),
    AFA&#146;s international president Pat Friend and
    US&#160;Airways, alleging that defendants conspired to deceive
    plaintiffs into believing that MidAtlantic was a separate entity
    from US&#160;Airways in order to deprive them of the benefits
    they are due as US&#160;Airways flight attendants pursuant to
    the US&#160;Airways collective bargaining agreement.
    Plaintiffs&#146; claims against US&#160;Airways include breach
    of collective bargaining agreement, violation of the Railway
    Labor Act and racketeering under RICO. Plaintiffs&#146;
    complaint requests $400&#160;million in damages from
    US&#160;Airways and injunctive relief. The complaint was served
    on US&#160;Airways on July&#160;7, 2006. On November&#160;24,
    2006, Plaintiffs filed with the district court a notice of
    voluntary dismissal of US&#160;Airways from the litigation, and
    on November&#160;27, 2006, US&#160;Airways filed a notice
    withdrawing its motion for sanctions. On December&#160;29, 2006,
    the district court entered an order dismissing US&#160;Airways
    from the litigation.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On October&#160;12, 2005, Bank of America, N.A., which is one of
    the issuing banks of the US&#160;Airways frequent flyer program
    credit card and which also acts as the processing bank for most
    airline ticket purchases paid for with credit cards, filed suit
    in the Delaware Chancery Court in New Castle County against
    US&#160;Airways, US&#160;Airways Group and AWA, alleging that
    US&#160;Airways breached its frequent flyer credit card contract
    with Bank of America by entering into a similar, competing
    agreement with Juniper and allowing Juniper to issue a
    US&#160;Airways frequent flyer credit card. Bank of America also
    alleges that US&#160;Airways Group and AWA induced these
    breaches. Bank of America seeks an order requiring
    US&#160;Airways to market the Bank of America card and prohibit
    Juniper from issuing a US&#160;Airways credit card, as well as
    unspecified damages. On October&#160;27, 2005, Juniper, which
    was not originally a party to the lawsuit, sought and later
    received court permission to intervene as a defendant in the
    case and has made counterclaims against Bank of America. Juniper
    seeks an order declaring the validity of its new agreement to
    issue a US&#160;Airways frequent flyer credit card. On
    November&#160;3, 2005, Bank of America filed a motion for
    partial summary judgment on the breach of contract claim against
    US&#160;Airways. After a series of procedural steps, Bank of
    America&#146;s motion, along with a cross-motion for summary
    judgment filed by Juniper, was heard in the Bankruptcy Court,
    where the case is now pending as an adversary proceeding. On
    January&#160;30, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court ruled that Bank of
    America was equitably estopped from pursuing its claims that
    US&#160;Airways breached its agreement with Bank of America by
    negotiating and entering into the agreement with Juniper. The
    Bankruptcy Court ruled in the alternative that US&#160;Airways
    did not breach its agreement with Bank of America to be the
    exclusive card issuer, but that US&#160;Airways had breached the
    &#147;no shop&#148; provision of the Bank of America agreement
    when US&#160;Airways negotiated with Juniper prior to reaching
    the Juniper agreement. Bank of America sought appeal of that
    ruling while it has continued to pursue certain administrative
    claims against US&#160;Airways in the Bankruptcy Court. The
    resolution of the final two claims that Bank of America made in
    the lawsuit, which are (i)&#160;that AWA tortiously interfered
    with the contractual relationship between US&#160;Airways and
    Bank of America and (ii)&#160;that US&#160;Airways Group and AWA
    tortiously interfered with Bank of America&#146;s right to
    future economic benefit under its agreement with
    US&#160;Airways, are dependent on the outcome of the pending
    appeal. Bank of America will pursue those two claims only if its
    appeal of the January&#160;30, 2006 order is ultimately
    successful. On July&#160;19, 2006, the Eastern District of
    Virginia affirmed the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s order in part,
    ruling that US&#160;Airways did not breach the exclusivity
    provisions of the contract. However, the Eastern District of
    Virginia reversed the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s decision on
    equitable estoppel and remanded the remainder of the case to the
    Bankruptcy Court to take further evidence. Bank of America and
    US&#160;Airways have each appealed the July&#160;19, 2006
    ruling. On January&#160;16, 2007, Bank of America amended its
    complaint to add additional breach of contract and tortious
    interference claims against US&#160;Airways and America West, as
    well as claims against Juniper.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    29
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On February&#160;9, 2007, passengers Daphne Renard and Todd
    Robins filed a class action suit against US&#160;Airways in
    San&#160;Francisco Superior Court. The complaint alleges that
    US&#160;Airways breached its contract of carriage by charging
    additional fares and fees, after the purchase of tickets on the
    usairways.com website, for passengers under two years of age who
    travel as &#147;lap children,&#148; meaning that the child does
    not occupy his or her own seat but travels instead on the lap of
    an accompanying adult. The named plaintiffs allege that they
    purchased international tickets through the website for
    themselves and a lap child. Plaintiffs allege that after
    initially receiving an electronic confirmation that there would
    be no charge for the lap child, they were later charged an
    additional $242.50. The complaint alleges a class period from
    February&#160;9, 2002 to the present. We have not yet been
    served with the lawsuit.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We are unable to estimate at this time the amount of loss or
    probable losses, if any, that might result from an adverse
    resolution of the proceedings discussed above, and currently are
    unable to predict whether the outcome of these proceedings will
    have a material adverse effect on our results of operations or
    financial condition. We intend, however, to vigorously pursue
    all available defenses and claims in these matters.
</DIV>
<A name='107'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

    of Matters to a Vote of Security Holders</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    No matters were submitted to a vote of security holders during
    the fourth quarter of 2006.
</DIV>
<A name='118'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">PART&#160;II</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<A name='108'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Item&#160;5.<I>&#160;&#160;</I></FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Market
    for US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s Common Equity, Related
    Stockholder Matters and Issuer</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 8%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B><I>Purchases of Equity Securities</I></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Stock
    Exchange Listing</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On September&#160;27, 2005, the effective date of the merger,
    our common stock began trading on the NYSE under the symbol
    &#147;LCC.&#148; As of February&#160;15, 2007, the closing price
    of our common stock on the NYSE was $57.40. As of
    February&#160;15, 2007, there were 2,791 holders of record of
    the common stock.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Prior to the effective date of the merger and pre-merger
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s emergence from the 2004 Bankruptcy,
    pre-merger US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s then outstanding
    Class&#160;A common stock was traded on the NASDAQ
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">over-the-counter</FONT>
    market under the symbol &#147;UAIRQ&#148; until the Class&#160;A
    common stock was cancelled upon the effectiveness of the plan of
    reorganization on September&#160;27, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Market
    Prices of Common Stock</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table sets forth, for the periods indicated, the
    high and low sale prices of our common stock on the NYSE and the
    previously outstanding Class&#160;A common stock on the NASDAQ
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">over-the-counter</FONT>
    market:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=lead -->
    <TD width="12%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="66%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=gutter -->

    <TD width="4%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=gutter -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    30
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group, organized under the laws of the State of
    Delaware, is subject to Sections&#160;160 and 170 of the
    Delaware General Corporation Law, which govern the payment of
    dividends on or the repurchase or redemption of its capital
    stock. US&#160;Airways Group is restricted from engaging in any
    of these activities unless it maintains a capital surplus.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group has not declared or paid cash or other
    dividends on its common stock since 1990 and currently does not
    intend to do so. Under the provisions of certain debt
    agreements, including our secured loans, our ability to pay
    dividends on or repurchase our common stock is restricted. Any
    future determination to pay cash dividends will be at the
    discretion of our board of directors, subject to applicable
    limitations under Delaware law, and will depend upon our results
    of operations, financial condition, contractual restrictions and
    other factors deemed relevant by our board of directors. See
    &#147;Liquidity and Capital Resources&#148; in Item&#160;7,
    &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial
    Condition and Results of Operation,&#148; below for more
    information, including information related to dividend
    restrictions associated with our secured loans.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Foreign
    Ownership Restrictions</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Under current federal law,
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">non-U.S.&#160;citizens</FONT>
    cannot own or control more than 25% of the outstanding voting
    securities of a domestic air carrier. We believe that we were in
    compliance with this statute during the time period covered by
    this report.
</DIV>
<A name='109'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Item&#160;6.&#160;&#160;<I>Selected
    Financial Data</I></FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Selected
    Consolidated Financial Data of US&#160;Airways Group</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The selected consolidated financial data presented below under
    the captions &#147;Consolidated Statements of Operations
    Data&#148; and &#147;Consolidated Balance Sheet Data&#148; as of
    and for the years ended December&#160;31, 2006, 2005, 2004, 2003
    and 2002 are derived from the audited consolidated financial
    statements of US&#160;Airways Group. The full year 2006 is
    comprised of the consolidated financial data of US&#160;Airways
    Group. The 2005 consolidated financial data presented includes
    the consolidated results of America West Holdings for the
    269&#160;days through September&#160;27, 2005, the effective
    date of the merger, and the consolidated results of
    US&#160;Airways Group and its subsidiaries, including
    US&#160;Airways, America West Holdings and AWA, for the
    96&#160;days from September&#160;27, 2005 to December&#160;31,
    2005. For periods prior to 2005, the consolidated financial data
    for US&#160;Airways Group reflect only the consolidated results
    of America West Holdings. The selected consolidated financial
    data should be read in conjunction with the consolidated
    financial statements for the respective periods, the related
    notes and the related reports of US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s
    independent registered public accounting firms.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The 2006 results include $131&#160;million of merger related
    transition expenses, offset by a $90&#160;million gain
    associated with the return of equipment deposits upon
    forgiveness of a loan and $14&#160;million of gains associated
    with the settlement of bankruptcy claims.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The 2005 results include $121&#160;million of special charges,
    including $28&#160;million of merger related transition
    expenses, a $27&#160;million loss on the sale and leaseback of
    six Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300</FONT>
    aircraft and two Boeing 757 aircraft, $7&#160;million of power
    by the hour program penalties associated with the return of
    certain leased aircraft and a $50&#160;million charge related to
    an amended Airbus purchase agreement, along with the write off
    of $7&#160;million in capitalized interest. The Airbus
    restructuring fee was paid by means of set-off against existing
    equipment purchase deposits held by Airbus.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    AWA&#146;s 2004 results include a $16&#160;million net credit
    associated with the termination of the rate per engine hour
    agreement with General Electric Engine Services for overhaul
    maintenance services on V2500-A1 engines. This credit was
    partially offset by $2&#160;million of net charges related to
    the return of certain Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT>
    aircraft, which includes termination payments of
    $2&#160;million, the write-down of leasehold improvements and
    deferred rent of $3&#160;million, offset by the net reversal of
    maintenance reserves of $3&#160;million related to the returned
    aircraft.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    AWA&#146;s 2003 results include $16&#160;million of charges
    resulting from the elimination of AWA&#146;s hub operations in
    Columbus, Ohio ($11&#160;million), the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">reduction-in-force</FONT>
    of certain management, professional and administrative employees
    ($2&#160;million) and the impairment of certain owned Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT>
    aircraft that were grounded ($3&#160;million), offset by a
    $1&#160;million reduction due to a revision of the estimated
    costs related to the early termination of certain aircraft
    leases and a $1&#160;million reduction related to the revision
    of estimated costs associated with the sale and leaseback of
    certain aircraft.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    32
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The 2002 period includes $19&#160;million of charges primarily
    related to the restructuring completed on January&#160;18, 2002,
    resulting from the events of September&#160;11, 2001.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The 2006 period includes a non-cash expense for income taxes of
    $85&#160;million related to the utilization of NOL acquired from
    US&#160;Airways. The valuation allowance associated with these
    acquired NOL was recognized as a reduction of goodwill rather
    than a reduction in tax expense. In addition, the period
    includes $6&#160;million of prepayment penalties and a
    $5&#160;million write-off of debt issuance costs in connection
    with the $1.25&#160;billion debt refinancing in the first
    quarter of 2006, $17&#160;million in payments in connection with
    the inducement to convert $70&#160;million of the 7%&#160;Senior
    Convertible Notes to common stock and a $2&#160;million
    write-off of debt issuance costs associated with those converted
    notes, all of which was offset by $8&#160;million of interest
    income earned by AWA on certain prior year Federal income tax
    refunds.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Nonoperating income (expense) in the 2005 period includes an
    $8&#160;million charge related to the write-off of the
    unamortized value of the Air Transportation Stabilization Board
    (&#147;ATSB&#148;) warrants upon their repurchase in October
    2005 and an aggregate $2&#160;million write-off of debt issuance
    costs associated with the exchange of the 7.25%&#160;Senior
    Exchangeable Notes due 2023 and retirement of a portion of the
    loan formerly guaranteed by the ATSB. In the fourth quarter 2005
    period, US&#160;Airways recorded $4&#160;million of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to-market</FONT>
    gains attributable to stock options in Sabre and warrants in a
    number of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">e-commerce</FONT>
    companies.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The 2004 period includes a $1&#160;million gain at AWA on the
    disposition of property and equipment due principally to the
    sale of one Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT>
    aircraft and a $1&#160;million charge for the write-off of debt
    issuance costs in connection with the refinancing of the term
    loan.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The 2003 period includes federal government assistance of
    $81&#160;million recognized as nonoperating income under the
    Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act and
    $9&#160;million in 2002 as nonoperating income under the Air
    Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The 2006 period includes a $1&#160;million benefit which
    represents the cumulative effect on the accumulated deficit of
    the adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards
    (&#147;SFAS&#148;) No.&#160;123R. The adjustment reflects the
    impact of estimating future forfeitures for previously
    recognized compensation expense.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The 2005 period includes a $202&#160;million adjustment which
    represents the cumulative effect on the accumulated deficit of
    the adoption of the direct expense method of accounting for
    major scheduled airframe, engine and certain component overhaul
    costs as of January&#160;1, 2005. (See Part&#160;II,
    Item&#160;8A, Note&#160;3 &#147;Change in Accounting Policy for
    Maintenance Costs&#148;).</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The 2002 period includes a $208&#160;million adjustment which
    represents the cumulative effect on retained earnings of the
    adoption of SFAS&#160;No.&#160;142, &#147;Goodwill and Other
    Intangible Assets&#148; which was issued by the FASB in June
    2001. SFAS&#160;No.&#160;142 primarily addresses the accounting
    for goodwill and intangible assets subsequent to their
    acquisition. Under SFAS&#160;No.&#160;142, Enterprise
    Reorganizational Value is reported as goodwill and accounted for
    in the same manner as goodwill. SFAS&#160;No.&#160;142 was
    effective for fiscal years beginning after December&#160;15,
    2001.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Includes debt, capital leases, postretirement benefits other
    than pensions (noncurrent) and employee benefit and other
    liabilities.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TR>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="99%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>

    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Selected
    Financial Data of US&#160;Airways, Inc.</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 9pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In connection with emergence from the first bankruptcy in March
    2003 and the second bankruptcy in September 2005,
    US&#160;Airways adopted fresh-start reporting in accordance with
    AICPA Statement of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Position&#160;90-7,</FONT>
    &#147;Financial Reporting by Entities in Reorganization Under
    the Bankruptcy Code.&#148; As a result of the application of
    fresh-start reporting, the financial statements prior to
    March&#160;31, 2003 are not comparable with the financial
    statements for the period April&#160;1, 2003 to
    September&#160;27, 2005, nor is either period comparable to
    periods after September&#160;27, 2005. References to
    &#147;Successor Company&#148; refer to US&#160;Airways on and
    after September&#160;27, 2005, after the application of
    fresh-start reporting for the second bankruptcy.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The 2006 results include $64&#160;million of merger related
    transition expenses, offset by a $40&#160;million gain
    associated with the return of equipment deposits upon
    forgiveness of a loan and $3&#160;million of&#160;gains
    associated with the settlement of bankruptcy claims.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The operating results for the three months ended
    December&#160;31, 2005 include $15&#160;million in
    merger-related transition costs.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The operating results for the nine months ended
    December&#160;31, 2003 include $212&#160;million, net of amounts
    due to certain affiliates, reduction in operating expenses in
    connection with the reimbursement for certain aviation-related
    security expenses in connection with the Emergency Wartime
    Supplemental Appropriations Act and a $35&#160;million charge in
    connection with US&#160;Airways&#146; intention not to take
    delivery of certain aircraft scheduled for future delivery.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The results for the year ended December&#160;31, 2002 include a
    $392&#160;million charge as a result of an impairment analysis
    conducted on the B737-300, B737-400, B757-200 and B767-200
    aircraft fleets as a result of changes to the aircraft&#146;s
    recoverability periods, the planned conversion of owned aircraft
    to leased aircraft and indications of possible material changes
    to the market values of these aircraft. The analysis revealed
    that estimated undiscounted future cash flows generated by these
    aircraft were less than their carrying values for four
    B737-300s, 15 B737-400s, 21 B757-200s and three B767-200s. In
    accordance with SFAS&#160;No.&#160;144, &#147;Accounting for the
    Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets,&#148; the carrying
    values were reduced to fair market value. The 2002 results also
    include a curtailment credit of $120&#160;million related to
    certain postretirement benefit plans, a $30&#160;million
    curtailment charge related to certain defined benefit pension
    plans and an impairment charge of $21&#160;million related to
    capitalized gates at certain airports in accordance with
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;142, &#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible
    Assets.&#148; The carrying values of the affected gates were
    reduced to fair value based on a third-party appraisal. </TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In addition to the items discussed in note (b)&#160;above, net
    income (loss) reflects the following items for the periods
    indicated. The year ended December&#160;31, 2006 includes a
    non-cash expense for income taxes of $85&#160;million related to
    the utilization of $85&#160;million of NOL acquired from
    US&#160;Airways. The release of the valuation allowance
    associated with these acquired NOL was recognized as a reduction
    of goodwill rather than a reduction in tax expense.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The nine months ended September&#160;30, 2005 and the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2004 include reorganization items which
    amounted to a $636&#160;million net gain and a $32&#160;million
    expense, respectively. The nine months ended December&#160;31,
    2003 include a $30&#160;million gain on the sale of
    US&#160;Airways&#146; investment in Hotwire, Inc. In connection
    with US&#160;Airways&#146; first bankruptcy, a
    $1.89&#160;billion gain and charges of $294&#160;million
    attributable to reorganization items, net are included
    for&#160;the three months ended March&#160;31, 2003 and the year
    ended December&#160;31, 2002, respectively.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    34
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Includes debt, capital leases, postretirement benefits other
    than pensions (noncurrent) and employee benefit and other
    liabilities. Also includes liabilities subject to compromise at
    December&#160;31, 2004 and December&#160;31, 2002.</TD>
