<A name='110'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Item&#160;7.<I>&#160;&#160;</I></FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Management&#146;s
    Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
    Operations</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Background</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group is a holding company whose primary
    business activity is the operation of a major network air
    carrier, through its ownership of the common stock of America
    West Holdings and its wholly owned subsidiary AWA,
    US&#160;Airways, Piedmont, PSA, MSC and Airways Assurance
    Limited. On September&#160;12, 2004, US&#160;Airways Group and
    its domestic subsidiaries, US&#160;Airways, Piedmont, PSA and
    MSC (collectively, the &#147;Reorganized Debtors&#148;), which
    at the time accounted for substantially all of the operations of
    US&#160;Airways Group, filed voluntary petitions for relief
    under Chapter&#160;11 of the U.S.&#160;Bankruptcy Code in the
    United States Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern District of
    Virginia, Alexandria Division. On May&#160;19, 2005,
    US&#160;Airways Group signed a merger agreement, subsequently
    amended on July&#160;7, 2005, with America West Holdings
    pursuant to which America West Holdings merged with a wholly
    owned subsidiary of US&#160;Airways Group. The plan of
    reorganization of US&#160;Airways Group and its domestic
    subsidiaries was confirmed by the Bankruptcy Court on
    September&#160;16, 2005. The merger became effective upon
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s emergence from bankruptcy on
    September&#160;27, 2005. Following the merger, America West
    Holdings continued as a wholly owned subsidiary of
    US&#160;Airways Group.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Following the merger, US&#160;Airways Group has been moving
    toward operating under the single brand name of
    &#147;US&#160;Airways&#148; through its two principal
    subsidiaries: US&#160;Airways and AWA. We expect to complete the
    integration of our two principal subsidiaries into one operation
    during 2007. As a result of the merger, through our two
    principal operating subsidiaries, we operate the fifth largest
    airline in the United States as measured by domestic RPMs and
    ASMs. We have primary hubs in Charlotte, Philadelphia and
    Phoenix and secondary hubs/focus cities in Pittsburgh, Las
    Vegas, New York, Washington,&#160;D.C. and Boston. We are a
    low-cost carrier offering scheduled passenger service on
    approximately 4,000 flights daily to 240 communities in the
    U.S., Canada, the Caribbean, Latin America and Europe, making us
    the only U.S.&#160;based low-cost carrier with a significant
    international route presence. We are also the only low-cost
    carrier with an established East Coast route network, including
    the US&#160;Airways Shuttle service, with substantial presence
    at capacity constrained airports including New York&#146;s
    LaGuardia Airport and the Washington,&#160;D.C. area&#146;s
    Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, our two principal subsidiaries operate
    359 mainline jets and are supported by our regional airline
    subsidiaries and affiliates operating as US&#160;Airways
    Express, which operate approximately 240 regional jets and 104
    turboprops. In 2006, we generated passenger revenues of
    $10.71&#160;billion.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The merger has been accounted for as a reverse acquisition using
    the purchase method of accounting. As a result, although the
    merger was structured such that America West Holdings became a
    wholly owned subsidiary of US&#160;Airways Group, America West
    Holdings was treated as the acquiring company for accounting
    purposes due to the following factors: (1)&#160;America West
    Holdings&#146; stockholders received the largest share of
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s common stock in the merger in
    comparison to unsecured creditors of US&#160;Airways Group;
    (2)&#160;America West Holdings received a larger number of
    designees to the board of directors; and (3)&#160;America West
    Holdings&#146; Chairman and Chief Executive Officer prior to the
    merger became the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the
    combined company. As a result of the reverse acquisition, the
    2005 consolidated statement of operations for the new
    US&#160;Airways Group presented in this report is comprised of
    the results of America West Holdings for the 269&#160;days
    through September&#160;27, 2005 and consolidated results of
    US&#160;Airways Group for the 96&#160;days from
    September&#160;27, 2005 through December&#160;31, 2005. The
    results of operations for fiscal years 2004 and 2003 are those
    of America West Holdings.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    35
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

</TD>

    <TD align="left">

    Employee Association, an alliance between the Communication
    Workers of America (CWA) and the International Brotherhood of
    Teamsters (IBT), the two unions that represent the
    airline&#146;s 7,700 passenger service employees and
    reservations agents;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Reached a final agreement with the Transport Workers Union
    (TWU), the union that represents flight dispatchers, on a single
    contract that transitions former AWA dispatchers to the labor
    agreement covering pre-merger US&#160;Airways dispatchers;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Recalled 100 furloughed US&#160;Airways pilots and 200
    furloughed US&#160;Airways flight attendants, due to increased
    operations since the merger; and
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Increased hiring in the Winston-Salem, North Carolina and Reno,
    Nevada reservation centers to bring some of the currently
    outsourced reservations work back in-house.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We are fast approaching several significant milestones as we
    near completion of our integration efforts. Our next steps
    include:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Migration to a single reservation system by the end of the first
    quarter of 2007;&#160;and
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Completion of the transition plan to merge the airlines into one
    FAA operating certificate during 2007.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Additionally, we are continuing to negotiate with the pilot,
    flight attendant, fleet service and mechanic labor groups in
    hopes of reaching final agreements with these unions. After
    final agreements are reached, we will make necessary changes to
    payroll and other labor-related systems.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="98%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Cost
    Control</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We remain committed to maintaining a low cost structure, which
    we believe is necessary to compete effectively in the airline
    industry. Low cost carriers, some of which have cost structures
    lower than ours, continue to enter and grow in the markets in
    which we operate. In addition, the traditional legacy carriers,
    which have competitive advantages including vast route networks,
    alliances and generous frequent flyer programs, remain focused
    on lowering their respective costs. This includes using the
    bankruptcy process to restructure with lower cost structures. In
    light of this environment, we continue to focus on minimizing
    unnecessary capital expenditures and prudent spending for
    discretionary expenses. We believe our combined mainline cost
    per available seat mile (&#147;CASM&#148;) will remain
    competitive with the low cost carriers and among the lowest of
    the traditional legacy
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    37
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    carriers, particularly as the benefits of our cost synergies are
    realized. See the US&#160;Airways Group, AWA and US&#160;Airways
    Results of Operations sections within Item&#160;7 of this report
    for analysis related to CASM.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="98%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Revenue
    Pricing Environment</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The revenue environment improved dramatically during 2006 as our
    mainline passenger revenue per available seat mile
    (&#147;PRASM&#148;) was 10.35 cents in 2006. For the fourth
    quarter of 2006, the first full quarter where US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s results were comparable on a
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">year-over-year</FONT>
    basis, US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s mainline PRASM increased to
    10.12 cents compared to PRASM in the 2005 period of 9.32 cents.
    For the full year 2006, AWA&#146;s mainline PRASM increased
    12.9% to 9.34 cents in 2006 from 8.27 cents in 2005.
    US&#160;Airways&#146; mainline PRASM increased 16.3% to 10.97
    cents in 2006 from 9.44 cents in 2005. The improvement in
    mainline PRASM during 2006 was driven by: (1)&#160;rational
    industry capacity growth, which led to pricing power and yield
    growth for the entire industry; (2)&#160;strong leisure demand;
    and (3)&#160;realization of some of the synergy benefits from
    the merger, including our fare restructuring, the implementation
    of a code share agreement between AWA and US&#160;Airways that
    helped each airline sell more tickets, an improved and combined
    frequent flyer program and a rationalized route network that
    eliminated capacity on our weakest routes.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="98%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Customer
    Service</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We are committed to building a successful combined airline by
    taking care of our customers. We believe that our focus on
    excellent customer service in every aspect of our operations
    including personnel, flight equipment, inflight and ancillary
    amenities, on-time performance, flight completion ratios and
    baggage handling, will strengthen customer loyalty and attract
    new customers. Combined DOT measures as reported by AWA and
    US&#160;Airways for the years ended December&#160;31, 2006, 2005
    and 2004 were as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our on-time performance for 2006 ranked second among the ten
    largest U.S.&#160;carriers as measured by the DOT. During 2006
    we achieved significant operational improvements at our
    Philadelphia hub. Specifically, customer complaints are down
    over 30&#160;percent from 2005 levels. In addition, mishandled
    baggage per 1,000 enplanements is down nearly 15&#160;percent
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">year-over-year,</FONT>
    with over 95&#160;percent of all local in-bound baggage now
    delivered to the baggage carousel in 19.1 minutes on average.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s Results of Operations</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The full year 2006 includes the consolidated results of the new
    US&#160;Airways Group and its subsidiaries, including
    US&#160;Airways, America West Holdings and AWA. As noted above,
    the 2005&#160;statement of operations presented includes the
    consolidated results of America West Holdings for the
    269&#160;days through September&#160;27, 2005, the effective
    date of the merger, and the consolidated results of the new
    US&#160;Airways Group for the 96&#160;days from
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 9pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Includes US&#160;Airways and US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s wholly
    owned subsidiaries, PSA, Piedmont and MSC.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2006, we realized operating income of $558&#160;million and
    income before cumulative effect of change in accounting
    principle of $303&#160;million. These results include
    $79&#160;million of net losses associated with AWA&#146;s fuel
    hedging transactions. This includes $9&#160;million of net
    realized losses on settled hedge transactions and
    $70&#160;million of unrealized losses resulting from the
    application of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to-market</FONT>
    accounting for changes in the fair value of fuel hedging
    instruments. AWA is required to use
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to-market</FONT>
    accounting as its fuel hedging instruments do not meet the
    requirements for hedge accounting as established by
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;133, &#147;Accounting for Derivative
    Instruments and Hedging Activities.&#148; Given the market
    volatility of jet fuel, the fair value of these fuel hedging
    instruments is expected to change until settled. The 2006
    results also include $27&#160;million of net special charges,
    including $131&#160;million of merger-related transition
    expenses, partially offset by a $90&#160;million credit related
    to the Airbus restructuring and $14&#160;million of credits
    related to the settlement of certain bankruptcy-related claims.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The 2006 results include nonoperating expenses of
    $6&#160;million for prepayment penalties and $5&#160;million
    write-off of debt issuance costs in connection with our
    refinancing of the ATSB and GECC loans (discussed below under
    &#147;Liquidity and Capital Resources&#160;&#151;
    Commitments&#148;), $17&#160;million in payments in connection
    with the inducement to convert $70&#160;million of the 7% Senior
    Convertible Notes to common stock and a $2&#160;million write
    off of debt issuance costs associated with those converted notes.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As a result of the merger timing, the fourth quarter of 2006 is
    the first full quarter where our results are comparable on a
    year-over-year basis. In the fourth quarter of 2006, our CASM
    was 10.98 cents compared to 11.12&#160;cents for the fourth
    quarter of 2005. The significant components of the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">quarter-over-quarter</FONT>
    net decrease in CASM are as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    A $28&#160;million decrease in fuel expense as the average cost
    per gallon of fuel decreased 7.2%, representing a decrease in
    CASM of 0.17 cents,&#160;and
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    A $26&#160;million decrease in net special items, due to a
    decrease in the merger and transition related expenses,
    representing a decrease in CASM of 0.14 cents, partially offset
    by
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    A $20&#160;million increase in expense related to our profit
    sharing and other employee bonus programs, which are included in
    salaries and related costs on our consolidated statements of
    operations, representing an increase in CASM of 0.10 cents.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways and AWA had a
    total of $980&#160;million of net operating loss carryforwards
    (NOL) to reduce future taxable income, which includes
    $69&#160;million of NOL related to stock-based
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    39
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    compensation deduction. Of this amount $795&#160;million is
    available to reduce federal taxable income in 2007. Deferred tax
    assets, which include the $795&#160;million of NOL discussed
    above, have been subject to a valuation allowance. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, that valuation allowance was
    $263&#160;million. We utilized NOL in 2006, a portion of which
    was reserved by a valuation allowance. The use of the NOL
    permitted the reversal of the valuation allowance which reduced
    income tax expenses. In 2007, we expect to utilize additional
    NOL and as a result, the remaining valuation allowance will be
    reduced.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For the full year 2006, US&#160;Airways recognized
    $85&#160;million of non-cash income tax expense, as NOL that was
    generated by US&#160;Airways prior to the merger was utilized.
    In accordance with SFAS No.&#160;109, &#147;Accounting for
    Income Taxes,&#148; as this was acquired NOL, the decrease in
    the valuation allowance associated with this NOL reduced
    goodwill instead of the provision for income taxes. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, the remaining valuation allowance
    associated with acquired NOL was $29&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We were subject to Alternative Minimum Tax liability
    (&#147;AMT&#148;) in 2006. In most cases the recognition of AMT
    does not result in tax expense. However, since our NOL was
    subject to a full valuation allowance, any liability for AMT is
    recorded as tax expense. We recorded AMT tax expense of
    $10&#160;million for the full year 2006. We also recorded
    $2&#160;million of state income tax provision in 2006 related to
    certain states where NOL was not available to be used.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2005, we realized operating losses of $217&#160;million and a
    loss before cumulative effect of change in accounting principle
    of $335&#160;million. In 2005, America West Holdings changed its
    accounting policy for certain maintenance costs from the
    deferral method to the direct expense method as if that change
    occurred January&#160;1, 2005. This resulted in a
    $202&#160;million loss from the cumulative effect of a change in
    accounting principle, or $6.41&#160;per common share. See
    note&#160;3, &#147;Change in Accounting Policy for Maintenance
    Costs,&#148; to the consolidated financial statements in
    Item&#160;8A of this report.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The 2005 results include $75&#160;million of net gains
    associated with AWA&#146;s fuel hedging transactions. This
    includes $71&#160;million of net realized gains on settled hedge
    transactions and $4&#160;million of unrealized gains resulting
    from the application of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to-market</FONT>
    accounting for changes in the fair value of fuel hedging
    instruments.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The 2005 results include $121&#160;million of special charges,
    including $28&#160;million of merger related transition
    expenses, a $27 million loss on the sale and leaseback of six
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300</FONT>
    aircraft and two 757 aircraft, $7&#160;million of power by the
    hour program penalties associated with the return of certain
    leased aircraft and a restructuring fee of $50&#160;million
    related to the amended Airbus purchase agreement, along with
    $7&#160;million in capitalized interest. The restructuring fee
    was paid by means of set-off against existing equipment purchase
    deposits held by Airbus. The 2005 results also include
    nonoperating expenses of $8&#160;million related to the
    write-off of the unamortized value of the ATSB warrants upon
    their repurchase in October 2005 and an aggregate
    $2&#160;million write-off of debt issuance costs associated with
    the exchange of the 7.25%&#160;Senior Exchangeable Notes due
    2023 and retirement of a portion of the loan formerly guaranteed
    by the ATSB.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2004, we realized operating losses of $20&#160;million and a
    loss before cumulative effect of change in accounting principle
    of $89&#160;million. These results include a $16&#160;million
    net credit associated with the termination of the rate per
    engine hour agreement with General Electric Engine Services for
    overhaul maintenance services on V2500-A1 engines. This credit
    was partially offset by $2&#160;million of net charges related
    to the return of certain Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT>
    aircraft, which includes termination payments of
    $2&#160;million, the write-down of leasehold improvements and
    deferred rent of $3&#160;million, offset by the net reversal of
    maintenance reserves of $3&#160;million related to the returned
    aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The 2004 results also include a $24&#160;million net gain on
    derivative instruments associated with AWA&#146;s fuel hedging
    program. This amount includes $26&#160;million of realized gains
    on settled hedge transactions and $2&#160;million of unrealized
    losses resulting from
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to-market</FONT>
    accounting for changes in the fair value of AWA&#146;s fuel
    hedging instruments. A $6&#160;million charge arising from the
    resolution of pending litigation, a $5&#160;million loss on the
    sale and leaseback of two new Airbus aircraft and a
    $1&#160;million charge for the write-off of debt issuance costs
    in connection with the refinancing of the Mizuho Corporate Bank
    term loan were also recognized in 2004.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    40
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group did not record an income tax benefit for
    the years ended December&#160;31, 2005 and 2004 and recorded a
    full valuation allowance on any future tax benefits generated in
    those periods as we had yet to achieve several consecutive
    quarters of profitable results coupled with an expectation of
    continued profitability.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">AWA&#146;s
    Results of Operations</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2006, AWA realized operating losses of $35&#160;million and a
    loss before income taxes and cumulative effect of change in
    accounting principle of $33&#160;million. Included in these
    results is $79&#160;million of net losses associated with its
    fuel hedging transactions. This includes $9&#160;million of net
    realized losses on settled hedge transactions and
    $70&#160;million of unrealized losses resulting from the
    application of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to-market</FONT>
    accounting for changes in the fair value of fuel hedging
    instruments.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The 2006 results include $17&#160;million of net special
    charges, including $68&#160;million of merger related transition
    expenses offset in part by a credit of $51&#160;million related
    to the Airbus restructuring. The 2006 results also include
    nonoperating expenses of $11&#160;million related to
    $6&#160;million for prepayment penalties and an aggregate
    $5&#160;million write off of debt issuance costs in connection
    with our refinancing of the ATSB and GECC loans.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2005, AWA realized operating losses of $120&#160;million and
    a loss before income taxes and cumulative effect of change in
    accounting principle of $195&#160;million. In 2005, AWA changed
    its accounting policy for certain maintenance costs from the
    deferral method to the direct expense method as if that change
    occurred January&#160;1, 2005. This resulted in a
    $202&#160;million loss from the cumulative effect of a change in
    accounting principle. See Note&#160;2, &#147;Change in
    Accounting Policy for Maintenance Costs,&#148; to AWA&#146;s
    consolidated financial statements in Item&#160;8B of this report.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA&#146;s 2005 results include $75&#160;million of net gains
    associated with its fuel hedging transactions. This includes
    $71&#160;million of net realized gains on settled hedge
    transactions and $4&#160;million of unrealized gains resulting
    from the application of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to-market</FONT>
    accounting for changes in the fair value of fuel hedging
    instruments.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The 2005 results include $106&#160;million of special charges,
    including $13&#160;million of merger related transition
    expenses, a $27&#160;million loss on the sale and leaseback of
    six <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300</FONT>
    aircraft and two 757 aircraft, $7&#160;million of power by the
    hour program penalties associated with the return of certain
    leased aircraft and a $50&#160;million charge related to an
    amended Airbus purchase agreement, along with $7&#160;million in
    capitalized interest. The Airbus restructuring fee was paid by
    means of setoff against existing equipment purchase deposits
    held by Airbus. The 2005 results also include nonoperating
    expenses of $8&#160;million related to the write-off of the
    unamortized value of the ATSB warrants upon their repurchase in
    October 2005 and an aggregate $2&#160;million write-off of debt
    issuance costs associated with the exchange of the 7.25% Senior
    Exchangeable Notes due 2023 and retirement of a portion of the
    loan formerly guaranteed by the ATSB.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2004, AWA realized operating losses of $16&#160;million and a
    loss before income taxes and cumulative effect of change in
    accounting principle of $85&#160;million. Included in these
    results was a $16&#160;million net credit associated with the
    termination of the rate per engine hour agreement with General
    Electric Engine Services for overhaul maintenance services on
    V2500-A1 engines. This credit was partially offset by
    $2&#160;million of net charges related to the return of certain
    Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT>
    aircraft, which includes termination payments of
    $2&#160;million, the write-down of leasehold improvements and
    deferred rent of $3&#160;million, offset by the net reversal of
    maintenance reserves of $3&#160;million related to the returned
    aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The 2004 results also include a $24&#160;million net gain on
    derivative instruments associated with AWA&#146;s fuel hedging
    program. This amount includes $26&#160;million of realized gains
    on settled hedge transactions and $2&#160;million of unrealized
    losses resulting from
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to-market</FONT>
    accounting for changes in the fair value of AWA&#146;s fuel
    hedging instruments. A $6&#160;million charge arising from the
    resolution of pending litigation, a $5&#160;million loss on the
    sale and leaseback of two new Airbus aircraft and a
    $1&#160;million charge for the write-off of debt issuance costs
    in connection with the refinancing of the term loan were also
    recognized in 2004.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    41
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 9pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Revenue passenger mile (&#147;RPM&#148;)&#160;&#151; A basic
    measure of sales volume. It is one passenger flown one mile.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Available seat mile (&#147;ASM&#148;)&#160;&#151; A basic
    measure of production. It is one seat flown one statute mile.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Load factor&#160;&#151; The percentage of available seats that
    are filled with revenue passengers.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Yield&#160;&#151; A measure of airline revenue derived by
    dividing passenger revenue by revenue passenger miles and
    expressed in cents per mile.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (e) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Passenger revenue per available seat mile
    (&#147;PRASM&#148;)&#160;&#151; Total passenger revenues divided
    by total available seat miles.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (f) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Passenger enplanements&#160;&#151; The number of passengers on
    board an aircraft including local, connecting and through
    passengers.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (g) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Block hours&#160;&#151; The hours measured from the moment an
    aircraft first moves under its own power, including taxi time,
    for the purposes of flight until the aircraft is docked at the
    next point of landing and its power is shut down.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (h) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Average stage length&#160;&#151; The average of the distances
    flown on each segment of every route.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (i) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Average passenger journey&#160;&#151; The average one-way trip
    measured in statute miles for one passenger origination.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    42
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

</TD>
<TD nowrap align="right" valign="bottom">

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total operating revenues for AWA for 2006 were
    $3.64&#160;billion, an increase of $373&#160;million from 2005.
    Passenger revenues were $2.76&#160;billion in 2006 compared to
    $2.52&#160;billion in 2005. RPMs decreased 2.9% as mainline
    capacity, as measured by ASMs, decreased 3.1%, resulting in a
    0.2 point increase in load factor to 79.7%. This increase in
    load factor was achieved with higher passenger yield, which
    increased 12.8% to 11.72 cents due to improvements in the
    revenue environment from increased demand, fuel driven fare
    increases and reductions in industry capacity. As a result,
    mainline PRASM during 2006 increased 12.9% to 9.34 cents from
    8.27 cents in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Express passenger revenues were $660&#160;million for 2006, an
    increase of $148&#160;million from 2005 due to increased flying
    by Mesa under its alliance agreement with AWA along with an
    increase in express yield. Express RPMs increased by 7.8% as
    express capacity, as measured by ASM&#146;s, increased 2.7%,
    resulting in a 3.6 point increase in load factor to 75.5%. In
    addition passenger yield increased by 19.5% in 2006 due to the
    improved industry pricing environment.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Cargo revenue was relatively flat in 2006 compared to 2005.
    Other revenues decreased 6.6% from $197&#160;million in 2005 to
    $184&#160;million in 2006 due principally to a decrease in net
    revenues associated with the sale of tour packages by the
    US&#160;Airways Vacations division and a decrease in ticket
    change and service fees.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Operating
    Expenses:</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total operating expenses were $3.67&#160;billion in 2006, an
    increase of $288&#160;million or 8.5% compared to 2005. Mainline
    operating expenses were $3.06&#160;billion in 2006, an increase
    of $222&#160;million from 2005, while ASMs
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    43
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    decreased 3.1%. Mainline CASM increased 11.3% to 10.35 cents in
    2006 from 9.30 cents in 2005. The 2006 period includes
    $17&#160;million of net special items, which comprises 0.06
    cents of mainline CASM, as compared to $106&#160;million of net
    special items, which comprises of 0.35 cents of mainline CASM in
    2005. The increase in CASM during 2006 was due principally to a
    16.5% increase in the average fuel price per gallon, combined
    with $79&#160;million of net losses associated with fuel hedging
    transactions in 2006 as compared to $75&#160;million in gains in
    2005. Aircraft fuel expense and losses on fuel hedging
    instruments totaled $990&#160;million in 2006, which accounted
    for $253&#160;million of the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">year-over-year</FONT>
    increase in mainline operating expenses.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    for AWA for the years ended December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005:

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Significant changes in the components of operating expense per
    ASM are explained as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft fuel and related tax expense per ASM increased 15.8%
    due primarily to a 16.5% increase in the average price per
    gallon of fuel to $2.09 in 2006 from $1.80 in 2005.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Salaries and related costs per ASM increased 8.3% primarily due
    to higher costs associated with employee incentive plans,
    including $23&#160;million recorded for the US&#160;Airways
    Group profit sharing plan.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft rent expense per ASM increased 6.9% due principally to
    aircraft mix, as previously owned and leased Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT> and
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300</FONT>
    aircraft were retired, returned to aircraft lessors or sold and
    leased back in 2005 and 2006 and replaced with leased Airbus
    A320 and A319 aircraft at higher monthly lease rates.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Depreciation and amortization expense per ASM decreased 11.1%
    due to a decrease in the number of owned aircraft in 2006 as a
    result of sale-leaseback transactions completed in 2005.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Other operating expenses per ASM increased 14.4% in 2006
    primarily due to the transition from the FlightFund frequent
    flyer program to the Dividend Miles program, which results in
    higher costs due to the Dividend Miles program allowing members
    to redeem awards on Star Alliance partner airlines.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Express expenses increased 12.1% in 2006 to $611&#160;million
    from $545&#160;million in 2005. Aircraft fuel expense accounted
    for $28&#160;million of the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">year-over-year</FONT>
    increase due to increases in fuel prices, while Express
    operating expenses increased $38&#160;million due to the
    increase in flying by Mesa under its alliance agreement with AWA.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    44
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA had net nonoperating income of $2&#160;million in 2006 as
    compared to net nonoperating expenses of $75&#160;million in
    2005. Interest income increased $43&#160;million to
    $68&#160;million in 2006 due to higher average cash balances and
    higher average rates of return on investments and
    $8&#160;million of interest income earned by AWA in 2006 on
    certain prior year federal tax refunds. Interest expense
    decreased $37&#160;million or 39.4% to $57&#160;million due to
    the conversion of the 7.25%&#160;Senior Exchangeable Notes in
    October 2005, the refinancing of the former ATSB loan at lower
    average interest rates in March 2006, and the conversion of the
    7.5%&#160;Convertible Senior Notes in April 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The 2006 period includes other nonoperating expenses of
    $11&#160;million related to prepayment penalties and write-off
    of debt issuance costs in connection with the refinancing of the
    former ATSB and GECC loans in March 2006. The 2005 period
    includes nonoperating expense of $8&#160;million related to the
    write-off of the unamortized value of the ATSB warrants upon
    their repurchase in October 2005 and an aggregate
    $2&#160;million write-off of debt issuance costs associated with
    the exchange of the 7.25%&#160;Senior Exchangeable Notes due
    2023 and retirement of a portion of the loan formerly guaranteed
    by the ATSB.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">2005
    Compared with 2004</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    17.9

<TR valign="bottom">
<TD align="left" valign="bottom">
<DIV style="text-indent: -10pt; margin-left: 30pt">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">Total operating revenues
    </FONT>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
    $
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="right" valign="bottom">
    3,263
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
    $
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="right" valign="bottom">
    2,756
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>

</TD>

&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total operating revenues for 2005 were $3.26&#160;billion, an
    increase of $507&#160;million from 2004. Passenger revenues were
    $2.52&#160;billion in 2005 compared to $2.20&#160;billion in
    2004. RPMs increased 4.0% as mainline capacity, as measured by
    ASMs, increased 1.2%, resulting in a 2.1 point increase in load
    factor to 79.5%. This increase in load factor was achieved with
    higher passenger yield, which increased 10.1% to 10.39 cents. As
    a result, mainline PRASM during 2005 increased 13.1% to 8.27
    cents from 7.31 cents in 2004, despite a 2.3% decrease in
    average stage length. The improvement in mainline PRASM during
    2005 was driven by a strong leisure demand and a reduction in
    industry capacity growth, which led to pricing power and yielded
    growth for the entire industry.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Express passenger revenues were $512&#160;million for 2005, an
    increase of $159&#160;million from 2004 due to increased flying
    by Mesa under its alliance agreement with AWA.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Cargo revenues for 2005 increased $5&#160;million, or 17.9%, to
    $33&#160;million due to higher mail volumes. Other revenues
    increased 14.5% from $172&#160;million in 2004 to
    $197&#160;million in 2005 due principally to net revenues
    associated with the sale of tour packages by the America West
    Vacations division and an increase in ticket change and service
    fees.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    45
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>

</TD>

</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD align="left" valign="bottom">
<DIV style="text-indent: -10pt; margin-left: 30pt">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">Total operating expenses
    </FONT>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
    $
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="right" valign="bottom">
    3,383
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
    $
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="right" valign="bottom">
    2,772
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>

</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">

</TD>

    22.0
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">

</TD>

</TD>

</TD>

</TD>

</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>

&nbsp;
</TD>

&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total operating expenses were $3.38&#160;billion in 2005, an
    increase of $611&#160;million or 22.0% compared to 2004.
    Mainline operating expenses were $2.84&#160;billion in 2005, an
    increase of $440&#160;million from 2004, while ASMs increased
    1.2%. Mainline CASM increased 17.0% to 9.30 cents in 2005 from
    7.95 cents in 2004. The 2005 period includes $106&#160;million
    of net special charges, which comprises 0.35 cents of mainline
    CASM, as compared to $16&#160;million of net special credits in
    2004. The increase in CASM during 2005 was due principally to a
    37.4% increase in the average fuel price per gallon, offset by
    the $75&#160;million net gain associated with the fuel hedging
    transactions discussed above.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The table below sets forth the major components of mainline CASM
    for AWA for the years ended December&#160;31, 2005 and 2004:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Significant changes in the components of operating expense per
    ASM are explained as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft fuel and related tax expense per ASM increased 36.0%
    due primarily to a 37.4% increase in the average price per
    gallon of fuel to $1.80 in 2005 from $1.31 in 2004.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    46
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Salaries and related costs per ASM increased 5.8% primarily due
    to a $23&#160;million increase in benefit related expenses,
    including $13&#160;million in defined contribution plan payments
    that our pilots became eligible for beginning on January&#160;1,
    2005, a $5&#160;million increase related to self-funded
    disability requirements and higher medical insurance costs of
    $4&#160;million. A $9&#160;million accrual for employee
    performance bonuses also contributed to the increase.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft rent expense per ASM increased 6.3% due principally to
    aircraft mix, as previously owned and leased Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT>
    aircraft were retired or returned to aircraft lessors and
    replaced with leased Airbus A320 and A319 aircraft at higher
    monthly lease rates.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft maintenance materials and repair expense per ASM
    increased 24.5% due principally to the change in AWA&#146;s
    accounting policy for certain maintenance costs in 2005
    discussed above. See Note&#160;2, &#147;Change in Accounting
    Policy for Maintenance Costs,&#148; to AWA&#146;s consolidated
    financial statements in Item&#160;8B of this report.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Express expenses increased 45.7% in 2005 to $545&#160;million
    from $374&#160;million in 2004 due to increased flying by Mesa
    under the alliance agreement with AWA. Aircraft operating
    expense for 2005 was $211&#160;million, which accounted for
    $56&#160;million of the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">year-over-year</FONT>
    increase in Express operating expenses. Aircraft fuel expense
    was $182&#160;million in 2005, which accounted for
    $80&#160;million of the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">year-over-year</FONT>
    increase.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Nonoperating
    Income (Expense):</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA had net nonoperating expenses of $75&#160;million in 2005 as
    compared to $69&#160;million in 2004. Interest income increased
    $11&#160;million to $25&#160;million in 2005 due to higher
    average cash balances and higher average rates of return on
    investments. Interest expense increased $8&#160;million or 9.3%
    to $94&#160;million primarily due to higher average outstanding
    debt, due in part to the merger and higher interest rates.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The 2005 period includes nonoperating expenses of
    $8&#160;million related to the write-off of the unamortized
    value of the ATSB warrants upon their repurchase in October 2005
    and an aggregate $2&#160;million write-off of debt issuance
    costs associated with the exchange of the 7.25%&#160;Senior
    Exchangeable Notes due 2023 and retirement of a portion of the
    loan formerly guaranteed by the ATSB. The 2004 period includes a
    $1&#160;million gain on the disposition of property and
    equipment due principally to the sale of two Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT>
    aircraft and a $1&#160;million charge for the write-off of debt
    issuance costs in connection with the refinancing of the Mizuho
    Corporate Bank term loan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways&#146;
    Results of Operations</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with emergence from bankruptcy in September 2005,
    US&#160;Airways adopted fresh-start reporting in accordance with
    AICPA Statement of Position
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">90-7,</FONT>
    &#147;Financial Reporting by Entities in Reorganization Under
    the Bankruptcy Code.&#148; As a result of the application of
    fresh-start reporting, the financial statements prior to
    September&#160;30, 2005 are not comparable with the financial
    statements for the periods after September&#160;30, 2005.
    However, for purposes of discussion of the results of
    operations, the combined results of operations of the Successor
    Company and Predecessor Company for 2005 have been compared to
    2006 and 2004. While the effective date of the plan of
    reorganization and the merger was September&#160;27, 2005, the
    results of operations for US&#160;Airways during the four day
    period from September 27 through September&#160;30, 2005 are not
    material to the financial statement presentation. References to
    &#147;Successor Company&#148; refer to US&#160;Airways on or
    after September&#160;30, 2005, after giving effect to the
    application of fresh- start reporting for bankruptcy. References
    to &#147;Predecessor Company&#148; refer to US&#160;Airways
    prior to September&#160;30, 2005.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    47
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For the full year 2006, US&#160;Airways&#146; operating revenues
    were $8.06&#160;billion, operating income was $592&#160;million
    and net income was $345&#160;million. The 2006 results include
    $21&#160;million of net special charges, including
    $64&#160;million of merger related transition expenses offset in
    part by a credit of $40&#160;million related to the Airbus
    restructuring and $3&#160;million of gains associated with the
    settlement of bankruptcy claims.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Operating revenues in 2005 were $7.21&#160;billion, operating
    loss was $213&#160;million and the net income was
    $160&#160;million. The 2005 results include $15&#160;million of
    net special charges related to merger related transition costs.
    Operating revenues for full year 2004 were $7.07&#160;billion,
    operating loss was $348&#160;million and net loss was
    $578&#160;million. US&#160;Airways&#146; results from operations
    and the net income in 2005 and net loss in 2004 were
    significantly impacted by the bankruptcy proceedings, and the
    2005 operating results also reflect the impact of the merger
    with America West Holdings.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    US&#160;Airways&#146; mainline operations.
</DIV>

</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Revenue passenger mile (&#147;RPM&#148;)&#160;&#151; A basic
    measure of sales volume. It is one passenger flown one mile.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Available seat mile (&#147;ASM&#148;)&#160;&#151; A basic
    measure of production. It is one seat flown one statute mile.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Load factor&#160;&#151; The percentage of available seats that
    are filled with revenue passengers.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Yield&#160;&#151; A measure of airline revenue derived by
    dividing passenger revenue by revenue passenger miles and
    expressed in cents per mile.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (e) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Passenger revenue per available seat mile
    (&#147;PRASM&#148;)&#160;&#151; Total passenger revenues divided
    by total available seat miles.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (f) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Passenger enplanements&#160;&#151; The number of passengers on
    board an aircraft including local, connecting and through
    passengers.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (g) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Block hours&#160;&#151; The hours measured from the moment an
    aircraft first moves under its own power, including taxi time,
    for the purposes of flight until the aircraft is docked at the
    next point of landing and its power is shut down.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (h) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Average stage length&#160;&#151; The average of the distances
    flown on each segment of every route.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (i) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Average passenger journey&#160;&#151; The average one-way trip
    measured in statute miles for one passenger origination.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    48
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total operating revenues for 2006 were $8.06&#160;billion, an
    increase from $7.21&#160;billion in 2005. Mainline passenger
    revenues were $5.21&#160;billion in 2006 compared to
    $4.86&#160;billion in 2005. RPMs decreased 4.5% as mainline
    capacity, as measured by ASMs, decreased 7.9%, resulting in a
    2.8 point increase in load factor to 78.3%. This increase in
    load factor was achieved with higher passenger yield, which
    increased 12.2% to 14.02 cents due to improvements in the
    revenue environment from increased demand, fuel driven fare
    increases and reductions in industry capacity. As a result,
    mainline PRASM during 2006 increased 16.3% to 10.97 cents from
    9.44 cents in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Express revenues are comprised of revenues associated with
    US&#160;Airways&#146; former MidAtlantic division,
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned regional airlines and
    affiliate regional airlines operating as US&#160;Airways
    Express. Express passenger revenues were $2.08&#160;billion for
    2006, an increase of $464&#160;million from 2005. Express RPMs
    increased by 6.6% as Express capacity, as measured by ASMs,
    decreased 1.7%, resulting in a 5.4 point increase in load factor
    to 69.4%. In addition, passenger yield increased by 20.7% in
    2006 also due to improvements in the revenue environment from
    increased demand, fuel driven fare increases and reductions in
    industry capacity.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Cargo revenues increased $26&#160;million in 2006 primarily due
    to a shift in the volume of international cargo from outsourcing
    to insourcing. Other revenues remained relatively flat in 2006
    compared to 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    Expenses:</FONT></I>
