<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total operating expenses in 2006 were $7.46&#160;billion, an
    increase of $44&#160;million, or 0.6%, compared to 2005.
    Mainline operating expenses were $5.40&#160;billion in 2006, a
    decrease of $154&#160;million as compared to 2005. Mainline
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    49
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    CASM increased 5.6% to 11.39 cents in 2006 from 10.79 cents in
    2005. The 2006 results include special items of
    $21&#160;million, which comprised 0.04 cents of mainline CASM,
    as compared to $15&#160;million of net special charges in 2005,
    which comprised of 0.03 cents of mainline CASM. The increase in
    CASM was mainly due to a 16.8% increase in the average fuel
    price per gallon.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The table below sets forth the major components of mainline CASM
    for US&#160;Airways for the years ended December&#160;31, 2006
    and 2005:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Significant changes in the components of mainline CASM are
    explained as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft fuel and related tax expense per ASM increased 17.4%
    primarily due to a 16.8% increase in the average price per
    gallon of fuel from $1.77 in 2005 to $2.07 in 2006.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Salaries and related costs per ASM increased 4.9% primarily due
    to costs associated with employee incentive plans in 2006,
    including $36&#160;million recorded for the US&#160;Airways
    Group profit sharing plan and that the 2005 period included a
    reduction of expenses of $71&#160;million for amortization of
    prior service benefit associated with the curtailment of
    postretirement benefits.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft rent expense per ASM increased 9.1% reflecting an
    increase in the mix of leased to owned aircraft in 2006 as a
    result of sale-leaseback transactions completed in 2005.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft maintenance per ASM increased 9.0% reflecting an
    increase in rates on the renewal of certain power by the hour
    maintenance agreements and the timing of certain engine
    maintenance cycles.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Selling expenses per ASM decreased 5.4% primarily due to
    reduction in travel agent commissions and booking fees as a
    result of lower rates renegotiated subsequent to the merger.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Depreciation and amortization decreased 20.7%&#160;per ASM as a
    result of fewer owned aircraft in the operating fleet as a
    result of sale lease back transactions completed in 2005.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Express expenses increased 10.6% to $2.06&#160;billion in 2006
    as compared to $1.86&#160;billion in 2005, as a result of higher
    fuel prices that were paid by US&#160;Airways for
    US&#160;Airways Express operations.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    50
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways had net nonoperating expense of
    $118&#160;million in 2006 compared to net nonoperating income of
    $371&#160;million in 2005. The change in nonoperating income
    (expense) is primarily a result of $636&#160;million of net
    reorganization items recognized in 2005, representing amounts
    incurred as a direct result of the Chapter&#160;11 proceedings
    and gains associated with the discharge of pre-petition
    liabilities. See 2005 to 2004 comparison for additional
    information on the components of reorganization items. Interest
    income increased $58&#160;million in 2006 as compared to 2005
    due to higher cash balances and higher average interest rates on
    cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments and the
    classification of $7&#160;million of interest income as a
    reorganization item in the first nine months of 2005. Interest
    expense decreased $72&#160;million as a result of reductions in
    the outstanding debt subsequent to the sale-leaseback
    transactions completed in 2005 and that interest expense in the
    first nine months of 2005 include penalty interest incurred as a
    result of the bankruptcy proceedings.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">2005
    Compared With 2004</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Revenues:</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="74%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=lead -->
    <TD width="4%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=lead -->
    <TD width="4%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=lead -->
    <TD width="4%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=hang1 -->
</TR>

<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD colspan="2" nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD colspan="2" nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total operating revenues for 2005 were $7.21&#160;billion, as
    compared to $7.07&#160;billion in 2004, an increase of 2.0%.
    Passenger revenue in the early part of 2005 was negatively
    impacted by US&#160;Airways&#146; bankruptcy proceedings.
    Mainline passenger revenues declined $108&#160;million, or 2.2%,
    as compared to 2004 due to a 2.7% decrease in RPMs, which was
    partially offset by a 0.6% increase in yield. ASMs decreased in
    2005 by 3.2%, resulting in an increase in load factor from 75.1%
    to 75.5% and a PRASM increase of 1.2% from 9.33 cents to 9.44
    cents.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Express passenger revenues were $1.62&#160;billion in 2005, an
    increase of $242&#160;million or 17.6% from 2004.
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned subsidiaries and
    US&#160;Airways&#146; former MidAtlantic division, which began
    service in April 2004, increased RPMs by 66.4% as compared to
    2004, and RPMs flown by affiliate carriers increased 4.0%. The
    yield for US&#160;Airways Express operations decreased 9.4% as
    compared to 2004 due to longer stage length and the deployment
    of regional jets into mainline markets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Cargo revenues decreased $36&#160;million in 2005 primarily due
    to lower volume. Other revenues increased 7.0% in 2005 primarily
    due to revenue generated through airline partner travel after
    US&#160;Airways joined the Star Alliance in May 2004 and an
    increase in marketing revenue related to award miles sold to
    credit card and other partners.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    51
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="text-indent: -10pt; margin-left: 20pt">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">Depreciation and amortization

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total operating expenses for 2005 were $7.42&#160;billion, which
    was relatively flat when compared to 2004. Mainline operating
    expenses were $5.56&#160;billion for 2005, a decrease of
    $286&#160;million as compared to 2004. Mainline CASM decreased
    1.7% to 10.79 cents in 2005 from 10.98 cents in 2004. The 2005
    results include special items of $15&#160;million, which
    comprised 0.03 cents of mainline CASM for the period. The
    decrease in mainline CASM was due to cost reductions achieved as
    a result of the bankruptcy proceedings, primarily related to
    salaries and related costs, which more than offset the increase
    in aircraft fuel and related taxes as the average fuel per
    gallon increased 58% to $1.77 in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The table below sets forth the major components of mainline CASM
    for US&#160;Airways for the years ended December&#160;31, 2005
    and 2004:
</DIV>

<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Significant changes in the components of mainline CASM are
    explained as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft fuel and related tax expense per ASM increased 54.8%
    primarily due to a 58.0% increase in the average price per
    gallon of fuel from $1.12 in 2004 to $1.77 in 2005, partially
    offset by a 4.8% decrease in consumption.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    52
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Salaries and related costs per ASM decreased 33.5% primarily due
    to lower wage and benefits rates as a result of the cost-savings
    agreements achieved with each of the collective bargaining
    groups, including the termination of defined benefit pension
    plans and the curtailment of postretirement benefits, as well as
    lower headcount as compared to the same period in 2004.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Aircraft maintenance per ASM increased 15.8% reflecting the
    shift to outside vendors to perform scheduled maintenance,
    partially offsetting the decrease in salaries and related costs
    described above.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Selling expenses per ASM decreased 7.4% primarily due to
    reduction in travel agent commissions, the termination of
    certain marketing contracts and reductions in advertising
    programs as a result of the bankruptcy.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Depreciation and amortization per ASM decreased 9.8% as a result
    of fewer owned aircraft in the operating fleet and lower book
    values on the continuing fleet as a result of fresh-start
    reporting.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Other operating expenses per ASM increased 7.9% primarily as a
    result of increases associated with the redemption of Dividend
    Miles on partner airlines and future travel on US&#160;Airways
    as well as with outsourced aircraft cleaning services. These
    increases were partially offset by decreases in insurance
    expense, outsourced technology services and schedule-related
    costs including passenger food expenses.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Express expenses increased 18.5% to $1.86&#160;billion in 2005
    as compared to 2004, reflecting a 14.8% increase in purchased
    ASMs, increased flying by the former MidAtlantic division in
    2005 and higher fuel prices that were paid by US&#160;Airways
    for US&#160;Airways Express operations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Nonoperating
    Income (Expense):</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways had net nonoperating income of $371&#160;million
    in 2005 compared to nonoperating expense of $237&#160;million in
    2004. The change in nonoperating income (expense) is primarily a
    result of $636&#160;million of net reorganization items
    representing amounts incurred as a direct result of the
    Chapter&#160;11 proceedings. See the description below for
    additional information on the components of reorganization
    items. Interest income increased $14&#160;million in 2005 as
    compared to 2004 due to higher cash balances, principally in the
    fourth quarter of 2005, and higher average interest rates on
    cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments. Interest
    expense increased $51&#160;million as a result of increased
    interest expense on the loan formerly guaranteed by the ATSB,
    including penalty interest incurred as a result of the
    bankruptcy proceedings and interest associated with the purchase
    of new regional jets. The 2005 period included nonoperating
    expenses of $4&#160;million, which include foreign exchange
    losses and unfavorable
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">mark-to-market</FONT>
    adjustments on certain stock options held by US&#160;Airways.
    The 2004 period includes $13&#160;million related to a business
    interruption insurance recovery and a $2&#160;million gain on
    the sale of four aircraft.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    53
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Description
    of Reorganization Items</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Reorganization items, net represent amounts incurred as a direct
    result of US&#160;Airways&#146; Chapter&#160;11 filings and are
    presented separately in the statements of operations. Such items
    consist of the following (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TD>

<TD>&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="background: #CCEEFF">
<TD align="left" valign="bottom">
<DIV style="text-indent: -10pt; margin-left: 10pt">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">Curtailment of postretirement
    benefits(a)
    </FONT>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
    $
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="right" valign="bottom">
    1,420
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In January 2005, the Bankruptcy Court approved settlement
    agreements between US&#160;Airways and its unions and the
    court-appointed Section&#160;1114 Committee, representing
    retirees other than those represented by the IAM and TWU, to
    begin the significant curtailment of postretirement medical
    benefits. US&#160;Airways recognized a gain of $183&#160;million
    in connection with this curtailment in the first quarter of
    2005. Upon the emergence from bankruptcy and effectiveness of
    the plan of reorganization, an additional gain of
    $1.24&#160;billion was recognized when the liability associated
    with the postretirement medical benefits was reduced to fair
    market value. See also Note&#160;6 to US&#160;Airways&#146;
    financial statements included in Item&#160;8C of this report.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Also in January 2005, US&#160;Airways terminated three defined
    benefit plans related to the flight attendants, mechanics and
    certain other employees (see Note&#160;6 to
    US&#160;Airways&#146; financial statements included in
    Item&#160;8C of this report). The Pension Benefit Guaranty
    Corporation (&#147;PBGC&#148;) was appointed trustee of the
    plans upon termination. US&#160;Airways recognized a curtailment
    gain of $24&#160;million and a $91&#160;million minimum pension
    liability adjustment in connection with the terminations in the
    first quarter of 2005. Upon the effective date of the plan of
    reorganization and in connection with the settlement with the
    PBGC, the remaining liabilities associated with these plans were
    written off, net of settlement amounts.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Reflects the discharge of trade accounts payable and other
    liabilities upon emergence from bankruptcy. Most of these
    obligations were only entitled to receive such distributions of
    cash and common stock as provided for under the plan of
    reorganization in each of the bankruptcies. A portion of the
    liabilities subject to compromise in the bankruptcies were
    restructured and continued, as restructured, to be liabilities
    of the Successor Company.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    As a result of US&#160;Airways&#146; bankruptcy filing in
    September 2004, US&#160;Airways was not able to secure the
    financing necessary to take on-time delivery of three scheduled
    regional jet aircraft and therefore accrued penalties of
    $3&#160;million until delivery of these aircraft was made to a
    US&#160;Airways Express affiliate in August 2005. Offsetting
    these penalties is the reversal of $33&#160;million in penalties
    recorded by US&#160;Airways in the nine months ended
    December&#160;31, 2003 due to its intention not to take delivery
    of certain aircraft scheduled for future delivery. In connection
    with the Airbus Memorandum of Understanding (&#147;MOU&#148;),
    the accrual for these penalties was reversed. </TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    54
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    &#160;</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    As the result of US&#160;Airways&#146; bankruptcy filing in
    September 2004, it failed to meet the conditions precedent for
    continued financing of regional jets and was not able to take
    delivery of scheduled aircraft and therefore incurred penalties
    of $7&#160;million in the fourth quarter of 2004.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (e) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Damage and deficiency claims are largely a result of
    US&#160;Airways&#146; election to either restructure, abandon or
    reject aircraft debt and leases during the bankruptcy
    proceedings. As a result of the confirmation of the plan of
    reorganization and the effectiveness of the merger, these claims
    were withdrawn and the accruals reversed.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (f) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    As of September&#160;30, 2005, US&#160;Airways recorded
    $1.5&#160;billion of adjustments to reflect assets and
    liabilities at fair value, including an initial net write-down
    of goodwill of $1.82&#160;billion. Goodwill of $584&#160;million
    was recorded to reflect the excess of the estimated fair value
    of liabilities and equity over identifiable assets. Subsequent
    to September&#160;30, 2005, US&#160;Airways recorded an
    additional $148&#160;million of goodwill to reflect adjustments
    to the estimated fair values of certain assets and liabilities.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (g) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In connection with filing for bankruptcy on September&#160;12,
    2004, US&#160;Airways achieved cost-savings agreements with its
    principal collective bargaining groups. In connection with the
    new labor agreements, approximately 5,000 employees across
    several of US&#160;Airways&#146; labor groups were involuntarily
    terminated or participated in voluntary furlough and termination
    programs.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (h) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In connection with the Airbus MOU, US&#160;Airways was required
    to pay a restructuring fee of $39&#160;million, which was paid
    by means of offset against existing equipment deposits held by
    Airbus. US&#160;Airways also received credits from Airbus
    totaling $4&#160;million in 2005, primarily related to equipment
    deposits. See also Note&#160;3 to US&#160;Airways&#146;
    financial statements included in Item&#160;8C of this report.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (i) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The GE Merger MOU provided for the continued use of certain
    leased Airbus, Boeing and regional jet aircraft, the
    modification of monthly lease rates and the return of certain
    other leased Airbus and Boeing aircraft. The GE Merger MOU also
    provided for the sale-leaseback of assets securing various GE
    obligations. In connection with these transactions,
    US&#160;Airways recorded a net loss of $5&#160;million.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Liquidity
    and Capital Resources</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Sources
    and Uses of Cash</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s cash,
    cash equivalents, short-term investments and restricted cash
    were $3.0&#160;billion, of which $2.4&#160;billion was
    unrestricted. US&#160;Airways Group has the ability to move
    funds freely between operating subsidiaries to support
    operations. These transfers are recognized as intercompany
    transactions. We believe that cash flows from operating
    activities, combined with cash balances and financing
    commitments, will be adequate to fund operating and capital
    needs as well as to maintain compliance with our various debt
    arrangements through the end of 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Net cash provided by operating activities was $618&#160;million
    and $46&#160;million in 2006 and 2005, respectively. Cash flows
    for 2005 include the results of America West Holdings for the
    269&#160;days through September&#160;27, 2005, the effective
    date of the merger, and the consolidated results of
    US&#160;Airways Group for the 96&#160;days from
    September&#160;27, 2005 to December&#160;31, 2005. The
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">year-over-year</FONT>
    increase in cash flows from operations is primarily the result
    of the 2006&#160;net income of $304&#160;million compared to a
    net loss of $537&#160;million in 2005, which included the
    non-cash $202&#160;million cumulative effect of change in
    accounting principle in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Net cash used in investing activities in 2006 was
    $903&#160;million compared to net cash provided by investing
    activities of $399&#160;million in 2005. Principal investing
    activities in 2006 included purchases of property and equipment
    totaling $232&#160;million, including the purchase of three
    Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">757-200</FONT> and
    two Embraer 190 aircraft, net purchases of short-term
    investments of $798&#160;million and a decrease in restricted
    cash of $128&#160;million primarily due to a decrease in cash
    reserves required under an agreement for processing credit card
    transactions. The 2005 period included the merger transaction,
    which included $258&#160;million of net cash acquired. Other
    investing activities in 2005 included net purchases of
    short-term investments totaling $295&#160;million and purchases
    of property and equipment totaling $44&#160;million. In 2005 we
    also received proceeds of $592&#160;million from flight
    equipment asset sales; the sale and leaseback of aircraft
    including six Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300,</FONT> two
    Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">757-200,</FONT>
    nine Airbus A319 and
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    55
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    five Airbus A330 aircraft; and sales of other property and
    equipment. Restricted cash increased by $112&#160;million in
    2005 primarily due to an increase in reserves required under an
    agreement for processing credit card transactions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Net cash provided by financing activities was $276&#160;million
    and $531&#160;million in 2006 and 2005, respectively. Principal
    financing activities in 2006 includes proceeds from the issuance
    of new debt totaling $1.4&#160;billion, which included
    borrowings of $1.25&#160;billion under the new GE loan, a
    $64&#160;million draw on one of the Airbus loans and
    $92&#160;million of equipment notes issued to finance the
    acquisition of three Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">757-200</FONT> and
    two Embraer 190 aircraft. Debt repayments totaled
    $1.2&#160;billion and using the proceeds from the new GE loan,
    included the repayment in full of the balances outstanding on
    our ATSB loans of $801&#160;million, Airbus loans of
    $161&#160;million, and two GECC term loans of $110&#160;million.
    We also made a $17&#160;million payment related to the partial
    conversion of the 7%&#160;Senior Convertible Notes. Principal
    financing activities in 2005 included the issuance of
    US&#160;Airways Group common stock for $732&#160;million, and
    proceeds from the issuance of debt totaling $655&#160;million,
    which included a $325&#160;million loan from an affinity credit
    card partner, $186&#160;million from the Airbus loans and
    $144&#160;million from the issuance of the 7%&#160;Senior
    Convertible Notes. The debt repayments totaled $741&#160;million
    in 2005 and included a $433&#160;million reduction in
    aircraft-related debt as a result of flight equipment asset
    sales and sale and leaseback transactions, the GE debt repayment
    of $125&#160;million, approximately $125&#160;million in ATSB
    loan repayments, and the redemption of AWA&#146;s
    10.75%&#160;senior unsecured notes totaling $40&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">AWA</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At December&#160;31, 2006, AWA&#146;s total cash, cash
    equivalents, short-term investments and restricted cash balance
    was $1.3&#160;billion, of which $1.1&#160;billion was
    unrestricted. Net cash provided by operating activities in 2006
    was $293&#160;million compared to net cash used in operating
    activities of $24&#160;million in 2005. The
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">year-over-year</FONT>
    increase in cash flows from operations of $317&#160;million is
    primarily the result of the decrease in net loss from
    $397&#160;million in 2005, which included the non-cash
    cumulative effect of change in accounting principle of
    $202&#160;million, to $37&#160;million in 2006. In addition, AWA
    air traffic liability (ticket sales for transportation that has
    not yet been provided) increased $141&#160;million in 2006 as
    compared to an increase of $23&#160;million in 2005. The
    significant increase in air traffic liability during 2006 is due
    principally to the integration of the AWA and US&#160;Airways
    web sites, as a result of which AWA incurs additional air
    traffic liability by selling tickets for travel on
    US&#160;Airways.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Net cash used in investing activities was $249&#160;million and
    $283&#160;million in 2006 and 2005, respectively. Principal
    investing activities during 2006 included net purchases of
    short-term investments totaling $186&#160;million and purchases
    of property and equipment totaling $76&#160;million, which
    includes costs to convert nine Boeing 757 aircraft to allow
    long-range over-water service and information technology
    infrastructure costs such as upgraded computer equipment and
    software. Restricted cash decreased by $18&#160;million during
    2006 primarily due to a decrease in reserves required under
    agreements for processing AWA&#146;s credit card transactions.
    The 2005 period included net purchases of short-term investments
    totaling $163&#160;million, purchases of property and equipment
    totaling $37&#160;million, $74&#160;million of net proceeds from
    the sale and leaseback of aircraft including six
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Boeing&#160;737-300</FONT>
    and two Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">757-200</FONT>
    aircraft; and sales of other property and equipment. Restricted
    cash increased by $157&#160;million during 2005 due to an
    increase in cash reserves required under an agreement for
    processing credit card transactions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2006, net cash used in financing activities was
    $56&#160;million, consisting principally of a decrease in the
    payable to affiliates (primarily US&#160;Airways) of
    $52&#160;million and $4&#160;million of debt repayments. In
    2005, net cash provided by financing activities was
    $811&#160;million, consisting principally of an increase in
    payable to related parties of $998&#160;million. The increase in
    payable to related parties reflects proceeds received in 2005 on
    behalf of US&#160;Airways Group from the merger-related
    financing transactions including the initial equity investments,
    the public stock offering, the exercise of options by equity
    investors, the issuance of 7%&#160;Senior Convertible Notes and
    the Airbus loans, net of cash retained by US&#160;Airways Group.
    Other 2005 financing activities included debt repayments of
    $183&#160;million, including principal repayments of
    $94&#160;million for the government guaranteed loan, the
    redemption of 10.75%&#160;senior unsecured notes totaling
    $40&#160;million and the retirement of $39&#160;million of
    equipment notes payable with the proceeds from the aircraft sale
    and leaseback transaction discussed above.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    56
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As discussed in &#147;Results of Operations,&#148; the financial
    statements of US&#160;Airways prior to September&#160;30, 2005
    are not comparable with the financial statements for the three
    months ended December&#160;31, 2005. However for purposes of
    discussion of US&#160;Airways&#146; sources and uses of cash,
    2006 has been compared to the combined cash flows of the
    Successor Company and Predecessor Company for 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways&#146; cash, cash
    equivalents, short-term investments and restricted cash were
    $1.6&#160;billion, of which $1.2&#160;billion was unrestricted.
    Net cash provided by operating activities in 2006 was
    $365&#160;million compared to net cash used in operating
    activities of $537&#160;million in 2005. The year over year
    increase in cash flows from operating activities of
    $902&#160;million is driven by the $345&#160;million in net
    income in 2006 compared to the $160&#160;million net income in
    2005, which includes non-cash adjustments of $697&#160;million
    from the application of fresh-start accounting in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Net cash used in investing activities was $644&#160;million in
    2006 compared to net cash provided by of $442&#160;million in
    2005. Investing activities in 2006 included purchases of
    property and equipment of $146&#160;million, including the
    purchase of three Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">757-200</FONT> and
    two Embraer 190 aircraft, net purchases of short-term
    investments of $612&#160;million, and a decrease in restricted
    cash of $109&#160;million primarily due to a decrease in
    reserves required under agreements for processing
    US&#160;Airways&#146; credit card transactions. The 2005 period
    included purchases of property and equipment totaling
    $141&#160;million, including the acquisition of three CRJ-700
    aircraft, proceeds of $750&#160;million from the sale-leaseback
    of 44 aircraft and other asset sale transactions, net purchases
    of short-term investments of $132&#160;million and an increase
    in restricted cash of $35&#160;million, primarily consisting of
    reserves required under agreements for processing credit card
    transactions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Net cash provided by financing activities in 2006 was
    $284&#160;million compared to net cash used in financing
    activities of $177&#160;million in 2005. Principal financing
    activities in 2006 included a net increase in payables to
    related parties of $288&#160;million, the issuance of
    $92&#160;million of debt to finance the acquisition of three
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Boeing&#160;757-200</FONT>
    and two Embraer 190 aircraft, and total debt repayments of
    $96&#160;million. The 2005 period included proceeds from the
    issuance of debt of $265&#160;million. The debt issuance
    proceeds included $125&#160;million of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">debtor-in-possession</FONT>
    financing that converted into shares of common stock of
    US&#160;Airways Group upon emergence from bankruptcy. Debt
    repayments during 2005 totaled $649&#160;million and included a
    $394&#160;million reduction in aircraft-related debt as a result
    of the flight equipment asset sale-leaseback transactions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Commitments</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, we had $3&#160;billion of
    long-term debt and capital leases (including current maturities
    and net of discount on debt), which consisted primarily of the
    items discussed below.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Refinancing
    Transactions</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On March&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group entered into a
    loan agreement with GECC and a syndicate of lenders pursuant to
    which we borrowed an aggregate principal amount of
    $1.1&#160;billion. On April&#160;7, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group
    entered into an amended and restated loan agreement, which
    increased the principal amount of the loan to
    $1.25&#160;billion. US&#160;Airways, America West Holdings, AWA,
    Piedmont, PSA and MSC are all guarantors of the GE&#160;loan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The GE loan bears interest at an index rate plus an applicable
    index margin or, at our option, LIBOR plus an applicable LIBOR
    margin for interest periods of one, two, three or six months.
    The applicable index margin, subject to adjustment, is 1.50%,
    2.00%, 2.25%, or 2.50% if the adjusted loan balance is
    respectively less than $600&#160;million, between
    $600&#160;million and $750&#160;million, between
    $750&#160;million and $900&#160;million, or between
    $900&#160;million and $1.25&#160;billion. The applicable LIBOR
    margin, subject to adjustment, is 2.50%, 3.00%, 3.25%, or 3.50%
    if the adjusted loan balance is respectively less than
    $600&#160;million, between $600&#160;million and
    $750&#160;million, between $750&#160;million and
    $900&#160;million, or between $900&#160;million and
    $1.25&#160;billion. In addition, interest on the GE loan may be
    adjusted based on the credit rating for the GE loan as follows:
    (i)&#160;subject to clause&#160;(ii) below, if the credit rating
    for the GE loan is B1 or better from Moody&#146;s and B+ or
    better from S&#38;P as of the last day of the most recently
    ended fiscal quarter, then (A)&#160;the applicable LIBOR margin
    will be the lower of 3.25% and the rate otherwise applicable
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    57
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    based upon the adjusted GE loan balance and (B)&#160;the
    applicable index margin will be the lower of 2.25% and the rate
    otherwise applicable based upon the adjusted GE loan balance,
    and (ii)&#160;if the credit rating for the loan is Ba3 or better
    from Moody&#146;s and BB- or better from S&#38;P as of the last
    day of the most recently ended fiscal quarter, then the
    applicable LIBOR margin will be 2.50% and the applicable index
    margin will be 1.50%. The GE loan matures on March&#160;31,
    2011, and no principal payments are scheduled until maturity.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    consolidated unrestricted cash and cash equivalents of not less
    than $750&#160;million, subject to partial reductions upon
    specified reductions in the outstanding principal amount of the
    GE loan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

    On March&#160;31, 2006, proceeds of the GE loan were used, in
    part, to repay in full the following indebtedness:
</DIV>

</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The amended and restated US&#160;Airways and AWA loans entered
    into on September&#160;27, 2005 that had previously been
    guaranteed by the ATSB. On October&#160;19, 2005,
    $777&#160;million of the loans, of which $752&#160;million had
    been guaranteed by the ATSB, was sold by the lenders by order of
    the ATSB to 13 fixed income investors, removing the ATSB
    guarantee. At the time of repayment of these loans on
    March&#160;31, 2006, the total outstanding balance of the loans
    was $801&#160;million, of which $551&#160;million was
    outstanding under the US&#160;Airways loan and $250&#160;million
    was outstanding under the AWA loan.

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The $161&#160;million loan entered into as of September&#160;27,
    2005 between US&#160;Airways and AWA and Airbus Financial
    Services, for which US&#160;Airways Group was the guarantor. At
    the time of repayment on March&#160;31, 2006, the outstanding
    balance of the loan was $161&#160;million. US&#160;Airways and
    AWA also had an $89&#160;million loan from Airbus Financial
    Services entered into as of September&#160;27, 2005. In
    accordance with the terms of the loan agreements, the
    outstanding principal amount of the $89&#160;million loan was to
    be forgiven in writing on the earlier of December&#160;31, 2010
    or the date that the outstanding principal amount of, accrued
    interest on, and all other amounts due under the Airbus
    $161&#160;million loan were paid in full, provided that we
    complied with the delivery schedule for certain Airbus aircraft.
    As a result of the prepayment of the $161&#160;million loan on
    March&#160;31, 2006, the $89&#160;million loan agreement was
    terminated and the outstanding balance of $89&#160;million was
    forgiven.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

    Parts Facility and the Engines Facility were $76&#160;million
    and $34&#160;million, respectively.
</TD>
