<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Conversion
    of 7.5%&#160;Convertible Senior Notes due 2009</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with the closing of AWA&#146;s original ATSB loan
    and the related transactions in January 2002, America West
    Holdings issued $105&#160;million of 7.5% Convertible Senior
    Notes due 2009. Beginning January&#160;18, 2005, these notes
    became convertible into shares of common stock, at the option of
    the holders, at an initial conversion price of $29.09&#160;per
    share or a conversion ratio of approximately 34.376&#160;shares
    per $1,000 principal amount of such notes, subject to standard
    anti-dilution adjustments. Interest on the 7.5%&#160;convertible
    senior notes was payable semiannually in arrears on June&#160;1
    and December&#160;1 of each year. At America West Holdings&#146;
    option, the first six interest payments were payable in the form
    of a deemed loan added to the principal amount of these notes.
    The 7.5%&#160;convertible senior notes were scheduled to mature
    on January&#160;18, 2009 unless earlier converted or redeemed.
    The payment of principal, premium and interest on the
    7.5%&#160;Convertible Senior Notes was fully and unconditionally
    guaranteed by AWA and US&#160;Airways Group.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On March&#160;24, 2006, America West Holdings gave notice to the
    holders of the 7.5%&#160;Convertible Senior Notes that it was
    redeeming the notes in full, at a redemption price of 102.50% of
    the principal amount of the notes, as required under the terms
    of the indenture, plus accrued and unpaid interest up to, but
    not including, the date of redemption. The redemption price,
    plus the relevant interest, was $1,052.50&#160;per $1,000
    principal amount of the notes, and the redemption date was
    April&#160;13, 2006. Holders had the right, at any time at or
    prior to the close of business on April&#160;11, 2006, to
    convert the notes into shares of the common stock of
    US&#160;Airways Group at a price of $29.09&#160;per share, or
    34.376&#160;shares per $1,000 principal amount. Holders who
    converted also received interest up to the date of conversion. A
    total of $112&#160;million in principal amount of the notes was
    converted into shares of common stock prior to the redemption
    date, resulting in the issuance of 3,860,358&#160;shares of
    common stock. As of December&#160;31, 2006 there were no
    7.5%&#160;Convertible Senior Notes outstanding.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">7%&#160;Senior
    Convertible Notes</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group received net proceeds of $139&#160;million
    related to the 7% Senior Convertible Notes due 2020 that were
    issued on September&#160;30, 2005. The 7%&#160;notes are
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s senior unsecured obligations and
    rank equally in right of payment to its other senior unsecured
    and unsubordinated indebtedness, and are effectively
    subordinated to its secured indebtedness to the extent of the
    value of assets securing such indebtedness. The 7%&#160;notes
    are fully and unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and severally
    and on a senior unsecured basis, by US&#160;Airways and AWA. The
    US&#160;Airways and AWA guarantees are the guarantors&#146;
    unsecured obligations, rank equally in right of payment to the
    other senior unsecured and unsubordinated indebtedness of the
    guarantors and are effectively subordinated to the
    guarantors&#146; secured indebtedness to the extent of the value
    of assets securing such indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The 7%&#160;notes bear interest at the rate of 7%&#160;per year
    payable in cash semiannually in arrears on March&#160;30 and
    September&#160;30 of each year, beginning March&#160;30, 2006.
    The 7%&#160;notes mature on September&#160;30, 2020. Holders may
    convert, at any time on or prior to maturity or redemption, any
    outstanding notes (or portions thereof) into shares of
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s common stock, initially at a
    conversion rate of 41.4508&#160;shares of US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s common stock per $1,000 principal amount of
    7%&#160;notes (equivalent to an initial conversion price of
    approximately $24.12&#160;per share of US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s common stock). If a holder elects to convert its
    7%&#160;notes in connection with certain specified fundamental
    changes that occur prior to October&#160;5, 2015, the holder
    will be entitled to receive additional shares of US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s common stock as a make whole premium upon
    conversion. In lieu of delivery of shares of US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s common stock upon conversion of all or any portion
    of the 7%&#160;notes, US&#160;Airways Group may elect to pay
    holders surrendering 7%&#160;notes for conversion cash or a
    combination of shares and cash.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Holders of the 7%&#160;notes may require US&#160;Airways Group
    to purchase for cash or shares or a combination thereof, at
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s election, all or a portion of their
    notes on September&#160;30, 2010 and September&#160;30, 2015 at
    a purchase price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the
    notes to be repurchased plus accrued and unpaid interest, if
    any, to the purchase date. In addition, if US&#160;Airways Group
    experiences a fundamental change (as defined in the indenture
    governing the notes), holders may require US&#160;Airways Group
    to purchase for cash, shares or a combination thereof, at its
    election, all or a portion of their notes, subject to specified
    exceptions, at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount of
    the notes plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the
    purchase date.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    59
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Prior to October&#160;5, 2010, the notes will not be redeemable
    at US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s option. US&#160;Airways Group
    may redeem all or a portion of the notes at any time on or after
    October&#160;5, 2010, at a price equal to 100% of the principal
    amount of the notes plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to
    the redemption date if the closing price of US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s common stock has exceeded 115% of the conversion
    price for at least 20 trading days in the 30&#160;consecutive
    trading day period ending on the trading day before the date on
    which US&#160;Airways Group mails the redemption notice.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In July 2006, approximately $21&#160;million of the
    $144&#160;million outstanding principal amount of the
    7%&#160;notes were converted into 883,523&#160;shares of common
    stock. In connection with the conversion, we paid a premium of
    $5&#160;million to the holders of the converted notes, which was
    recorded in other non-operating expenses. In November 2006,
    approximately $49&#160;million of the remaining
    $123&#160;million outstanding principal amount of the notes were
    converted into 2,026,113&#160;shares of common stock. In
    connection with the conversion, we paid a premium of
    $12&#160;million to the holders of the converted notes, which
    was recorded in other non-operating expenses.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">General
    Electric</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Of the $139&#160;million net proceeds from the 7%&#160;notes,
    $125&#160;million was paid in September 2005 to General Electric
    (&#147;GE&#148;). Under certain agreements among GE and
    US&#160;Airways Group, GE agreed, in consideration for the early
    return of 51 aircraft and six engines, the assumption of certain
    modified leases and the payment of $125&#160;million in cash by
    September&#160;30, 2005, to: (1)&#160;retire an existing bridge
    loan facility, (2)&#160;complete a purchase by GE of
    21&#160;aircraft and 28 engines with a simultaneous lease back
    of the equipment to US&#160;Airways at market rates,
    (3)&#160;allow US&#160;Airways Group to draw additional amounts
    under an existing credit facility, which resulted in a total
    principal outstanding balance under that facility of
    approximately $28&#160;million, (4)&#160;restructure lease
    obligations of US&#160;Airways relating to 59 aircraft at market
    rates, (5)&#160;provide financing for current and additional
    aircraft, (6)&#160;grant concessions regarding return condition
    obligations with respect to the return of aircraft and engines,
    (7)&#160;waive penalties for the removal of engines currently
    under GE engine maintenance agreements, and (8)&#160;reduce
    outstanding balances for deferred charges under its rate per
    hour engine agreements, which resulted in a remaining balance
    due of $54&#160;million. During 2006, the outstanding balance
    for deferred charges was further reduced by $9&#160;million
    resulting from credits received on engines removed from the
    agreements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Restructuring
    of Affinity Credit Card Partner Agreement</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with the merger, AWA, pre-merger US&#160;Airways
    Group and Juniper Bank, a subsidiary of Barclays PLC, entered
    into an amended credit card agreement on August&#160;8, 2005.
    Pursuant to the amended credit card agreement, Juniper agreed to
    offer and market an airline mileage award credit card program to
    the general public to participate in US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s Dividend Miles program through the use of a
    co-branded credit card. The amended credit card agreement went
    into effect on January&#160;1, 2006. Prior to that date, the AWA
    credit card program was administered by Bank of America, N.A.
    (USA), under an agreement that terminated on December&#160;31,
    2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s credit card program was also
    administered by Bank of America, N.A. (USA) prior to the merger.
    On December&#160;28, 2005, US&#160;Airways issued a notice of
    termination under its agreement with Bank of America, and that
    notice will become effective on December&#160;28, 2007. Pending
    termination of the Bank of America agreement, there is a dual
    branding period during which both Juniper and Bank of America
    are running separate credit card programs for US&#160;Airways
    Group. The amended credit card agreement is the subject of
    pending litigation filed by Bank of America against
    US&#160;Airways Group, US&#160;Airways and AWA. (See
    Part&#160;I, Item&#160;3, &#147;Legal Proceedings.&#148;)
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The amended credit card agreement with Juniper took effect at
    the effective time of the merger. The credit card services
    provided by Juniper under the amended credit card agreement
    commenced in early January 2006, and will continue until the
    expiration date, which is the later of December&#160;31, 2012 or
    seven years from the date on which Juniper commences marketing
    to the general public.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Under the amended credit card agreement, Juniper pays
    US&#160;Airways Group fees for each mile awarded to each credit
    card account administered by Juniper, subject to certain
    exceptions. Juniper also agreed to pay a one-time bonus payment
    of $130&#160;million following the effectiveness of the merger
    and an annual bonus of $5&#160;million to
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    60
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group, subject to certain exceptions, for each
    year after Juniper becomes the exclusive issuer of the
    co-branded credit card. The one-time bonus was paid to
    US&#160;Airways Group on October&#160;3, 2005. If Juniper is not
    granted exclusivity to offer a co-branded credit card after the
    dual branding period with Bank of America, US&#160;Airways Group
    must repay this bonus payment and repurchase unused pre-paid
    miles with interest, plus repay a $20&#160;million bonus payment
    AWA received under the original credit card agreement with
    Juniper and pay $50&#160;million in liquidated damages. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006 we have not recorded income from the
    bonus payments and have a deferred liability of
    $150&#160;million recorded in other long-term liabilities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On October&#160;3, 2005, Juniper pre-paid for miles from
    US&#160;Airways Group totaling $325&#160;million, subject to the
    same conditions as apply to the $130&#160;million bonus payment
    described above. To the extent that these miles are not used by
    Juniper as allowed under the co-branded credit card program in
    certain circumstances, US&#160;Airways Group will repurchase
    these miles in 12 equal quarterly installments beginning on the
    fifth year prior to the expiration date of the co-branded credit
    card agreement with Juniper, until paid in full. US&#160;Airways
    Group makes monthly interest payments at LIBOR plus 4.75% to
    Juniper, beginning on November&#160;1, 2005, based on the amount
    of pre-purchased miles that have not been used by Juniper in
    connection with the co-branded credit card program and have not
    been repurchased by US&#160;Airways Group. US&#160;Airways Group
    will be required to repurchase pre-purchased miles under certain
    reductions in the collateral held under the credit card
    processing agreement with JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. Accordingly,
    the prepayment has been recorded as additional indebtedness in
    the consolidated financial statements of AWA and US&#160;Airways
    Group.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Juniper requires US&#160;Airways Group to maintain an average
    quarterly balance of cash, cash equivalents and short-term
    investments of at least $1&#160;billion for the entirety of the
    agreement. Further, the agreement requires US&#160;Airways Group
    to maintain certain financial ratios beginning January&#160;1,
    2006. As of December&#160;31, 2006, we were in compliance with
    these ratios. Juniper may, at its option, terminate the amended
    credit card agreement, make payments to US&#160;Airways Group
    under the amended credit card agreement in the form of
    pre-purchased miles rather than cash, or require US&#160;Airways
    Group to repurchase the pre-purchased miles before the fifth
    year prior to the expiration date in the event that
    US&#160;Airways Group breaches its obligations under the amended
    credit card agreement, or upon the occurrence of certain events.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Restructuring
    of Credit Card Processing Agreement</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with the merger, on August&#160;8, 2005, AWA,
    JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A.,
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">successor-in-interest</FONT>
    to JPMorgan Chase Bank, and Chase Merchant Services, L.L.C.
    (collectively, &#147;Chase&#148;), entered into the First
    Amendment to the Merchant Services Bankcard Agreement. Pursuant
    to this amended card processing agreement, Chase performs
    authorization, processing and settlement services for
    U.S.&#160;Dollars (&#147;USD&#148;) sales on Visa and MasterCard
    for AWA and US&#160;Airways following the merger. The original
    card processing agreement is guaranteed by America West
    Holdings, and US&#160;Airways Group executed a guarantee of the
    amended card processing agreement on the effective date of the
    merger.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Prior to the merger, US&#160;Airways&#146; USD Visa and
    MasterCard credit card processing was administered by Bank of
    America, and those processing services were transferred to Chase
    in July 2006. US&#160;Airways is now a party to the amended card
    processing agreement, effective as of the transfer of the
    services to Chase.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The amended card processing agreement took effect at the
    effective time of the merger and continues until the expiration
    of the initial term, which is three years from the effective
    date. Upon expiration of the initial term, the amended card
    processing agreement will automatically renew for successive
    one-year periods pursuant to the terms of the agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Under the amended card processing agreement, AWA and
    US&#160;Airways will pay to Chase fees in connection with card
    processing services such as sales authorization, settlement
    services and customer service. AWA and US&#160;Airways will also
    be required to maintain a reserve account to secure Chase&#146;s
    exposure to outstanding air traffic liability. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, $390&#160;million in cash collateral is
    classified as restricted cash on US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s
    consolidated balance sheet to secure credit card sales under its
    various processing agreements.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    61
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Asset
    Based Financings</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On March&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways entered into a loan
    agreement with Landesbank Baden-W&#252;rttemberg
    (&#147;LBBW&#148;) as Loan Participant and Arranger, Wells Fargo
    Bank Northwest, National Association, as Security Trustee, and
    US&#160;Airways Group, as guarantor, in the amount of
    $48&#160;million. The LBBW loan bears interest at a rate of
    LIBOR plus a margin, subject to adjustment, with
    $46.5&#160;million of the loan amortizing over ten years and
    $1.5&#160;million of the loan amortizing over three quarterly
    installments on the first three interest payment dates. The LBBW
    loan is secured by three Boeing 757 aircraft that we purchased
    in February 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On October&#160;18, 2006, US&#160;Airways entered into a
    facility agreement with The Royal Bank of Scotland, PLC
    (&#147;RBS&#148;) as Lender and Arranger, Wells Fargo Bank
    Northwest, National Association, as Indenture Trustee, and AWA,
    as guarantor, in the total aggregate amount of $242&#160;million
    to finance the acquisition of eleven Embraer 190 aircraft. The
    RBS loan bears interest at a rate of LIBOR plus a margin, and is
    amortized over twelve years with a balloon payment at maturity.
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, $44&#160;million of the RBS loan
    is outstanding and secured by two Embraer 190 aircraft that we
    purchased in December 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Embraer
    Purchase Commitments</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On June&#160;13, 2006, we and Embraer executed an Amended and
    Restated Purchase Agreement and an Amended and Restated Letter
    Agreement. In accordance with the terms of these agreements, we
    placed an initial firm order for 25 Embraer 190 aircraft and an
    additional firm order for 32 Embraer 190 aircraft. The progress
    and deposit payments totaling approximately $18&#160;million
    previously paid by us to Embraer in accordance with the terms of
    the Purchase Agreement dated as of May&#160;9, 2003, will be
    applied to these orders in accordance with the terms of the
    amended and restated agreements. In addition, we have the option
    to purchase up to 50 additional Embraer 190 aircraft and to
    convert certain of the Embraer 190 aircraft to Embraer 170,
    Embraer 175 or Embraer 195 aircraft, subject to availability and
    upon agreed notice. Embraer has agreed to provide financing for
    certain of the aircraft. On July&#160;21, 2006, we assigned 30
    of the purchase options to Republic Airline Inc. On
    January&#160;12, 2007, we assigned eight additional purchase
    options to Republic Airline. We purchased and took delivery of
    two Embraer 190 aircraft in December 2006. We expect to take
    delivery of nine Embraer 190 aircraft in 2007 and fourteen 190
    aircraft in 2008.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Bombardier
    Purchase Commitments</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On December&#160;14, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court approved a
    Global Settlement Letter between US&#160;Airways Group and
    Bombardier Inc. which had been executed by the parties on
    November&#160;10, 2006. The Global Settlement Letter amends the
    master purchase agreement dated as of May&#160;9, 2003, as
    amended, between US&#160;Airways Group and Bombardier. The
    Bankruptcy Court authorized the assumption of the master
    purchase agreement, as modified and amended by the Global
    Settlement Letter. The parties agreed to modify and amend the
    master purchase agreement to terminate all obligations of
    US&#160;Airways Group to purchase and take delivery of 42 firm
    aircraft remaining undelivered under the agreement, as well as
    the rights of US&#160;Airways Group to purchase and take
    delivery of 90 additional aircraft and options to take 94
    aircraft in the future. All obligations of Bombardier to
    manufacture and deliver these aircraft were also terminated. The
    master purchase agreement was amended to provide US&#160;Airways
    Group with the right to purchase Bombardier CRJ 200/700/900
    series aircraft from time to time during a period of five years.
    The Global Settlement Letter further provides that all
    pre-delivery payments held by Bombardier be returned to
    US&#160;Airways Group. Under the Global Settlement Letter, all
    claims of Bombardier asserted against US&#160;Airways Group and
    its subsidiaries in the Chapter&#160;11 cases were resolved and
    Bombardier was granted a total aggregate allowed general
    unsecured claim in the amount of $148&#160;million. As a result
    of the settlement, we recorded an $11&#160;million gain
    reflected in special items, net on the 2006&#160;statements of
    operations. The effects of distributions for general unsecured
    claims were reflected in US&#160;Airways&#146; financial
    statements upon emergence and will not have any further impact
    on the results of operations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Airbus
    Purchase Commitments</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In August 2006, AWA amended its
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A320/A319</FONT>
    Purchase Agreement with Airbus to add seven new
    Airbus&#160;A321s to an existing order for thirty A320 family
    aircraft. The amendment also converted one A320&#160;aircraft
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    62
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    and seven A319 aircraft to an order of eight A321 aircraft.
    Deliveries of the 15 new A321 aircraft will begin in 2008 and
    run through 2010. The new A321s will be configured to
    accommodate up to 187 passengers in two classes of service and
    will be used for replacement purposes or modest expansion should
    market conditions warrant.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    To modernize our international product and improve the
    efficiency of our international network, we were scheduled to
    begin accepting deliveries of A350 aircraft in 2011 pursuant to
    an Airbus A350 Purchase Agreement that US&#160;Airways Group,
    US&#160;Airways and AWA entered into in September 2005 with
    Airbus. US&#160;Airways Group has been notified that the A350
    will be undergoing significant design changes and will be
    delivered several years beyond the originally scheduled delivery
    dates. We are currently evaluating the revised technical and
    commercial aspects of the A350 program.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In September 2005, we amended our
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A330/340</FONT>
    Purchase Agreement dated as of November&#160;24, 1998 between
    US&#160;Airways Group and Airbus to reschedule our order for ten
    A330-200 aircraft for delivery during the period 2009 and 2010.
    We have the right to cancel these A330 orders in the event that
    US&#160;Airways makes certain predelivery payments under the
    A350 Purchase Agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA has an agreement with International Aero Engines which
    provides for the purchase by AWA of five new V2500-A5 spare
    engines scheduled for delivery through 2010 for use on certain
    of the Airbus A320 fleet.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Covenants
    and Credit Rating</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition to the minimum cash balance requirements, our
    long-term debt agreements contain various negative covenants
    that restrict or limit our actions, including our ability to pay
    dividends or make other restricted payments. Certain long-term
    debt agreements also contain cross-default provisions, which may
    be triggered by defaults by US&#160;Airways Group under other
    agreements relating to indebtedness. See &#147;Risk Factors
    Relating to the Company and Industry Related Risks&#160;&#151;
    Our high level of fixed obligations limits our ability to fund
    general corporate requirements and obtain additional financing,
    limits our flexibility in responding to competitive developments
    and increases our vulnerability to adverse economic and industry
    conditions&#148; in Item&#160;1A, &#147;Risk Factors&#148;. As
    of December&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group and its
    subsidiaries were in compliance with the covenants in their
    long-term debt agreements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s credit ratings, like those of most
    airlines, are relatively low, with S&#38;P&#146;s assessment of
    the issuer credit rating for US&#160;Airways Group and
    US&#160;Airways at B&#8722; and senior unsecured debt rating at
    CCC for US&#160;Airways Group. Fitch&#146;s ratings for
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s long-term debt and senior unsecured
    debt are CCC and CC, respectively. Moody&#146;s has rated
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s long-term corporate family rating
    at B3. AWA is no longer rated separately. A decrease in our
    credit ratings could cause our borrowing costs to increase,
    which would increase our interest expense and could affect our
    net income, and our credit ratings could adversely affect our
    ability to obtain additional financing. If our financial
    performance or industry conditions do not improve, we may face
    future downgrades, which could further negatively impact our
    borrowing costs and the prices of our equity or debt securities.
    In addition, any downgrade of our credit ratings may indicate a
    decline in our business and in our ability to satisfy our
    obligations under our indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s Emergence from Bankruptcy</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In accordance with the Bankruptcy Code, the plan of
    reorganization classified claims into classes according to their
    relative priority and other criteria and provided for the
    treatment for each class of claims. Pursuant to the bankruptcy
    process, the Reorganized Debtors&#146; claims agent received
    timely-filed proofs of claims totaling approximately
    $26.4&#160;billion in the aggregate, exclusive of approximately
    $13.6&#160;billion in claims by governmental entities. The
    Reorganized Debtors continue to be responsible for administering
    and resolving claims related to the bankruptcy process. The
    administrative claims objection deadline passed on
    September&#160;15, 2006. As of December&#160;31, 2006, there
    were approximately $472&#160;million of unresolved claims. The
    ultimate resolution of certain of the claims asserted against
    the Reorganized Debtors in the Chapter&#160;11 cases will be
    subject to negotiations, elections and Bankruptcy Court
    procedures. The recovery to individual creditors ultimately
    distributed to any particular general unsecured creditor under
    the plan of reorganization will depend on a number of variables,
    including the agreed value of any general unsecured claims filed
    by that creditor, the aggregate value of all resolved general
    unsecured claims and the value of shares of the new common stock
    of US&#160;Airways Group in the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    63
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    marketplace at the time of distribution. The effects of these
    distributions were reflected in US&#160;Airways&#146; financial
    statements upon emergence and will not have any further impact
    on the results of operations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    While a significant amount of the Reorganized Debtors&#146;
    liabilities were extinguished as a result of the discharge
    granted upon confirmation of the plan of reorganization, not all
    of the Reorganized Debtors&#146; liabilities were subject to
    discharge. The types of obligations that the Reorganized Debtors
    remain responsible for include those relating to their secured
    financings, aircraft financings, certain environmental
    liabilities, the continuing obligations arising under contracts
    and leases assumed by the Reorganized Debtors and certain
    grievances with our labor unions, as well as allowed
    administrative claims. Allowed administrative claims consist
    primarily of the costs and expenses of administration of the
    Chapter&#160;11 cases, including the costs of operating the
    Reorganized Debtors&#146; businesses since filing for
    bankruptcy. The Reorganized Debtors received a large number of
    timely filed administrative claims, as well as additional claims
    that were late filed without permission of the Bankruptcy Court.
    Included in these claims, however, are claims for amounts
    arising in the ordinary course that have either already been
    paid, or that are included in the Reorganized Debtors&#146;
    business plan and are expected to be paid in the ordinary
    course. Also included are claims that are duplicative, claims
    for which the Reorganized Debtors believe there is no legal
    merit for a claim of any status, and claims that the Reorganized
    Debtors believe may be valid as unsecured claims but are not
    entitled to administrative claims status. Accordingly, the
    Reorganized Debtors believe that only a very small portion of
    the claims filed in response to the bar dates for non-ordinary
    course administrative expense claims will actually be allowed in
    amounts exceeding the ordinary course expenditures already
    contained in the Reorganized Debtors&#146; business plan.
    However, there can be no assurances that the aggregate amount of
    the claims ultimately allowed will not be material. To the
    extent any of these claims are allowed, they will generally be
    satisfied in full.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Off-Balance
    Sheet Arrangements</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    An off-balance sheet arrangement is any transaction, agreement
    or other contractual arrangement involving an unconsolidated
    entity under which a company has (1)&#160;made guarantees,
    (2)&#160;a retained or a contingent interest in transferred
    assets, (3)&#160;an obligation under derivative instruments
    classified as equity or (4)&#160;any obligation arising out of a
    material variable interest in an unconsolidated entity that
    provides financing, liquidity, market risk or credit risk
    support to the company, or that engages in leasing, hedging or
    research and development arrangements with the company.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group, AWA and US&#160;Airways have no
    off-balance sheet arrangements of the types described in the
    first three categories above that they believe may have a
    material current or future effect on financial condition,
    liquidity or results of operations. Certain guarantees that
    US&#160;Airways Group, AWA, and US&#160;Airways do not expect to
    have a material current or future effect on financial condition,
    liquidity or results of operations are disclosed in
    Note&#160;10(e) to the consolidated financial statements of
    US&#160;Airways Group included in Item&#160;8A of this report,
    Note&#160;7(e) to the consolidated financial statements of AWA
    included in Item&#160;8B of this report, and Note&#160;8(e) to
    the financial statements of US&#160;Airways included in
    Item&#160;8C of this report.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">AWA</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Pass Through Trusts</I>&#160;&#151; Since AWA&#146;s
    restructuring in 1994, AWA has set up 19 pass through trusts,
    which have issued over $1.4&#160;billion of pass through trust
    certificates (also known as &#147;Enhanced Equipment
    Trust&#160;Certificates&#148; or &#147;EETCs&#148;) covering the
    financing of 54 aircraft. These trusts are off-balance sheet
    entities, the primary purpose of which is to finance the
    acquisition of aircraft. Rather than finance each aircraft
    separately when such aircraft is purchased or delivered, these
    trusts allow AWA to raise the financing for several aircraft at
    one time and place such funds in escrow pending the purchase or
    delivery of the relevant aircraft. The trusts are also
    structured to provide for certain credit enhancements, such as
    liquidity facilities to cover certain interest payments, that
    reduce the risks to the purchasers of the trust certificates
    and, as a result, reduce the cost of aircraft financing to AWA.
    AWA does not believe it is the primary beneficiary under these
    lease arrangements based upon its cash flow analysis.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Each trust covered a set amount of aircraft scheduled to be
    delivered within a specific period of time. At the time of each
    covered aircraft financing, the relevant trust used the funds in
    escrow to purchase equipment notes relating to the financed
    aircraft. The equipment notes were issued, at AWA&#146;s
    election, either by AWA in connection
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    64
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    with a mortgage financing of the aircraft or by a separate owner
    trust in connection with a leveraged lease financing of the
    aircraft. In the case of a leveraged lease financing, the owner
    trust then leased the aircraft to AWA. In both cases, the
    equipment notes are secured by a security interest in the
    aircraft. The pass through trust certificates are not direct
    obligations of, nor guaranteed by, America West Holdings or AWA.
    However, in the case of mortgage financings, the equipment notes
    issued to the trusts are direct obligations of AWA and in the
    case of leveraged lease financings, the leases are direct
    obligations of AWA. In addition, neither America West Holdings
    nor AWA guarantee or participate in any way in the residual
    value of the leased aircraft. All aircraft financed by these
    trusts are currently structured as leveraged lease financings,
    which are not reflected as debt on the balance sheets of either
    AWA or America West Holdings.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Special Facility Revenue Bonds</I>&#160;&#151; In June 1999,
    Series&#160;1999 special facility revenue bonds (the &#147;New
    Bonds&#148;), were issued by a municipality to fund the
    retirement of the Series&#160;1994A bonds (the &#147;Old
    Bonds&#148;), and the construction of a new concourse with 14
    gates at Terminal 4 in Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport
    in support of AWA&#146;s strategic growth plan. The New Bonds
    are due June 2019 with interest accruing at 6.25%&#160;per annum
    payable semiannually on June&#160;1 and December&#160;1,
    commencing on December&#160;1, 1999. The New Bonds are subject
    to optional redemption prior to the maturity date on or after
    June&#160;1, 2009 in whole or in part, on any interest payment
    date at the following redemption prices: 101% on June&#160;1 or
    December&#160;1, 2009; 100.5% on June&#160;1 or December&#160;1,
    2010; and 100% on June&#160;1, 2011 and thereafter. In
    accordance with Emerging Issues Task Force (&#147;EITF&#148;)
    Issue
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;97-10,</FONT>
    &#147;The Effect of Lessee Involvement in Asset
    Construction,&#148; AWA accounts for this as an operating lease.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with these bonds, AWA entered into an Amended and
    Restated Airport Use Agreement, pursuant to which AWA agreed to
    make sufficient rental payments to the Industrial Development
    Authority (the &#147;IDA&#148;) to cover the principal and
    interest of the bonds and to indemnify the IDA for any claims
    arising out of the issuance and sale of the bonds and the use
    and occupancy of the concourses financed by these bonds and the
    Old Bonds. At December&#160;31, 2006, the outstanding principal
    amount of the bonds was $22&#160;million. AWA estimates its
    remaining payments to cover the principal and interest of these
    bonds will be approximately $39&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA is also the lessee under certain long-term leases at various
    airports. At certain of these airports, municipalities have
    issued revenue bonds to improve airport facilities that are
    leased by AWA and accounted for as operating leases. AWA does
    not guarantee the underlying debt related to these operating
    leases.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Pass Through Trusts</I>&#160;&#151; US&#160;Airways has also
    set up pass through trusts established specifically to purchase,
    finance and lease aircraft for which US&#160;Airways is the
    lessee and the pass through trust serves as lessor. These trusts
    issue EETCs, allowing US&#160;Airways to raise the financing for
    several aircraft at one time and place such funds in escrow
    pending the purchase or delivery of the relevant aircraft. The
    trusts are also structured to provide for certain credit
    enhancements, such as liquidity facilities to cover certain
    interest payments, that reduce the risks to the purchasers of
    the trust certificates, and as a result, reduce the cost of
    aircraft financing to US&#160;Airways. US&#160;Airways reviewed
    62 aircraft operating leases financed through EETCs, each of
    which contains a fixed-price purchase option that allows
    US&#160;Airways to purchase the aircraft at predetermined prices
    on specified dates during the latter part of the lease term.
    However, US&#160;Airways does not guarantee the residual value
    of the aircraft. US&#160;Airways does not believe it is the
    primary beneficiary under these lease arrangements based upon
    its cash flow analysis.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Special Facility Revenue Bonds</I>&#160;&#151;
    US&#160;Airways guarantees the payment of principal and interest
    on certain special facility revenue bonds issued by
    municipalities to build or improve certain airport and
    maintenance facilities which are leased to US&#160;Airways.
    Under such leases, US&#160;Airways is required to make rental
    payments through 2023, sufficient to pay maturing principal and
    interest payments on the related bonds. As of December&#160;31,
    2006, the principal amount outstanding on these bonds was
    $74&#160;million. Remaining lease payments guaranteeing the
    principal and interest on these bonds will be $124&#160;million.
    US&#160;Airways also reviewed long-term operating leases at a
    number of airports, including leases where US&#160;Airways is
    also the guarantor of the underlying debt. These leases are
    typically with municipalities or other governmental entities.
    The arrangements are not required to be consolidated based on
    the provisions of FIN&#160;46(R).
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Jet Service Agreements</I>&#160;&#151; Certain entities with
    which US&#160;Airways has capacity purchase agreements are
    considered variable interest entities under FIN&#160;46(R). In
    connection with its restructuring and emergence from
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    65
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    bankruptcy, US&#160;Airways contracted with Air Wisconsin, a
    related party, and Republic to purchase a significant portion of
    these companies&#146; regional jet capacity for a period of ten
    years. US&#160;Airways has determined that it is not the primary
    beneficiary of these variable interest entities, based on cash
    flow analyses. Additionally, US&#160;Airways has analyzed the
    arrangements with other carriers with which US&#160;Airways has
    long-term capacity purchase agreements and concluded that it is
    not required to consolidate any of the entities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Other
    Indebtedness and Obligations</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table provides details of our future cash
    contractual obligations as of December&#160;31, 2006 (in
    millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We expect to fund these cash obligations from funds provided by
    operations and future financings, if necessary. The cash
    available to us from these sources, however, may not be
    sufficient to cover these cash obligations because economic
    factors outside our control may reduce the amount of cash
    generated by operations or increase our costs. For instance, an
    economic downturn or general global instability caused by
    military actions, terrorism, disease outbreaks and natural
    disasters could reduce the demand for air travel, which would
    reduce the amount of cash generated by operations. An increase
    in our costs, either due to an increase in borrowing costs
    caused by a reduction
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    66
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    in our credit rating or a general increase in interest rates or
    due to an increase in the cost of fuel, maintenance, aircraft
    and aircraft engines and parts, could decrease the amount of
    cash available to cover the cash obligations. Moreover, the GE
    loan and Juniper agreement contain a minimum cash balance
    requirement. As a result, we cannot use all of our available
    cash to fund operations, capital expenditures and cash
    obligations without violating these requirements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Other
    Information</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Income
    Taxes</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group has
    available NOL and tax credit carryforwards for federal income
    tax purposes of approximately $980&#160;million and
    $37&#160;million, respectively. The NOL expires during the years
    2022 through 2025. The breakdown of the NOL and tax credit
    carryforwards on a separate company basis are as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    AWA has available NOL carryforwards and tax credit carryforwards
    for federal income tax purposes of approximately
    $400&#160;million and $7&#160;million, respectively. The NOL
    expires during the years 2022 through 2025.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    US&#160;Airways has available NOL carryforwards and tax credit
    carryforwards for federal income tax purposes of approximately
    $580&#160;million and $30&#160;million respectively. The NOL
    expires during the years 2024 and 2025.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group had a change of ownership upon emergence
    from bankruptcy and its issuance of new common stock. Internal
    Revenue Code Section&#160;382 substantially limits the annual
    usage of remaining tax attributes that were generated prior to
    the change in ownership. In addition, as a result of America
    West Holdings&#146; merger with US&#160;Airways Group, AWA also
    experienced an ownership change and AWA&#146;s ability to
    utilize its regular and AMT&#160;NOL and tax credit
    carryforwards may be restricted. As of December&#160;31, 2006,
    US&#160;Airways Group estimates $795&#160;million of the NOL
    will be available to offset federal taxable income in the
    calendar year 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Related
    Party Transactions</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Each of US&#160;Airways Group, AWA and US&#160;Airways have
    entered into transactions with various members of its board of
    directors and related entities. See Notes&#160;13, 13
    and&#160;10, &#147;Related Party Transactions&#148; in
    Items&#160;8A, 8B and 8C, respectively, of this report for
    additional information, which information is incorporated herein
    by reference.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Critical
    Accounting Policies and Estimates</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The preparation of our consolidated financial statements in
    accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the
    United States requires that we make certain estimates and
    assumptions that affect the reported amount of assets and
    liabilities, revenues and expenses, and the disclosure of
    contingent assets and liabilities at the date of our financial
    statements. We believe our estimates and assumptions are
    reasonable; however, actual results could differ from those
    estimates. Critical accounting policies are defined as those
    that are reflective of significant judgments and uncertainties
    and potentially result in materially different results under
    different assumptions and conditions. We have identified the
    following critical accounting policies that impact the
    preparation of our financial statements. See also the summary of
    significant accounting policies included in the notes to the
    financial statements under Items&#160;8A, 8B and 8C of this
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Form&#160;10-K</FONT>
    for additional discussion of the application of these estimates
    and other accounting policies.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    67
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Passenger
    Revenue</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Passenger revenue is recognized when transportation is provided.
    Ticket sales for transportation that has not yet been provided
    are initially deferred and recorded as air traffic liability on
    the balance sheet. The air traffic liability represents tickets
    sold for future travel dates and estimated future refunds and
    exchanges of tickets sold for past travel dates. The balance in
    the air traffic liability fluctuates throughout the year based
    on seasonal travel patterns and fare sale activity. The air
    traffic liability was as follows (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
