<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The adoption of the recognition provisions of
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;158 had no effect on the Company&#146;s
    consolidated statements of operations for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006 or for any prior period presented.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    This statement also requires plan assets and obligations to be
    measured as of the employer&#146;s balance sheet date. The
    measurement provisions of this statement will be effective for
    years beginning after December&#160;15, 2008. The Company has
    not yet adopted the measurement provisions of this statement
    with respect to its postretirement benefit plans, which are
    measured on September&#160;30, and is in the process of
    determining the impact of the adoption on the Company&#146;s
    consolidated financial statements. The Company&#146;s defined
    benefit pension plans are measured as of the balance sheet date.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In September, 2006, the FASB issued FASB Staff Position
    (&#147;FSP&#148;) No.&#160;AUG AIR-1 &#147;Accounting for
    Planned Major Maintenance Activities&#148;. This amends the
    existing major maintenance accounting guidance contained within
    the AICPA Industry Audit Guide &#147;Audits of Airlines&#148;
    and prohibits the use of the accrue in advance method of
    accounting for planned major maintenance activities for owned
    aircraft. The provisions of the announcement are applicable for
    fiscal years beginning after December&#160;15, 2006.
    US&#160;Airways Group currently uses the direct expense method
    of accounting for planned major maintenance, an acceptable
    method under generally accepted accounting
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    92
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    principles in the United States of America. Therefore, the
    adoption of FSP No.&#160;AUG AIR-1 is not expected to have any
    material impact on US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s consolidated
    financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In September 2006, the SEC issued Staff Accounting
    Bulletin&#160;No.&#160;108 (&#147;SAB&#160;108&#148;). Due to
    diversity in practice among registrants, SAB&#160;108 expresses
    SEC staff views regarding the process by which misstatements in
    financial statements are evaluated for purposes of determining
    whether financial statement restatement is necessary.
    SAB&#160;108 is effective for fiscal years ending after
    November&#160;15, 2006. The Company has adopted SAB&#160;108 in
    the fourth quarter of 2006 and its adoption had no effect on the
    Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements for the year
    ended December&#160;31, 2006 or for any prior period presented.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In June 2006, the FASB issued Interpretation No.&#160;48,
    &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes, an
    interpretation of FASB Statement No.&#160;109&#148;
    (&#147;FIN&#160;48&#148;), which clarifies the accounting for
    uncertainty in income taxes recognized in financial statements.
    FIN&#160;48 requires the impact of a tax position to be
    recognized in the financial statements if that position is more
    likely than not of being sustained by the taxing authority.
    US&#160;Airways Group will be required to adopt FIN&#160;48 in
    the first quarter of fiscal year 2007. Management has evaluated
    the requirements of FIN&#160;48 and does not expect it to have a
    material impact on US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s consolidated
    financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On November&#160;10, 2005, the FASB issued FASB Staff Position
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;FAS&#160;123R-3,</FONT>
    &#147;Transition Election Related to Accounting for Tax Effects
    of Share-Based Payment Awards.&#148; The Company elected to
    adopt the modified prospective method, which is the simplified
    method provided in the FASB Staff Position for calculating the
    tax effects of stock-based compensation pursuant to
    SFAS&#160;123R. The modified prospective method was used to
    determine the beginning balance of the additional paid-in
    capital pool (&#147;APIC pool&#148;) related to the tax effects
    of employee stock-based compensation. Due to the Company&#146;s
    history of tax net operating losses, the Company had no
    beginning balance in the APIC pool at the date of adoption of
    SFAS&#160;123R on January&#160;1, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company uses the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">&#147;with-and-without&#148;</FONT>
    or &#147;incremental&#148; approach for determining the order in
    which tax benefits derived from the share-based payment awards
    are utilized. Using the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">with-and-without</FONT>
    approach, actual income taxes payable for the period are
    compared to the amount of income taxes that would have been
    payable if there had been no share-based compensation expense
    for tax purposes in excess of the compensation expense
    recognized for financial reporting purposes. As a result of this
    approach, tax net operating loss carry forwards not related to
    share-based compensation are utilized before the current
    period&#146;s share-based compensation deduction. As a result of
    this accounting treatment, the Company has a fully reserved
    deferred tax asset of approximately $25&#160;million related to
    tax net operating loss carry forwards related to deductions for
    excess tax benefits. The benefit of the valuation allowance
    release related to these deductions will be recorded directly to
    equity as additional
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">paid-in-capital</FONT>
    when such benefits are realized.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">2.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">New
    equity structure and conversion</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Pursuant to US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s plan of reorganization,
    all securities of US&#160;Airways Group outstanding prior to
    September&#160;27, 2005 were cancelled upon emergence from
    Chapter&#160;11. In connection with the merger, US&#160;Airways
    Group adopted an Amended and Restated Certificate of
    Incorporation and Amended and Restated Bylaws effective
    September&#160;27, 2005. US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s authorized
    capital stock, following the merger, consists of
    200&#160;million shares of common stock, par value
    $0.01&#160;per share. Holders of the new US&#160;Airways Group
    common stock are entitled to one vote per share on all matters
    submitted to a vote of common shareholders, except that voting
    rights of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">non-U.S.&#160;citizens</FONT>
    are limited to the extent that the shares of common stock held
    by such
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">non-U.S.&#160;persons</FONT>
    would otherwise be entitled to more than 24.9% of the aggregate
    votes of all outstanding equity securities of US&#160;Airways
    Group.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In the merger, holders of America West Holdings Class&#160;A
    common stock received 0.5362 of a share of new US&#160;Airways
    Group common stock for each share of America West Holdings
    Class&#160;A common stock they owned,
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    93
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    and holders of America West Holdings Class&#160;B common stock
    received 0.4125 of a share of new US&#160;Airways Group common
    stock for each share of America West Holdings Class&#160;B
    common stock they owned, according to the terms specified in the
    merger agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On September&#160;27, 2005, US&#160;Airways Group received new
    equity investments of $565&#160;million in the aggregate from
    ACE Aviation Holdings Inc. (&#147;ACE&#148;); Par Investment
    Partners, L.P. (&#147;Par&#148;); Peninsula Investment Partners,
    L.P. (&#147;Peninsula&#148;); a group of investors under the
    management of Wellington Management Company, LLP
    (&#147;Wellington&#148;); Tudor Proprietary Trading, L.L.C. and
    certain investors advised by Tudor Investment Corp.
    (&#147;Tudor&#148;); and Eastshore Aviation, LLC
    (&#147;Eastshore&#148;). In connection with the equity
    investments, each of the equity investors received an option to
    purchase additional shares at $15.00&#160;per share. Par
    purchased the options granted to ACE and Eastshore, and each
    option holder exercised the first two-thirds of its option on
    September&#160;28, 2005, for aggregate proceeds to
    US&#160;Airways Group of approximately $75&#160;million. On
    October&#160;13, 2005, each of the equity investors exercised
    the remaining portion of its option for aggregate proceeds to
    US&#160;Airways Group of approximately $38&#160;million.
    Proceeds from these new equity investments, including the option
    exercises, totaled approximately $678&#160;million. The new
    equity investors acquired an aggregate of approximately
    44&#160;million shares of common stock, including the shares
    acquired upon exercise of their options.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">3.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Change in
    accounting policy for maintenance costs</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As discussed in Note&#160;1(o), AWA changed its accounting
    policy from the deferral method to the direct expense method
    during the fourth quarter of 2005. The effect of this change in
    accounting for aircraft maintenance and repairs is recorded as a
    cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle. The
    effect of the change in 2005 was to increase net loss by
    approximately $48&#160;million (or $1.52&#160;per share). The
    increase in the 2005&#160;net loss of $202&#160;million is the
    cumulative effect on retained earnings of the adoption as of
    January&#160;1, 2005. The cumulative effect of the change in
    accounting principle is not presented net of tax as any tax
    effects resulting from the change have been immediately offset
    by the recording of a valuation allowance through the same
    financial statement caption.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The pro forma net loss shown on the consolidated statements of
    operations have been adjusted for the effects of retroactive
    application of the impact of maintenance costs. The following
    pro forma loss per share amounts show the effect of the
    retroactive application of the change in accounting principle.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="92%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=lead -->
    <TD width="4%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=hang1 -->
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom" align="center">
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD colspan="2" nowrap align="center" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">
    <B>2004</B>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">
<TD>&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="background: #CCEEFF">
<TD align="left" valign="bottom">
<DIV style="text-indent: -10pt; margin-left: 10pt">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">Loss per share
    </FONT>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="right" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD align="left" valign="bottom">
<DIV style="text-indent: -10pt; margin-left: 10pt">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">Basic&#160;&#151; As Reported
    before cumulative effect of change in accounting principle
    </FONT>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
    $
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="right" valign="bottom">
    (5.99
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
    )
</TD>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<P>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">4.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Earning/loss
    per common share</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Basic earnings (loss) per common share (&#147;EPS&#148;) is
    computed by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted average
    number of shares of common stock outstanding during the period.
    Diluted EPS reflects the maximum dilution that would result
    after giving effect to all potential dilutive common shares from
    stock options, stock appreciation rights, restricted stock unit
    awards, warrants and convertible debt. The number of additional
    shares is calculated by assuming that outstanding,
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">in-the-money</FONT>
    stock awards were exercised and the proceeds from such exercises
    were used to buy back shares of common stock at the average
    market price for the reporting period. The following table
    presents the computation of basic and diluted EPS (in millions,
    except share amounts):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row -->

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For the year ended December&#160;31, 2006, 1,254,960 stock
    options and stock appreciation rights are not included in the
    computation of diluted EPS because the option exercise prices
    were greater than the average market price of common stock for
    the period. Also, 34,650 performance-based restricted stock unit
    awards were excluded as the performance-based provision had not
    been met as of December&#160;31, 2006. In addition, 1,054,692
    incremental shares from assumed conversion of the
    7.5%&#160;senior convertible notes are not included in the
    computation of diluted EPS because of the antidilutive effect on
    EPS.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For the year ended December&#160;31, 2005, 2,656,804 stock
    options are not included in the computation of diluted EPS
    because the option exercise prices were greater than the average
    market price of common stock for the period. Options to acquire
    930,976 common shares and 3,021,908 warrants issued in
    conjunction with the AWA ATSB Loan and related transactions are
    not included in the computation of diluted EPS because of the
    antidilutive effect on EPS. In addition, 1,506,141 incremental
    shares from assumed conversion of the 7%&#160;senior convertible
    notes, 3,860,289 incremental shares from assumed conversion of
    the 7.5%&#160;senior convertible notes and 3,042,555 incremental
    shares from assumed conversion of the 7.25%&#160;senior
    exchangeable notes are not included in the computation of
    diluted EPS because of the antidilutive effect on EPS.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For the year ended December&#160;31, 2004, 2,165,168 stock
    options and 3,033,108 warrants issued in conjunction with the
    AWA ATSB Loan and related transactions are not included in the
    computation of diluted EPS because the option and warrant
    exercise prices were greater than the average market price of
    common stock for the period. In addition, 3,339,535&#160;shares
    issuable upon conversion of the 7.25%&#160;senior exchangeable
    notes due 2023 and 3,586,275 issuable upon conversion of the
    7.5%&#160;convertible senior notes are not included in the
    computation of diluted EPS because of the antidilutive effect on
    EPS.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">5.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Special
    items, net</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Special items, net included within the statements of operations
    include the following components (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="74%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=lead -->
    <TD width="2%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="6%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=lead -->
    <TD width="2%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=hang1 -->

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In the third quarter of 2005, in connection with the merger and
    a Memorandum of Understanding (the &#147;Airbus MOU&#148;)
    executed between AVSA S.A.R.L., an affiliate of Airbus S.A.S.
    (&#147;Airbus&#148;), US&#160;Airways Group, US&#160;Airways and
    AWA, certain aircraft firm orders were restructured. In
    connection with that restructuring, US&#160;Airways Group and
    America West Holdings were required to pay non-refundable
    restructuring fees totaling $89&#160;million by means of set-off
    against existing equipment deposits of US&#160;Airways and AWA
    held by Airbus of $39&#160;million and $50&#160;million
    respectively. In 2005, AWA&#146;s restructuring fee of
    $50&#160;million has been classified as a special charge, along
    with $7&#160;million in associated capitalized interest. Also in
    connection with the Airbus MOU, US&#160;Airways and AWA entered
    into two loan agreements with aggregate commitments of up to </TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    96
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<P>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    $161&#160;million and $89&#160;million. As described in further
    detail in Note&#160;7, on March&#160;31, 2006, the outstanding
    principal and accrued interest on the $89&#160;million loan was
    forgiven upon repayment in full of the $161&#160;million loan in
    accordance with terms of the Airbus loans. As a result, in 2006
    the Company recognized a gain associated with the return of
    these equipment deposits upon forgiveness of the loan totaling
    $90&#160;million, consisting of the $89&#160;million in
    equipment deposits and accrued interest of $1&#160;million.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In 2006, the Company incurred $131&#160;million of merger
    related transition costs. These items include $41&#160;million
    of personnel costs for severance, retention payments and stock
    awards; $38&#160;million of professional and technical fees;
    $17&#160;million of aircraft livery costs; $2&#160;million in
    merger related aircraft lease return expenses; $6&#160;million
    of training and related costs; $7&#160;million of employee
    moving expenses; $11&#160;million of costs associated with the
    integration of the AWA FlightFund and US&#160;Airways Dividend
    Miles frequent traveler programs; and $9&#160;million of other
    expenses.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In 2005, the Company incurred $28&#160;million of merger related
    transition costs in the fourth quarter of 2005 related to
    transitioning the employees, systems and facilities of AWA and
    US&#160;Airways into one consolidated company. These items
    include insurance premiums of $11&#160;million related to
    policies for former officers and directors, compensation expense
    of $8&#160;million for severance and special stock awards
    granted under a program designed to retain key employees through
    the integration period, professional and technical fees of
    $3&#160;million, sales and marketing program expenses of
    $2&#160;million related to notifying frequent traveler program
    members about the merger, $1&#160;million of aircraft livery
    costs, $1&#160;million of programming service expense and
    $2&#160;million in other expenses.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Due to the requirements for continued service, severance expense
    is recorded over the remaining service period. The Company
    expects to record severance expense and make remaining
    termination and benefit payments of $1&#160;million during 2007.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In the third quarter of 2005, a $27&#160;million loss was
    incurred related to the sale-leaseback of six Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT>
    aircraft and two Boeing 757 aircraft.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In the fourth quarter of 2005, in connection with the return of
    certain leased aircraft, AWA incurred expenses of
    $7&#160;million related to penalties incurred under an
    outsourced maintenance arrangement.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (e) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In the third and fourth quarter of 2005, AWA recorded severance
    expense totaling approximately $2&#160;million for terminated
    employees resulting from the merger.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (f) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In August 2004, AWA entered into definitive agreements with two
    lessors to return six Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT>
    aircraft. Three of these aircraft were returned to the lessors
    in the third quarter of 2004, two were returned in the fourth
    quarter of 2004 and one was returned in January 2005. In
    connection with the return of the aircraft, AWA recorded
    $2&#160;million of special charges in 2004, which included lease
    termination payments of $2&#160;million and the write-down of
    leasehold improvements and aircraft rent balances of
    $3&#160;million, offset by the net reversal of lease return
    provisions of $3&#160;million. In the first quarter of 2005, AWA
    recorded $1&#160;million in special charges related to the final
    Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT>
    aircraft, which was removed from service in January 2005.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

    <BR>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (g) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In the first quarter of 2004, AWA recorded a $1&#160;million
    reduction in special charges related to the revision of
    estimated costs associated with the sale and leaseback of
    certain aircraft.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (h) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In December 2004, AWA and General Electric (&#147;GE&#148;)
    mutually agreed to terminate the V2500
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A-1</FONT> power by
    hour (&#147;PBH&#148;) agreement effective January&#160;1, 2005.
    This agreement was entered into March 1998 with an original term
    of ten years. For terminating the agreement early, AWA received
    a $20&#160;million credit to be applied to amounts due for other
    engines under the 1998 agreement. AWA had capitalized PBH
    payments for V2500
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A-1</FONT> engines
    in excess of the unamortized cost of the overhauls performed by
    GE of approximately $4&#160;million. With the termination of
    this agreement, these payments were not realizable and as a
    result, AWA wrote off this amount against the $20&#160;million
    credit referred to above, resulting in a $16&#160;million net
    gain.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (i) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In the fourth quarter of 2006, the Company recognized
    $14&#160;million in gains in connection with the settlement of
    bankruptcy claims, which includes $11&#160;million related to
    the Bombardier settlement, see Note&#160;10(a).</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">6.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Financial
    instruments</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(a)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">General</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On January&#160;1, 1998, as part of a comprehensive information
    technology services agreement with Sabre, US&#160;Airways was
    granted two tranches of stock options (&#147;SHC Stock
    Options&#148;) to acquire up to 6,000,000&#160;shares of
    Class&#160;A Common Stock, $0.01&#160;par value, of Sabre
    Holdings Corporation (&#147;SHC Common Stock&#148;),
    Sabre&#146;s parent company. Each tranche included 3,000,000
    stock options. In December 1999, US&#160;Airways exercised the
    first tranche of stock options at an exercise price of
    $27&#160;per option and received proceeds of $81&#160;million in
    January 2000 in lieu of receiving SHC Common Stock. Realized
    gains resulting from the exercise of Sabre options are subject
    to a clawback provision. Under the clawback provision, if
    US&#160;Airways elects to terminate its information technology
    service agreement with Sabre, it will be required to pay Sabre
    an amount equal to the gain multiplied by the ratio of the
    remaining months in the contract period over 180&#160;months.
    The deferred gain from the 1999 exercise is amortized on a
    straight-line basis over a contractually determined period
    ending December 2012. In February 2000, SHC declared a cash
    dividend resulting in a dilution adjustment to the terms of the
    second tranche. The adjusted terms of the second tranche include
    stock options to acquire 3,406,914&#160;shares of SHC Common
    Stock at an exercise price of $23.78 subject to a
    $111.83&#160;per share cap on the fair market value of the
    underlying common stock. These options are exercisable during a
    ten-year period beginning January&#160;2, 2003. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, the fair value of the SHC Stock Options
    was $21&#160;million and was recorded in other assets, net. On
    December&#160;12, 2006, Sabre announced that it had agreed to be
    acquired by several private equity groups for $32.75&#160;per
    share in cash. The Company anticipates exercising the second
    tranche of options and converting the related shares to cash in
    connection with the Sabre acquisition. Any gain realized on the
    eventual sale of Sabre stock from the exercise of the second
    tranche of options will be subject to the same clawback
    provisions as the first tranche.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(b)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Fuel
    Price Risk Management</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Under its fuel hedging program, the Company may enter into
    certain hedging transactions with approved counterparties for a
    period generally not exceeding 12&#160;months. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, the Company had entered into costless
    collar transactions hedging approximately 29% of the
    Company&#146;s projected 2007 fuel requirements. The fair value
    of the financial derivative instruments was a net liability of
    $66&#160;million and a net asset of $4&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, the Company had $48&#160;million of
    deposits held as collateral on the open fuel hedge positions
    that are recorded as prepaid expenses and other on the
    consolidated balance sheets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company is exposed to credit risks in the event any
    counterparty to a hedge transaction fails to meet its
    obligations. The Company does not anticipate such
    non-performance as counterparties are selected based on credit
    ratings and exposure to any one counterparty is closely
    monitored.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    98
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The carrying amount of cash equivalents approximates fair value
    because of the short-term nature of these instruments. All
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">held-to-maturity</FONT>
    securities mature in one year or less. Contractual maturities
    for
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">available-for-sale</FONT>
    securities are greater than ten years with a reset date
    approximately every 28&#160;days. The carrying values of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">available-for-sale</FONT>
    securities approximate fair value. There were no unrealized
    gains or losses on these investments for the years ended
    December&#160;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004 due to the frequent
    resetting of interest rates on the auction rate securities.
    Gross proceeds from sales of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">available-for-sale</FONT>
    securities for the years ended December&#160;31, 2006, 2005 and
    2004 were $749&#160;million, $411&#160;million and
    $589&#160;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company had no long-term investments in debt securities as
    of December&#160;31, 2006 and December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Long-term
    Debt</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, the fair value of long-term
    debt was approximately $3.09&#160;billion and
    $3.12&#160;billion, respectively. The Company&#146;s variable
    rate long-term debt with a carrying value of $1.94&#160;billion
    and $1.85&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005,
    respectively, approximates fair value because these borrowings
    have variable interest rate terms that approximate market
    interest rates for similar debt instruments. The fair value of
    the Company&#146;s other long-term debt is determined based on
    quoted market prices if available or market prices for
    comparable debt instruments.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    99
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    On March&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group entered into a
    loan agreement with General Electric Capital Corporation
    (&#147;GECC&#148;) and a syndicate of lenders pursuant to which
    the Company borrowed an aggregate principal amount of
    $1.1&#160;billion. On April&#160;7, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group
    entered into an amended and restated loan agreement, which
    increased the principal amount of the loan to $1.25&#160;billion
    (as amended and restated, the &#147;GE Loan&#148;).
    US&#160;Airways, America West Holdings, AWA, Piedmont, PSA and
    MSC are all guarantors of the GE Loan.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The GE Loan bears interest at an index rate plus an applicable
    index margin or, at the Company&#146;s option, LIBOR plus an
    applicable LIBOR margin for interest periods of one, two, three
    or six months. The applicable index margin, subject to
    adjustment, is 1.50%, 2.00%, 2.25%, or 2.50% if the adjusted
    loan balance is respectively less than $600&#160;million,
    between $600&#160;million and $750&#160;million, between
    $750&#160;million and $900&#160;million, or between
    $900&#160;million and $1.25&#160;billion. The applicable LIBOR
    margin, subject to adjustment, is 2.50%, 3.00%, 3.25%, or 3.50%
    if the adjusted loan balance is respectively less than
    $600&#160;million, between $600&#160;million and
    $750&#160;million, between $750&#160;million and
    $900&#160;million, or between $900&#160;million and
    $1.25&#160;billion. In addition, interest on the GE Loan may be
    adjusted based on the credit rating for the GE Loan as follows:
    (i)&#160;subject to clause&#160;(ii) below, if the credit rating
    for the GE Loan is B1 or better from Moody&#146;s and B+ or
    better from Standard&#160;&#38; Poor (&#147;S&#38;P&#148;) as of
    the last day of the most recently ended fiscal quarter, then
    (A)&#160;the applicable LIBOR margin will be the lower of 3.25%
    and the rate otherwise applicable based upon the adjusted GE
    Loan balance and (B)&#160;the applicable index margin will be
    the lower of 2.25% and the rate otherwise applicable based upon
    the adjusted GE Loan balance, and (ii)&#160;if the credit rating
    for the Loan is Ba3 or better from Moody&#146;s and BB- or
    better from S&#38;P as of the last day of the most recently
    ended fiscal quarter, then the applicable LIBOR margin will be
    2.50% and the applicable index margin will be 1.50%. The GE Loan
    matures on March&#160;31, 2011, and no principal payments are
    scheduled until maturity.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In addition, the GE Loan requires certain mandatory prepayments
    upon certain events, establishes certain financial covenants,
    including minimum cash requirements and maintenance of certain
    minimum ratios, contains customary affirmative covenants and
    negative covenants, and contains customary events of default.
    Under the GE Loan, US&#160;Airways Group is required to maintain
    consolidated unrestricted cash and cash equivalents of not less
    than $750&#160;million, subject to partial reductions upon
    specified reductions in the outstanding principal amount of the
    GE Loan.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    On March&#160;31, 2006, proceeds of the GE Loan were used, in
    part, to repay in full the following indebtedness:</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The amended and restated US&#160;Airways and AWA loans entered
    into on September&#160;27, 2005 that had previously been
    guaranteed by the Air Transportation Stabilization Board
    (&#147;ATSB&#148;). On October&#160;19, 2005, $777&#160;million
    of the loans, of which $752&#160;million had been guaranteed by
    the ATSB, was sold by the lenders by order of the ATSB to 13
    fixed income investors, for which Citibank, N.A served as agent,
    removing the ATSB guarantee (the &#147;Citibank Loans&#148;). At
    the time of repayment of these loans on March&#160;31, 2006, the
    total outstanding balance of the loans was $801&#160;million, of
    which $551&#160;million was outstanding under the
    US&#160;Airways loan and $250&#160;million was outstanding under
    the AWA loan. Proceeds were also used to pay $15&#160;million of
    accrued interest and fees on the US&#160;Airways loan, and
    $8&#160;million of accrued interest and $5&#160;million of
    prepayment penalty on the AWA loan.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The $161&#160;million loan entered into as of September&#160;27,
    2005 between US&#160;Airways and AWA and Airbus Financial
    Services, for which US&#160;Airways Group was the guarantor. At
    the time of repayment on March&#160;31, 2006, the outstanding
    balance of the loan was $161&#160;million. US&#160;Airways and
    AWA also had an $89&#160;million loan from Airbus Financial
    Services entered into as of September&#160;27, 2005. In
    accordance with the terms of the loan agreements, the
    outstanding principal amount of the $89&#160;million loan was to
    be forgiven on the earlier of December&#160;31, 2010 or the date
    that the outstanding principal amount of, accrued interest on,
    and all other amounts due under the Airbus $161&#160;million
    loan were paid in full, provided that the Company complied with
    the delivery schedule for certain Airbus aircraft. As a result
    of the prepayment of the $161&#160;million loan
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    101

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD align="left">
    on March&#160;31, 2006, the $89&#160;million loan agreement was
    terminated and the outstanding balance of $89&#160;million was
    forgiven along with $1&#160;million in accrued interest.
</TD>
</TR>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

    <TD width="5%"></TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Two loans provided by GECC to AWA pursuant to loan agreements
    entered into as of September&#160;3, 2004 referred to as the
    Spare Parts Facility and the Engines Facility (collectively, the
    &#147;GECC term loan&#148;). At the time of repayment, the
    principal amounts outstanding under the Spare Parts Facility and
    the Engines Facility were $76&#160;million and $34&#160;million,
    respectively. Proceeds were also used to pay $1&#160;million of
    accrued interest and $1&#160;million of prepayment penalties on
    these two GECC loans.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    On December&#160;27, 2004, AWA raised additional capital by
    financing its Phoenix maintenance facility and flight training
    center. The flight training center was previously unencumbered,
    and the maintenance facility became unencumbered earlier in 2004
    when AWA refinanced its term loan. Using its leasehold interest
    in these two facilities as collateral, AWA, through a wholly
    owned subsidiary named FTCHP LLC, raised $31&#160;million
    through the issuance of senior secured discount notes. The notes
    were issued by FTCHP at a discount pursuant to the terms of a
    senior secured term loan agreement among the Company, FTCHP,
    Heritage Bank SSB, as administrative agent, Citibank, N.A., as
    the initial lender, and the other lenders from time to time
    party thereto. Citibank, N.A. subsequently assigned all of its
    interests in the notes to third party lenders.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    AWA has fully and unconditionally guaranteed the payment and
    performance of FTCHP&#146;s obligations under the notes and the
    loan agreement. The notes require aggregate principal payments
    of $36&#160;million with principal payments of $2&#160;million
    due on each of the first two anniversary dates and the remaining
    principal amount due on the fifth anniversary date. The notes
    may be prepaid in full at any time (subject to customary LIBOR
    breakage costs) and in partial amounts of $2&#160;million on the
    third and fourth anniversary dates. The unpaid principal amount
    of the notes bears interest based on LIBOR plus a margin subject
    to adjustment based on a loan to collateral value ratio.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The loan agreement contains customary covenants applicable to
    loans of this type, including obligations relating to the
    preservation of the collateral and restrictions on the
    activities of FTCHP. In addition, the loan agreement contains
    events of default, including payment defaults, cross-defaults to
    other debt of FTCHP, if any, breach of covenants, bankruptcy and
    insolvency defaults and judgment defaults.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In connection with this financing, AWA sold all of its leasehold
    interests in the maintenance facility and flight training center
    to FTCHP and entered into subleases for the facilities with
    FTCHP at lease rates expected to approximate the interest
    payments due under the notes. In addition, AWA agreed to make
    future capital contributions to FTCHP in amounts sufficient to
    cover principal payments and other amounts owing pursuant to the
    notes and the loan agreement.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The proceeds from this financing, together with $11&#160;million
    from operating cash flow, were irrevocably deposited with the
    trustee for AWA&#146;s
    10<FONT style="vertical-align: top; font-size: 70&#37;">3</FONT>/<FONT style="font-size: 70&#37;">4</FONT>%&#160;senior
    unsecured notes due 2005, and the notes were subsequently
    redeemed on January&#160;26, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In September 2005, US&#160;Airways entered into an agreement to
    sell and leaseback certain of its commuter slots at Ronald
    Reagan Washington National Airport and New York LaGuardia
    Airport. US&#160;Airways continues to hold the right to
    repurchase the slots anytime after the second anniversary of the
    slot sale-leaseback transaction. These transactions were
    accounted for as secured financings. Installments are due
    monthly through 2015. In December 2006, Republic and
    US&#160;Airways modified terms of the agreement to conform to
    subsequent regulatory changes at LaGuardia, and the slots were
    returned to US&#160;Airways. The need for a subsequent
    modification was fully contemplated in the original agreement.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (e) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Capital lease obligations consist principally of certain airport
    maintenance and facility leases which expire in 2018 and 2021.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (f) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    GE, together with its affiliates, is US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s largest aircraft creditor, having financed or
    leased a substantial portion of its aircraft prior to the most
    recent Chapter&#160;11 filing. In June 2005, GE purchased the
    assets securing the credit facility obtained from GE in 2001
    (the &#147;GE Credit Facility&#148;) in a sale-leaseback </TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    transaction. The sale proceeds realized from the sale-leaseback
    transaction were applied to repay the liquidity facility
    obtained from GE in 2003 in connection with the Company&#146;s
    emergence from its first bankruptcy (the &#147;2003 GE Liquidity
    Facility&#148;), the mortgage financing associated with the CRJ
    aircraft and a portion of the 2001 GE Credit Facility. The
    balance of the GECC Credit Facility was amended to allow
    additional borrowings of $21&#160;million in July 2005, which
    resulted in a total principal balance outstanding thereunder of
    $28&#160;million. The operating leases are cross-defaulted with
    all other GE obligations, other than excepted obligations, and

    September&#160;30, 2010 to December&#160;31, 2008 and required

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (g) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    On September&#160;30, 2005, US&#160;Airways Group issued
    $144&#160;million aggregate principal amount of 7%&#160;Senior
    Convertible Notes due 2020 (the &#147;7%&#160;Senior Convertible
    Notes&#148;) for proceeds, net of expenses, of approximately
    $139&#160;million. The 7% Senior Convertible Notes are
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s senior unsecured obligations and
    rank equally in right of payment to its other senior unsecured
    and unsubordinated indebtedness and are effectively subordinated
    to its secured indebtedness to the extent of the value of assets
    securing such indebtedness. The 7%&#160;Senior Convertible Notes
    are fully and unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and severally
    and on a senior unsecured basis, by US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s
    two major operating subsidiaries, US&#160;Airways and AWA. The
    guarantees are the guarantors&#146; unsecured obligations and
    rank equally in right of payment to the other senior unsecured
    and unsubordinated indebtedness of the guarantors and are
    effectively subordinated to the guarantors&#146; secured
    indebtedness to the extent of the value of assets securing such
    indebtedness.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The 7%&#160;Senior Convertible Notes bear interest at the rate
    of 7%&#160;per year payable in cash semiannually in arrears on
    March&#160;30 and September&#160;30 of each year, beginning
    March&#160;30, 2006. The 7%&#160;Senior Convertible Notes mature
    on September&#160;30, 2020.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Holders may convert, at any time on or prior to maturity or
    redemption, any outstanding notes (or portions thereof) into
    shares of US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s common stock, initially
    at a conversion rate of 41.4508&#160;shares of US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s common stock per $1,000 principal amount of notes
    (equivalent to an initial conversion price of approximately
    $24.12 per share of US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s common stock).
    If a holder elects to convert its notes in connection with
    certain specified fundamental changes that occur prior to
    October&#160;5, 2015, the holder will be entitled to receive
    additional shares of US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s common stock
    as a make whole premium upon conversion. In lieu of delivery of
    shares of US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s common stock upon
    conversion of all or any portion of the notes, US&#160;Airways
    Group may elect to pay holders surrendering notes for conversion
    cash or a combination of shares and cash.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Holders may require US&#160;Airways Group to purchase for cash
    or shares or a combination thereof, at US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s election, all or a portion of their 7%&#160;Senior
    Convertible Notes on September&#160;30, 2010 and
    September&#160;30, 2015 at a purchase price equal to 100% of the
    principal amount of the 7%&#160;Senior Convertible Notes to be
    repurchased plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the
    purchase date. In addition, if US&#160;Airways Group experiences
    a specified fundamental change, holders may require
    US&#160;Airways Group to purchase for cash, shares or a
    combination thereof, at its election, all or a portion of their
    7%&#160;Senior Convertible Notes, subject to specified
    exceptions, at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount of
    the 7%&#160;Senior Convertible Notes plus accrued and unpaid
    interest, if any, to the purchase date. Prior to October&#160;5,
    2010, the 7%&#160;Senior Convertible Notes will not be
    redeemable at US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s option.
    US&#160;Airways Group may redeem all or a portion of the
    7%&#160;Senior Convertible Notes at any time on or after
    October&#160;5, 2010, at a price equal to 100% of the principal
    amount of the 7%&#160;Senior Convertible Notes plus accrued and
    unpaid interest, if any, to the redemption date if the closing
    price of US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s common stock has exceeded
    115% of the conversion price for at least 20 trading days in the
    30 consecutive trading day period ending on the trading day
    before the date on which US&#160;Airways Group mails the
    optional redemption notice.</TD>
</TR>

    In 2006, $70&#160;million of the $144&#160;million outstanding
    principal amount was converted into 2,909,636&#160;shares of
    common stock. In connection with the conversion, the Company
    paid a premium of $17&#160;million to the holders of the

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (h) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In January 2002, in connection with the closing of the original
    AWA ATSB loan and the related transactions, America West
    Holdings issued $105&#160;million of 7.5%&#160;Convertible
    Senior Notes due 2009, of which approximately $112&#160;million
    remained outstanding at December&#160;31, 2005 (including
    $22&#160;million of interest paid through December&#160;31, 2004
    as a deemed loan added to the initial principal thereof).
    Beginning January&#160;18, 2005, these notes were convertible
    into shares of common stock of US&#160;Airways Group, at the
    option of the holders, at an initial conversion price of
    $29.09&#160;per share or a conversion ratio of approximately
    34.376&#160;shares per $1,000 principal amount of such notes,
    subject to standard anti-dilution adjustments. The payment of
    principal, premium and interest on the 7.5%&#160;convertible
    senior notes was fully and unconditionally guaranteed by AWA and
    US&#160;Airways Group. For financial reporting purposes, America
    West Holdings recorded the convertible senior notes at their
    fair market value on the date of issuance. The balance at
    December&#160;31, 2005 was net of an unamortized discount of
    $18&#160;million.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    On March&#160;24, 2006, America West Holdings gave notice to the
    holders of the 7.5%&#160;convertible senior notes that it was
    redeeming the notes in full, at a redemption price of 102.50% of
    the principal amount of the notes, as required under the terms
    of the indenture, plus accrued and unpaid interest up to, but
    not including, the date of redemption. The redemption price,
    plus the relevant interest, was $1,052.50&#160;per $1,000
    principal amount of the notes, and the redemption date was
    April&#160;13, 2006. Holders had the right, at any time at or
    prior to the close of business on April&#160;11, 2006, to
    convert the notes into shares of common stock of US&#160;Airways
    Group at a price of $29.09&#160;per share, or 34.376&#160;shares
    per $1,000 principal amount. Holders who converted also received
    interest up to the date of conversion. A total of
    $112&#160;million in principal amount of the notes was converted
    into shares of common stock prior to the redemption date,
    resulting in the issuance of 3,860,358&#160;shares of common
    stock. In connection with the conversion of the notes into
    common stock, the associated unamortized discount of
    $17&#160;million was recorded as a reduction in the amount of
    paid in capital for the conversion.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (i) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In December 2004, deferred charges under US&#160;Airways&#146;
    maintenance agreements with GE Engine Systems, Inc. were
    converted into a $54&#160;million unsecured term note. The
    original note balance of $54&#160;million was reduced by a
    credit of $9.4&#160;million as a result of the merger. Interest
    on the note accrues at LIBOR plus 4%, and becomes payable
    beginning in January 2008, at which time principal and interest
    payments are due in 48&#160;monthly installments.</TD>

    whole or in part, on any interest payment date at the following

    August&#160;8, 2005 amending AWA&#146;s co-branded credit card

    the amended credit card agreement, Juniper agreed to offer and
    market an airline mileage award credit card program to the
    general public to participate in US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s
    Dividend Miles program through the use of a co-branded credit
    card.</TD>

    termination under its agreement with Bank of America and that
    notice will become effective on December&#160;28, 2007. Pending
    termination of the Bank of America agreement, both Juniper and
    Bank of America will run separate credit card programs for
    US&#160;Airways Group. The amended credit card agreement is the
    subject of pending litigation filed by Bank of America against
    US&#160;Airways Group, US&#160;Airways and AWA (See
    Note&#160;10(d)).</TD>

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<P>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    the expiration date, which is the later of December&#160;31,
    2012 or seven years from the date on which Juniper commences
    marketing to the general public.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Under the amended credit card agreement, Juniper will pay to
    US&#160;Airways Group fees for each mile awarded to each credit
    card account administered by Juniper, subject to certain
    exceptions. Pursuant to the original credit card agreement,
    Juniper paid to AWA a bonus of $20&#160;million. Juniper also
    agreed to pay a one-time bonus payment of $130&#160;million,
    following the effectiveness of the merger, subject to certain
    conditions. The $130&#160;million bonus payment was made to AWA
    on October&#160;3, 2005. The entire $150&#160;million balance
    for bonus payments are included in &#147;Deferred gains and
    other liabilities&#148; in the accompanying consolidated balance
    sheets as of December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005. US&#160;Airways
    Group will not recognize any revenue from the bonus payments
    until the dual branding period has expired, approximately
    February 2008. At that time the Company expects to begin
    recognizing revenue from the bonus payments on a straight-line
    basis through December 2012, the expiration date of the Juniper
    agreement. Further, if Juniper is not granted exclusivity to
    offer a co-branded credit card after the dual branding period,
    US&#160;Airways Group must repay the bonus payments and
    repurchase unused pre-paid miles with interest, plus a
    $50&#160;million penalty. Juniper will pay an annual bonus of
    $5&#160;million to US&#160;Airways Group, subject to certain
    exceptions, for each year after Juniper becomes the exclusive
    issuer of the co-branded credit card.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    On October&#160;3, 2005, Juniper pre-paid for miles from
    US&#160;Airways Group totaling $325&#160;million, subject to the
    same conditions as apply to the $130&#160;million bonus payment.
    To the extent that these miles are not used by Juniper as
    allowed under the co-branded credit card program in certain
    circumstances, US&#160;Airways Group will repurchase these miles
    in 12 equal quarterly installments beginning on the fifth year
    prior to the expiration date of the co-branded credit card
    agreement with Juniper until paid in full. US&#160;Airways Group
    makes monthly interest payments at LIBOR plus 4.75% to Juniper,
    beginning on November&#160;1, 2005, based on the amount of
    pre-purchased miles that have not been used by Juniper in
    connection with the co-branded credit card program and have not
    been repurchased by US&#160;Airways Group. US&#160;Airways Group
    will be required to repurchase pre-purchased miles under certain
    reductions in the collateral held under the credit card
    processing agreement with JP Morgan Chase Bank, N.A.
    Accordingly, the prepayment has been recorded as additional
    indebtedness.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Juniper requires US&#160;Airways Group to maintain an average
    quarterly balance of cash, cash equivalents and short-term
    investments of at least $1&#160;billion for the entirety of the
    agreement. Further, the agreement requires US&#160;Airways Group
    to maintain certain financial ratios beginning January&#160;1,
    2006. Juniper may, at its option, terminate the amended credit
    card agreement, make payments to US&#160;Airways Group under the
    amended credit card agreement in the form of pre-purchased miles
    rather than cash, or require US&#160;Airways Group to repurchase
    the pre-purchased miles before the fifth year prior to the
    expiration date of the co-branded credit card agreement with
    Juniper in the event that US&#160;Airways Group breaches its
    obligations under the amended credit card agreement, or upon the
    occurrence of certain events.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (l) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In connection with US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s emergence from
    bankruptcy in September 2005, it reached a settlement with the
    PBGC related to the termination of three of its defined benefit
    pension plans. The settlement included the issuance of a
    $10&#160;million note which matures in 2012 and bears interest
    at 6% payable annually in arrears.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    105
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
