<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Certain of US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s long-term debt
    agreements contain minimum cash balance requirements and other
    covenants with which the Company was in compliance at
    December&#160;31, 2006. Certain of US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s
    long-term debt agreements contain cross-default provisions,
    which may be triggered by defaults by AWA or US&#160;Airways
    Group under other agreements relating to indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Interest rates on $1.94&#160;billion principal amount of
    long-term debt as of December&#160;31, 2006 are subject to
    adjustment to reflect changes in floating interest rates. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, the weighted average effective interest
    rate was 8.95% for the variable interest rate debt.
</DIV>

    certain service and other requirements are eligible to
    participate in various pension, medical, dental, life insurance,

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(a)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Defined
    Benefit and Other Postretirement Benefit Plans</FONT></I></B>
</TD>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Prior to the merger, America West Holdings had no obligations
    for defined benefit or other postretirement benefit plans. The
    following table sets forth changes in the fair value of plan
    assets, benefit obligations and the funded status of the plans
    acquired by the Company on September&#160;27, 2005 as of
    December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005 (in millions). As discussed in
    Note&#160;1(s), effective December&#160;31, 2006, the Company
    adopted the recognition provisions of SFAS&#160;158. In
    accordance with SFAS&#160;158, the Company recognized a
    liability for the underfunded status of its postretirement
    benefit plans of $215&#160;million, of which $187&#160;million
    is noncurrent, and the underfunded status of its pension plans
    of $14&#160;million, of which $13&#160;million is noncurrent.
    The Company has also recognized an increase of $3&#160;million
    in accumulated other comprehensive income at December&#160;31,
    2006 associated with the net actuarial gain on its pension and
    other postretirement plans. Future changes to the funded status
    of these plans will be recognized in the year which the change
    occurs through other comprehensive income. Prior to the adoption
    of the recognition provisions of SFAS&#160;158, the Company
    accounted for its defined benefit pension and post-retirement
    benefit plans
</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    For plans with accumulated benefit obligations in excess of plan
    assets, the aggregate accumulated benefit obligations, projected
    benefit obligations and plan assets were $57&#160;million,
    $59&#160;million and $45&#160;million, as of December&#160;31,
    2006 and $56&#160;million, $60&#160;million and
    $37&#160;million, as of December&#160;31, 2005, respectively.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table presents the weighted average assumptions
    used to determine benefit obligations:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, the Company discounted
    its pension obligations based on the current rates earned on
    high quality Aa rated long-term bonds.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company assumed discount rates for measuring its other
    postretirement benefit obligations, based on a hypothetical
    portfolio of high quality publicly traded U.S.&#160;bonds (Aa
    rated, non-callable or callable with make-whole provisions), for
    which the timing and cash outflows approximate the estimated
    benefit payments of the other postretirement benefit plans.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of September&#160;30, 2006, the assumed health care cost
    trend rates are 10% in 2007 and 9% in 2008, decreasing to 5.5%
    in 2012 and thereafter. As of September&#160;30, 2005, the
    assumed health care cost trend rates were
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    107
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    10% in 2006 and 9% in 2007, decreasing to 5% in 2011 and
    thereafter. The assumed health care cost trend rates could have
    a significant effect on amounts reported for retiree health care
    plans. A one-percentage point change in the health care cost
    trend rates would have the following effects on other
    postretirement benefits as of September&#160;30, 2006 (in
    millions):
</DIV>

<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">

</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As discussed above, $3&#160;million has been included in
    accumulated other comprehensive income that has not been
    recognized in the net periodic benefit cost of the
    Company&#146;s pension plans and other post retirement benefit
    plans at December&#160;31, 2006. Components of the net and total
    periodic cost for pension and other post retirement benefits (in
    millions):
</DIV>

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2007, the Company expects to contribute $1&#160;million and
    $29&#160;million to its defined benefit pension plans and other
    postretirement plans, respectively. The following benefits,
    which reflect expected future service, as appropriate, are
    expected to be paid from the other postretirement plans (in
    millions):

&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>

</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>

    &#151;
</TD>

</TR>

    </FONT>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company assumed that its pension plans&#146; assets would
    generate a long-term rate of return of 8% at December&#160;31,
    2006 and December&#160;31, 2005. The expected long-term rate of
    return assumption was developed by evaluating input from the
    plans&#146; investment consultants, including their review of
    asset class return expectations and long-term inflation
    assumptions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company&#146;s targeted asset allocation as of
    December&#160;31, 2006 is approximately 70% equity securities,
    25% debt securities and 5% other. The Company believes that its
    long-term asset allocation on average will approximate the
    targeted allocation. The Company regularly reviews its actual
    asset allocation and periodically rebalances its investments to
    its targeted allocation when considered appropriate.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(b)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Defined
    Contribution Plans</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company sponsors several defined contribution plans for
    certain employees. The Company makes cash contributions to
    certain plans based on the employee&#146;s age, compensation, a
    match that is annually determined by the Board of Directors, and
    elected contributions. The Company also participates in a
    multi-employer plan for certain employees. Expenses related to
    these plans, excluding expenses related to the Company&#146;s
    pilot defined contribution plans (see below), were approximately
    $28&#160;million, $16&#160;million and $11&#160;million for the
    years ended December&#160;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with its first reorganization under
    Chapter&#160;11 of the Bankruptcy Code, US&#160;Airways
    terminated the Retirement Income Plan for Pilots of
    US&#160;Airways, Inc. and the related nonqualified pilot plan
    effective March&#160;31, 2003. The Company implemented a
    qualified and nonqualified defined contribution plan for pilots
    effective April&#160;1, 2003. The defined contribution amount
    was individually determined based on a target normal retirement
    date balance of approximately $1&#160;million for a career
    US&#160;Airways pilot. The target balance included the estimated
    value of other retirement benefits including, but not limited
    to, the estimated benefit pilots are expected to receive from
    the PBGC, the trustee for the terminated pilot defined benefit
    plan. Effective October&#160;15, 2004, each pilot&#146;s
    contribution rate became the lesser of the original rate or 10%
    of eligible compensation. Expenses for this plan were
    $42&#160;million for 2006, $16&#160;million for 2005 and
    $11&#160;million for 2004 and are included in the Company&#146;s
    consolidated financial results.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Effective January&#160;1, 2005 America West Holdings amended its
    defined contribution plan, requiring AWA to make a non-elective
    discretionary employer contribution equal to 7% of the annual
    compensation for each pilot covered under the collective
    bargaining agreement between AWA and the Air Line Pilots
    Association (as defined in the plan and subject to statutory
    annual maximums). Effective January&#160;1, 2006 the
    non-elective discretionary employer contribution was increased
    to 10% of each pilot&#146;s annual compensation. These
    non-elective discretionary employer contributions replace the
    existing AWA company match under the 401(k) defined contribution
    plan for pilots. The AWA company match continues for all other
    eligible covered employees under the plan. AWA&#146;s
    contribution expense to this plan totaled $19&#160;million and
    $13&#160;million for 2006 and 2005, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(c)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Postemployment
    Benefits</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company provides certain postemployment benefits to its
    employees. These benefits include disability-related and
    workers&#146; compensation benefits for certain employees. The
    Company accrues for the cost of such benefit expenses once an
    appropriate triggering event has occurred.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(d)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Profit
    Sharing Plans</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Most non-executive employees of US&#160;Airways Group are
    eligible to participate in the 2005 Profit Sharing Plan, an
    annual bonus program, which was established subsequent to the
    merger. Annual bonus awards are paid from a profit-sharing pool
    equal to (i)&#160;ten percent of the annual profits of
    US&#160;Airways Group (excluding unusual items) for pre-tax
    profit margins up to ten percent, plus (ii)&#160;15% of the
    annual profits of US&#160;Airways Group (excluding unusual
    items) for pre-tax profit margins greater than ten percent.
    Awards are paid as a lump sum no later than March 15 after the
    end of each fiscal year. The profit-sharing pool is shared among
    eligible employee groups in proportion to each group&#146;s
    share of overall cost savings achieved through
    US&#160;Airways&#146; 2005 transformation plan; however, the
    represented pilots&#146; and flight attendants&#146; portions of
    the pool will not be less than 36% and 14.5%, respectively. An
    employee&#146;s share of the pool is based on the ratio that the
    employee&#146;s compensation bears to the respective employee
    group&#146;s aggregate compensation. The Company recorded
    $59&#160;million for profit sharing in 2006, which is recorded
    in salaries and related costs.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">9.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Income
    Taxes</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company accounts for income taxes according to the
    provisions in SFAS&#160;No.&#160;109, &#147;Accounting for
    Income Taxes.&#148; The Company files a consolidated federal
    income tax return with its wholly owned subsidiaries. The
    Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries allocate tax and tax
    items, such as net operating losses (&#147;NOL&#148;) and net
    tax credits, between members of the group based on their
    proportion of taxable income and other items. Accordingly, the
    Company&#146;s tax expense is based on taxable income, taking
    into consideration allocated tax loss carryforwards/carrybacks
    and tax credit carryforwards.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In assessing the realizability of the deferred tax assets,
    management considers whether it is more likely than not that
    some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will be realized.
    The Company has recorded a valuation allowance against its net
    deferred tax asset. The ultimate realization of deferred tax
    assets is dependent upon the generation of future taxable income
    (including reversals of deferred tax liabilities) during the
    periods in which those temporary differences will become
    deductible.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group has
    available NOL and tax credit carryforwards for federal income
    tax purposes of approximately $980&#160;million and
    $37&#160;million, respectively. The NOL expires during the years
    2022 through 2025. Accordingly, approximately $795&#160;million
    of the NOL is available to shelter federal taxable income in the
    calendar year 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2006, US&#160;Airways utilized NOL that was generated
    prior to the merger. In accordance with SFAS&#160;No.&#160;109,
    as this was acquired NOL, the corresponding decrease in the
    valuation allowance reduced goodwill instead of the provision
    for income taxes. Accordingly, the Company recognized
    $85&#160;million of non-cash tax expense for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006. As of December&#160;31, 2006, the
    remaining valuation allowance associated with acquired NOL is
    $29&#160;million related to state NOL.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company is subject to Alternative Minimum Tax liability
    (&#147;AMT&#148;) for the full year 2006. In most cases, the
    recognition of AMT does not result in tax expense. However,
    since the Company&#146;s NOL was subject to a full valuation
    allowance, any liability for AMT is recorded as tax expense. The
    Company recorded AMT expense of $10&#160;million for the year
    ended December&#160;31, 2006. The Company also recorded
    $2&#160;million of state income tax related to certain states
    where NOL was not available or limited, for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways is part of the US&#160;Airways Group
    consolidated income tax return for the tax year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006. AWA is included in America West
    Holdings&#146; consolidated income tax returns for the periods
    ending on December&#160;31, 2004 and for the period beginning
    January&#160;1, 2005 and ending on September&#160;27, 2005, the
    date of the merger. America West Holdings and AWA, as part of
    the merger, became members of the consolidated US&#160;Airways
    Group on September&#160;28, 2005. The current tax provision for
    the year ended December&#160;31, 2006 was prepared in accordance
    with this tax return methodology.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    110
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The reason for significant differences between taxable and
    pretax book income primarily relates to depreciation on fixed
    assets, employee pension and postretirement benefit costs,
    employee-related accruals and leasing transactions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The federal income tax returns of the Company through 2002 have
    been examined and settled with the Internal Revenue Service.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company is not currently under examination.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">10.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Commitments
    and Contingencies</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(a)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Commitments
    to Purchase Flight Equipment and Maintenance
    Services</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Airbus
    Purchase Commitments</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In August 2006, AWA amended its
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A320/A319</FONT>
    Purchase Agreement with Airbus to add seven new Airbus A321s to
    an existing order for thirty A320 family aircraft. The amendment
    also converted one A320 aircraft and seven A319 aircraft to an
    order of eight A321 aircraft. Deliveries of the 15 new A321
    aircraft will begin in 2008 and run through 2010. The new A321s
    will be configured to accommodate up to 187 passengers in two
    classes of service and will be used for replacement purposes or
    modest expansion should market conditions warrant.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    112
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    To modernize the Company&#146;s international product and
    improve the efficiency of its international network, the Company
    was scheduled to begin accepting deliveries of Airbus A350
    aircraft in 2011 pursuant to a purchase agreement that
    US&#160;Airways Group, US&#160;Airways and AWA entered into in
    September 2005 with Airbus. US&#160;Airways Group has been
    notified that the A350 will be undergoing significant design
    changes and will be delivered several years beyond the
    originally scheduled delivery dates. The Company is currently
    evaluating the revised technical and commercial aspects of the
    A350 program.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In September 2005, the Company amended its
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A330/340</FONT>
    Purchase Agreement with Airbus dated as of November&#160;24,
    1998 to reschedule the order for ten A330-200 aircraft for
    delivery during the period 2009 and 2010. The Company has the
    right to cancel these A330 orders in the event that
    US&#160;Airways makes certain predelivery payments under the
    A350 Purchase Agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The future commitments under the purchase agreements with Airbus
    and US&#160;Airways&#160;Group totals $3.27&#160;billion as of
    December&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Embraer
    Purchase Commitments</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On June&#160;13, 2006, the Company executed an Amended and
    Restated Purchase Agreement and an Amended and Restated Letter
    Agreement with Embraer. In accordance with the terms of these
    agreements, the Company placed an initial firm order for 25
    Embraer 190 aircraft and an additional firm order for 32 Embraer
    190 aircraft. The progress and deposit payments totaling
    approximately $18&#160;million previously paid by the Company to
    Embraer in accordance with the terms of the Purchase Agreement
    dated as of May&#160;9, 2003, will be applied to these orders in
    accordance with the terms of the amended and restated
    agreements. In addition, the Company has the option to purchase
    up to 50 additional Embraer 190 aircraft and to convert certain
    of the Embraer 190 aircraft to Embraer 170, Embraer 175 or
    Embraer 195 aircraft, subject to availability and upon agreed
    notice. Embraer has agreed to provide financing for certain of
    the aircraft. On July&#160;21, 2006, the Company assigned 30 of
    the purchase options to Republic. On January&#160;12, 2007, the
    Company assigned eight additional purchase options to Republic.
    The Company purchased and took delivery of two Embraer 190
    aircraft in December 2006 and expects to take delivery of nine
    Embraer 190 aircraft in 2007 and 14 Embraer 190 aircraft in
    2008. The future commitments under the purchase agreement with
    Embraer and US&#160;Airways&#160;Group totals $661&#160;million
    as of December&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Bombardier
    Purchase Commitments</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On December&#160;14, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court approved a
    Global Settlement Letter between US&#160;Airways Group and
    Bombardier Inc., which had been executed by the parties on
    November&#160;10, 2006. The Global Settlement Letter amends the
    master purchase agreement dated as of May&#160;9, 2003, as
    amended, between US&#160;Airways Group and Bombardier. The
    Bankruptcy Court authorized the assumption of the master
    purchase agreement, as modified and amended by the Global
    Settlement Letter. The parties agreed to modify and amend the
    master purchase agreement to terminate all obligations of
    US&#160;Airways Group to purchase and take delivery of 42 firm
    aircraft remaining undelivered under the agreement, as well as
    the rights of US&#160;Airways Group to purchase and take
    delivery of 90 additional aircraft and options to take 94
    aircraft in the future. All obligations of Bombardier to
    manufacture and deliver these aircraft were also terminated. The
    master purchase agreement was amended to provide US&#160;Airways
    Group with the right to purchase Bombardier CRJ 200/700/900
    series aircraft from time to time during a period of five years.
    The Global Settlement Letter further provides that all
    pre-delivery payments held by Bombardier be returned to
    US&#160;Airways Group. Under the Global Settlement Letter, all
    claims of Bombardier asserted against US&#160;Airways Group and
    its subsidiaries in the Chapter&#160;11 cases were resolved and
    Bombardier was granted a total aggregate allowed general
    unsecured claim in the amount of $148&#160;million. As a result
    of the settlement, the Company recorded an $11&#160;million gain
    reflected in special items, net on the 2006&#160;statement of
    operations. The effects of distributions for general unsecured
    claims were reflected in US&#160;Airways&#146; financial
    statements upon emergence and will not have any further impact
    on the results of operations.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    113
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.<BR>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Engine
    Maintenance Commitments</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with the merger, US&#160;Airways and AWA
    restructured their rate per engine hour agreements with General
    Electric Engine Services for overhaul maintenance services.
    Under the restructured agreements, the minimum monthly payment
    on account of accrued engine flight hours for both the
    US&#160;Airways and AWA agreements together will equal
    $3&#160;million as long as both agreements remain in effect
    through October 2009.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(b)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Leases</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company leases certain aircraft, engines, and ground
    equipment, in addition to the majority of its ground facilities
    and terminal space. As of December&#160;31, 2006, the Company
    had 376 aircraft under operating leases, with remaining terms
    ranging from one month to approximately 18&#160;years. Ground
    facilities include executive offices, maintenance facilities and
    ticket and administrative offices. Public airports are utilized
    for flight operations under lease arrangements with the
    municipalities or agencies owning or controlling such airports.
    Substantially all leases provide that the lessee must pay taxes,
    maintenance, insurance and certain other operating expenses
    applicable to the leased property. Some leases also include
    renewal and purchase options.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, obligations under noncancelable
    operating leases for future minimum lease payments were as
    follows (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For the years ended December&#160;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004,
    rental expense under operating leases, excluding landing fees,
    was $1.24&#160;billion, $632&#160;million and $421&#160;million,
    respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&#160;million loan supported
    by a $380&#160;million government loan guarantee from the ATSB
    that resulted in a restructuring of its aircraft lease
    commitments. Under the restructured lease agreements, annual
    rent payments have been reduced through January 2007. Certain of
    these leases contain put options pursuant to which the lessors
    could require AWA to renew the leases for periods up to
    approximately nine&#160;years or call options pursuant to which
    the lessors could require AWA to return the aircraft to the
    lessors upon receipt of six to nine months written notice. The
    Company also has options to purchase certain of the aircraft at
    fair market values at the end of the lease terms. Certain of the
    agreements require security deposits, minimum return provisions
    and supplemental rent payments.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA and US&#160;Airways have set up pass through trusts, which
    have issued pass through trust certificates (also known as
    &#147;Enhanced Equipment Trust&#160;Certificates&#148; or
    &#147;EETCs&#148;) covering the financing of 19 owned aircraft
    and 116 leased aircraft. These trusts are off-balance sheet
    entities, the primary purpose of which is to finance the
    acquisition of aircraft. Rather than finance each aircraft
    separately when such aircraft is purchased or delivered, these
    trusts allow the Company to raise the financing for several
    aircraft at one time and place such funds in escrow pending the
    purchase or delivery of the relevant aircraft. The trusts are
    also structured to provide for certain credit enhancements, such
    as liquidity facilities to cover certain interest payments, that
    reduce the risks to the purchasers of the trust certificates
    and, as a result, reduce the cost of aircraft financing to the
    Company.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Each trust covered a set amount of aircraft scheduled to be
    delivered within a specific period of time. At the time of each
    covered aircraft financing, the relevant trust used the funds in
    escrow to purchase equipment notes
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    114
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    relating to the financed aircraft. The equipment notes were
    issued, at AWA or US&#160;Airways&#146; election, either by AWA
    or US&#160;Airways in connection with a mortgage financing of
    the aircraft or by a separate owner trust in connection with a
    leveraged lease financing of the aircraft. In the case of a
    leveraged lease financing, the owner trust then leased the
    aircraft to AWA or US&#160;Airways. In both cases, the equipment
    notes are secured by a security interest in the aircraft. The
    pass through trust certificates are not direct obligations of,
    nor are they guaranteed by, US&#160;Airways Group, AWA or
    US&#160;Airways. However, in the case of mortgage financings,
    the equipment notes issued to the trusts are direct obligations
    of AWA and US&#160;Airways and in the case of leveraged lease
    financings, the leases are direct obligations of AWA and
    US&#160;Airways. Neither US&#160;Airways Group, AWA nor
    US&#160;Airways guarantee or participate in any way in the
    residual value of the leased aircraft. All of the AWA aircraft
    financed by these trusts are currently structured as leveraged
    lease financings, which are not reflected as debt on the balance
    sheet of AWA. AWA does not provide residual value guarantees
    under these lease arrangements. A portion of the US&#160;Airways
    aircraft financed by these trusts are mortgage financings, and
    as of December&#160;31, 2006, $615&#160;million is reflected as
    debt in the accompanying balance sheets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    These leasing entities meet the criteria for variable interest
    entities. However, they do not meet the consolidation criteria
    under FIN&#160;46(R) because the Company is not the primary
    beneficiary under these arrangements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(c)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Regional
    Jet Capacity Purchase Agreements</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company has entered into capacity purchase agreements with
    certain regional jet operators. The capacity purchase agreements
    provide that all revenues (passenger, mail and freight) go to
    the Company. In return, the Company agrees to pay predetermined
    fees to the regional airlines for operating an agreed upon
    number of aircraft, without regard to the number of passengers
    onboard. In addition, these agreements provide that certain
    variable costs, such as fuel and airport landing fees, will be
    reimbursed 100% by the Company. The Company controls marketing,
    scheduling, ticketing, pricing and seat inventories. The
    regional jet capacity purchase agreements have expirations from
    2012 to 2020 and provide for optional extensions at the
    Company&#146;s discretion. The future minimum noncancelable
    commitments under the regional jet capacity purchase agreements
    are $1.57&#160;billion in 2007, $1.73&#160;billion in 2008,
    $1.79&#160;billion in 2009, $1.83&#160;billion in 2010,
    $1.86&#160;billion in 2011 and $7.57&#160;billion thereafter.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Certain entities with which the Company has capacity purchase
    agreements are considered variable interest entities under
    FIN&#160;46(R). In connection with its restructuring and
    emergence from bankruptcy, US&#160;Airways contracted with Air
    Wisconsin, a related party, and Republic to purchase a
    significant portion of these companies&#146; regional jet
    capacity for a period of ten years. The Company has determined
    that it is not the primary beneficiary of these variable
    interest entities, based on cash flow analyses. Additionally,
    other carriers with which US&#160;Airways has long-term capacity
    purchase agreements fall under the business scope exception of
    FIN&#160;46(R); therefore, US&#160;Airways does not consolidate
    any of the entities with which it has jet service agreements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(d)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Legal
    Proceedings</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On September&#160;12, 2004, US&#160;Airways Group and its
    domestic subsidiaries (the &#147;Reorganized Debtors&#148;)
    filed voluntary petitions for relief under Chapter&#160;11 of
    the Bankruptcy Code in the United States Bankruptcy Court for
    the Eastern District of Virginia, Alexandria Division (Case Nos.
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">04-13819-SSM</FONT>
    through
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">03-13823-SSM)</FONT>
    (the &#147;2004 Bankruptcy&#148;). On September&#160;16, 2005,
    the Bankruptcy Court issued an order confirming the plan of
    reorganization submitted by the Reorganized Debtors and on
    September&#160;27, 2005, the Reorganized Debtors emerged from
    the 2004 Bankruptcy. The Bankruptcy Court&#146;s order
    confirming the plan included a provision called the plan
    injunction, which forever bars other parties from pursuing most
    claims against the Reorganized Debtors that arose prior to
    September&#160;27, 2005 in any forum other than the Bankruptcy
    Court. The great majority of these claims are pre-petition
    claims that, if paid out at all, will be paid out in common
    stock of the post-bankruptcy US&#160;Airways Group at a fraction
    of the actual claim amount.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    115
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On February&#160;26, 2004, a company called I.A.P. Intermodal,
    LLC filed suit against US&#160;Airways Group and its wholly
    owned airline subsidiaries in the United States District Court
    for the Eastern District of Texas alleging that the
    defendants&#146; computer scheduling system infringes upon three
    patents held by plaintiffs, all of which patents are entitled,
    &#147;Method to Schedule a Vehicle in Real-Time to Transport
    Freight and Passengers.&#148; Plaintiff seeks various injunctive
    relief as well as costs, fees and treble damages.
    US&#160;Airways Group and its subsidiaries were formally served
    with the complaint on June&#160;21, 2004. On the same date, the
    same plaintiff filed what US&#160;Airways Group believes to be
    substantially similar cases against nine other major airlines,
    including British Airways, Northwest Airlines Corporation,
    Korean Airlines Co., Ltd., Deutsche Lufthansa AG, Air France,
    Air Canada, Singapore Airlines Ltd., Delta Air Lines and
    Continental Airlines, Inc., and had filed a suit against AMR
    Group, Inc., the parent company of American Airlines, along with
    its airline subsidiaries, in December 2003. This action has been
    stayed as to US&#160;Airways Group and its wholly owned
    subsidiaries as a result of the 2004 Bankruptcy. In the
    meantime, several foreign airline defendants were dismissed from
    the case for reasons unique to their status as foreign
    operators, and the remaining defendants in September 2005
    obtained a ruling that there had been no infringement of any of
    I.A.P.&#146;s patents. In October 2005, I.A.P. entered into
    consent judgments with several defendants. I.A.P. appealed the
    judgment in favor of Continental Airlines and the AMR Group
    defendants, but the trial court&#146;s ruling was affirmed on
    November&#160;13, 2006. No further appeals have been taken.
    I.A.P. did not file any claims against US&#160;Airways Group or
    any of its subsidiaries in the 2004 Bankruptcy.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On January&#160;7, 2003, the Internal Revenue Service
    (&#147;IRS&#148;) issued a notice of proposed adjustment to
    US&#160;Airways Group proposing to disallow $573&#160;million of
    capital losses that US&#160;Airways Group sustained in the tax
    year 1999 on the sale of stock of USLM Corporation (the
    &#147;USLM matter&#148;). On February&#160;5, 2003, the IRS
    filed a proof of claim with the Bankruptcy Court in connection
    with the bankruptcy case filed on August&#160;11, 2002 (the
    &#147;2002 Bankruptcy&#148;) asserting the following claims
    against US&#160;Airways with respect to the USLM matter:
    (1)&#160;secured claims for U.S.&#160;federal income tax and
    interest of $1&#160;million; (2)&#160;unsecured priority claims
    for U.S.&#160;federal income tax of $68&#160;million and
    interest of $14&#160;million; and (3)&#160;an unsecured general
    claim for penalties of $25&#160;million. On May&#160;8, 2003,
    US&#160;Airways Group reached a tentative agreement with the IRS
    on the amount of U.S.&#160;federal income taxes, interest and
    penalties due subject to final approval from the Joint Committee
    on Taxation. By letter dated September&#160;11, 2003,
    US&#160;Airways Group was notified that the Joint Committee on
    Taxation had accepted the tentative agreement with the IRS,
    including a settlement of all federal income taxes through the
    end of 2002. Due to the 2004 Bankruptcy filing, which suspended
    payment of prepetition liabilities, final payment terms under
    the agreement have not been submitted to the Bankruptcy Court
    for approval. The IRS has submitted a proof of claim relating to
    the USLM matter in the 2004 Bankruptcy in the amount of
    approximately $31&#160;million, and on August&#160;2, 2005 the
    IRS filed a motion for relief from the automatic stay seeking to
    setoff against approximately $4&#160;million of tax refunds due
    to the Reorganized Debtors. On October&#160;20, 2005, the IRS
    filed an amended proof of claim reducing its claim in the USLM
    matter to $11&#160;million. On November&#160;3, 2005, the IRS
    filed an amended motion continuing to seek relief for the
    $4&#160;million setoff. US&#160;Airways and the IRS have reached
    an agreement to settle the USLM matter whereby the IRS would
    setoff approximately $4.5&#160;million of tax refunds and the
    IRS would be allowed an unsecured priority claim in the amount
    of approximately $6.5&#160;million, payable within 30&#160;days
    after the agreement is filed with the Bankruptcy Court. The
    agreement was filed with the Bankruptcy Court on
    February&#160;15, 2007 and the matter is now closed.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On February&#160;8, 2006, 103 flight attendants employed by the
    former MidAtlantic division of US&#160;Airways filed a complaint
    against the Association of Flight Attendants (&#147;AFA&#148;),
    AFA&#146;s international president Pat Friend and
    US&#160;Airways, alleging that defendants conspired to deceive
    plaintiffs into believing that MidAtlantic was a separate entity
    from US&#160;Airways in order to deprive them of the benefits
    they are due as US&#160;Airways flight attendants pursuant to
    the US&#160;Airways collective bargaining agreement.
    Plaintiffs&#146; claims against US&#160;Airways include breach
    of collective bargaining agreement, violation of the Railway
    Labor Act and racketeering under RICO. Plaintiffs&#146;
    complaint requests $400&#160;million in damages from
    US&#160;Airways and injunctive relief. The complaint was served
    on US&#160;Airways on July&#160;7, 2006. On November&#160;24,
    2006, plaintiffs filed with the district court a notice of
    voluntary
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    116
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways
    Group, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    dismissal of US&#160;Airways from the litigation, and on
    November&#160;27, 2006, US&#160;Airways filed a notice
    withdrawing its motion for sanctions. On December&#160;29, 2006,
    the district court entered an order dismissing US&#160;Airways
    from the litigation.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On October&#160;12, 2005, Bank of America, N.A., which is one of
    the issuing banks of the US&#160;Airways frequent flyer program
    credit card and which also acts as the processing bank for most
    airline ticket purchases paid for with credit cards, filed suit
    in the Delaware Chancery Court in New Castle County against
    US&#160;Airways, US&#160;Airways Group and AWA, alleging that
    US&#160;Airways breached its frequent flyer credit card contract
    with Bank of America by entering into a similar, competing
    agreement with Juniper and allowing Juniper to issue a
    US&#160;Airways frequent flyer credit card. Bank of America also
    alleges that US&#160;Airways Group and AWA induced these
    breaches. Bank of America seeks an order requiring
    US&#160;Airways to market the Bank of America card and prohibit
    Juniper from issuing a US&#160;Airways credit card, as well as
    unspecified damages. On October&#160;27, 2005, Juniper, which
    was not originally a party to the lawsuit, sought and later
    received court permission to intervene as a defendant in the
    case and has made counterclaims against Bank of America. Juniper
    seeks an order declaring the validity of its new agreement to
    issue a US&#160;Airways frequent flyer credit card. On
    November&#160;3, 2005, Bank of America filed a motion for
    partial summary judgment on the breach of contract claim against
    US&#160;Airways. After a series of procedural steps, Bank of
    America&#146;s motion, along with a cross-motion for summary
    judgment filed by Juniper, was heard in the Bankruptcy Court,
    where the case is now pending as an adversary proceeding. On
    January&#160;30, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court ruled that Bank of
    America was equitably estopped from pursuing its claims that
    US&#160;Airways breached its agreement with Bank of America by
    negotiating and entering into the agreement with Juniper. The
    Bankruptcy Court ruled in the alternative that US&#160;Airways
    did not breach its agreement with Bank of America to be the
    exclusive card issuer, but that US&#160;Airways had breached the
    &#147;no shop&#148; provision of the Bank of America agreement
    when US&#160;Airways negotiated with Juniper prior to reaching
    the Juniper agreement. Bank of America sought appeal of that
    ruling while it has continued to pursue certain administrative
    claims against US&#160;Airways in the Bankruptcy Court. The
    resolution of the final two claims that Bank of America made in
    the lawsuit, which are (i)&#160;that AWA tortiously interfered
    with the contractual relationship between US&#160;Airways and
    Bank of America and (ii)&#160;that US&#160;Airways Group and AWA
    tortiously interfered with Bank of America&#146;s right to
    future economic benefit under its agreement with
    US&#160;Airways, are dependent on the outcome of the pending
    appeal. Bank of America will pursue those two claims only if its
    appeal of the January&#160;30, 2006 order is ultimately
    successful. On July&#160;19, 2006, the Eastern District of
    Virginia affirmed the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s order in part,
    ruling that US&#160;Airways did not breach the exclusivity
    provisions of the contract. However, the Eastern District of
    Virginia reversed the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s decision on
    equitable estoppel and remanded the remainder of the case to the
    Bankruptcy Court to take further evidence. Bank of America and
    US&#160;Airways have each appealed the July&#160;19, 2006
    ruling. On January&#160;16, 2007, Bank of America amended its
    complaint to add additional breach of contract and tortious
    interference claims against US&#160;Airways and AWA, as well as
    claims against Juniper.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On February&#160;9, 2007, passengers Daphne Renard and Todd
    Robins filed a class action suit against US&#160;Airways in
    San&#160;Francisco Superior Court. The complaint alleges that
    US&#160;Airways breached its contract of carriage by charging
    additional fares and fees, after the purchase of tickets on the
    usairways.com website, for passengers under two years of age who
    travel as &#147;lap children,&#148; meaning that the child does
    not occupy his or her own seat but travels instead on the lap of
    an accompanying adult. The named plaintiffs allege that they
    purchased international tickets through the website for
    themselves and a lap child. Plaintiffs allege that after
    initially receiving an electronic confirmation that there would
    be no charge for the lap child, they were later charged an
    additional $242.50. The complaint alleges a class period from
    February&#160;9, 2002 to the present. The Company has not yet
    been served with the lawsuit.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company is unable to estimate at this time the amount of
    loss or probable losses, if any, that might result from an
    adverse resolution of the proceedings discussed above, and
    currently is unable to predict whether the outcome of these
    proceedings will have a material adverse effect on its results
    of operations or financial condition. The Company intends,
    however, to vigorously pursue all available defenses and claims
    in these matters.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    117
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
