<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial Statements</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">1.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Basis of
    Presentation and Summary of Significant Accounting
    Policies</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(a)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Nature
    of Operations and Operating Environment</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    America West Airlines, Inc. (&#147;AWA&#148;) is a certificated
    air carrier engaged primarily in the business of transporting
    passengers, property and mail. AWA enplaned approximately
    21&#160;million passengers in 2006. As of December&#160;31,
    2006, AWA operated 133 jet aircraft, along with AWA Express,
    provided regularly scheduled service at 98 airports in the
    continental United States, Alaska, Hawaii, Canada and Latin
    America.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Most of AWA&#146;s operations are in competitive markets.
    Competitors include other air carriers along with other modes of
    transportation. Although a competitive strength in some regards,
    the concentration of significant operations in the western
    U.S.&#160;results in AWA being susceptible to changes in certain
    regional conditions that may have an adverse effect on
    AWA&#146;s financial condition and results of operations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, AWA employed approximately 12,400
    active full-time equivalent employees. Approximately 77% of
    AWA&#146;s employees are covered by collective bargaining
    agreements with various labor unions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(b)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Basis
    of Presentation</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The accompanying consolidated financial statements include the
    accounts of AWA and its wholly owned subsidiary FTCHP, LLC
    (&#147;FTCHP&#148;). AWA is a wholly owned subsidiary of America
    West Holdings Corporation (&#147;America West Holdings&#148;),
    which is a wholly owned subsidiary of US&#160;Airways Group, Inc
    (&#147;US&#160;Airways Group&#148;).
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On May&#160;19, 2005, US&#160;Airways Group signed a merger
    agreement with America West Holdings pursuant to which America
    West Holdings merged with a wholly owned subsidiary of
    US&#160;Airways Group upon US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s
    emergence from bankruptcy on September&#160;27, 2005.
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s plan of reorganization was
    confirmed by the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern
    District of Virginia, Alexandria Division on September&#160;16,
    2005 and became effective on September&#160;27, 2005, the same
    day that the merger with America West Holdings became effective.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group has the ability to move funds freely
    between its operating subsidiaries, including its other
    principal operating subsidiary, US&#160;Airways, Inc.
    (&#147;US&#160;Airways&#148;) to support operations. These
    transfers are recognized as intercompany transactions. In the
    accompanying consolidated statements of cash flows, these
    intercompany transactions are designated as payable to affiliate
    and are classified as financing activities as US&#160;Airways
    Group has no plans to settle these transactions in the near
    term. All significant intercompany balances and transactions
    have been eliminated in consolidation. As discussed further in
    Note&#160;13, AWA&#146;s consolidated financial statements
    include certain related party transactions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Certain prior year amounts have been reclassified to conform
    with the 2006 presentation.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The preparation of financial statements in conformity with
    accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of
    America requires management to make estimates and assumptions
    that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and
    disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of
    the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues
    and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results could
    differ from those estimates. The principal areas of judgment
    relate to passenger revenue recognition, impairment of
    long-lived assets and intangible assets, and accounting for the
    frequent traveler program.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(c)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Cash
    Equivalents and Short-term Investments</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Cash equivalents and short-term investments consist primarily of
    cash in money market securities of various banks, highly liquid
    debt instruments, commercial paper and asset-backed securities
    of various financial institutions and securities backed by the
    U.S.&#160;government. All highly liquid investments purchased
    within three months of
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    136
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    maturity are classified as cash equivalents. Cash equivalents
    are stated at cost, which approximates fair value due to the
    highly liquid nature and short maturities of the underlying
    securities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    All other highly liquid investments with original maturities
    greater than three months but less than one year are classified
    as short-term investments. Debt securities, other than auction
    rate securities, are classified as
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">held-to-maturity</FONT>
    in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards
    (&#147;SFAS&#148;) No.&#160;115, &#147;Accounting for Certain
    Investments in Debt and Equity Securities&#148;
    (&#147;SFAS&#160;115&#148;).
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Held-to-maturity</FONT>
    investments are carried at amortized cost. Investments in
    auction rate securities are classified as available for sale, as
    the terms of the securities exceed one year; however, the
    interest rates are generally reset every 28&#160;days.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(d)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Restricted
    Cash</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Restricted cash includes cash deposits in trust accounts
    primarily to fund certain taxes and fees and collateralize
    letters of credit and workers&#146; compensation claims, cash
    deposits securing certain letters of credit and surety bonds and
    cash deposits held by institutions that process credit card
    sales transactions. Restricted cash is stated at cost, which
    approximates fair value.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(e)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Materials
    and Supplies, Net</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Inventories of materials and supplies are valued at the lower of
    cost or fair value. Costs are determined using average costing
    methods. An allowance for obsolescence is provided for flight
    equipment expendable and repairable parts. These items are
    generally charged to expense when issued for use.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(f)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Property
    and Equipment</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Property and equipment are recorded at cost. Interest expenses
    related to the acquisition of certain property and equipment are
    capitalized as an additional cost of the asset or as a leasehold
    improvement if the asset is leased. Interest capitalized for the
    years ended December&#160;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004 was
    $1&#160;million, $3&#160;million and $2&#160;million,
    respectively. Property and equipment is depreciated and
    amortized to residual values over the estimated useful lives or
    the lease term, whichever is less, using the straight-line
    method. Costs of major improvements that enhance the usefulness
    of the asset are capitalized and depreciated over the estimated
    useful life of the asset or the modifications, whichever is less.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The estimated useful lives range from three to 12&#160;years for
    owned property and equipment and from 18 to 30&#160;years for
    training equipment and buildings. The estimated useful lives of
    owned aircraft, jet engines, flight equipment and rotable parts
    range from five to 25&#160;years. Leasehold improvements
    relating to flight equipment and other property on operating
    leases are amortized over the life of the lease or the life of
    the asset, whichever is shorter.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA records impairment losses on long-lived assets used in
    operations when events and circumstances indicate that the
    assets might be impaired as defined by SFAS&#160;No.&#160;144,
    &#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived
    Assets.&#148; Recoverability of assets to be held and used is
    measured by a comparison of the carrying amount of an asset to
    undiscounted future net cash flows expected to be generated by
    the asset. If such assets are considered to be impaired, the
    impairment to be recognized is measured by the amount by which
    the carrying amount of the assets exceeds the fair value of the
    assets. Assets to be disposed of are reported at the lower of
    the carrying amount or fair value less cost to sell. AWA
    recorded no impairment charges in the years ended
    December&#160;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(g)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Income
    Taxes</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Income taxes are accounted for under the asset and liability
    method. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for
    the future tax consequences attributable to differences between
    the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and
    liabilities and their respective tax bases and operating loss
    and tax credit
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    137
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    carryforwards. A valuation allowance is established, if
    necessary, for the amount of any tax benefits that, based on
    available evidence, are not expected to be realized.
</DIV>

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(i)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Frequent
    Traveler Program</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At the time of the merger, US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s
    principal operating subsidiaries, AWA and US&#160;Airways,
    maintained separate frequent travel award programs known as
    &#147;Flight Fund&#148; and &#147;Dividend Miles,&#148;
    respectively. Following the merger, the two frequent flyer
    programs were modified to allow customers of each airline to
    earn and use miles on the other airline, and in May 2006, the
    two programs were merged into the new Dividend Miles program,
    which is substantially the same as the former US&#160;Airways
    program. As part of the merger of the plans, the accounts of
    members participating in both programs were merged into single
    accounts of the new program. Members of the new Dividend Miles
    program can redeem miles on AWA, US&#160;Airways, or other
    members of the Star Alliance. During the second quarter of 2006,
    AWA recorded $12&#160;million of expense in special items,
    net&#160;&#151; merger related transition expenses to increase
    its estimated cost of providing free travel based on the terms
    of the new Dividend Miles program, principally as a result of
    members of the former FlightFund program gaining access to
    international routes operated by US&#160;Airways and Star
    Alliance members.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The estimated cost of providing the free travel, using the
    incremental cost method as adjusted for estimated redemption
    rates, is recognized as a liability and charged to operations as
    program members accumulate mileage and requisite mileage award
    levels are achieved. For travel awards on partner airlines, the
    liability is based on the average contractual amount to be paid
    to the other airline per redemption. Costs associated with the
    Dividend Miles program are allocated between AWA and
    US&#160;Airways based on mainline RPMs. As of December&#160;31,
    2006, Dividend Miles members had accumulated mileage credits for
    approximately 3.8&#160;million awards. The portion of
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s liability for the future travel
    awards accrued on AWA&#146;s balance sheets within other accrued
    liabilities was $35&#160;million and $10&#160;million as of
    December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA sells mileage credits to participating airline and
    non-airline business partners. Revenue earned from selling
    mileage credits to other companies is recognized in two
    components. A portion of the revenue from these sales is
    deferred, representing the estimated fair value of the
    transportation component of the sold mileage credits. The
    deferred revenue for the transportation component is amortized
    on a straight-line basis over the period in which the credits
    are expected to be redeemed for travel as passenger revenue,
    which is currently estimated to be 28&#160;months. The marketing
    component, which is earned at the time the miles are sold, is
    recognized in other revenues at the time of the sale. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, AWA had $11&#160;million and
    $10&#160;million, respectively, in deferred revenue from the
    sale of mileage credits included in other accrued liabilities on
    its balance sheets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(j)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Derivative
    Instruments</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA utilizes financial derivative instruments primarily to
    manage its risk associated with changing jet fuel prices. All
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s fuel hedges are placed by AWA and
    therefore recorded on AWA&#146;s financial statements. AWA
    utilizes heating oil-based derivative instruments to hedge a
    portion of its exposure to jet fuel price
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    138
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    increases. These instruments primarily consist of costless
    collars which hedge approximately 29% of US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s 2007 total anticipated jet fuel requirements as of
    December&#160;31, 2006. AWA does not purchase or hold any
    derivative financial instruments for trading purposes.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

    The weighted average collar ranges of the fuel hedges
    outstanding as of December&#160;31, 2006 are as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;133, &#147;Accounting for Derivative
    Instruments and Hedging Activities, as amended,&#148;
    (&#147;SFAS&#160;133&#148;) requires that all derivatives be
    marked to market (fair value) and recorded on the balance sheet.
    Derivatives that are not hedges must be adjusted to fair value
    through income.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, AWA had open fuel hedge
    positions in place, which do not currently qualify for hedge
    accounting under SFAS&#160;133. Accordingly, the derivative
    hedging instruments are recorded as an asset or liability on the
    balance sheet at fair value and any changes in fair value are
    recorded as gains in fuel hedging instruments, net in operating
    expenses in the accompanying consolidated statements of
    operations in the period of change. During 2006, 2005 and 2004,
    AWA recognized a net loss of $79&#160;million and net gains of
    $75&#160;million and $24&#160;million, respectively, related to
    hedging activities. The fair value of AWA&#146;s financial
    derivative instruments at December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005 was a
    net liability of approximately $66&#160;million and a net asset
    of $4&#160;million, respectively. Since AWA&#146;s financial
    derivative instruments are not traded on a market exchange, the
    fair values are determined by the use of valuation models with
    assumptions about commodity prices based on those observed in
    the underlying markets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(k)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Deferred
    Credits</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Rents for operating leases were adjusted to fair market value
    when AWA emerged from bankruptcy in 1994. The net present value
    of the difference between the stated lease rates and the fair
    market rates has been recorded as a deferred credit in the
    accompanying balance sheets. The deferred credit will be
    decreased on a straight-line basis as a reduction in rent
    expense over the applicable lease periods. At December&#160;31,
    2006 and 2005, the unamortized balance of the deferred credit
    was $30&#160;million and $37&#160;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&#160;million loan supported
    by a $380&#160;million government loan guarantee from the Air
    Transportation Stabilization Board (&#147;ATSB&#148;). This loan
    triggered aircraft rent concessions negotiated with
    approximately 20 aircraft lessors. Approximately
    $18&#160;million of aircraft rent, which was accrued as of
    December&#160;31, 2001, was waived by the aircraft lessors. This
    amount has been recorded as a deferred credit in the
    accompanying consolidated balance sheets and is being amortized
    over the remaining lives of the applicable leases as a reduction
    in rent expense. At December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, the
    unamortized balance of the deferred credit was approximately
    $1&#160;million and $3&#160;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(l)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Revenue
    Recognition</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Passenger
    Revenue</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Passenger revenue is recognized when transportation is provided.
    Ticket sales for transportation that has not yet been provided
    are initially recorded as air traffic liability on the balance
    sheet. The air traffic liability represents tickets sold for
    future travel dates and estimated future refunds and exchanges
    of tickets sold for past travel dates. The majority of tickets
    sold are nonrefundable. Tickets that are sold but not flown on
    the travel date may be reused for another flight, up to a year
    from the date of sale, or refunded, if the ticket is refundable,
    after taking into account any cancellation penalties or change
    fees. A small percentage of tickets, or partially used tickets,
    expire unused. Due to complex pricing structures, refund and
    exchange policies, and interline agreements with other airlines,
    certain amounts are recognized in revenue using estimates
    regarding both the timing of the revenue recognition and the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    139
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    amount of revenue to be recognized. These estimates are
    generally based on the analysis of our historical data. AWA and
    members of the airline industry have consistently applied this
    accounting method to estimate revenue from forfeited tickets at
    the date travel was to be provided. Estimated future refunds and
    exchanges included in the air traffic liability are routinely
    evaluated based on subsequent activity to validate the accuracy
    of AWA&#146;s estimates. Any adjustments resulting from periodic
    evaluations of the estimated air traffic liability are included
    in results of operations during the period in which the
    evaluations are completed.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Passenger traffic commissions and related fees are expensed when
    the related revenue is recognized. Passenger traffic commissions
    and related fees not yet recognized are included as a prepaid
    expense.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA purchases the capacity, or ASMs, of Mesa in certain markets.
    Mesa operates regional jet aircraft in these markets as part of
    AWA Express. AWA classifies revenues related to capacity
    purchase arrangements as Express passenger revenues. Liabilities
    related to tickets sold for travel on Mesa are also included in
    AWA&#146;s air traffic liability and are subsequently relieved
    in the same manner as described above.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    See Note&#160;1(i) above for information on the revenue
    recognition for the sale of Dividend Miles.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Cargo
    Revenue</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Cargo revenue is recognized when shipping services for mail and
    other cargo are provided.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Other
    Revenue</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Other revenue includes excess baggage charges, ticket change and
    service fees, commissions earned on tickets sold for flights on
    other airlines, sales of tour packages by the US&#160;Airways
    Vacations division and the marketing component earned from
    selling mileage credits to partners, as discussed in
    Note&#160;1(i)&#160;&#147;Frequent Traveler Program&#148;.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(m)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Stock-based
    Compensation</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Prior to January&#160;1, 2006, AWA accounted for stock-based
    compensation plans in accordance with Accounting Principles
    Board Opinion No.&#160;25, &#147;Accounting for Stock Issued to
    Employees&#148; (&#147;APB&#160;25&#148;) and related
    interpretations. Effective January&#160;1, 2006, AWA adopted
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123R, &#147;Share-Based Payment&#148;
    (&#147;SFAS&#160;123R&#148;), using the modified prospective
    transition method. Under the modified prospective transition
    method, compensation cost is recognized in the financial
    statements beginning with the effective date based on the
    requirements of SFAS&#160;123R for all share-based payments
    granted after that date, and based on the requirements of
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123, &#147;Accounting for Stock Based
    Compensation&#148; (&#147;SFAS&#160;123&#148;) for all unvested
    awards granted prior to the effective date of SFAS&#160;123R.
    Results for prior periods are not restated using the modified
    prospective transition method.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Had US&#160;Airways Group determined compensation cost based on
    the fair value at the grant date for its stock options, stock
    appreciation rights and restricted stock units under
    SFAS&#160;123 for the years ended December&#160;31, 2005 and
    2004 and allocated the compensation expense to AWA for its
    employees participating in the stock option plans, AWA&#146;s
    net loss would have been adjusted to the pro forma amounts
    indicated below (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(n)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Maintenance
    and Repair Costs</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Maintenance and repair costs for owned and leased flight
    equipment are charged to operating expense as incurred. AWA
    historically recorded the cost of major scheduled airframe,
    engine and certain component overhauls
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    140
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    as capitalized assets that were subsequently amortized over the
    periods benefited (referred to as the deferral method).
    US&#160;Airways Group historically charged maintenance and
    repair costs for owned and leased flight equipment to operating
    expense as incurred (direct expense method). In 2005, AWA
    changed its accounting policy from the deferral method to the
    direct expense method. While the deferral method is permitted
    under accounting principles generally accepted in the United
    States of America, US&#160;Airways Group and AWA believe that
    the direct expense method is preferable and the predominant
    method used in the airline industry. The effect of this change
    in accounting for aircraft maintenance and repairs is recorded
    as a cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle (see
    also Note&#160;2, &#147;Change in Accounting Policy for
    Maintenance Costs&#148;).
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(o)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Selling
    Expenses</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Selling expenses include commissions, credit card fees,
    computerized reservations systems fees and advertising and
    promotional expenses. Advertising and promotional expenses are
    expensed when incurred. Advertising and promotional expenses for
    the years ended December&#160;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004 were
    $9&#160;million, $12&#160;million and $10&#160;million,
    respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(p)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Express
    Expenses</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Expenses associated with AWA&#146;s regional alliance agreement
    with Mesa are classified as &#147;Express expenses&#148; on the
    statements of operations. Express expenses on the statements of
    operations consist of the following (in millions):
</DIV>

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(q)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Recent
    Accounting Pronouncements</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In June 2006, the Financial Accounting Standards Board
    (&#147;FASB&#148;) ratified Emerging Issues Task Force Issue
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;06-3</FONT>
    (&#147;EITF
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">06-3&#148;),</FONT>
    &#147;How Taxes Collected from Customers and Remitted to
    Governmental Authorities Should Be Presented in the Income
    Statement (That Is, Gross versus Net Presentation).&#148; The
    scope of EITF
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">06-3</FONT>
    includes any tax assessed by a governmental authority that is
    directly imposed on a revenue-producing transaction between a
    seller and a customer. This issue provides that a company may
    adopt a policy of presenting taxes either gross within revenue
    or net. If taxes subject to this issue are significant, a
    company is required to disclose its accounting policy for
    presenting taxes and the amount of such taxes that are
    recognized on a gross basis. This statement is effective to
    financial reports for interim and annual reporting periods
    beginning after December&#160;15, 2006. AWA adopted EITF
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">06-3</FONT> on
    January&#160;1, 2007. AWA collects various excise taxes on its
    ticket sales, which are accounted for on a net basis. The
    adoption of EITF
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">06-3</FONT> will
    not have a material impact on AWA&#146;s consolidated financial
    statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In September 2006, the FASB issued SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157,
    &#147;Fair Value Measurements.&#148; This standard defines fair
    value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value in
    accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of
    America, and expands disclosure about fair value measurements.
    This pronouncement applies to other accounting standards that
    require or permit fair value measurements. Accordingly, this
    statement does not require any new fair value measurement. This
    statement is effective for fiscal years beginning after
    November&#160;15, 2007, and interim periods within those fiscal
    years. AWA will be required to adopt SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157 in
    the first quarter of fiscal
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    141
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    year 2008. Management is currently evaluating the requirements
    of SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157 and has not yet determined the impact
    on AWA&#146;s consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In September, 2006, the FASB issued FASB Staff Position
    (&#147;FSP&#148;) No.&#160;AUG AIR-1 &#147;Accounting for
    Planned Major Maintenance Activities&#148;. This amends the
    existing major maintenance accounting guidance contained within
    the AICPA Industry Audit Guide &#147;Audits of Airlines&#148;
    and prohibits the use of the accrue in advance method of
    accounting for planned major maintenance activities for owned
    aircraft. The provisions of the announcement are applicable for
    fiscal years beginning after December&#160;15, 2006. AWA
    currently uses the direct expense method of accounting for
    planned major maintenance, an acceptable method under generally
    accepted accounting principles in the United States of America.
    Therefore, the adoption of FSP No.&#160;AUG AIR-1 is not
    expected to have any material impact on AWA&#146;s consolidated
    financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In September 2006, the Securities and Exchange Commission
    (&#147;SEC&#148;) issued Staff Accounting
    Bulletin&#160;No.&#160;108 (&#147;SAB&#160;108&#148;). Due to
    diversity in practice among registrants, SAB&#160;108 expresses
    SEC staff views regarding the process by which misstatements in
    financial statements are evaluated for purposes of determining
    whether financial statement restatement is necessary.
    SAB&#160;108 is effective for fiscal years ending after
    November&#160;15, 2006. AWA has adopted SAB&#160;108 in the
    fourth quarter of 2006 and its adoption had no effect on
    AWA&#146;s consolidated financial statements for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006 or for any prior period presented.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In June 2006, the FASB issued Interpretation No.&#160;48,
    &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes, an
    interpretation of FASB Statement No.&#160;109&#148;
    (&#147;FIN&#160;48&#148;), which clarifies the accounting for
    uncertainty in income taxes recognized in financial statements.
    FIN&#160;48 requires the impact of a tax position to be
    recognized in the financial statements if that position is more
    likely than not of being sustained by the taxing authority. AWA
    will be required to adopt FIN&#160;48 in the first quarter of
    fiscal year 2007. Management has evaluated the requirements of
    FIN&#160;48 and does not expect it to have a material impact on
    AWA&#146;s consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On November&#160;10, 2005, the FASB issued FASB Staff Position
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;FAS&#160;123R-3,</FONT>
    &#147;Transition Election Related to Accounting for Tax Effects
    of Share-Based Payment Awards.&#148; AWA elected to adopt the
    modified prospective method, which is the simplified method
    provided in the FASB Staff Position for calculating the tax
    effects of stock-based compensation pursuant to SFAS&#160;123R.
    The modified prospective method was used to determine the
    beginning balance of the additional paid-in capital pool
    (&#147;APIC pool&#148;) related to the tax effects of employee
    stock-based compensation. Due to AWA&#146;s history of tax net
    operating losses, AWA had no beginning balance in the APIC pool
    at the date of adoption of SFAS&#160;123R on January&#160;1,
    2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA uses the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">&#147;with-and-without&#148;</FONT>
    or &#147;incremental&#148; approach for determining the order in
    which tax benefits derived from the share-based payment awards
    are utilized. Using the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">with-and-without</FONT>
    approach, actual income taxes payable for the period are
    compared to the amount of income taxes that would have been
    payable if there had been no share-based compensation expense
    for tax purposes in excess of the compensation expense
    recognized for financial reporting purposes. As a result of this
    approach, tax net operating loss carry forwards not related to
    share-based compensation are utilized before the current
    period&#146;s share-based compensation deduction. As a result of
    this accounting treatment, AWA has a fully reserved deferred tax
    asset of approximately $22&#160;million related to tax net
    operating loss carry forwards related to deductions for excess
    tax benefits. The benefit of the valuation allowance release
    related to these deductions will be recorded directly to equity
    as additional
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">paid-in-capital</FONT>
    when such benefits are realized.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">2.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Change in
    Accounting Policy for Maintenance Costs</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As discussed in Note&#160;1(n), AWA changed its accounting
    policy from the deferral method to the direct expense method in
    the fourth quarter of 2005. The effect of this change in
    accounting for aircraft maintenance and repairs is recorded as a
    cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle. The
    effect of the change in 2005 was to increase the net loss by
    approximately $48&#160;million. The increase in the
    2005&#160;net loss of $202&#160;million is the cumulative effect
    on retained earnings of the adoption as of January&#160;1, 2005.
    The cumulative effect of the change in accounting
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    142
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    principle is not presented net of tax as any tax effects
    resulting from the change have been immediately offset by the
    recording of a valuation allowance through the same financial
    statement caption.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>

    Special charges included within the statements of operations
    include the following components (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In the third quarter of 2005, in connection with the merger and
    a memorandum of understanding (the &#147;Airbus MOU&#148;)
    executed between AVSA S.A.R.L., an affiliate of Airbus S.A.S.
    (&#147;Airbus&#148;), US&#160;Airways Group, US&#160;Airways and
    AWA, certain aircraft firm orders were restructured. In
    connection with that restructuring, US&#160;Airways Group and
    America West Holdings were required to pay non-refundable
    restructuring fees totaling $89&#160;million by means of set-off
    against existing equipment deposits of US&#160;Airways and AWA
    held by Airbus of $39&#160;million and $50&#160;million
    respectively. AWA&#146;s restructuring fee of $50&#160;million
    has been classified as a special charge, along with
    $7&#160;million in associated capitalized interest. Also in
    connection with the Airbus MOU, US&#160;Airways and AWA entered
    into two loan agreements with aggregate commitments of up to
    $161&#160;million and $89&#160;million. As described in further
    detail in Note&#160;6, on March&#160;31, 2006, the outstanding
    principal and accrued interest on the $89&#160;million loan was
    forgiven upon repayment in full of the $161&#160;million loan in
    accordance with terms of the Airbus loans. As a result, AWA
    recognized a gain associated with the return of these equipment
    deposits upon forgiveness of the loan totaling $51&#160;million,
    consisting of the $50&#160;million in equipment deposits and
    accrued interest of $1&#160;million.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In the third quarter of 2005, a $27&#160;million loss was
    incurred related to the sale-leaseback of six
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-300</FONT>
    aircraft and two 757 aircraft.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In 2006, AWA incurred $68&#160;million of transition and merger
    integration costs. These items included $16&#160;million in
    personnel costs for severance, retention payments and stock
    awards; $12 of costs associated with the integration of the AWA
    FlightFund and US&#160;Airways Dividend Miles frequent traveler
    programs; $1&#160;million in merger related aircraft lease
    return expenses; $15&#160;million of aircraft livery costs;
    $15&#160;million in professional and technical fees;
    $3&#160;million of training related expenses; and
    $6&#160;million of other expenses.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In the fourth quarter of 2005, AWA recorded $13&#160;million of
    merger related expenses related to transitioning the employees,
    systems and facilities of AWA and US&#160;Airways into one
    consolidated company. The $13&#160;million includes insurance
    premiums of $4&#160;million related to policies for former
    officers and directors, compensation expense of $3&#160;million
    for special stock awards, granted under a program designed to
    retain key employees through the integration period,
    professional and technical fees of $3&#160;million and sales and
    marketing program expenses of $2&#160;million related to
    notifying frequent traveler program members about the merger.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In the fourth quarter of 2005, in connection with the return of
    certain leased aircraft, AWA incurred expenses of
    $7&#160;million related to penalties incurred under the
    outsourced maintenance arrangement.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    143
