<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (e) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In the third and fourth quarter of 2005, AWA recorded severance
    expense totaling approximately $2&#160;million for terminated
    employees resulting from the merger.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (f) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In August 2004, AWA entered into definitive agreements with two
    lessors to return six Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT>
    aircraft. Three of these aircraft were returned to the lessors
    in the third quarter of 2004, two were returned in the fourth
    quarter of 2004 and one was returned in January 2005. In
    connection with the return of the aircraft, AWA recorded
    $2&#160;million of special charges in 2004, which include lease
    termination payments of $2&#160;million and the write-down of
    leasehold improvements and aircraft rent balances of
    $3&#160;million, offset by the net reversal of lease return
    provisions of $3&#160;million. In the first quarter of 2005, AWA
    recorded $1&#160;million in special charges related to the final
    Boeing
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">737-200</FONT>
    aircraft which was removed from service in January 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (g) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In the first quarter of 2004, AWA recorded a $1&#160;million
    reduction in special charges related to the revision of
    estimated costs associated with the sale and leaseback of
    certain aircraft.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (h) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In December 2004, AWA and GE mutually agreed to terminate the
    V2500 <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A-1</FONT>
    power by hour (&#147;PBH&#148;) agreement effective
    January&#160;1, 2005. This agreement was entered into March 1998
    with an original term of ten years. For terminating the
    agreement early, AWA received a $20&#160;million credit to be
    applied to amounts due for other engines under the 1998
    agreement. AWA had capitalized PBH payments for V2500
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A-1</FONT> engines
    in excess of the unamortized cost of the overhauls performed by
    GE of approximately $4&#160;million. With the termination of
    this agreement, these payments were not realizable and as a
    result, AWA wrote off this amount against the $20&#160;million
    credit referred to above, resulting in a $16&#160;million net
    gain.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">4.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Stock-based
    Compensation</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Prior to January&#160;1, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group accounted
    for stock-based compensation plans in accordance with
    APB&#160;25 and related interpretations. Effective
    January&#160;1, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group adopted
    SFAS&#160;123R, using the modified prospective transition
    method. Under the modified prospective transition method,
    compensation cost is recognized in the financial statements
    beginning with the effective date based on the requirements of
    SFAS&#160;123R for all share-based payments granted after that
    date, and based on the requirements of SFAS&#160;123 for all
    unvested awards granted prior to the effective date of
    SFAS&#160;123R. Results for prior periods are not restated using
    the modified prospective transition method.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Substantially all of America West Holdings and AWA employee
    stock options outstanding at the time of the merger were fully
    vested in accordance with the change of control provisions of
    America West Holdings&#146; stock option plans and were
    converted into options of US&#160;Airways Group. Existing stock
    options of US&#160;Airways Group outstanding prior to the merger
    on September&#160;27, 2005 were cancelled as part of the plan of
    reorganization. Accordingly, as of January&#160;1, 2006, only
    unvested stock options, stock appreciation rights and restricted
    stock units granted subsequent to and in connection with the
    merger are subject to the transition provisions of
    SFAS&#160;123R. As part of the plan of reorganization, the
    Bankruptcy Court approved a new equity incentive plan, referred
    to as the 2005 Incentive Equity Plan (the &#147;2005 Incentive
    Plan&#148;). The 2005 Incentive Plan provides for the grant of
    incentive stock options, nonstatutory stock options, stock
    appreciation rights, stock purchase awards, stock bonus awards,
    stock unit awards, and other forms of equity compensation,
    collectively referred to as stock awards, as well as
    performance-based cash awards. Incentive stock options granted
    under the 2005 Incentive Plan are intended to qualify as
    &#147;incentive stock options&#148; within the meaning of
    Section&#160;422 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as
    amended. Nonstatutory stock options granted under the 2005
    Incentive Plan are not intended to qualify as incentive stock
    options under the Internal Revenue Code.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    A maximum of 12.5% of the fully-diluted shares (as of the
    completion of the merger) of US&#160;Airways Group common stock
    is available for issuance under the 2005 Incentive Plan,
    totaling 10,969,191&#160;shares. Any or all of these shares may
    be granted pursuant to incentive stock options. Shares of
    US&#160;Airways Group common stock issued under the 2005
    Incentive Plan may be unissued shares or reacquired shares,
    purchased on the open market or otherwise. At December&#160;31,
    2006, approximately 5.5&#160;million shares are available for
    grant under the 2005 Equity Incentive Plan.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    144
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The number of shares of US&#160;Airways Group common stock
    available for issuance under the 2005 Incentive Plan will be
    reduced by (i)&#160;one share for each share of stock issued
    pursuant to a stock option or a stock appreciation right, and
    (ii)&#160;three shares for each share of stock issued pursuant
    to a stock purchase award, stock bonus award, stock unit award,
    and other full-value types of stock awards. Stock awards that
    are terminated, forfeited or repurchased will result in an
    increase in the share reserve of the 2005 Incentive Plan
    corresponding to the reduction originally made in respect of the
    award.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    If a stock award granted under the 2005 Incentive Plan or
    AWA&#146;s previous incentive plan (the &#147;2002 Incentive
    Plan&#148;) expires or otherwise terminates without being
    exercised in full, or if any shares of US&#160;Airways Group
    common stock issued pursuant to a stock award under the 2005
    Incentive Plan are forfeited to or repurchased by
    US&#160;Airways Group, including, but not limited to, any
    repurchase or forfeiture caused by the failure to meet a
    contingency or condition required for the vesting of such
    shares, then the shares of US&#160;Airways Group common stock
    not issued under that stock award, or forfeited to or
    repurchased by US&#160;Airways Group, will revert to and again
    become available for issuance under the 2005 Incentive Plan. If
    any shares subject to a stock award are not delivered to a
    participant because those shares are withheld for the payment of
    taxes or the stock award is exercised through a reduction of
    shares subject to the stock award (i.e., &#147;net
    exercised&#148;), the number of shares that are not delivered
    will remain available for issuance under the 2005 Incentive
    Plan. If the exercise price of any stock award is satisfied by
    tendering shares of US&#160;Airways Group common stock held by
    the participant, then the number of shares so tendered (whether
    by actual tender or by attestation of ownership) will remain
    available for issuance under the 2005 Incentive Plan. Shares of
    US&#160;Airways Group common stock subject to stock awards
    issued in substitution for previously outstanding awards assumed
    in connection with a merger, consolidation or similar
    transaction will not reduce the number of shares available for
    issuance under the 2005 Incentive Plan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s net income for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006 includes $35&#160;million of compensation
    costs related to share-based payments. Of the $35&#160;million
    recorded by US&#160;Airways Group, $12&#160;million was
    allocated to the financials of AWA and $23&#160;million was
    allocated to the financials of US&#160;Airways. Compensation
    expense of $4&#160;million, calculated using the provisions of
    APB&#160;25, was recorded for stock appreciation rights and
    restricted stock units granted to employees of US&#160;Airways
    Group in the fourth quarter of 2005. Of the $4&#160;million
    recorded by US&#160;Airways Group, $3&#160;million was allocated
    to the financials of AWA and $1&#160;million was allocated to
    the financials of US&#160;Airways. Upon adoption of
    SFAS&#160;123R, US&#160;Airways Group recorded a cumulative
    benefit from the accounting change of $1&#160;million, which
    reflects the impact of estimating future forfeitures for
    previously recognized compensation expense. Pursuant to
    APB&#160;25, stock compensation expense was not reduced for
    estimated future forfeitures, but instead was reversed upon
    actual forfeiture. No income tax effect related to share-based
    payments or cumulative effect has been recorded as the effects
    have been immediately offset by the recording of a valuation
    allowance through the same financial statement caption.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Restricted Stock Unit Awards</I>&#160;&#151; As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group has outstanding
    restricted stock unit awards (&#147;RSUs&#148;) with service
    conditions (vesting periods) and RSUs with service and
    performance conditions (vesting periods and obtaining a combined
    operating certificate for AWA and US&#160;Airways).
    SFAS&#160;123R requires that the grant-date fair value of RSUs
    be equal to the market price of the share on the date of grant
    if vesting is based on a service or a performance condition. The
    grant-date fair value of RSU awards that are subject to both a
    service and a performance condition are being expensed over the
    vesting period, as the performance condition is considered
    probable and the vesting periods of the awards are longer than
    the period allowed to meet the performance condition. Vesting
    periods for RSU awards range from two to four years. RSUs are
    classified as equity awards.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    145
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, there was $12&#160;million of
    total unrecognized compensation costs related to RSUs which will
    be allocated to AWA and US&#160;Airways. These costs are
    expected to be recognized over a weighted average period of
    1.1&#160;years. The total fair value of restricted stock awards
    vested during 2006 was $3&#160;million. No restricted stock
    vested during 2005 or 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Stock Options and Stock Appreciation Rights</I>&#160;&#151;
    Stock options and stock appreciation rights (&#147;SARs&#148;)
    are granted with an exercise price equal to the fair market
    value of US&#160;Airways Group common stock at the date of each
    grant and generally become exercisable over a three to four-year
    period and expire if unexercised at the end of ten years. Stock
    options and SARs are classified as equity awards. The exercise
    of SARs will be settled with the issuance of shares of
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s common stock.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    146
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The fair value of stock options and SARs is determined at the
    grant date using a Black-Scholes option pricing model, which
    requires several assumptions. The risk-free interest rate is
    based on the U.S.&#160;Treasury yield curve in effect for the
    expected term of the stock option or SAR at the time of grant.
    The dividend yield is assumed to be zero since US&#160;Airways
    Group does not pay dividends and has no current plans to do so
    in the future. The volatility is based on the historical
    volatility of US&#160;Airways Group common stock over a time
    period equal to the expected term of the stock option or SAR.
    The expected life of stock options and SARs is based on the
    historical experience of US&#160;Airways Group.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The per share weighted-average grant-date fair value of stock
    options and SARs granted and the weighted-average assumptions
    used for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006, 2005, and 2004
    were as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, there was $24&#160;million of
    total unrecognized compensation costs related to stock options
    and SARs which will be allocated to AWA and US&#160;Airways.
    These costs are expected to be recognized over a weighted
    average period of 1.4&#160;years.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The total intrinsic value of stock options and SARs exercised
    during the years ended December&#160;31, 2006, 2005, and 2004
    was $68&#160;million, $13&#160;million, and $1&#160;million,
    respectively. Cash received from stock option and SAR exercises
    during the year ended December&#160;31, 2006 totaled
    $51&#160;million. AWA realized a tax benefit from stock options
    and SARs exercised and RSUs vested and released during 2006 of
    $22&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The carrying amount of cash equivalents approximates fair value
    because of the short-term nature of these instruments. All
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">held-to-maturity</FONT>
    securities mature in one year or less. Contractual maturities
    for
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">available-for-sale</FONT>
    securities are greater than ten years with a reset date
    approximately every 28&#160;days. The carrying values of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">available-for-sale</FONT>
    securities approximate fair value. There were no unrealized
    gains or losses on these investments for the years ended
    December&#160;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004 due to the frequent
    resetting of interest rates on the auction rate securities.
    Gross proceeds from sales of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">available-for-sale</FONT>
    securities for the years ended December&#160;31, 2006, 2005 and
    2004 were $561&#160;million, $349&#160;million and
    $589&#160;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA had no long-term investments in debt securities as of
    December&#160;31, 2006 and December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Long-term
    Debt</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, the fair value of long-term
    debt was approximately $387&#160;million and $1.04&#160;billion,
    respectively. AWA&#146;s variable rate long-term debt with a
    carrying value of $358&#160;million and $911&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively, approximates fair
    value because these borrowings have variable interest rate terms
    that approximate market interest rates for similar debt
    instruments. The fair value of AWA&#146;s other long-term debt
    is determined based on quoted market prices, if available, or
    market prices for comparable debt instruments.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">(b)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Fuel
    Price Risk Management</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Under its fuel hedging program, AWA may enter into certain
    hedging transactions with approved counterparties for a period
    generally not exceeding 12&#160;months. As of December&#160;31,
    2006, AWA had entered into costless collar transactions hedging
    approximately 29% of US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s projected 2007
    fuel requirements. The fair value of AWA&#146;s financial
    derivative instruments was a net liability of approximately
    $66&#160;million and a net asset of $4&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, AWA had $48&#160;million of deposits
    held as collateral on the open fuel hedge positions that are
    recorded as prepaid expenses and other on the consolidated
    balance sheet.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    149
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA is exposed to credit risks in the event any counterparty to
    a hedge transaction fails to meet its obligations. AWA does not
    anticipate such non-performance as counterparties are selected
    based on credit ratings and exposure to any one counterparty is
    closely monitored.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    Long-term debt at December&#160;31, 2006 and December&#160;31,
    2005 consists of the following (variable interest rates listed
    are the rates as of December&#160;31, 2006 unless noted) (in
    millions):

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    On March&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group entered into a
    loan agreement with General Electric Capital Corporation
    (&#147;GECC&#148;) and a syndicate of lenders pursuant to which
    the Company borrowed an aggregate principal amount of
    $1.1&#160;billion. On April&#160;7, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group
    entered into an amended and restated loan agreement, which
    increased the principal amount of the loan to $1.25&#160;billion
    (as amended and restated, the &#147;GE Loan&#148;).
    US&#160;Airways, America West Holdings, AWA and other
    subsidiaries of US&#160;Airways Group are all guarantors of the
    GE Loan.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    On March&#160;31, 2006, proceeds of the GE Loan were used, in
    part, to repay in full the following indebtedness of AWA:</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The amended and restated AWA loans entered into on
    September&#160;27, 2005 that had previously been guaranteed by
    the ATSB. On October&#160;19, 2005, $238&#160;million of the
    loans, of which $228&#160;million had been guaranteed by the
    ATSB, was sold by the lenders by order of the ATSB to 13 fixed
    income investors, for which Citibank, N.A served as agent,
    removing the ATSB guarantee (the &#147;Citibank Loans&#148;). As
    a result of the sale of the loan, the AWA ATSB Loan is now
    called the AWA Citibank Loan. At the time of repayment of these
    loans on March&#160;31, 2006, the total outstanding balance of
    the loan was $250&#160;million.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    150
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The $161&#160;million loan entered into as of September&#160;27,
    2005 between US&#160;Airways and AWA and Airbus Financial
    Services, for which US&#160;Airways Group was the guarantor. At
    the time of repayment on March&#160;31, 2006, the outstanding
    balance of the loan was $161&#160;million. US&#160;Airways and
    AWA also had an $89&#160;million loan from Airbus Financial
    Services entered into as of September&#160;27, 2005. In
    accordance with the terms of the loan agreements, the
    outstanding principal amount of the $89&#160;million loan was to
    be forgiven on the earlier of December&#160;31, 2010 or the date
    that the outstanding principal amount of, accrued interest on,
    and all other amounts due under the Airbus $161&#160;million
    loan were paid in full, provided that US&#160;Airways Group
    complies with the delivery schedule for certain Airbus aircraft.
    As a result of the prepayment of the $161&#160;million loan on
    March&#160;31, 2006, the $89&#160;million loan agreement was
    terminated and the outstanding balance of $89&#160;million was
    forgiven.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Two loans provided by GECC to AWA pursuant to loan agreements
    entered into as of September&#160;3, 2004 referred to as the
    Spare Parts Facility and the Engines Facility (collectively, the
    &#147;GECC term loan&#148;). At the time of repayment, the
    principal amounts outstanding under the Spare Parts Facility and
    the Engines Facility were $76&#160;million and $34&#160;million,
    respectively.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (b) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    On December&#160;27, 2004, AWA raised additional capital by
    financing its Phoenix maintenance facility and flight training
    center. The flight training center was previously unencumbered,
    and the maintenance facility became unencumbered in 2004 when
    AWA refinanced its term loan. Using its leasehold interest in
    these two facilities as collateral, AWA, through a wholly owned
    subsidiary named FTCHP LLC, raised $31&#160;million through the
    issuance of senior secured discount notes. The notes were issued
    by FTCHP at a discount pursuant to the terms of a senior secured
    term loan agreement among AWA, FTCHP, Heritage Bank SSB, as
    administrative agent, Citibank, N.A., as the initial lender, and
    the other lenders from time to time party thereto. Citibank,
    N.A. subsequently assigned all of its interests in the notes to
    third party lenders.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    AWA has fully and unconditionally guaranteed the payment and
    performance of FTCHP&#146;s obligations under the notes and the
    loan agreement. The notes require aggregate principal payments
    of $36&#160;million with principal payments of $2&#160;million
    due on each of the first two anniversary dates and the remaining
    principal amount due on the fifth anniversary date. The notes
    may be prepaid in full at any time (subject to customary LIBOR
    breakage costs) and in partial amounts of $2&#160;million on the
    third and fourth anniversary dates. The unpaid principal amount
    of the notes bears interest based on LIBOR plus a margin subject
    to adjustment based on a loan to collateral value ratio.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The loan agreement contains customary covenants applicable to
    loans of this type, including obligations relating to the
    preservation of the collateral and restrictions on the
    activities of FTCHP. In addition, the loan agreement contains
    events of default, including payment defaults, cross-defaults to
    other debt of FTCHP, if any, breach of covenants, bankruptcy and
    insolvency defaults and judgment defaults.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In connection with this financing, AWA sold all of its leasehold
    interests in the maintenance facility and flight training center
    to FTCHP and entered into subleases for the facilities with
    FTCHP at lease rates expected to approximate the interest
    payments due under the notes. In addition, AWA agreed to make
    future capital contributions to FTCHP in amounts sufficient to
    cover principal payments and other amounts owing pursuant to the
    notes and the loan agreement.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (c) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In January 2002, in connection with the closing of the original
    AWA ATSB loan and the related transactions, America West
    Holdings issued $105&#160;million of 7.5%&#160;convertible
    senior notes due 2009, of which approximately $112&#160;million
    remained outstanding at December&#160;31, 2005 (including
    $22&#160;million of interest paid through December&#160;31, 2004
    as a deemed loan added to the initial principal thereof).
    Beginning January&#160;18, 2005, these notes became convertible
    into shares of common stock, at the option of the holders, at an
    initial conversion price of $29.09&#160;per share or a
    conversion ratio of approximately 34.376&#160;shares per $1,000
    principal amount of such notes, subject to standard
    anti-dilution adjustments. Interest on the 7.5%&#160;convertible
    senior notes was payable semiannually in arrears on June&#160;1
    and December&#160;1 of each year. At America West Holdings&#146;
    option, the first six interest payments were payable in the form
    of a deemed loan added to the principal amount of these notes.
    The 7.5%&#160;convertible senior notes were scheduled to mature
    on January&#160;18, 2009 unless earlier </TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

    <TD valign="bottom">
    converted or redeemed. The payment of principal, premium and
    interest on the 7.5%&#160;convertible senior notes was fully and
    unconditionally guaranteed by AWA and US&#160;Airways Group.</TD>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    On March&#160;24, 2006, America West Holdings gave notice to the
    holders of the 7.5%&#160;convertible senior notes that it was
    redeeming the notes in full, at a redemption price of 102.50% of
    the principal amount of the notes, as required under the terms
    of the indenture, plus accrued and unpaid interest up to, but
    not including, the date of redemption. The redemption price,
    plus the relevant interest, was $1,052.50&#160;per $1,000
    principal amount of the notes, and the redemption date was
    April&#160;13, 2006. Holders had the right, at any time at or
    prior to the close of business on April&#160;11, 2006, to
    convert the notes into shares of common stock of US&#160;Airways
    Group at a price of $29.09&#160;per share, or 34.376&#160;shares
    per $1,000 principal amount. Holders who converted also received
    interest up to the date of conversion. A total of
    $112&#160;million in principal amount of the notes was converted
    into shares of common stock prior to the redemption date,
    resulting in the issuance of 3,860,358&#160;shares of common
    stock.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (d) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The industrial development revenue bonds are due April 2023.
    Interest at 6.3% is payable semiannually on April&#160;1 and
    October&#160;1. The bonds are subject to optional redemption
    prior to the maturity date on or after April&#160;1, 2008, in
    whole or in part, on any interest payment date at the following
    redemption prices: 102% on April&#160;1 or October&#160;1, 2008;
    101% on April&#160;1 or October&#160;1, 2009; and 100% on
    April&#160;1, 2010 and thereafter.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (e) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In connection with the merger, AWA, US&#160;Airways Group and
    Juniper Bank, a subsidiary of Barclays PLC
    (&#147;Juniper&#148;), entered into an agreement on
    August&#160;8, 2005 amending AWA&#146;s co-branded credit card
    agreement with Juniper, dated January&#160;25, 2005. Pursuant to
    the amended credit card agreement, Juniper agreed to offer and
    market an airline mileage award credit card program to the
    general public to participate in US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s
    Dividend Miles program through the use of a co-branded credit
    card.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s credit card program was also
    administered by Bank of America, N.A. (USA) prior to the merger.
    On December&#160;28, 2005, US&#160;Airways issued a notice of
    termination under its agreement with Bank of America and that
    notice will become effective on December&#160;28, 2007. Pending
    termination of the Bank of America agreement, both Juniper and
    Bank of America will run separate credit card programs for
    US&#160;Airways Group. The amended credit card agreement is the
    subject of pending litigation filed by Bank of America against
    US&#160;Airways Group, US&#160;Airways and AWA (See
    Note&#160;7(d)).</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The amended credit card agreement took effect at the effective
    time of the merger. The credit card services provided by Juniper
    under the amended credit card agreement began in January 2006,
    and will continue until the expiration date, which is the later
    of December&#160;31, 2012 or seven years from the date on which
    Juniper commences marketing to the general public.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Under the amended credit card agreement, Juniper will pay to
    US&#160;Airways Group fees for each mile awarded to each credit
    card account administered by Juniper, subject to certain
    exceptions. Pursuant to the original credit card agreement,
    Juniper paid to AWA a bonus of $20&#160;million. Juniper also
    agreed to pay a one-time bonus payment of $130&#160;million,
    following the effectiveness of the merger, subject to certain
    conditions. The $130&#160;million bonus payment was made to AWA
    on October&#160;3, 2005. The entire $150&#160;million balance
    for bonus payments are included in &#147;Deferred gains and
    other liabilities&#148; in the accompanying consolidated balance
    sheet as of December&#160;31, 2005. US&#160;Airways Group will
    not recognize any revenue from the bonus payments until the dual
    branding period has expired in approximately February 2008. At
    that time AWA expects to begin recognizing revenue from the
    bonus payments on a straight-line basis through December 2012,
    the expiration date of the Juniper agreement. Further, if
    Juniper is not granted exclusivity to offer a co-branded credit
    card after the dual branding period, US&#160;Airways Group must
    repay the bonus payments and repurchase unused pre-paid miles
    with interest, plus a $50&#160;million penalty. Juniper will pay
    an annual bonus of $5&#160;million to US&#160;Airways Group,
    subject to certain exceptions, for each year after Juniper
    becomes the exclusive issuer of the co-branded credit card.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    On October&#160;3, 2005, Juniper pre-paid for miles from
    US&#160;Airways Group totaling $325&#160;million, subject to the
    same conditions that apply to the $130&#160;million bonus
    payment. To the extent that these miles are not used by Juniper
    as allowed under the co-branded credit card program in certain
    circumstances, US&#160;Airways Group will repurchase these miles
    in 12 equal quarterly installments beginning on the fifth year
    prior to the expiration date </TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    of the co-branded credit card agreement with Juniper, until paid
    in full. US&#160;Airways Group makes monthly interest payments
    at LIBOR plus 4.75% to Juniper, beginning on November&#160;1,
    2005, based on the amount of pre-purchased miles that have not
    been used by Juniper in connection with the co-branded credit
    card program and have not been repurchased by US&#160;Airways
    Group. US&#160;Airways Group will be required to repurchase
    pre-purchased miles under certain reductions in the collateral
    held under the credit card processing agreement with JP Morgan
    Chase Bank, N.A. Accordingly, the prepayment has been recorded

    Juniper requires US&#160;Airways Group to maintain an average
    quarterly balance of cash, cash equivalents and short-term
    investments of at least $1&#160;billion for the entirety of the
    agreement. Further, the agreement requires US&#160;Airways Group
    to maintain certain financial ratios beginning January&#160;1,
    2006. Juniper may, at its option, terminate the amended credit
    card agreement, make payments to US&#160;Airways Group under the
    amended credit card agreement in the form of pre-purchased miles
    rather than cash, or require US&#160;Airways Group to repurchase
    the pre-purchased miles before the fifth year prior to the
    expiration date of the co-branded credit card agreement with

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Certain of AWA&#146;s long-term debt agreements contain minimum
    cash balance requirements and other covenants with which AWA is
    in compliance at December&#160;31, 2006. Finally, AWA&#146;s
    long-term debt agreements contain cross-default provisions,
    which may be triggered by defaults by AWA under other agreements
    relating to indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Interest rates on $358&#160;million principal amount of
    long-term debt as of December&#160;31, 2006 are subject to
    adjustment to reflect changes in floating interest rates. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, the weighted average effective interest
    rate was 9.98% for the variable rate debt.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">7.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>

    and Contingencies</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">(a)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>

    <TD>

    to Purchase Flight Equipment and Maintenance
    Services</FONT></I></B>
</TD>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Airbus
    Purchase Commitments</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In August 2006, AWA amended its
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A320/A319</FONT>
    Purchase Agreement with Airbus to add seven new Airbus A321s to
    an existing order for thirty A320 family aircraft. The amendment
    also converted one A320 aircraft and seven A319 aircraft to an
    order of eight A321 aircraft. Deliveries of the 15 new A321
    aircraft will begin in 2008 and run through 2010. The new A321s
    will be configured to accommodate up to 187 passengers in two
    classes of service and will be used for replacement purposes or
    modest expansion should market conditions warrant.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    To modernize US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s international product
    and improve the efficiency of its international network,
    US&#160;Airways Group was scheduled to begin accepting
    deliveries of Airbus A350 aircraft in 2011 pursuant to a
    purchase agreement that US&#160;Airways Group, US&#160;Airways
    and AWA entered into in September 2005 with Airbus.
    US&#160;Airways Group has been notified that the A350 will be
    undergoing significant design changes and will
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    153
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

    be delivered several years beyond the originally scheduled
    delivery dates. US&#160;Airways Group is currently evaluating
    the revised technical and commercial aspects of the A350 program.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

    Airbus totals $1.56&#160;billion as of December&#160;31, 2006.

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Engine
    Purchase Commitments</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA has an agreement with International Aero Engines which
    provides for the purchase by AWA of five new
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">V2500-A5</FONT>
    spare engines scheduled for delivery through 2010 for use on
    certain of the Airbus A320 fleet the total engine purchase
    commitment was $42&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Engine
    Maintenance Commitments</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with the merger, US&#160;Airways and AWA
    restructured their rate per engine hour agreements with General
    Electric Engine Services for overhaul maintenance services.
    Under the restructured agreements, the minimum monthly payment
    on account of accrued engine flight hours for both the
    US&#160;Airways and AWA agreements together will equal
    $3&#160;million as long as both agreements remain in effect or
    through October 2009.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">(b)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>

    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Leases</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA leases certain aircraft, engines, and ground equipment, in
    addition to the majority of its ground facilities and terminal
    space. As of December&#160;31, 2006, AWA had 133 aircraft under
    operating leases, with remaining terms ranging from one month to
    approximately 17&#160;years. Ground facilities include executive
    offices, maintenance facilities and ticket and administrative
    offices. Public airports are utilized for flight operations
    under lease arrangements with the municipalities or agencies
    owning or controlling such airports. Substantially all leases
    provide that the lessee must pay taxes, maintenance, insurance
    and certain other operating expenses applicable to the leased
    property. Some leases also include renewal and purchase options.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    rental payments under noncancelable operating leases with
    initial terms of more than one year are as follows (in millions):
</DIV>
