    Rent expense (excluding landing fees) was approximately
    $461&#160;million, $449&#160;million and $421&#160;million for
    the years ended December&#160;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004
    respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Collectively, the operating lease agreements require security
    deposits with lessors of $35&#160;million, which have been
    classified as other assets, net in the accompanying balance
    sheets, and bank letters of credit of $31&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&#160;million loan supported
    by a $380&#160;million government loan guarantee that resulted
    in a restructuring of its aircraft lease commitments. Under the
    restructured lease agreements, annual rent payments have been
    reduced through January 2007. Certain of these leases contain
    put options pursuant to which the lessors could require AWA to
    renew the leases for periods up to approximately nine years or
    call options pursuant to which the lessors could require AWA to
    return the aircraft to the lessors upon receipt of six to nine
    months advance written notice. AWA also has options to purchase
    certain of the aircraft at fair market values at the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    154
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    end of the lease terms. Certain of the agreements require
    security deposits, minimum return provisions and supplemental
    rent payments.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA has set up pass through trusts, which have issued pass
    through trust certificates (also known as &#147;Enhanced
    Equipment Trust Certificates&#148; or &#147;EETCs&#148;)
    covering the financing of 54 leased aircraft. These trusts are
    off-balance sheet entities, the primary purpose of which is to
    finance the acquisition of aircraft. Rather than finance each
    aircraft separately when such aircraft is purchased or
    delivered, these trusts allow AWA to raise the financing for
    several aircraft at one time and place such funds in escrow
    pending the purchase or delivery of the relevant aircraft. The
    trusts are also structured to provide for certain credit
    enhancements, such as liquidity facilities to cover certain
    interest payments, that reduce the risks to the purchasers of
    the trust certificates and, as a result, reduce the cost of
    aircraft financing to AWA.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Each trust covered a set amount of aircraft scheduled to be
    delivered within a specific period of time. At the time of each
    covered aircraft financing, the relevant trust used the funds in
    escrow to purchase equipment notes relating to the financed
    aircraft. The equipment notes were issued, at AWA&#146;s
    election, either by AWA in connection with a mortgage financing
    of the aircraft or by a separate owner trust in connection with
    a leveraged lease financing of the aircraft. In the case of a
    leveraged lease financing, the owner trust then leased the
    aircraft to AWA. In both cases, the equipment notes are secured
    by a security interest in the aircraft. The pass through trust
    certificates are not direct obligations of, nor are they
    guaranteed by AWA. However, in the case of mortgage financings,
    the equipment notes issued to the trusts are direct obligations
    of AWA and in the case of leveraged lease financings, the leases
    are direct obligations of AWA. In addition, AWA does not
    guarantee or participate in any way in the residual value of the
    leased aircraft. All aircraft financed by these trusts are
    currently structured as leveraged lease financings, and
    therefore are not reflected as debt on the balance sheet of AWA.
    AWA does not provide residual value guarantees under these lease
    arrangements. Each lease contains a purchase option that allows
    AWA to purchase the aircraft at a fixed price, which at the
    inception of the lease approximated the aircraft&#146;s expected
    fair market value at the option date, near the end of the lease
    term.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    These leasing entities meet the criteria for variable interest
    entities. However, they do not meet the consolidation criteria
    under FIN&#160;46(R) because US&#160;Airways Group is not the
    primary beneficiary under these arrangements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">(c)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Regional
    Jet Capacity Purchase Agreements</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA has entered into capacity purchase agreements with Mesa. The
    capacity purchase agreements provide that all revenues
    (passenger, mail and freight) go to AWA. In return, AWA agrees
    to pay predetermined fees to Mesa for operating an agreed upon
    number of aircraft, without regard to the number of passengers
    onboard. In addition, these agreements provide that certain
    variable costs, such as fuel and airport landing fees, will be
    reimbursed 100% by AWA. AWA controls marketing, scheduling,
    ticketing, pricing and seat inventories. The current regional
    jet capacity purchase agreements with Mesa expire in 2012 and
    provide for optional extensions at US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s
    discretion. The future minimum noncancelable commitments under
    the regional jet capacity purchase agreements are
    $538&#160;million in 2007, $530&#160;million in 2008,
    $541&#160;million in 2009, $552&#160;million in 2010,
    $563&#160;million in 2011 and $287&#160;million thereafter.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">(d)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Legal
    Proceedings</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On October&#160;12, 2005, Bank of America, N.A., which is one of
    the issuing banks of the US&#160;Airways frequent flyer program
    credit card and which also acts as the processing bank for most
    airline ticket purchases paid for with credit cards, filed suit
    in the Delaware Chancery Court in New Castle County against
    US&#160;Airways, US&#160;Airways Group and AWA, alleging that
    US&#160;Airways breached its frequent flyer credit card contract
    with Bank of America by entering into a similar, competing
    agreement with Juniper and allowing Juniper to issue a
    US&#160;Airways frequent flyer credit card. Bank of America also
    alleges that US&#160;Airways Group and AWA induced these
    breaches. Bank of America seeks an order requiring
    US&#160;Airways to market the Bank of America card and prohibit
    Juniper from issuing
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    155
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    a US&#160;Airways credit card, as well as unspecified damages.
    On October&#160;27, 2005, Juniper, which was not originally a
    party to the lawsuit, sought and later received court permission
    to intervene as a defendant in the case and has made
    counterclaims against Bank of America. Juniper seeks an order
    declaring the validity of its new agreement to issue a
    US&#160;Airways frequent flyer credit card. On November&#160;3,
    2005, Bank of America filed a motion for partial summary
    judgment on the breach of contract claim against
    US&#160;Airways. After a series of procedural steps, Bank of
    America&#146;s motion, along with a cross-motion for summary
    judgment filed by Juniper, was heard in the Bankruptcy Court,
    where the case is now pending as an adversary proceeding. On
    January&#160;30, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court ruled that Bank of
    America was equitably estopped from pursuing its claims that
    US&#160;Airways breached its agreement with Bank of America by
    negotiating and entering into the agreement with Juniper. The
    Bankruptcy Court ruled in the alternative that US&#160;Airways
    did not breach its agreement with Bank of America to be the
    exclusive card issuer, but that US&#160;Airways had breached the
    &#147;no shop&#148; provision of the Bank of America agreement
    when US&#160;Airways negotiated with Juniper prior to reaching
    the Juniper agreement. Bank of America sought appeal of that
    ruling while it has continued to pursue certain administrative
    claims against US&#160;Airways in the Bankruptcy Court. The
    resolution of the final two claims that Bank of America made in
    the lawsuit, which are (i)&#160;that AWA tortiously interfered
    with the contractual relationship between US&#160;Airways and
    Bank of America and (ii)&#160;that US&#160;Airways Group and AWA
    tortiously interfered with Bank of America&#146;s right to
    future economic benefit under its agreement with
    US&#160;Airways, are dependent on the outcome of the pending
    appeal. Bank of America will pursue those two claims only if its
    appeal of the January&#160;30, 2006 order is ultimately
    successful. On July&#160;19, 2006, the Eastern District of
    Virginia affirmed the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s order in part,
    ruling that US&#160;Airways did not breach the exclusivity
    provisions of the contract. However, the Eastern District of
    Virginia reversed the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s decision on
    equitable estoppel and remanded the remainder of the case to the
    Bankruptcy Court to take further evidence. Bank of America and
    US&#160;Airways have each appealed the July&#160;19, 2006
    ruling. On January&#160;16, 2007, Bank of America amended its
    complaint to add additional breach of contract and tortious
    interference claims against US&#160;Airways and AWA, as well as
    claims against Juniper.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA is unable to estimate at this time the amount of loss or
    probable losses, if any, that might result from an adverse
    resolution of the proceedings discussed above, and currently is
    unable to predict whether the outcome of these proceedings will
    have a material adverse effect on its results of operations or
    financial condition. AWA intends, however, to vigorously pursue
    all available defenses and claims in these matters.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">(e)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Guarantees
    and Indemnifications</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In June 1999, Series&#160;1999 special facility revenue bonds
    (&#147;new bonds&#148;) were issued by a municipality to fund
    the retirement of the Series&#160;1994A bonds (&#147;old
    bonds&#148;) and the construction of a new concourse with 14
    gates at Terminal&#160;4 in Phoenix Sky Harbor International
    Airport in support of AWA&#146;s strategic growth plan. The new
    bonds are due June 2019 with interest accruing at 6.25% per
    annum payable semiannually on June&#160;1 and December&#160;1,
    commencing on December&#160;1, 1999. The new bonds are subject
    to optional redemption prior to the maturity date on or after
    June&#160;1, 2009 in whole or in part, on any interest payment
    date at the following redemption prices: 101% on June&#160;1 or
    December&#160;1, 2009; 100.5% on June&#160;1 or December&#160;1,
    2010; and 100% on June&#160;1, 2011 and thereafter. In
    accordance with EITF Issue
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;97-10,</FONT>
    &#147;The Effect of Lessee Involvement in Asset
    Construction,&#148; AWA accounts for its payments under this
    financing facility as an operating lease.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with the new bonds, AWA entered into an Amended
    and Restated Airport Use Agreement, pursuant to which AWA agreed
    to make sufficient payments to the Phoenix Industrial
    Development Authority (&#147;IDA&#148;) to cover the principal
    and interest of the bonds and to indemnify the IDA for any
    claims arising out of the issuance and sale of the bonds and the
    use and occupancy of the concourses financed by the new bonds
    and the old bonds. At December&#160;31, 2006, the outstanding
    principal amount of the bonds was $22&#160;million. AWA
    estimates its remaining payments to cover the principal and
    interest of these bonds will be approximately $39&#160;million.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    156
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition, AWA is also the lessee under certain long-term
    leases at various airports. At certain of these airports,
    municipalities have issued revenue bonds to improve airport
    facilities that are leased by AWA and accounted for as operating
    leases. AWA does not guarantee the underlying debt related to
    these operating leases.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA is the lessee under many aircraft financing agreements
    (including leveraged lease financings of aircraft under pass
    through trusts) and real estate leases. It is common in such
    transactions for AWA as the lessee to agree to indemnify the
    lessor and other related third parties for the manufacture,
    design, ownership, financing, use, operation and maintenance of
    the aircraft, and for tort liabilities that arise out of or
    relate to AWA&#146;s use or occupancy of the leased asset. In
    some cases, this indemnity extends to related liabilities
    arising from the negligence of the indemnified parties, but
    usually excludes any liabilities caused by their gross
    negligence or willful misconduct. Additionally, in the case of
    real estate leases, AWA typically indemnifies such parties for
    any environmental liability that arises out of or relates to
    AWA&#146;s use of the leased premises.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways, America West Holdings, AWA, and other
    subsidiaries of US&#160;Airways Group are all guarantors of the
    $1.25&#160;billion GE Loan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s 7%&#160;Senior Convertible Notes
    are fully and unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and severally
    and on a senior unsecured basis, by US&#160;Airways and AWA.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">(f)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Concentration
    of Credit Risk</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA invests available cash in money market securities of various
    banks, commercial paper and asset-backed securities of various
    financial institutions, other companies with high credit ratings
    and securities backed by the U.S.&#160;government.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, most of AWA&#146;s receivables
    related to tickets sold to individual passengers through the use
    of major credit cards or to tickets sold by other airlines and
    used by passengers on AWA or its regional airline affiliates.
    These receivables are short-term, mostly being settled within
    seven days after sale. Bad debt losses, which have been minimal
    in the past, have been considered in establishing allowances for
    doubtful accounts. AWA does not believe it is subject to any
    significant concentration of credit risk.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">8.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Income
    Taxes</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA accounts for income taxes according to the provisions in
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;109, &#147;Accounting for Income Taxes.&#148;
    AWA files a consolidated federal income tax return with its
    parent company, US&#160;Airways Group. US&#160;Airways Group and
    its wholly owned subsidiaries allocate tax and tax items, such
    as net operating losses (&#147;NOL&#148;) and net tax credits,
    between members of the group based on their proportion of
    taxable income and other items. Accordingly, AWA&#146;s tax
    expense is based on its taxable income, taking into
    consideration its allocated tax loss carryforwards/carrybacks
    and tax credit carryforwards.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In assessing the realizability of the deferred tax assets,
    management considers whether it is more likely than not that
    some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will be realized.
    AWA has recorded a valuation allowance against its net deferred
    tax asset. The ultimate realization of deferred tax assets is
    dependent upon the generation of future taxable income
    (including reversals of deferred tax liabilities) during the
    periods in which those temporary differences will become
    deductible.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, AWA has available NOL
    carryforwards and tax credit carry forwards for federal income
    tax purposes of approximately $400&#160;million and
    $7&#160;million, respectively. The NOL expires during the years
    2022 through 2025. As a result of a statutory &#147;ownership
    change&#148; (as defined for purposes of Section&#160;382 of the
    Internal Revenue Code) that occurred as a result of America West
    Holding&#146;s merger with US&#160;Airways Group on
    September&#160;27, 2005, AWA&#146;s ability to utilize its
    regular and AMT NOL and tax credit carryforwards may be
    restricted.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    157
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA is subject to Alternative Minimum Tax liability
    (&#147;AMT&#148;) for the full year 2006. In most cases, the
    recognition of AMT does not result in tax expense. However,
    since AWA&#146;s NOL was subject to a full valuation allowance,
    any liability for AMT is recorded as tax expense. AWA recorded
    AMT expense of $5&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA and the Internal Revenue Service (&#147;IRS&#148;) favorably
    reached an agreement to carry forward all
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">pre-1994</FONT> NOL
    that were restricted, as a result of a statutory &#147;ownership
    change&#148; (as defined for purposes of Section&#160;382 of the
    Internal Revenue Code) that occurred as a result of AWA&#146;s
    reorganization in 1994. In June 2006, as a result of that
    agreement, the IRS notified AWA that the Congressional Joint
    Committee on Taxation approved the IRS settlement with AWA,
    which resulted in the recognition of $8&#160;million of interest
    income earned on certain prior year federal income tax refunds.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    AWA is included in America West Holdings&#146; consolidated
    income tax returns for the periods ending December&#160;31, 2004
    and for the period beginning January&#160;1, 2005 ending on
    September&#160;27, 2005. On September&#160;27, 2005,
    US&#160;Airways Group consummated the transactions contemplated
    by its plan of reorganization, including the merger transaction
    with America West Holdings. As a result of the merger, America
    West Holdings became a wholly owned subsidiary of
    US&#160;Airways Group. America West Holdings and AWA, as part of
    the merger, became members of the consolidated US&#160;Airways
    Group on September&#160;28, 2005. AWA is included in the
    US&#160;Airways Group consolidated income tax return for the
    period ended December&#160;31, 2006. The current tax provision
    for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006 was prepared in
    accordance with this tax return methodology.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The components of the provision (credit) for income taxes are as
    follows (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The reason for significant differences between taxable and
    pretax book income primarily relates to depreciation on fixed
    assets, employee pension and postretirement benefit costs,
    employee-related accruals and leasing transactions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

    <TD width="97%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">9.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Employee
    Benefit Plans</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(a)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Defined
    Contribution Plan</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    America West Holdings has a 401(k) defined contribution plan,
    covering substantially all employees of AWA. Participants may
    contribute from 1% to 50% of their pretax earnings, up to a
    maximum of $15,000 in 2006. AWA&#146;s
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    159
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    matching contribution is determined annually by the Board of
    Directors. AWA&#146;s contribution expense to the plan totaled
    $6&#160;million, $10&#160;million and $11&#160;million in 2006,
    2005 and 2004, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Effective January&#160;1, 2005 America West Holdings amended its
    defined contribution plan, requiring AWA to make a non-elective
    discretionary employer contribution equal to 7% of the annual
    compensation for each pilot covered under the collective
    bargaining agreement between AWA and the Air Line Pilots
    Association (as defined in the plan and subject to statutory
    annual maximums). Effective January&#160;1, 2006 the
    non-elective discretionary employer contribution was increased
    to 10% of each pilot&#146;s annual compensation. These
    non-elective discretionary employer contributions replace the
    existing AWA company match under the 401(k) defined contribution
    plan for pilots. The AWA company match continues for all other
    eligible covered employees under the plan. AWA&#146;s
    contribution expense to this plan totaled $19&#160;million and
    $13&#160;million for 2006 and 2005, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(b)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Profit
    Sharing Plans</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Most non-executive employees of US&#160;Airways Group are
    eligible to participate in the 2005 Profit Sharing Plan, an
    annual bonus program, which was established subsequent to the
    merger. Annual bonus awards are paid from a profit-sharing pool
    equal to (i)&#160;ten percent of the annual profits of
    US&#160;Airways Group (excluding unusual items) for pre-tax
    profit margins up to ten percent, plus (ii)&#160;15% of the
    annual profits of US&#160;Airways Group (excluding unusual
    items) for pre-tax profit margins greater than ten percent.
    Awards are paid as a lump sum no later than March 15 after the
    end of each fiscal year. The profit-sharing pool is shared among
    eligible employee groups in proportion to each group&#146;s
    share of overall cost savings achieved through
    US&#160;Airways&#146; 2005 transformation plan; however, the
    represented pilots&#146; and flight attendants&#146; portions of
    the pool will not be less than 36% and 14.5%, respectively. An
    employee&#146;s share of the pool is based on the ratio that the
    employee&#146;s compensation bears to the respective employee
    group&#146;s aggregate compensation. AWA recorded
    $23&#160;million for profit sharing in 2006, which is recorded
    in salaries and related costs.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">10.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Stockholder&#146;s
    Equity</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(a)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Common
    Stock</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The holder of common stock is entitled to one vote per share on
    all matters submitted to a vote of the common shareholder. All
    common stock of AWA is held by America West Holdings.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(b)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Warrants</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As compensation for various elements of AWA&#146;s financial
    restructuring completed in January 2002, America West Holdings
    issued a warrant to purchase 18.8&#160;million shares of its
    Class&#160;B common stock to the ATSB and additional warrants to
    purchase 3.8&#160;million shares of its Class&#160;B common
    stock to other loan participants, in each case at an exercise
    price of $3&#160;per share and a term of ten years. For
    accounting purposes, the warrants were valued at
    $35&#160;million, or $1.57&#160;per share, using the
    Black-Scholes pricing model with the following assumptions:
    expected dividend yield of 0.0%, risk-free interest rate of
    4.8%, and volatility of 44.9% and an expected life of ten years.
    The warrants were recorded by AWA as a non-cash capital
    contribution in the consolidated statements of
    stockholder&#146;s equity and comprehensive income and
    classified as other assets, net in the consolidated balance
    sheet. The warrants were being amortized over the life of the
    government guaranteed loan as an increase to interest expense.
    In the first quarter of 2004, approximately 220,000 warrants
    were exercised at $3&#160;per share. In the third quarter of
    2003, approximately 2.6&#160;million warrants were exercised at
    $3&#160;per share. These warrant exercises were cashless
    transactions resulting in the issuance of approximately
    1.6&#160;million shares of America West Holdings&#146;
    Class&#160;B common stock.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In the fourth quarter of 2005, US&#160;Airways Group announced
    an agreement to repurchase all of the replacement warrants
    issued to the ATSB in connection with the merger with America
    West Holdings. US&#160;Airways Group repurchased approximately
    7.7&#160;million warrants to purchase shares of common stock
    that had an exercise price of
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    160
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    $7.27&#160;per share. The total purchase price for the warrants
    was $116&#160;million, the estimated fair value of such warrants
    on the purchase date. In connection with this repurchase, AWA
    recorded $8&#160;million of non operating expense. This amount
    represented the unamortized balance recorded as an other asset,
    which was being amortized over the life of the government
    guaranteed loan as an increase to interest expense. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, there were no warrants outstanding.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">11.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Nonoperating
    Income (Expenses)&#160;&#151; Other, Net</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In the first quarter of 2006, AWA recorded $6&#160;million in
    prepayment penalties and wrote off $5&#160;million of debt
    issuance costs related to the March&#160;31, 2006 repayment of
    the AWA Citibank Loan (formerly ATSB loan) and the GECC loan
    that were paid off with the proceeds of the GE Loan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In the fourth quarter of 2005, US&#160;Airways Group repurchased
    warrants issued to the ATSB. In connection with this repurchase,
    AWA recorded $8&#160;million of nonoperating expense. This
    amount represented the unamortized balance recorded as an other
    asset, which was being amortized over the life of the government
    guaranteed loan as an increase to interest expense.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In the fourth quarter of 2005, AWA wrote off $2&#160;million in
    issuance costs in connection with the conversion of the 7.25%
    exchangeable notes.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with the term loan refinancing with GECC, AWA
    wrote off $1&#160;million of debt issuance costs associated to
    the term loan with Mizuho in 2004. This amount was recorded in
    nonoperating expenses.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    161
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, AWA had net payables to related
    parties of $981&#160;million, which was classified in current
    liabilities on AWA&#146;s balance sheet. The net payable to
    US&#160;Airways Group consists of proceeds received by AWA on
    behalf of US&#160;Airways Group in connection with the initial
    equity investments, the public stock offering, the exercise of
    options by equity investors, the issuance of 7%&#160;Senior
    Convertible Notes and the Airbus loans and
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    162
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">America
    West Airlines, Inc.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    amounts payable to US&#160;Airways Group related to the
    conversion of the 7.25%&#160;notes, net of cash retained by
    US&#160;Airways Group. The net payable to US&#160;Airways Group
    increased by $634&#160;million during 2006. The majority of the
    increase relates to debt previously recorded at AWA that was
    refinanced with the proceeds from the GE Loan and the allocation
    of the forgiveness of the Airbus loans.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The net receivable from US&#160;Airways consists of amounts due
    to and from US&#160;Airways relating to items such as debt
    extinguishment, merger related payments and receipts, and
    various other transactions that occur in the normal course of
    business that one airline settles on behalf of the other.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2006, AWA started to purchase a portion of its aviation
    fuel from US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned subsidiary,
    Material Services Company, Inc. (&#147;MSC&#148;), which acts as
    a fuel wholesaler to AWA in certain circumstances. AWA&#146;s
    aviation fuel purchases from MSC were $8&#160;million for the
    year ended December&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&#160;million loan supported
    by a $380&#160;million government loan guarantee. AWA&#146;s net
    advances to America West Holdings as a result of this
    transaction have been classified in other assets on AWA&#146;s
    balance sheet. As of December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, AWA had
    net advances to parent company of $261&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(b)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Shared
    Operating Expenses</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The operating expenses of AWA reflect expenses for certain
    services shared with US&#160;Airways, including technology and
    data processing services, corporate functions such as tax,
    legal, compliance, finance and operations, and the costs of the
    combined Dividend Miles frequent traveler program. These shared
    costs have been allocated based on AWA&#146;s and
    US&#160;Airways&#146; respective revenue passenger miles
    (&#147;RPMs&#148;). The operating expenses of AWA also reflect
    shared expenses incurred at more than 30 overlap airports where
    the operations of AWA and US&#160;Airways have been
    consolidated. These shared costs have been allocated based on
    AWA&#146;s and US&#160;Airways&#146; respective departures at
    those airports. Management believes that the methodologies
    underlying the allocation of these shared costs are reasonable.
    The following details the total corporate shared expenses and
    airport shared expenses allocated to AWA and US&#160;Airways
    that are included in operating expenses for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006 (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Robert A. Milton, a member of the board of directors of
    US&#160;Airways Group until April&#160;19, 2006, was the
    Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of ACE. ACE
    purchased 5,000,000&#160;shares of US&#160;Airways Group common
    stock at a purchase price of $15.00&#160;per share, for a total
    investment of $75&#160;million. ACE or its subsidiaries entered
    into commercial agreements with US&#160;Airways Group and
    America West Holdings for various services including maintenance
    and airport handling. The amount paid in 2005 for these
    commercial agreements was approximately $2&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Richard P. Schifter, a member of the board of directors of
    US&#160;Airways Group until November&#160;15, 2006, is a partner
    of Texas Pacific Group, which was a controlling stockholder of
    America West Holdings prior to the completion of the merger. An
    affiliate of Texas Pacific Group received $6&#160;million as an
    advisory fee for providing financial advisory services rendered
    in connection with the merger and in contribution for and
    reimbursement for certain expenses incurred by Texas Pacific
    Group and its affiliates in connection with the merger.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    163
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->
<A name='114'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Item&#160;8C.<I>&#160;&#160;</I></FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Financial
    Statements and Supplementary Data of US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Management&#146;s
    Annual Report on Internal Control over Financial
    Reporting</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Management of US&#160;Airways is responsible for establishing
    and maintaining adequate internal control over financial
    reporting as defined in
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Rules&#160;13a-15(f)</FONT>
    and
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">15d-15(f)</FONT>
    under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended.
    US&#160;Airways&#146; internal control over financial reporting
    is designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the
    reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of
    financial statements for external purposes in accordance with
    generally accepted accounting principles. US&#160;Airways&#146;
    internal control over financial reporting includes those
    policies and procedures that:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable
    detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and
    dispositions of the assets of US&#160;Airways;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as
    necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in
    accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and
    that receipts and expenditures of US&#160;Airways are being made
    only in accordance with authorizations of management and
    directors of US&#160;Airways;&#160;and
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely
    detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of
    US&#160;Airways&#146; assets that could have a material effect
    on the financial statements.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over
    financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
    Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future
    periods are subject to the risk that controls may become
    inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree
    of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Management assessed the effectiveness of US&#160;Airways&#146;
    internal control over financial reporting as of
    December&#160;31, 2006. In making this assessment, management
    used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring
    Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO) in Internal
    Control-Integrated Framework.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Based on our assessment and those criteria, management concludes
    that US&#160;Airways maintained effective internal control over
    financial reporting as of December&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways&#146; independent registered public accounting
    firm has issued an audit report on management&#146;s assessment
    of US&#160;Airways&#146; internal control over financial
    reporting. That report has been included herein.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    165
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Report of
    Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Board of Directors and Stockholder
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways, Inc.:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We have audited management&#146;s assessment, included in the
    accompanying Management&#146;s Annual Report on Internal Control
    over Financial Reporting that US&#160;Airways, Inc.
    (&#147;US&#160;Airways&#148; or the &#147;Company&#148;)
    maintained effective internal control over financial reporting
    as of December&#160;31, 2006, based on criteria established in
    Internal Control&#160;&#151; Integrated Framework issued by the
    Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission
    (COSO). US&#160;Airways&#146; management is responsible for
    maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting
    and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control
    over financial reporting. Our responsibility is to express an
    opinion on management&#146;s assessment and an opinion on the
    effectiveness of the Company&#146;s internal control over
    financial reporting based on our audit.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the
    Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those
    standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain
    reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control
    over financial reporting was maintained in all material
    respects. Our audit included obtaining an understanding of
    internal control over financial reporting, evaluating
    management&#146;s assessment, testing and evaluating the design
    and operating effectiveness of internal control, and performing
    such other procedures as we considered necessary in the
    circumstances. We believe that our audit provides a reasonable
    basis for our opinion.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    A company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting is a
    process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the
    reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of
    financial statements for external purposes in accordance with
    generally accepted accounting principles. A company&#146;s
    internal control over financial reporting includes those
    policies and procedures that (1)&#160;pertain to the maintenance
    of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly
    reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the
    company; (2)&#160;provide reasonable assurance that transactions
    are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial
    statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting
    principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company
    are being made only in accordance with authorizations of
    management and directors of the company; and (3)&#160;provide
    reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of
    unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the
    company&#146;s assets that could have a material effect on the
    financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over
    financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
    Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future
    periods are subject to the risk that controls may become
    inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree
    of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In our opinion, management&#146;s assessment that
    US&#160;Airways maintained effective internal control over
    financial reporting as of December&#160;31, 2006, is fairly
    stated, in all material respects, based on criteria established
    in <I>Internal Control&#160;&#151; Integrated Framework</I>
    issued by COSO. Also, in our opinion, US&#160;Airways
    maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control
    over financial reporting as of December&#160;31, 2006, based on
    criteria established in <I>Internal Control&#160;&#151;
    Integrated Framework</I> issued by COSO.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the
    Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the
    balance sheets of US&#160;Airways as of December&#160;31, 2006
    and 2005, and the related statements of operations,
    stockholders&#146; equity (deficit) and cash flows for the year
    ended December&#160;31, 2006, and the three months ended
    December&#160;31, 2005 for the Successor Company, and for the
    nine months ended September&#160;30, 2005, and the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2004 for the Predecessor Company, and our
    report dated February&#160;27, 2007 expressed an unqualified
    opinion on those financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <DIV style="display:inline; text-align:left;">/s/&#160;&#160;KPMG
    LLP</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Phoenix, Arizona<BR>
    February 27, 2007
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    166
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Report of
    Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Board of Directors and Stockholder
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways, Inc.:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We have audited the accompanying balance sheets of
    US&#160;Airways, Inc. (US&#160;Airways) as of December&#160;31,
    2006 and 2005, and the related statements of operations,
    stockholders&#146; equity (deficit) and cash flows for year
    ended December&#160;31, 2006, the three months ended
    December&#160;31, 2005 for the Successor Company, and for the
    nine months ended September&#160;30, 2005, and the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2004 for the Predecessor Company. These
    financial statements are the responsibility of the
    Company&#146;s management. Our responsibility is to express an
    opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the
    Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those
    standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain
    reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are
    free of material misstatement. An audit includes examining, on a
    test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in
    the financial statements. An audit also includes assessing the
    accounting principles used and significant estimates made by
    management, as well as evaluating the overall financial
    statement presentation. We believe that our audits provide a
    reasonable basis for our opinion.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above
    present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position
    of US&#160;Airways as of December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005,and the
    results of its operations and its cash flows for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006, the three months ended December&#160;31,
    2005 for the Successor Company, and for the nine months ended
    September&#160;30, 2005, and the year ended December&#160;31,
    2004, for the Predecessor Company, in conformity with
    U.S.&#160;generally accepted accounting principles.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As discussed in Note&#160;1 and 2(b) to the financial
    statements, on September&#160;16, 2005, the Bankruptcy Court
    confirmed the Company&#146;s Plan of Reorganization (the Plan),
    related to its Chapter&#160;11 bankruptcy proceeding. The Plan
    became effective on September&#160;27, 2005 and US&#160;Airways
    and its parent Company, US&#160;Airways Group, Inc.
    (US&#160;Airways Group), emerged from the Chapter&#160;11
    bankruptcy proceeding. In connection with its emergence from the
    Chapter&#160;11 bankruptcy proceedings, US&#160;Airways adopted
    fresh-start reporting pursuant to Statement of Position
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">90-7,</FONT>
    &#147;Financial Reporting by Entities in Reorganization Under
    the Bankruptcy Code&#148; as of September&#160;27, 2005. As a
    result, the financial statements of the Successor Company are
    presented on a different basis than those of the Predecessor
    Company and, therefore, are not comparable in all respects.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As discussed in Note&#160;6 to the financial statements, the
    Company adopted the provisions of the Statement of Financial
    Accounting Standards (&#147;SFAS&#148;) No.&#160;158,
    <I>Employers Accounting for Defined Benefit Pension and Other
    Postretirement Plans, an amendment of FASB Statements
    No.&#160;87,88,106,and 132(R)</I>, effective December&#160;31,
    2006 and as discussed in Note&#160;14 to the financial
    statements, the Company adopted the provisions of SFAS
    No.&#160;123(R), <I>Shared Based Payment</I>, effective
    January&#160;1, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the
    Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the
    effectiveness of the US&#160;Airways&#146; internal control over
    financial reporting as of December&#160;31, 2006, based on
    criteria established in <I>Internal Control-Integrated
    Framework</I> issued by the Committee of Sponsoring
    Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO), and our report
    dated February&#160;27, 2007 expressed an unqualified opinion on
    management&#146;s assessment of, and the effective operation of,
    internal control over financial reporting.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 24pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <DIV style="display:inline; text-align:left;">/s/&#160;&#160;KPMG
    LLP</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Phoenix, Arizona<BR>
    February&#160;27, 2007
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    167
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
