<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">1.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Basis of
    Presentation and Summary of Significant Accounting
    Policies</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(a)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Nature
    of Operations and Operating Environment</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways, Inc. (&#147;US&#160;Airways&#148;), a Delaware
    corporation, is a certificated air carrier engaged primarily in
    the business of transporting passengers, property and mail.
    US&#160;Airways enplaned approximately 36&#160;million
    passengers in 2006. As of December&#160;31, 2006,
    US&#160;Airways operated 226 jet aircraft. During 2006,
    US&#160;Airways, along with US&#160;Airways Express, provided
    regularly scheduled service or seasonal service at 178 airports
    in the continental United States, Canada, Latin America, the
    Caribbean and Europe.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Most of US&#160;Airways&#146; operations are in competitive
    markets. Competitors include other air carriers along with other
    modes of transportation. Although a competitive strength in some
    regards, the concentration of significant operations in the
    eastern U.S.&#160;results in US&#160;Airways being susceptible
    to changes in certain regional conditions that may have an
    adverse effect on US&#160;Airways&#146; financial condition and
    results of operations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways employed
    approximately 19,400&#160;full-time equivalent employees.
    Approximately 85% of US&#160;Airways&#146; active employees are
    covered by collective bargaining agreements with various labor
    unions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(b)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Basis
    of Presentation and Use of Estimates</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The accompanying financial statements include the accounts of
    US&#160;Airways. US&#160;Airways is a wholly owned subsidiary of
    US&#160;Airways Group, Inc. (&#147;US&#160;Airways Group&#148;).
    On September&#160;12, 2004, US&#160;Airways filed a voluntary
    petition for relief under Chapter&#160;11 of the United States
    Bankruptcy Code (the &#147;Bankruptcy Code&#148;) in the United
    States Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern District of Virginia,
    Alexandria Division (the &#147;Bankruptcy Court&#148;) (Case
    Nos.
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">04-13819-SSM</FONT>
    through
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">04-13823-SSM).</FONT>
    On the same day, US&#160;Airways Group and three of its other
    subsidiaries (collectively with US&#160;Airways, the
    &#147;Reorganized Debtors&#148;) also filed voluntary petitions
    for relief under Chapter&#160;11 of the Bankruptcy Code. On
    May&#160;19, 2005, US&#160;Airways Group signed a merger
    agreement with America West Holdings Corporation (&#147;America
    West Holdings&#148;) pursuant to which America West Holdings
    merged with a wholly owned subsidiary of US&#160;Airways Group
    upon US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s emergence from bankruptcy on
    September&#160;27, 2005. The Reorganized Debtors&#146; plan of
    reorganization was confirmed by the Bankruptcy Court on
    September&#160;16, 2005 and became effective on
    September&#160;27, 2005, the same day that the merger with
    America West Holdings became effective. While the merger was
    structured such that US&#160;Airways Group was the legal
    acquirer, the merger has been accounted for as a reverse
    acquisition such that America West Holdings was treated as the
    accounting acquirer.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group has the ability to move funds freely
    between its operating subsidiaries, including its other
    principal operating subsidiary, America West Airlines, Inc.
    (&#147;AWA&#148;), to support operations. These transfers are
    recognized as intercompany transactions. In the accompanying
    statements of cash flows, these intercompany transactions are
    designated as payable to affiliate and are classified as
    financing activities as US&#160;Airways Group has no plans to
    settle these transactions in the near term. As discussed further
    in Note&#160;10, US&#160;Airways&#146; financial results are
    significantly influenced by related party transactions. Certain
    prior year amounts have been reclassified to conform with the
    2006 presentation. Among these reclassifications, passenger
    revenue associated with US&#160;Airways&#146; former MidAtlantic
    division and US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned regional
    airlines and affiliate regional airlines operating as
    US&#160;Airways Express have been reclassified as &#147;Express
    passenger.&#148; Expenses associated with US&#160;Airways&#146;
    former MidAtlantic division, US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s wholly
    owned regional airlines and affiliate regional airlines
    operating as US&#160;Airways Express have been reclassified
    under the &#147;Express expenses&#148; caption. See
    Note&#160;1(q) for additional information related to Express
    expenses.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The preparation of financial statements in conformity with
    accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of
    America requires management to make estimates and assumptions
    that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and
    disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of
    the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues
    and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results could
    differ from those
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    172
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    estimates. The principal areas of judgment relate to passenger
    revenue recognition, impairment of long-lived assets and
    intangible assets, accounting for the frequent traveler program,
    estimates of fair value for assets and liabilities established
    in fresh-start reporting and purchase accounting and pensions
    and other postretirement benefit obligations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with emergence from its first bankruptcy in March
    2003 and its second bankruptcy in September 2005,
    US&#160;Airways adopted fresh-start reporting in accordance with
    AICPA Statement of Position
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">90-7,</FONT>
    &#147;Financial Reporting by Entities in Reorganization Under
    the Bankruptcy Code&#148;
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">(&#147;SOP&#160;90-7&#148;).</FONT>
    As a result of the application of fresh-start reporting, the
    financial statements prior to March&#160;31, 2003 are not
    comparable with the financial statements for the period
    April&#160;1, 2003 to September&#160;30, 2005, nor is either
    period comparable to periods after September&#160;30, 2005.
    References to &#147;Successor Company&#148; refer to
    US&#160;Airways on and after September&#160;30, 2005, after
    giving effect to the application of fresh-start reporting for
    the second bankruptcy and purchase accounting. References in the
    financial statements and the notes to the financial statements
    to &#147;Predecessor Company&#148; refer to US&#160;Airways
    prior to September&#160;30, 2005. While the effective date of
    the plan of reorganization and the merger was September&#160;27,
    2005, the results of operations for US&#160;Airways during the
    four day period from September 27 through September&#160;30,
    2005 are not material to the financial statement presentation.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">SOP&#160;90-7</FONT>
    requires that the financial statements for periods following the
    Chapter&#160;11 filing through the emergence date distinguish
    transactions and events that are directly associated with the
    reorganization from the ongoing operations of the business.
    Accordingly, revenues, expenses, realized gains and losses and
    provisions for losses incurred prior to emergence and directly
    associated with the reorganization and restructuring of the
    business are reported separately as reorganization items, net in
    the statements of operations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(c)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Cash
    Equivalents and Short-term Investments</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Cash equivalents and short-term investments consist primarily of
    cash in money market securities of various banks, highly liquid
    debt instruments, commercial paper and asset-backed securities
    of various financial institutions and securities backed by the
    U.S.&#160;government. All highly liquid investments purchased
    within three months of maturity are classified as cash
    equivalents. Cash equivalents are stated at cost, which
    approximates fair value due to the highly liquid nature and
    short maturities of the underlying securities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    All other highly liquid investments with original maturities
    greater than three months but less than one year are classified
    as short-term investments. Debt securities, other than auction
    rate securities, are classified as
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">held-to-maturity</FONT>
    in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards
    (&#147;SFAS&#148;) No.&#160;115, &#147;Accounting for Certain
    Investments in Debt and Equity Securities&#148;
    (&#147;SFAS&#160;115&#148;).
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Held-to-maturity</FONT>
    investments are carried at amortized cost. Investments in
    auction rate securities are classified as available for sale, as
    the terms of the securities exceed one year, however; the
    interest rates are generally reset every 28&#160;days.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(d)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Restricted
    Cash</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Restricted cash includes deposits in trust accounts primarily to
    fund certain taxes and fees and collateralize letters of credit
    and workers&#146; compensation claims, cash deposits securing
    certain letters of credit and surety bonds and cash deposits
    held by institutions that process credit card sales
    transactions. Restricted cash is stated at cost, which
    approximates fair value.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(e)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Materials
    and Supplies, Net</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Inventories of materials and supplies are valued at the lower of
    cost or fair value. Costs are determined using average costing
    methods. An allowance for obsolescence is provided for flight
    equipment expendable and repairable parts. These items are
    generally charged to expense when issued for use.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    173
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(f)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Property
    and Equipment</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Property and equipment are recorded at cost. Interest expenses
    related to the acquisition of certain property and equipment are
    capitalized as an additional cost of the asset or as a leasehold
    improvement if the asset is leased. Interest capitalized for the
    year ended December&#160;31, 2006, the three months ended
    December&#160;31, 2005, the nine months ended September&#160;30,
    2005 and the year ended December&#160;31, 2004 was
    $2&#160;million, $300,000, $500,000, and $5&#160;million
    respectively. Property and equipment is depreciated and
    amortized to estimated residual values over the estimated useful
    lives or the lease term, whichever is less, using the
    straight-line method. Costs of major improvements that enhance
    the usefulness of the asset are capitalized and depreciated over
    the estimated useful life of the asset or the modifications,
    whichever is less.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Effective with the emergence from bankruptcy and the merger with
    America West Holdings, US&#160;Airways conformed its estimated
    useful lives to those of America West Holdings. The estimated
    useful lives range from 3 to 12&#160;years for owned property
    and equipment and 18 to 30&#160;years for training equipment and
    buildings. The estimated useful lives of owned aircraft, jet
    engines, flight equipment and rotable parts range from 5 to
    25&#160;years. Leasehold improvements relating to flight
    equipment and other property or operating leases are amortized
    over the life of the lease or the life of the asset, whichever
    is shorter. For periods prior to September&#160;30, 2005, the
    estimated useful lives for owned property and equipment ranged
    from 5 to 10&#160;years, the estimated useful lives for training
    equipment and buildings ranged from 10 to 30&#160;years and the
    estimated useful lives of owned aircraft, jet engines, flight
    equipment and rotable parts ranged from 5 to 30&#160;years.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways records impairment losses on long-lived assets
    used in operations when events and circumstances indicate that
    the assets might be impaired as defined by
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;144, &#147;Accounting for the Impairment or
    Disposal of Long-Lived Assets&#148; (&#147;SFAS&#160;144&#148;).
    Recoverability of assets to be held and used is measured by a
    comparison of the carrying amount of an asset to undiscounted
    future net cash flows expected to be generated by the asset. If
    such assets are considered to be impaired, the impairment to be
    recognized is measured by the amount by which the carrying
    amount of the assets exceeds the fair value of the assets.
    Assets to be disposed of are reported at the lower of the
    carrying amount or fair value less cost to sell. US&#160;Airways
    recorded no impairment charges in the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006, the three months ended December&#160;31,
    2005, the nine months ended September&#160;31, 2005 and the year
    ended December&#160;31, 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(g)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Income
    Taxes</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Income taxes are accounted for under the asset and liability
    method. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for
    the future tax consequences attributable to differences between
    the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and
    liabilities and their respective tax bases and operating loss
    and tax credit carryforwards. A valuation allowance is
    established, if necessary, for the amount of any tax benefits
    that, based on available evidence, are not expected to be
    realized.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(h)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Goodwill
    and Other Intangibles, Net</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At December&#160;31, 2006, goodwill represents the purchase
    price in excess of the net amount assigned to assets acquired
    and liabilities assumed by America West Holdings on
    September&#160;27, 2005. Since that time, there have been no
    events or circumstances that would indicate an impairment to
    goodwill. US&#160;Airways performs its annual impairment test on
    October&#160;1, unless events or changes indicate a potential
    impairment in the carrying value. The provisions of
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;142, &#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible
    Assets&#148; (&#147;SFAS&#160;142&#148;) require that a two-step
    impairment test be performed on goodwill. In the first step, the
    fair value of the reporting unit is compared to its carrying
    value. If the fair value of the reporting unit exceeds the
    carrying value of the net assets of the reporting unit, goodwill
    is not impaired and no further testing is required. If the
    carrying value of the net assets of the reporting unit exceeds
    the fair value of the reporting unit, then a second step must be
    performed in order to determine the implied fair value of the
    goodwill and compare it to the carrying value of the goodwill.
    If the carrying value of goodwill exceeds its implied fair
    value, then an impairment loss is recorded equal to the
    difference. US&#160;Airways tested its
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    174
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    goodwill for impairment during the fourth quarter of 2006.
    US&#160;Airways concluded that the fair value of the reporting
    unit was in excess of the carrying value. US&#160;Airways
    assessed the fair value of the reporting unit considering both
    the income approach and market approach. Under the market
    approach, the fair value of the reporting unit is based on
    quoted market prices for US&#160;Airways Group common stock and
    the number of shares outstanding of US&#160;Airways Group common
    stock. Under the income approach, the fair value of the
    reporting unit is based on the present value of estimated future
    cash flows.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Other intangible assets consist primarily of trademarks,
    international route authorities and airport take-off and landing
    slots and airport gates. As of December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005,
    US&#160;Airways had $55&#160;million and $56&#160;million of
    international route authorities on the balance sheets,
    respectively. The carrying value of trademarks was
    $30&#160;million as of December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005.
    International route authorities and trademarks are classified as
    indefinite lived assets under SFAS&#160;142. Indefinite-lived
    assets are not amortized but instead are reviewed for impairment
    annually and more frequently if events or circumstances indicate
    that the asset may be impaired. International route authorities
    and trademarks were tested for impairment during the fourth
    quarter of 2006, at which time US&#160;Airways concluded that no
    impairment exists. US&#160;Airways will perform its next annual
    impairment test on October&#160;1, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    SFAS&#160;142 requires that intangible assets with estimable
    useful lives be amortized over their respective estimated useful
    lives to their estimated residual values, and reviewed for
    impairments in accordance with SFAS&#160;144. The following
    table provides information relating to US&#160;Airways&#146;
    intangible assets subject to amortization as of
    December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005 (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The intangible assets subject to amortization generally are
    amortized over 25&#160;years for airport take-off and landing
    slots, over the term of the lease for airport gate leasehold
    rights and over five years for capitalized software costs on a
    straight-line basis and are included in depreciation and
    amortization on the statements of operations. For the years
    ended December&#160;31, 2006, the three months ended
    December&#160;31, 2005, the nine months ended September&#160;30,
    2005, and the year ended December&#160;31, 2004, US&#160;Airways
    recorded amortization expense of $27&#160;million,
    $8&#160;million, $19&#160;million, and $35&#160;million,
    respectively, related to its intangible assets. US&#160;Airways
    expects to record annual amortization expense of
    $23&#160;million in year 2007, $23&#160;million in year 2008,
    $23&#160;million in year 2009, $22&#160;million in year 2010,
    and $20&#160;million in year 2011 related to these intangible
    assets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(i)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Other
    Assets, Net</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005:
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with fresh-start reporting for US&#160;Airways,
    aircraft operating leases were adjusted to fair value and
    $101&#160;million of assets were established for leasehold
    interests in aircraft for aircraft leases with rental rates
    deemed to be below market rates. These leasehold interests are
    amortized on a straight-line basis as an increase to aircraft
    rent expense over the applicable remaining lease periods,
    generally 17&#160;years.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(j)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Frequent
    Traveler Program</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At the time of the merger, US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s
    principal operating subsidiaries, AWA and US&#160;Airways,
    maintained separate frequent travel award programs known as
    &#147;Flight Fund&#148; and &#147;Dividend Miles,&#148;
    respectively. Following the merger, the two frequent flyer
    programs were modified to allow customers of each airline to
    earn and use miles on the other airline, and in May 2006, the
    two programs were merged into the new Dividend Miles program,
    which is substantially the same as the former US&#160;Airways
    program. As part of the merger of the plans, the accounts of
    members participating in both programs were merged into single
    accounts of the new program. Members of the new Dividend Miles
    program can redeem miles on either AWA, US&#160;Airways, or
    other members of the Star Alliance. During the second quarter of
    2006, US&#160;Airways recorded a reduction in the liability of
    $1&#160;million through special items, net&#160;&#151; merger
    related transition expenses as a result of reduced booking fees
    due to combining the two programs.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The estimated cost of providing the free travel, using the
    incremental cost method as adjusted for estimated redemption
    rates, is recognized as a liability and charged to operations as
    program members accumulate mileage and requisite mileage award
    levels are achieved. For travel awards on partner airlines, the
    liability is based on the average contractual amount to be paid
    to the other airline per redemption. Costs associated with the
    Dividend Miles program are allocated between AWA and
    US&#160;Airways based on mainline RPMs. As of December&#160;31,
    2006, Dividend Miles members had accumulated mileage credits for
    approximately 3.8&#160;million awards. The portion of
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s liability for the future travel
    awards accrued on US&#160;Airways&#146; balance sheets within
    other accrued liabilities was $166&#160;million and
    $147&#160;million as of December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005,
    respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways sells mileage credits to participating airline
    and non-airline business partners. Revenue earned from selling
    mileage credits to other companies is recognized in two
    components. A portion of the revenue from these sales is
    deferred, representing the estimated fair value of the
    transportation component of the sold mileage credits. The
    deferred revenue for the transportation component is amortized
    on a straight-line basis over the period in which the credits
    are expected to be redeemed for travel as passenger revenue,
    which is currently estimated to be 28&#160;months. The marketing
    component, which is earned at the time the miles are sold, is
    recognized in other revenues at the time of the sale. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, US&#160;Airways had
    $209&#160;million and $204&#160;million, respectively, in
    deferred revenue from the sale of mileage credits included in
    other accrued liabilities on its balance sheets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(k)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Derivative
    Instruments</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;133, &#147;Accounting for Derivative
    Instruments and Hedging Activities&#148;
    (&#147;SFAS&#160;133&#148;) requires all derivatives to be
    recognized on the balance sheet at fair value. Derivatives that
    are not hedges must be adjusted to fair value through income. If
    the derivative is a hedge, depending on the nature of the hedge,
    changes in the fair value of derivatives are either offset
    against the change in fair value of assets, liabilities or firm
    commitments through earnings or recognized in other
    comprehensive income until the hedged item is recognized in
    earnings. The ineffective portion of a hedging derivative&#146;s
    change in fair value is immediately recognized in earnings. As
    of December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, US&#160;Airways had no open
    fuel hedge positions in place.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Due to the application of fresh-start reporting, US&#160;Airways
    recognized a one-time gain of $6&#160;million related to
    unrecognized fuel hedge gains included in reorganization items,
    net for the nine months ended September&#160;30, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways holds stock options in Sabre Holding Corporation
    (&#147;Sabre&#148;) and warrants in a number of companies as a
    result of service agreements with them. On an ongoing basis,
    US&#160;Airways adjusts its balance sheet to
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    176
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    reflect changes in the current fair market value of the stock
    options and warrants to other, net on its statements of
    operations. See Note&#160;4(a) for more information on these
    options and warrants.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(l)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Deferred
    Gains and Credits, Net</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with fresh-start reporting and purchase
    accounting, aircraft operating leases were adjusted to fair
    value and deferred credits of $190&#160;million were established
    in the accompanying balance sheet representing the net present
    value of the difference between stated lease rates and the fair
    market rates. These deferred credits are amortized on a
    straight-line basis as a decrease to aircraft rent expense over
    the applicable remaining lease periods, generally one to
    17&#160;years. At December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, the
    unamortized balance of the deferred credit was $141&#160;million
    and $178&#160;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The gain related to certain Sabre options exercised in 1999 has
    been deferred and amortized over the contract period as a
    reduction to other operating expenses. At December&#160;31, 2006
    and 2005, the unamortized balance of the deferred credit was
    $31&#160;million and $37&#160;million, respectively. See
    Note&#160;4(a) for more information related to the Sabre options.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(m)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Revenue
    Recognition</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Passenger
    Revenue</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Passenger revenue is recognized when transportation is provided.
    Ticket sales for transportation that has not yet been provided
    are initially recorded as air traffic liability on the balance
    sheet. The air traffic liability represents tickets sold for
    future travel dates and estimated future refunds and exchanges
    of tickets sold for past travel dates. The majority of tickets
    sold on US&#160;Airways are nonrefundable. Tickets that are sold
    but not flown on the travel date may be reused for another
    flight, up to a year from the date of sale, or refunded, if the
    ticket is refundable, after taking into account any cancellation
    penalties or change fees. A small percentage of tickets, or
    partially used tickets, expire unused. Due to complex pricing
    structures, refund and exchange policies, and interline
    agreements with other airlines, certain amounts are recognized
    in revenue using estimates regarding both the timing of the
    revenue recognition and the amount of revenue to be recognized.
    These estimates are based on the analysis of historical data.
    US&#160;Airways has applied this accounting method to estimate
    and recognize revenue from forfeited tickets at the date travel
    was to be provided. Estimated future refunds and exchanges
    included in the air traffic liability are routinely evaluated
    based on subsequent activity to validate the accuracy of
    US&#160;Airways&#146; estimates. Any adjustments resulting from
    periodic evaluations of the estimated air traffic liability are
    included in results of operations during the period in which the
    evaluations are completed.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Passenger traffic commissions and related fees are expensed when
    the related revenue is recognized. Passenger traffic commissions
    and related fees not yet recognized are included as a prepaid
    expense.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with the application of purchase accounting,
    effective September&#160;27, 2005, US&#160;Airways recorded a
    $124&#160;million reduction to its air traffic liability to
    conform its accounting policies for recognizing revenue from
    forfeited tickets to those of America West Holdings.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways purchases capacity (available seat miles)
    generated by US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned regional
    air carriers and the capacity of Air Wisconsin Airlines Corp.
    (&#147;Air Wisconsin&#148;), Republic Airways Holdings
    (&#147;Republic&#148;), Mesa Airlines, Inc. (&#147;Mesa&#148;)
    and Chautauqua Airlines, Inc. (&#147;Chautauqua&#148;) in
    certain markets. Air Wisconsin, Mesa, Chautauqua, and Republic
    operate regional jet aircraft in these markets as part of
    US&#160;Airways Express. US&#160;Airways classifies revenues
    related to capacity purchase arrangements as Express passenger
    revenues. Liabilities related to tickets sold for travel on
    these air carriers are also included in US&#160;Airways&#146;
    air traffic liability and are subsequently relieved in the same
    manner as described above.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    See note&#160;1(j) above for information on the revenue
    recognition for the sale of Dividend Miles.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    177
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Cargo
    Revenue</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Cargo revenue is recognized when shipping services for mail and
    other cargo are provided.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Other
    Revenue</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Other revenue includes excess baggage charges, ticket change and
    service fees, commissions earned on tickets sold for flights on
    other airlines, sales of tour packages by the US&#160;Airways
    Vacations division and the marketing component earned from
    selling mileage credits to partners, as discussed in
    Note&#160;1(j)&#160;&#147;Frequent Traveler Programs&#148;.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(n)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Stock-based
    Compensation</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Upon emergence from the first bankruptcy in March 2003, the
    Predecessor Company adopted the fair value method of recording
    stock-based employee compensation contained in
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123 &#147;Accounting for Stock-Based
    Compensation&#148; (&#147;SFAS&#160;123&#148;) and accounted for
    this change in accounting principle using the &#147;prospective
    method&#148; as described by SFAS&#160;No.&#160;148,
    &#147;Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation&#160;&#151;
    Transition and Disclosure, an amendment of FASB Statement
    No.&#160;123&#148; (&#147;SFAS&#160;148&#148;). Accordingly, the
    fair values of all Predecessor Company stock option and warrant
    grants, as determined on the date of grant, were amortized as
    compensation expense in the statements of operations over the
    vesting period. All stock options and warrants were cancelled
    upon emergence from the second bankruptcy.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Effective with the emergence from bankruptcy and merger with
    America West Holdings, US&#160;Airways applied the provisions of
    Accounting Principles Board (&#147;APB&#148;) Opinion
    No.&#160;25, &#147;Accounting for Stock Issued to
    Employees&#148; (&#147;APB&#160;25&#148;) and related
    interpretations to account for awards of stock-based
    compensation granted to employees. If US&#160;Airways had
    applied the fair value based recognition provisions of
    SFAS&#160;123, stock-based compensation expense would have been
    $1&#160;million greater for the three months ended
    December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Effective January&#160;1, 2006, US&#160;Airways adopted
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123R, &#147;Share-Based Payment&#148;
    (&#147;SFAS&#160;123R&#148;), using the modified prospective
    transition method. Under the modified prospective transition
    method, compensation cost is recognized in the financial
    statements beginning with the effective date based on the
    requirements of SFAS&#160;123R for all share-based payments
    granted after that date, and based on the requirements of
    SFAS&#160;123 for all unvested awards granted prior to the
    effective date of SFAS&#160;123R. Results for prior periods are
    not restated using the modified prospective transition method.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(o)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Maintenance
    and Repair Costs</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Maintenance and repair costs for owned and leased flight
    equipment are charged to operating expense as incurred.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(p)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Selling
    expenses</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Selling expenses include commissions, credit card fees,
    computerized reservations systems fees and advertising and
    promotional expenses. Advertising and promotional expenses are
    expensed when incurred. Advertising and promotional expenses for
    the year ended December&#160;31, 2006, the three months ended
    December&#160;31, 2005, the nine months ended September&#160;30,
    2005, and the year ended December&#160;31, 2004 were
    $7&#160;million, $1&#160;million, $14&#160;million, and
    $27&#160;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(q)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Express
    Expenses</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Expenses associated with US&#160;Airways&#146; former
    MidAtlantic division, US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned
    regional airlines and affiliate regional airlines operating as
    US&#160;Airways Express have been classified as &#147;Express
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    expenses&#148; on the statements of operations. Express expenses
    on the statements of operations consist of the following (in
    millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
