<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(r)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Variable
    Interest Entities</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways determined that certain entities with which it
    has capacity purchase agreements are considered variable
    interest entities under Financial Accounting Standards Board
    (&#147;FASB&#148;) Interpretation No.&#160;46
    &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; as
    revised (&#147;FIN&#160;46(R)&#148;). US&#160;Airways has
    determined that it is not the primary beneficiary of any of
    these variable interest entities, and accordingly, does not
    consolidate any of the entities with which it has jet service
    agreements. (See also Note&#160;8(c)).
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(s)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Recent
    Accounting Pronouncements</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In June 2006, the Financial Accounting Standards Board
    (&#147;FASB&#148;) ratified Emerging Issues Task Force Issue
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;06-3</FONT>
    (&#147;EITF
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">06-3&#148;),</FONT>
    &#147;How Taxes Collected from Customers and Remitted to
    Governmental Authorities Should Be Presented in the Income
    Statement (That Is, Gross versus Net Presentation).&#148; The
    scope of EITF
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">06-3</FONT>
    includes any tax assessed by a governmental authority that is
    directly imposed on a revenue-producing transaction between a
    seller and a customer. This issue provides that a company may
    adopt a policy of presenting taxes either gross within revenue
    or net. If taxes subject to this issue are significant, a
    company is required to disclose its accounting policy for
    presenting taxes and the amount of such taxes that are
    recognized on a gross basis. This statement is effective to
    financial reports for interim and annual reporting periods
    beginning after December&#160;15, 2006. US&#160;Airways adopted
    EITF <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">06-3</FONT> on
    January&#160;1, 2007. US&#160;Airways collects various excise
    taxes on its ticket sales, which are accounted for on a net
    basis. The adoption of EITF
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">06-3</FONT> will
    not have a material impact on US&#160;Airways&#146; financial
    statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In September 2006, the FASB issued SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157,
    &#147;Fair Value Measurements.&#148; This standard defines fair
    value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value in
    accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of
    America, and expands disclosure about fair value measurements.
    This pronouncement applies to other accounting standards that
    require or permit fair value measurements. Accordingly, this
    statement does not require any new fair value measurement. This
    statement is effective for fiscal years beginning after
    November&#160;15, 2007, and interim periods within those fiscal
    years. US&#160;Airways will be required to adopt
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157 in the first quarter of fiscal year 2008.
    Management is currently evaluating the requirements of
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157 and has not yet determined the impact on
    US&#160;Airways&#146; financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Effective December&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways adopted the
    recognition provisions of SFAS&#160;No.&#160;158,
    &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting for Defined Benefit Pension and
    Other Postretirement Plans, an amendment of FASB Statements
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    179
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    No.&#160;87, 88, 106, and 132(R).&#148; This statement requires
    employers to recognize in their balance sheets the overfunded or
    underfunded status of defined benefit post-retirement plans,
    measured as the difference between the fair value of plan assets
    and the benefit obligation (the projected benefit obligation for
    pension plans and the accumulated postretirement benefit
    obligation for other postretirement plans). Employers must
    recognize the change in the funded status of the plan in the
    year in which the change occurs through other comprehensive
    income.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Prior to the adoption of the recognition provisions of
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;158, US&#160;Airways accounted for its
    postretirement benefit plans in accordance with
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;106, &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting for
    Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions.&#148;
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;106 required that the liability recorded
    should represent the actuarial present value of all future
    benefits attributable to an employees&#146; service rendered to
    date. Under SFAS&#160;No.&#160;106, changes in the funded status
    were not immediately recognized, rather, they were deferred and
    recognized ratably over future periods. The impact of adopting
    the recognition provisions of SFAS&#160;No.&#160;158 was not
    material. US&#160;Airways recognized a nominal amount of prior
    changes in the funded status of its postretirement benefit plans
    through accumulated other comprehensive income. The adoption of
    the recognition provisions of SFAS&#160;No.&#160;158 had no
    effect on US&#160;Airways&#146; statement of operations for the
    year ended December&#160;31, 2006 or for any prior period
    presented.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    This statement also requires plan assets and obligations to be
    measured as of the employer&#146;s balance sheet date. The
    measurement provisions of this statement will be effective for
    years beginning after December&#160;15, 2008. US&#160;Airways
    has not yet adopted the measurement provisions of this statement
    and is in the process of determining the impact of the adoption
    on its financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In September 2006, the FASB issued FASB Staff Position
    (&#147;FSP&#148;) No.&#160;AUG AIR-1 &#147;Accounting for
    Planned Major Maintenance Activities&#148;. This amends the
    existing major maintenance accounting guidance contained within
    the AICPA Industry Audit Guide &#147;Audits of Airlines&#148;
    and prohibits the use of the accrue in advance method of
    accounting for planned major maintenance activities for owned
    aircraft. The provisions of the announcement are applicable for
    fiscal years beginning after December&#160;15, 2006.
    US&#160;Airways currently uses the direct expense method of
    accounting for planned major maintenance, an acceptable method
    under generally accepted accounting principles in the United
    States of America. Therefore, the adoption of FSP No.&#160;AUG
    AIR-1 is not expected to have any material impact on
    US&#160;Airways&#146; financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In September 2006, the Securities and Exchange Commission
    (&#147;SEC&#148;) issued Staff Accounting
    Bulletin&#160;No.&#160;108 (&#147;SAB&#160;108&#148;). Due to
    diversity in practice among registrants, SAB&#160;108 expresses
    SEC staff views regarding the process by which misstatements in
    financial statements are evaluated for purposes of determining
    whether financial statement restatement is necessary.
    SAB&#160;108 is effective for fiscal years ending after
    November&#160;15, 2006. US&#160;Airways has adopted SAB&#160;108
    in the fourth quarter of 2006 and its adoption had no effect on
    the US&#160;Airways&#146; financial statements for the year
    ended December&#160;31, 2006 or for any prior period presented.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In June 2006, the FASB issued Interpretation No.&#160;48,
    &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes, an
    interpretation of FASB Statement No.&#160;109&#148;
    (&#147;FIN&#160;48&#148;), which clarifies the accounting for
    uncertainty in income taxes recognized in financial statements.
    FIN&#160;48 requires the impact of a tax position to be
    recognized in the financial statements if that position is more
    likely than not of being sustained by the taxing authority.
    US&#160;Airways will be required to adopt FIN&#160;48 in the
    first quarter of fiscal year 2007. Management has evaluated the
    requirements of FIN&#160;48 and does not expect it to have a
    material impact on US&#160;Airways&#146; financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On November&#160;10, 2005, the FASB issued FASB Staff Position
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;FAS&#160;123R-3,</FONT>
    &#147;Transition Election Related to Accounting for Tax Effects
    of Share-Based Payment Awards.&#148; US&#160;Airways elected to
    adopt the modified prospective method, which is the simplified
    method provided in the FASB Staff Position for calculating the
    tax effects of stock-based compensation pursuant to
    SFAS&#160;123R. The modified prospective method was used to
    determine the beginning balance of the additional paid-in
    capital pool (&#147;APIC pool&#148;) related to the tax effects
    of employee stock-based compensation. Due to
    US&#160;Airways&#146; history of tax net operating losses,
    US&#160;Airways had no beginning balance in the APIC pool at the
    date of adoption of SFAS&#160;123R on January&#160;1, 2006.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    180
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways uses the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">&#147;with-and-without&#148;</FONT>
    or &#147;incremental&#148; approach for determining the order in
    which tax benefits derived from the share-based payment awards
    are utilized. Using the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">with-and-without</FONT>
    approach, actual income taxes payable for the period are
    compared to the amount of income taxes that would have been
    payable if there had been no share-based compensation expense
    for tax purposes in excess of the compensation expense
    recognized for financial reporting purposes. As a result of this
    approach, tax net operating loss carryforwards not related to
    share-based compensation are utilized before the current
    period&#146;s share-based compensation deduction. As a result of
    this accounting treatment, US&#160;Airways has a fully reserved
    deferred tax asset of approximately $3&#160;million related to
    tax net operating loss carryforwards related to deductions for
    excess tax benefits. The benefit of the valuation allowance
    release related to these deductions will be recorded directly to
    equity as additional
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">paid-in-capital</FONT>
    when such benefits are realized.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">2.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Emergence
    from Bankruptcy</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(a)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Emergence
    and Claims Resolution</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On September&#160;16, 2005, the Bankruptcy Court entered an
    order approving and confirming the Joint Plan of Reorganization
    of US&#160;Airways, Inc. and Its Affiliated Debtors and
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Debtors-in-Possession</FONT>
    (the &#147;Plan of Reorganization&#148;). The Plan of
    Reorganization provides for a reorganization of each of the five
    Reorganized Debtors. In accordance with the Plan of
    Reorganization, US&#160;Airways Group entered into a merger
    transaction with America West Holdings.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Initially, the equity of the new US&#160;Airways Group was
    allocated to three categories of holders. First, existing shares
    of America West Holdings were converted into shares of common
    stock of US&#160;Airways Group. Second, the new equity investors
    received shares for their initial investments and the exercise
    of their options. Third, unsecured creditors of the Reorganized
    Debtors have received or will receive distributions totaling
    8.2&#160;million shares of the new common stock of
    US&#160;Airways Group in satisfaction of allowed unsecured
    claims, including shares issued to the Pension Benefit Guaranty
    Corporation (&#147;PBGC&#148;) and the Air Line Pilots
    Association (&#147;ALPA&#148;).
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Plan of Reorganization classified claims into classes
    according to their relative seniority and other criteria and
    provides for the treatment for each class of claims. Pursuant to
    the bankruptcy process, the Reorganized Debtors&#146; claims
    agent received approximately 4,600 timely-filed proofs of claims
    as of the general bar date totaling approximately
    $26.4&#160;billion in the aggregate, and approximately 530
    proofs of claims timely-filed by governmental entities totaling
    approximately $13.6&#160;billion in the aggregate. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, there are $472&#160;million of
    unresolved claims. The ultimate resolution of certain of the
    claims asserted against the Reorganized Debtors in the
    Chapter&#160;11 cases will be subject to negotiations, elections
    and Bankruptcy Court procedures. The value of stock ultimately
    distributed to any particular general unsecured creditor under
    the Plan of Reorganization will depend on a number of variables,
    including the value of any claims filed by that creditor, the
    aggregate of all general unsecured claims and the value of
    shares of the new common stock of US&#160;Airways Group in the
    marketplace at the time of distribution. The effects of these
    distributions were reflected in US&#160;Airways&#146; financial
    statements upon emergence and will not have any further impact
    on the results of operations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>PBGC Claim</I>&#160;&#151; On November&#160;12, 2004,
    US&#160;Airways filed a motion requesting a determination from
    the Bankruptcy Court that US&#160;Airways satisfied the
    financial requirements for a &#147;distress termination&#148;
    under section&#160;4041(c)(2)(B)(ii)(IV) of the Employee
    Retirement Security Act of 1974, as amended (&#147;ERISA&#148;),
    of the Retirement Plan for Flight Attendants in the Service of
    US&#160;Airways, Inc. (&#147;AFA Plan&#148;), the Pension Plan
    for Employees of US&#160;Airways, Inc. Who Are Represented by
    the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace
    Workers (the &#147;IAM Plan&#148;), and the Retirement Plan for
    Certain Employees of US&#160;Airways, Inc. (the &#147;CE
    Plan&#148;), as well as approval of each plan&#146;s
    termination. These plans had aggregate benefit obligations of
    $2.71&#160;billion and aggregate plan assets of
    $1.76&#160;billion, as of the plans&#146; termination dates in
    January 2005. On January&#160;6, 2005, the Bankruptcy Court
    entered an order (i)&#160;finding that the financial
    requirements for a distress termination of the plans had been
    met and (ii)&#160;approving termination of the plans. The AFA
    Plan and the IAM Plan were terminated effective January&#160;10,
    2005, which was the date agreed to by the PBGC and
    US&#160;Airways. The CE
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    181
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Plan was terminated effective January&#160;17, 2005, which was
    the date agreed to by the PBGC and US&#160;Airways. Effective
    February&#160;1, 2005, the PBGC was appointed trustee for each
    of the three plans. As a result of these terminations, the PBGC
    filed claims against US&#160;Airways for the unfunded portion of
    each of the plans. Under the Plan of Reorganization, the PBGC
    received, as treatment for its claims: (i)&#160;cash in the
    amount of $13,500,000; (ii)&#160;an unsecured promissory note in
    the principal amount of $10,000,000 issued by US&#160;Airways
    and guaranteed by US&#160;Airways Group, bearing interest at a
    rate of 6.00%&#160;per annum payable annually in arrears, with
    such promissory note to be payable in a single installment on
    the seventh anniversary of the effective date of the Plan of
    Reorganization; and (iii)&#160;70%, or 4,873,485&#160;shares, of
    the common stock of US&#160;Airways Group issued to the
    unsecured creditors, net of shares allocated to ALPA.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Agreements with ALPA</I>&#160;&#151; On September&#160;14,
    2005, US&#160;Airways Group, US&#160;Airways, America West
    Holdings and AWA reached agreement with the two ALPA-represented
    pilot groups at the separate airlines on a comprehensive
    agreement (the &#147;Transition Agreement&#148;) that will
    govern many merger-related aspects of the parties&#146;
    relationships until there is a single collective bargaining
    agreement covering all pilots. US&#160;Airways Group and
    US&#160;Airways had entered into a separate letter of agreement
    that provided that US&#160;Airways&#146; pilots designated by
    ALPA would receive 1.25&#160;million shares of US&#160;Airways
    Group common stock and options to purchase 1.1&#160;million
    shares of US&#160;Airways Group common stock. The
    1.25&#160;million shares were drawn from the 8.2&#160;million
    shares initially allocated to unsecured creditors in the Plan of
    Reorganization and were issued to the pilots in accordance with
    the instructions provided by ALPA during the fourth quarter of
    2005. The options will be issued according to the following
    schedule: the first tranche of 500,000 options was issued on
    January&#160;31, 2006, a second tranche of 300,000 options was
    issued on January&#160;31, 2007, and the third tranche of
    300,000 options will be issued on January&#160;31, 2008. The
    options will have a term of five years from date of issuance.
    The exercise price for each tranche of options is the average of
    the closing price per share of US&#160;Airways Group common
    stock as reflected on the New York Stock Exchange for the 20
    business day period prior to the applicable option issuance
    date. The letter of agreement also includes provisions
    restricting transfer of the options and governing anti-dilution.
    In connection with the negotiation of the Transition Agreement
    and the letter of agreement, US&#160;Airways also agreed with
    ALPA to eliminate an existing 1% pay reduction that would have
    otherwise applied to all pilots as a result of a lump sum
    payment due to pilots recalled from furlough and further agreed
    to pay $500,000 to resolve an outstanding grievance over pay
    credits for pilots assigned by US&#160;Airways to travel to and
    from certain duty assignments.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    While a significant amount of the Reorganized Debtors&#146;
    liabilities were extinguished as a result of the discharge
    granted upon confirmation of the Plan of Reorganization, not all
    of the Reorganized Debtors&#146; liabilities were subject to
    discharge. The types of obligations that the Reorganized Debtors
    remain responsible for include those relating to their secured
    financings, aircraft financings, certain environmental
    liabilities, the continuing obligations arising under contracts
    and leases assumed by the Reorganized Debtors and certain
    grievances with labor unions, as well as allowed administrative
    claims. Allowed administrative claims consist primarily of the
    costs and expenses of administration of the Chapter&#160;11
    cases, including the costs of operating the Reorganized
    Debtors&#146; businesses since filing for bankruptcy. The
    Bankruptcy Court set August&#160;22, 2005 and November&#160;14,
    2005 as the bar dates by which creditors asserting
    administrative claims, other than administrative claims arising
    in the ordinary course of business, were required to be filed.
    The Reorganized Debtors received a large number of timely filed
    administrative claims, as well as additional claims that were
    filed late without permission of the Bankruptcy Court. Included
    in these claims, however, are claims for amounts arising in the
    ordinary course that have either already been paid, or that are
    included in the Reorganized Debtors&#146; business plan and are
    expected to be paid in the ordinary course. Also included are
    claims that are duplicative, claims for which the Reorganized
    Debtors believe there is no legal merit for a claim of any
    status, and claims that the Reorganized Debtors believe may be
    valid as unsecured claims but are not entitled to administrative
    claims status. Accordingly, the Reorganized Debtors believe that
    only a very small portion of the claims filed in response to the
    bar dates for non-ordinary course administrative expense claims
    will actually be allowed in amounts exceeding the ordinary
    course expenditures already contained in the Reorganized
    Debtors&#146; business plan. However, there can be no assurances
    that the aggregate amount of the claims
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    182
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    ultimately allowed will not be material. To the extent any of
    these claims are allowed, they will generally be satisfied in
    full.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(b)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Fresh-start
    Reporting and Purchase Accounting</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with its emergence from bankruptcy on
    September&#160;27, 2005, US&#160;Airways adopted fresh-start
    reporting in accordance with
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">SOP&#160;90-7.</FONT>
    Accordingly, US&#160;Airways valued its assets and liabilities
    at fair value. In addition, as a result of the merger which is
    accounted for as a reverse acquisition under
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;141 &#147;Business Combinations,&#148;
    (&#147;SFAS&#160;141&#148;) with America West Holdings as the
    accounting acquirer, US&#160;Airways Group applied the
    provisions of SFAS&#160;141 and allocated the purchase price to
    the assets and liabilities of US&#160;Airways Group and to its
    wholly owned subsidiaries including US&#160;Airways. The
    purchase price or value of the merger consideration was
    determined based upon America West Holdings&#146; traded market
    price per share due to the fact that US&#160;Airways Group was
    operating under bankruptcy protection. The $4.82&#160;per share
    value was based on the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">five-day</FONT>
    average share price of America West Holdings common stock, with
    May&#160;19, 2005, the merger announcement date, as the
    midpoint. Certain unsecured creditors of US&#160;Airways Group
    have been or will be issued an aggregate of approximately
    8.2&#160;million shares of US&#160;Airways Group common stock in
    settlement of their claims, including stock issued to the PBGC
    and ALPA. The fair value of that common stock valued at an
    equivalent price based on the $4.82 value of the America West
    Holdings stock is $96&#160;million, which was determined to be
    the reorganization value of US&#160;Airways Group. America West
    Holdings incurred $21&#160;million of direct acquisition costs
    in connection with the merger. The following table summarizes
    the purchase price (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways&#146; equity value of $1&#160;million was
    determined based on an allocation of the purchase price to each
    of US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s subsidiaries&#146; fair values
    of assets and liabilities. The remaining equity of
    $116&#160;million was assigned to US&#160;Airways Group and its
    other subsidiaries. In connection with US&#160;Airways&#146;
    emergence from bankruptcy, significant prepetition liabilities
    were discharged. The surviving liabilities and the assets
    acquired in the merger are shown at estimated fair value.
    Liabilities assumed reflects the discharge of $1.24&#160;billion
    of liabilities for postretirement benefits, $868&#160;million of
    liabilities related to the termination of US&#160;Airways&#146;
    defined benefit pension plans and $75&#160;million of
    liabilities related to trade accounts payable and other
    liabilities. Most of these obligations were only entitled to
    receive such distributions of cash and common stock as provided
    for under the Plan of Reorganization. The surviving liabilities
    and the assets acquired in the merger are shown at estimated
    fair value. US&#160;Airways used an outside appraisal firm to
    assist in determining the fair value of long-lived tangible and
    identifiable intangible assets. Significant assets and
    liabilities adjusted to fair market value include expendable
    spare parts and supplies, property and equipment, airport
    take-off and landing slots, aircraft leases, deferred revenue
    and continuing debt obligations. The foregoing estimates and
    assumptions are inherently subject to significant uncertainties
    and contingencies beyond the control of US&#160;Airways.
    Accordingly, there can be no assurance that the estimates,
    assumptions, and values reflected in the valuations will be
    realized, and actual results could vary materially
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The excess of the reorganization value over tangible assets and
    identifiable intangible assets and liabilities has been
    reflected as goodwill on the balance sheet of December&#160;31,
    2005. The net assets acquired and liabilities
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    183
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    assumed in connection with the merger and initial allocation of
    purchase price to US&#160;Airways are as follows (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="91%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As a result of the adoption of fresh-start reporting,
    US&#160;Airways&#146; post-emergence financial statements are
    not comparable with its pre-emergence financial statements,
    because they are, in effect, those of a new entity.
    US&#160;Airways also recorded certain purchase accounting
    adjustments specifically related to the merger with America West
    Holdings. The purchase accounting adjustments include those made
    to conform the accounting policies of US&#160;Airways to those
    of America West Holdings, including an adjustment to reduce the
    air traffic liability by $124&#160;million to conform its
    accounting policies for recognizing revenue from forfeited
    tickets, and an increase to noncurrent employee benefit
    liabilities and other of $16&#160;million to conform to America
    West Holdings&#146; policy of not discounting its workers
    compensation liability. Adjustments to conform accounting
    policies were recorded as direct adjustments to goodwill. In
    connection with the merger, primarily due to the relocation of
    the corporate headquarters from Arlington, Virginia to Tempe,
    Arizona, US&#160;Airways accrued in purchase accounting
    $24&#160;million of severance and benefits related to planned
    reductions in force for its non-union employees. US&#160;Airways
    Group incurred additional severance and benefits for reductions
    in force related to the merger; however, due to requirements for
    continued service during the integration period, these severance
    and benefits were not recorded as an adjustment to the purchase
    price allocation but were expensed. See Note&#160;3
    &#147;Special Items, net&#148; for discussion of amounts
    expensed for severance and benefits in the fourth quarter of
    2005 and during 2006.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    184
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

    and purchase accounting through December&#160;31, 2005 on the

    millions):

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Reflects the discharge or reclassification of estimated
    liabilities subject to compromise. Most of these obligations are
    only entitled to receive such distributions of cash and common
    stock as provided for under the Plan of Reorganization. A
    portion of the estimated liabilities subject to compromise was
    restructured and will continue, as restructured, to be
    liabilities of the Successor Company.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Includes adjustments to reflect assets and liabilities at fair
    value and the write-off of the Predecessor Company&#146;s equity
    accounts.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In conjunction with the merger and application of purchase
    accounting, US&#160;Airways adjusted certain balances to conform
    its accounting policies to those of America West Holdings.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In accordance with SFAS&#160;141, the allocation of equity
    values is subject to adjustment within one year after the date
    of acquisition when additional information on asset and
    liability valuations becomes available.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Adjustments made in the year ended December&#160;31, 2006 to
    previously recorded fair values are as follows (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="background: #CCEEFF">
<TD align="left" valign="bottom">
<DIV style="text-indent: -10pt; margin-left: 10pt">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">Goodwill reported as of
    December&#160;31, 2006
    </FONT>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
    $
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="right" valign="bottom">
    629
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Adjustments recorded in 2006 resulted as further refinement of
    information became available on assets and liabilities that
    existed as of the acquisition date. Significant adjustments
    included an adjustment for pre-merger NOL utilization related to
    NOL utilized that was generated by US&#160;Airways prior to the
    merger which in accordance with SFAS&#160;No.&#160;109 the
    associated decrease in the valuation allowance reduced goodwill;
    an adjustment to accounts receivable to reflect credits due from
    Republic related to pre-merger aircraft lease assumptions;
    adjustments to materials and supplies for the refinement of fair
    market value information available at the time of the
    acquisition; adjustments to other assets for the application of
    pre-merger airport operating expense and rent credits and a fair
    market value adjustment to an investment and adjustments to
    employee benefits for refinements of estimated liabilities for
    US&#160;Airways&#146; long term disability plans.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(c)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Reorganization
    Items, Net</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">SOP&#160;90-7</FONT>
    requires that the financial statements for periods following the
    Chapter&#160;11 filing through emergence distinguish
    transactions and events that are directly associated with the
    reorganization from the ongoing operations of the business.
    Accordingly, revenues, expenses, realized gains and losses and
    provisions for losses directly associated with the
    reorganization and restructuring of the business are reported
    separately as reorganization items,
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    186
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

    net in the statements of operations. Reorganization items, net
    as shown on the statements of operations related to the

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In January 2005, the Bankruptcy Court approved settlement
    agreements between US&#160;Airways and its unions and the
    court-appointed Section&#160;1114 Committee, representing
    retirees other than those represented by the IAM and TWU, to
    begin the significant curtailment of postretirement medical
    benefits. US&#160;Airways recognized a gain of $183&#160;million
    in connection with this curtailment in the first quarter of
    2005. Upon the emergence from bankruptcy and effectiveness of
    the Plan of Reorganization, an additional gain of
    $1.24&#160;billion was recognized as the liability associated
    with the postretirement medical benefits was reduced to fair
    market value. See also Note&#160;6.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Also in January 2005, US&#160;Airways terminated three defined
    benefit plans related to the flight attendants, mechanics and
    certain other employees (see Note&#160;6). The PBGC was
    appointed trustee of the plans upon termination. US&#160;Airways
    recognized a curtailment gain of $24&#160;million and a
    $91&#160;million minimum pension liability adjustment in
    connection with the terminations in the first quarter of 2005.
    Upon the effective date of the Plan of Reorganization and in
    connection with the settlement with the PBGC, the remaining
    liabilities associated with these plans were written off, net of
    settlement amounts.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Reflects the discharge of trade accounts payable and other
    liabilities upon emergence from bankruptcy. Most of these
    obligations were only entitled to receive such distributions of
    cash and common stock as provided for under the plan of
    reorganization in each of the bankruptcies. A portion of the
    liabilities subject to compromise in the bankruptcies were
    restructured and continued, as restructured, to be liabilities
    of the Successor Company.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    As a result of US&#160;Airways&#146; bankruptcy filing in
    September 2004, US&#160;Airways was not able to secure the
    financing necessary to take on-time delivery of three scheduled
    regional jet aircraft and therefore accrued penalties of
    $3&#160;million until delivery of these aircraft was made to a
    US&#160;Airways Express affiliate in August 2005. Offsetting
    these penalties is the reversal of $33&#160;million in penalties
    recorded by US&#160;Airways in the nine months ended
    December&#160;31, 2003 due to its intention not to take delivery
    of certain aircraft scheduled for future delivery. In connection
    with the Airbus Memorandum of Understanding (&#147;MOU&#148;),
    the accrual for these penalties was reversed (see also
    Note&#160;3).</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    187
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    As the result of US&#160;Airways&#146; bankruptcy filing in
    September 2004, it failed to meet the conditions precedent for
    continued financing of regional jets and was not able to take
    delivery of scheduled aircraft and therefore incurred penalties
    of $7&#160;million in the fourth quarter of 2004.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (e) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Damage and deficiency claims are largely a result of
    US&#160;Airways&#146; election to either restructure, abandon or
    reject aircraft debt and leases during the bankruptcy
    proceedings. As a result of the confirmation of the Plan of
    Reorganization and the effectiveness of the merger, these claims
    were withdrawn and the accruals reversed.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (f) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    As of September&#160;30, 2005, US&#160;Airways recorded
    $1.5&#160;billion of adjustments to reflect assets and
    liabilities at fair value, including an initial net write-down
    of goodwill of $1.82&#160;billion. Goodwill of $584&#160;million
    was recorded to reflect the excess of the estimated fair value
    of liabilities and equity over identifiable assets. Subsequent
    to September&#160;30, 2005, US&#160;Airways reduced goodwill by
    $103&#160;million to reflect adjustments to the fair value of
    certain assets and liabilities. See Note 2(b) for a description
    of changes in goodwill subsequent to September&#160;30, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (g) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In connection with filing for bankruptcy on September&#160;12,
    2004, US&#160;Airways achieved cost-savings agreements with its
    principal collective bargaining groups. In connection with the
    new labor agreements, approximately 5,000 employees across
    several of US&#160;Airways&#146; labor groups were involuntarily
    terminated or participated in voluntary furlough and termination
    programs.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (h) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In connection with the Airbus MOU, US&#160;Airways was required
    to pay a restructuring fee of $39&#160;million, which was paid
    by means of offset against existing equipment deposits held by
    Airbus. US&#160;Airways also received credits from Airbus
    totaling $4&#160;million in 2005, primarily related to equipment
    deposits. See also Note&#160;3.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (i) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The GE Merger MOU provided for the continued use of certain
    leased Airbus, Boeing and regional jet aircraft, the
    modification of monthly lease rates and the return of certain
    other leased Airbus and Boeing aircraft. The GE Merger MOU also
    provided for the sale-leaseback of assets securing various GE
    obligations. In connection with these transactions,
    US&#160;Airways recorded a net loss of $5&#160;million.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">3.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Special
    Items, Net</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <TD width="95%"></TD>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In connection with the merger with America West Holdings,
    US&#160;Airways incurred $15&#160;million of transition and
    merger integration costs in the fourth quarter of 2005. These
    items included $7&#160;million in insurance premiums related to
    policies for former officers and directors; $5&#160;million for
    severance, retention payments and stock awards; $1&#160;million
    of aircraft livery costs; $1&#160;million of programming service
    expense; and $1&#160;million in other expenses.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In connection with the merger, US&#160;Airways incurred
    $64&#160;million of transition and merger integration costs in
    2006. These items included $25&#160;million in personnel costs
    for severance, retention payments and stock awards;
    $2&#160;million of aircraft livery costs; $23&#160;million in
    professional and technical fees; $3&#160;million in training
    related expenses; $7&#160;million in employee moving expenses;
    $4&#160;million of other expenses; $1&#160;million of aircraft
    lease </TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Due to the requirements for continued service, severance expense
    is recorded over the remaining service period. The Company
    expects to record severance expense and make remaining
    termination and benefit payments of $1&#160;million during 2007.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In connection with the merger and the Airbus MOU executed
    between AVSA S.A.R.L, an affiliate of Airbus S.A.S.
    (&#147;Airbus&#148;), US&#160;Airways Group, US&#160;Airways and
    AWA, certain aircraft firm orders were restructured. In
    connection with that restructuring, US&#160;Airways Group and
    America West Holdings were required to pay restructuring fees
    totaling $89&#160;million by means of set-off against existing
    equipment deposits of US&#160;Airways and AWA held by Airbus of
    $39&#160;million and $50&#160;million, respectively. Also in
    connection with the Airbus MOU, US&#160;Airways and AWA entered
    into two loan agreements with aggregate commitments of up to
    $161&#160;million and $89&#160;million. As described in further
    detail in Note&#160;5, on March&#160;31, 2006, the outstanding
    principal and accrued interest on the $89&#160;million loan was
    forgiven upon repayment in full of the $161&#160;million loan in
    accordance with terms of the Airbus loans. As a result,
    US&#160;Airways recognized a gain associated with the return of
    these equipment deposits upon forgiveness of the loan totaling
    $40&#160;million, consisting of the $39&#160;million in
    equipment deposits and accrued interest of $1&#160;million.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In the fourth quarter of 2006, US&#160;Airways recognized a
    $3&#160;million gain in connection with the settlement of a
    property tax bankruptcy claim.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">4.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Financial
    Instruments</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(a)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">General</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On January&#160;1, 1998, as part of a comprehensive information
    technology services agreement with Sabre, US&#160;Airways was
    granted two tranches of stock options (&#147;SHC Stock
    Options&#148;) to acquire up to 6,000,000&#160;shares of
    Class&#160;A Common Stock, $0.01&#160;par value, of Sabre
    Holdings Corporation (&#147;SHC Common Stock&#148;),
    Sabre&#146;s parent company. Each tranche included 3,000,000
    stock options. In December 1999, US&#160;Airways exercised the
    first tranche of stock options at an exercise price of
    $27&#160;per option and received proceeds of $81&#160;million in
    January 2000 in lieu of receiving SHC Common Stock. Realized
    gains resulting from the exercise of Sabre options are subject
    to a clawback provision. Under the clawback provision, if
    US&#160;Airways elects to terminate its information technology
    service agreement with Sabre it will be required to pay Sabre an
    amount equal to the gain multiplied by the ratio of the
    remaining months in the contract period over 180&#160;months.
    The deferred gain from the 1999 exercise is amortized on a
    straight-line basis over a contractually determined period
    ending December 2012. In February 2000, SHC declared a cash
    dividend resulting in a dilution adjustment to the terms of the
    second tranche. The adjusted terms of the second tranche include
    stock options to acquire 3,406,914&#160;shares of SHC Common
    Stock at an exercise price of $23.78 subject to an
    $111.83&#160;per share cap on the fair market value of the
    underlying common stock. These options are exercisable during a
    ten-year period beginning January&#160;2, 2003. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, the fair value of the SHC Stock Options
    was $21&#160;million and was recorded in other assets, net.
    US&#160;Airways anticipates exercising the second tranche of
    options and converting the related shares to cash in connection
    with the Sabre acquisition. Any
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    189
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    gain realized on the eventual sale of Sabre stock from the
    exercise of the second tranche of options will be subject to the
    same clawback provisions as the first tranche.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2004 US&#160;Airways utilized fixed price swap agreements and
    other similar instruments to manage its exposure related to jet
    fuel price changes. For the year ended December&#160;31, 2004,
    US&#160;Airways recognized gains of approximately
    $130&#160;million related to its fuel hedging activities. These
    recognized gains were primarily included in aircraft fuel and
    related taxes on the statements of operations. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, US&#160;Airways had no open
    fuel hedge positions in place. At December&#160;31, 2004,
    US&#160;Airways had $22&#160;million of unrealized gains related
    to previously liquidated fuel hedge positions. During the nine
    months ended September&#160;30, 2005, US&#160;Airways realized
    $17&#160;million of the gain as a reduction to aircraft fuel
    expense. The remaining $5&#160;million was recognized as a gain
    in reorganization items, net as part of fresh-start reporting.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

    <TD>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The carrying amount of cash equivalents approximates fair value
    because of the short-term nature of these investments. The
    carrying values of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">available-for-sale</FONT>
    securities approximate fair value. There were no unrealized
    gains or losses on these investments for the years ended
    December&#160;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004 due to the frequent
    resetting of interest rates on the auction rate securities..
    Gross proceeds from sales of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">available-for-sale</FONT>
    securities for the years ended December&#160;31, 2006, 2005 and
    2004 were $189&#160;million, $62&#160;million and zero,
    respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways had no long-term investments in debt securities
    as of December&#160;31, 2006 and December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Long-term
    Debt</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, the fair value of long-term
    debt was approximately $1.25&#160;billion and
    $1.97&#160;billion, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways&#146; variable rate long-term debt with a
    carrying value of $336&#160;million and $1.13&#160;billion at
    December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively, approximates fair
    value because these borrowings have variable interest rate terms
    that approximate market interest rates for similar debt
    instruments. The fair value of US&#160;Airways&#146; other
    long-term debt is determined based on quoted market prices, if
    available, or market prices for comparable debt instruments.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    190
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (a) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    On March&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group entered into a
    loan agreement with General Electric Capital Corporation
    (&#147;GECC&#148;) and a syndicate of lenders pursuant to which
    the Company borrowed an aggregate principal amount of
    $1.1&#160;billion. On April&#160;7, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group
    entered into an amended and restated loan agreement, which
    increased the principal amount of the loan to $1.25&#160;billion
    (as amended and restated, the &#147;GE Loan&#148;).
    US&#160;Airways, America West Holdings, AWA, and other
    subsidiaries of US&#160;Airways Group are all guarantors of the
    GE Loan.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    On March&#160;31, 2006, proceeds of the GE Loan were used, in
    part, to repay in full the following indebtedness of
    US&#160;Airways:</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The amended and restated US&#160;Airways loans entered into on
    September&#160;27, 2005 that had previously been guaranteed by
    the Air Transportation Stabilization Board (the
    &#147;ATSB&#148;). On October&#160;19, 2005, $539&#160;million
    of the loans, of which $525&#160;million had been guaranteed by
    the ATSB, was sold by the lenders by order of the ATSB to 13
    fixed income investors, for which Citibank, N.A. served as
    agent, removing the ATSB guarantee (the &#147;Citibank
    Loans&#148;). As a result of the sale of the loan, the
    US&#160;Airways ATSB Loan is now called the US&#160;Airways East
    Citibank Loan. At the time of repayment of these loans on
    March&#160;31, 2006, the total outstanding balance of the loan
    was $551&#160;million.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The $161&#160;million loan entered into as of September&#160;27,
    2005 between US&#160;Airways and AWA and Airbus Financial
    Services, for which US&#160;Airways Group was the guarantor. At
    the time of repayment on March&#160;31,
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    191
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
