<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    2006, the outstanding balance of the loan was $161&#160;million.
    US&#160;Airways and AWA also had an $89&#160;million loan from
    Airbus Financial Services entered into as of September&#160;27,
    2005. In accordance with the terms of the loan agreements, the
    outstanding principal amount of the $89&#160;million loan was to
    be forgiven on the earlier of December&#160;31, 2010 or the date
    that the outstanding principal amount of, accrued interest on,
    and all other amounts due under the Airbus $161&#160;million
    loan were paid in full, provided that the US&#160;Airways Group
    complies with the delivery schedule for certain Airbus aircraft.
    As a result of the prepayment of the $161&#160;million loan on
    March&#160;31, 2006, the $89&#160;million loan agreement was
    terminated and the outstanding balance of $89&#160;million was
    forgiven.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (b) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In September 2005, US&#160;Airways entered into an agreement to
    sell and leaseback certain of its commuter slots at Ronald
    Reagan Washington National Airport and New York LaGuardia
    Airport. US&#160;Airways continues to hold the right to
    repurchase the slots anytime after the second anniversary of the
    slot sale-leaseback transaction. These transactions were
    accounted for as secured financings. Installments are due
    monthly through 2015 at a rate of 8%. In December 2006, Republic
    and US&#160;Airways modified terms of the agreement to conform
    with subsequent regulatory changes at LaGuardia, and the slots
    were returned to US&#160;Airways. The need for a subsequent
    modification was fully contemplated in the original agreement.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (c) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Capital lease obligations consist principally of certain airport
    maintenance and facility leases which expire in 2018 and 2021.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (d) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    General Electric, together with its affiliates (&#147;GE&#148;),
    is US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s largest aircraft creditor,
    having financed or leased a substantial portion of its aircraft
    prior to the most recent Chapter 11 filing. In June 2005, GE
    purchased the assets securing the credit facility obtained from
    GE in 2001 (the &#147;GE Credit Facility&#148;) in a
    sale-leaseback transaction. The sale proceeds realized from the
    sale-leaseback transaction were applied to repay the liquidity
    facility obtained from GE in 2003 in connection with
    US&#160;Airways&#146; emergence from its first bankruptcy (the
    &#147;2003 GE Liquidity Facility&#148;), the mortgage financing
    associated with the CRJ aircraft and a portion of the 2001 GE
    Credit Facility. The balance of the GECC Credit Facility was
    amended to allow additional borrowings of $21&#160;million in
    July 2005, which resulted in a total principal balance
    outstanding thereunder of $28&#160;million. The operating leases
    are cross-defaulted with all other GE obligations, other than
    excepted obligations, and are subject to agreed upon return
    conditions. On March&#160;31, 2006, the agreement was amended to
    change the maturity date from September&#160;30, 2010 to
    December&#160;31, 2008 and required US&#160;Airways to make
    equal quarterly principal payments through maturity beginning
    March&#160;31, 2006.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (e) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In December 2004, deferred charges under US&#160;Airways&#146;
    maintenance agreements with GE Engine Systems, Inc. were
    converted into a $54&#160;million unsecured term note. The
    original note balance of $54&#160;million was reduced by a
    credit of $9.4&#160;million as a result of the merger. Interest
    on the note accrues at LIBOR plus 4%, and becomes payable
    beginning in January 2008, at which time principal and interest
    payments are due in 48&#160;monthly installments.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD valign="top">
    (f) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In connection with US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s emergence from
    bankruptcy in September 2005, it reached a settlement with the
    PBGC related to the termination of three of its defined benefit
    pension plans, which included the issuance of a $10&#160;million
    note that matures in 2012 and bears interest at 6% payable
    annually in arrears.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Certain of US&#160;Airways&#146; long-term debt agreements
    contain minimum cash balance requirements and other covenants
    with which US&#160;Airways is in compliance. Certain of
    US&#160;Airways&#146; long-term debt agreements contain
    cross-default provisions, which may be triggered by defaults by
    AWA or US&#160;Airways Group under other agreements relating to
    indebtedness.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Interest rates on $336&#160;million principal amounts of
    long-term debt as of December&#160;31, 2006 are subject to
    adjustment to reflect changes in floating interest rates. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, the weighted average effective interest
    rate was 8.08% for the variable rate debt.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">6.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Employee
    Pension and Benefit Plans</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Substantially all of US&#160;Airways&#146; employees meeting
    certain service and other requirements are eligible to
    participate in various pension, medical, dental, life insurance,
    disability and survivorship plans.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(a)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Defined
    Benefit and Other Postretirement Benefit Plans</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On November&#160;12, 2004, US&#160;Airways filed a motion
    requesting a determination from the Bankruptcy Court that
    US&#160;Airways satisfied the financial requirements for a
    &#147;distress termination&#148; under
    section&#160;4041(c)(2)(B)(ii)(IV) of ERISA of the AFA Plan, the
    IAM Plan and the CE Plan, and approval of each such plan&#146;s
    termination. These plans had aggregate benefit obligations of
    $2.71&#160;billion and aggregate plan assets of
    $1.76&#160;billion, as of the plans&#146; termination dates in
    January 2005. On January&#160;6, 2005, the Bankruptcy Court
    entered an order (i)&#160;finding that the financial
    requirements for a distress termination of the plans had been
    met and (ii)&#160;approving termination of the plans. The AFA
    Plan and the IAM Plan were terminated effective January&#160;10,
    2005, which was the date agreed to by the PBGC and
    US&#160;Airways. The CE Plan was terminated effective
    January&#160;17, 2005, which was the date agreed to by the PBGC
    and US&#160;Airways. Effective February&#160;1, 2005, the PBGC
    was appointed trustee for each of the three plans.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Upon termination of the plans, US&#160;Airways recognized a
    curtailment gain of $24&#160;million and a $91&#160;million
    charge related to the minimum pension liability, which was
    previously recorded in other comprehensive income. These amounts
    are included in reorganization items, net in the statements of
    operations. Upon emergence from bankruptcy on September&#160;27,
    2005, the Bankruptcy Court approved a settlement agreement
    between US&#160;Airways and the PBGC which required the PBGC to
    release all claims against US&#160;Airways in return for
    US&#160;Airways issuing (i)&#160;a $13.5&#160;million cash
    payment, paid in October 2005, (ii)&#160;a 6.00%&#160;note
    payable for $10&#160;million, and (iii)&#160;70%, or
    4,873,485&#160;shares, of the unsecured creditors stock, net of
    the shares allocated to ALPA, valued at $57&#160;million.
    Accordingly, US&#160;Airways eliminated the $948&#160;million
    liability related to the three terminated plans, including the
    minimum liability adjustment, and recognized a net settlement
    gain of $868&#160;million. This gain is included in
    reorganization items, net in the statements of operations.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    193
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During hearings in late 2004 and January 2005, the Bankruptcy
    Court approved various settlement agreements between
    US&#160;Airways and its unions, and between US&#160;Airways and
    the court-appointed Section&#160;1114 Committee (representing
    retirees not represented by the unions) to begin the significant
    curtailments of postretirement benefits. Effective March&#160;1,
    2005, those benefits were significantly reduced. US&#160;Airways
    re-measured its postretirement benefit obligation based on the
    new terms, which resulted in a reduction in the postretirement
    benefit obligation of approximately $1.1&#160;billion and a
    curtailment gain of $183&#160;million. Since the remeasurement
    and reduction of the postretirement benefit obligation created a
    significant unrecognized prior service gain, US&#160;Airways
    recognized net periodic other postretirement benefit income
    until the emergence from bankruptcy on September&#160;27, 2005.
    In accordance with
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">SOP&#160;90-7,</FONT>
    US&#160;Airways revalued its postretirement benefit obligation
    on emergence, and adjusted its liability to $229&#160;million, a
    reduction of $1.25&#160;billion. Of this, a $1.24&#160;billion
    gain, including the recognition of the unamortized portion of
    the prior service gain created as a result of the benefit
    curtailment, is included in reorganization items, net in the
    statement of operations. Adjustments made subsequent to
    September&#160;30, 2005 totaling $10&#160;million were made
    directly to goodwill.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In December 2003, the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement
    and Modernization Act of 2003 (the &#147;Medicare Prescription
    Drug Act&#148;) became law in the United States. The Medicare
    Prescription Drug Act introduces a prescription drug benefit
    under Medicare as well as a federal subsidy to sponsors of
    retiree health care benefit plans that provide a benefit that is
    at least actuarially equivalent to the Medicare benefit.
    US&#160;Airways elected to recognize the effects of the Medicare
    Prescription Drug Act in the quarter ended June&#160;30, 2004,
    as permitted by FASB Staff Position
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">FAS&#160;106-2,</FONT>
    &#147;Accounting and Disclosure Requirements Related to the
    Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of
    2003.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The recognition of this subsidy resulted in a reduction in
    expense of $20&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31,
    2004 and a $198&#160;million actuarial gain that was subject to
    amortization, based over the remaining period to expected
    retirement. Significant assumptions included in the
    remeasurement of the accumulated postretirement benefit
    obligation were a 6.25% discount rate and a reduction in retiree
    participation in the company-sponsored plan as certain defined
    drug benefit caps make the plan more costly to retirees than
    Medicare.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As discussed in Note&#160;1, effective December&#160;31, 2006,
    US&#160;Airways adopted the recognition provisions of
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;158. In accordance with SFAS&#160;158,
    US&#160;Airways recognized a liability for the underfunded
    status of its postretirement benefit plans of $212&#160;million
    of which $183&#160;million is noncurrent. Additionally,
    US&#160;Airways recorded in accumulated other comprehensive
    income the prior service cost and net actuarial gain of its
    plans. Future changes to the funded status of these plans will
    be recognized in the year in which the change occurs through
    other comprehensive income. The impact of adoption of
    SFAS&#160;158 was not material and the amount recorded to other
    comprehensive income was nominal.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    194
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table sets forth changes in the fair value of plan
    assets, benefit obligations and the funded status of the plans
    as of the measurement date of September&#160;30, 2006 and 2005,
    in addition to the amounts recognized in US&#160;Airways&#146;
    balance sheets as of December&#160;31, 2006 and
    December&#160;31, 2005 (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The accumulated benefit obligation for defined benefit pension
    plans was zero as of September&#160;30, 2005 and
    December&#160;31, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (2) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In 2005, US&#160;Airways recognized curtailments and settlements
    related to the termination of its remaining material defined
    benefit pension plans. These curtailments and settlements were
    recognized in accordance with SFAS&#160;No.&#160;88,
    &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting for Settlements and
    Curtailments of Defined Benefit Pension Plans and for
    Termination Benefits.&#148; In 2005, US&#160;Airways recognized
    curtailments related to the significant redesign of the other
    postretirement benefit plans (primarily medical and dental
    benefits). These curtailments were recognized in accordance with
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;106, &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting for
    Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions.&#148;</TD>
</TR>

    <BR>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways&#146; September&#160;30, 2006 and 2005 assumed
    discount rates of 5.67% and 5.30%, respectively for measuring
    its other postretirement benefit obligations are based on a
    hypothetical portfolio of high quality publicly traded
    U.S.&#160;bonds (Aa rated, non-callable or callable with
    make-whole provisions), for which the timing and cash outflows
    approximate the estimated benefit payments of the other
    postretirement benefit plans.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of September&#160;30, 2006, the assumed health care cost
    trend rates are 10% in 2007 and 9% in 2008, decreasing to 5.5%
    in 2012 and thereafter. As of September&#160;30, 2005, the
    assumed health care cost trend rates were 10% in 2006 and 9% in
    2007, decreasing to 5% in 2011 and thereafter. The assumed
    health care cost trend rates could have a significant effect on
    amounts reported for retiree health care plans. A one-percentage
    point change in the health care cost trend rates would have the
    following effects on other postretirement benefits as of
    September&#160;30, 2006 (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="75%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=lead -->
    <TD width="8%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=lead -->
    <TD width="8%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=hang1 -->
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom" align="center">
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD colspan="2" nowrap align="center" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">
    <B>1% Increase</B>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD colspan="2" nowrap align="center" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">
    <B>1% Decrease</B>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">
<TD>&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="background: #CCEEFF">
<TD align="left" valign="bottom">
<DIV style="text-indent: -10pt; margin-left: 10pt">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">Effect on postretirement benefit
    obligation
    </FONT>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
    $
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="right" valign="bottom">
    13
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
    $
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="right" valign="bottom">
    (11
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
    )
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>

    in other comprehensive income (loss) was $120&#160;million and
    $(34)&#160;million for the nine months ended September&#160;30,
    2005 and the year ended December&#160;31, 2004, respectively.
    See Note&#160;9 for a reconciliation of the components of other
    comprehensive income.

    other postretirement plans in 2007. The following benefits,
    which reflect expected future service, as appropriate, are
    expected to be paid (in millions):

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(b)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Defined
    Contribution Plans</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways sponsors several defined contribution plans for
    certain employees. US&#160;Airways makes cash contributions to
    certain plans based on the employee&#146;s age, compensation and
    elected contributions. US&#160;Airways also participates in a
    multi-employer plan for certain employees. Company contributions
    as a percentage of compensation were generally reduced in late
    2004 in connection with US&#160;Airways&#146; restructured labor
    agreements and non-union wage and benefits reductions. Expenses
    related to these plans, excluding expenses related to the
    US&#160;Airways pilot defined contribution plans, were
    approximately $22&#160;million, $5&#160;million,
    $24&#160;million, $49&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006, the three months ended December&#160;31,
    2005, the nine months ended September&#160;30, 2005, and the
    year ended December&#160;31, 2004, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with first reorganization under Chapter&#160;11 of
    the Bankruptcy Code, US&#160;Airways terminated the Retirement
    Income Plan for Pilots of US&#160;Airways, Inc. and the related
    nonqualified pilot plan effective March&#160;31, 2003.
    US&#160;Airways implemented a qualified and nonqualified defined
    contribution plan for pilots effective April&#160;1, 2003. The
    defined contribution amount was individually determined based on
    a target normal retirement date balance of approximately
    $1&#160;million for a career US&#160;Airways pilot. The target
    balance included the estimated value of other retirement
    benefits including, but not limited to, the estimated benefit
    pilots are expected to receive from the PBGC, the trustee for
    the terminated pilot defined benefit plan. Effective
    October&#160;15, 2004, each pilot&#146;s
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    197
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    contribution rate became the lessor of the original rate or 10%
    of eligible compensation. Expenses for this plan were
    $42&#160;million, $10&#160;million, $32&#160;million, and
    $134&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006, the
    three months ended December&#160;31, 2005, the nine months ended
    September&#160;30, 2005, and the year ended December&#160;31,
    2004, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(c)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Postemployment
    Benefits</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways provides certain postemployment benefits to its
    employees. These benefits include disability-related benefits
    for certain employees. US&#160;Airways accrues for the cost of
    these benefit expenses once an appropriate triggering event has
    occurred.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(d)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Profit
    Sharing Plans</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Most non-executive employees of US&#160;Airways Group are
    eligible to participate in the 2005 Profit Sharing Plan, an
    annual bonus program, which was established subsequent to the
    merger. Annual bonus awards are paid from a profit-sharing pool
    equal to (i)&#160;ten percent of the annual profits of
    US&#160;Airways Group (excluding unusual items) for pre-tax
    profit margins up to ten percent, plus (ii)&#160;15% of the
    annual profits of US&#160;Airways Group (excluding unusual
    items) for pre-tax profit margins greater than ten percent.
    Awards are paid as a lump sum no later than March 15 after the
    end of each fiscal year. The profit-sharing pool is shared among
    eligible employee groups in proportion to each group&#146;s
    share of overall cost savings achieved through
    US&#160;Airways&#146; 2005 transformation plan; however, the
    represented pilots&#146; and flight attendants&#146; portions of
    the pool will not be less than 36% and 14.5%, respectively. An
    employee&#146;s share of the pool is based on the ratio that the
    employee&#146;s compensation bears to the respective employee
    group&#146;s aggregate compensation. US&#160;Airways recorded
    $36&#160;million for profit sharing in 2006, which is recorded
    in salaries and related costs.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">7.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Income
    Taxes</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways accounts for income taxes according to the
    provisions in SFAS&#160;No.&#160;109, &#147;Accounting for
    Income Taxes.&#148; US&#160;Airways files a consolidated federal
    income tax return with its parent company, US&#160;Airways
    Group. US&#160;Airways Group and its wholly owned subsidiaries
    allocate tax and tax items, such as net operating losses
    (&#147;NOL&#148;) and net tax credits, between members of the
    group based on their proportion of taxable income and other
    items. Accordingly, US&#160;Airways&#146; tax expense is based
    on its taxable income, taking into consideration its allocated
    tax loss carryforwards/carrybacks and tax credit carryforwards.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In assessing the realizability of the deferred tax assets,
    management considers whether it is more likely than not that
    some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will be realized.
    US&#160;Airways has recorded a valuation allowance against its
    net deferred tax asset. The ultimate realization of deferred tax
    assets is dependent upon the generation of future taxable income
    (including reversals of deferred tax liabilities) during the
    periods in which those temporary differences will become
    deductible.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways has a
    $580&#160;million federal net operating loss carryforwards with
    $428&#160;million expiring in 2024, $151&#160;million expiring
    in 2025, and $30&#160;million of alternative minimum tax credits
    which do not expire.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2006, US&#160;Airways utilized NOL that was generated
    prior to the merger. In accordance with SFAS&#160;No.&#160;109,
    as this was acquired NOL, the corresponding decrease in the
    valuation allowance reduced goodwill instead of the provision
    for income taxes. Accordingly, US&#160;Airways Group recognized
    $85&#160;million of non-cash tax expense for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006. As of December&#160;31, 2006, the
    remaining valuation allowance associated with acquired NOL is
    approximately $23&#160;million related to state NOL.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways is subject to Alternative Minimum Tax liability
    (&#147;AMT&#148;) for the full year 2006. In most cases, the
    recognition of AMT does not result in tax expense. However,
    since US&#160;Airways&#146; NOL was subject to a full valuation
    allowance, any liability for AMT is recorded as tax expense.
    US&#160;Airways recorded AMT expense of $1&#160;million for
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    198
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    the year ended December&#160;31, 2006. US&#160;Airways also
    recorded $3&#160;million of state income tax related to certain
    states where NOL was not available or limited, for the year
    ended December&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways is part of the US&#160;Airways Group
    consolidated income tax return for the tax year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006. The current tax provision for the
    12&#160;months ended December&#160;31, 2006 was prepared in
    accordance with this tax return methodology.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The components of the provision (credit) for income taxes are as
    follows (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    A reconciliation of taxes computed at the statutory federal tax
    rate on income (loss) before income taxes to the provision
    (credit) for income taxes is provided below (in millions):

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The tax effects of temporary differences that give rise to
    significant portions of the deferred tax assets and liabilities
    as of December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005 are as follows (in
    millions):

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Included in the employee benefit deferred tax assets at
    December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, among other items, are
    $100&#160;million and $90&#160;million, respectively, related to
    obligations of postretirement medical benefits.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The reason for significant differences between taxable and
    pretax book income primarily relates to depreciation of fixed
    assets, employee pension and postretirement benefit costs,
    employee-related accruals and leasing transactions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The federal income tax returns of US&#160;Airways through 2002
    have been examined and settled with the Internal Revenue
    Service. US&#160;Airways is not currently under examination.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">8.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Commitments
    and contingencies</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(a)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Commitments
    to Purchase Flight Equipment and Maintenance
    Services</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Airbus
    Purchase Commitments</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    To modernize US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s international product
    and improve the efficiency of its international network,
    US&#160;Airways Group was scheduled to begin accepting
    deliveries of Airbus A350 aircraft in 2011 pursuant to a
    purchase agreement that US&#160;Airways Group, US&#160;Airways
    and AWA entered into in September 2005 with Airbus.
    US&#160;Airways Group has been notified that the A350 will be
    undergoing significant design changes and will be delivered
    several years beyond the originally scheduled delivery dates.
    US&#160;Airways Group is currently evaluating the revised
    technical and commercial aspects of the A350 program.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    200
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In September 2005, US&#160;Airways Group amended its
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">A330/340</FONT>
    Purchase Agreement with Airbus dated as of November&#160;24,
    1998 to reschedule its order for ten A330-200 aircraft for
    delivery during the period 2009 and 2010. US&#160;Airways Group
    has the right to cancel these A330 orders in the event that
    US&#160;Airways makes certain predelivery payments under the
    A350 Purchase Agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The future commitments under purchase agreements with Airbus and
    US&#160;Airways&#160;Group totals $3.27&#160;billion as of
    December&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Embraer
    Purchase Commitments</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On June&#160;13, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group executed an Amended
    and Restated Purchase Agreement and an Amended and Restated
    Letter Agreement with Embraer. In accordance with the terms of
    these agreements, US&#160;Airways Group placed an initial firm
    order for 25 Embraer 190 aircraft and an additional firm order
    for 32&#160;Embraer 190 aircraft. The progress and deposit
    payments totaling approximately $18&#160;million previously paid
    by US&#160;Airways Group to Embraer in accordance with the terms
    of the Purchase Agreement dated as of May&#160;9, 2003, will be
    applied to these orders in accordance with the terms of the
    amended and restated agreements. In addition, US&#160;Airways
    Group has the option to purchase up to 50 additional Embraer 190
    aircraft and to convert certain of the Embraer 190 aircraft to
    Embraer 170, Embraer 175 or Embraer 195 aircraft, subject to
    availability and upon agreed notice. Embraer has agreed to
    provide financing for certain of the aircraft. On July&#160;21,
    2006, US&#160;Airways Group assigned 30 of the purchase options
    to Republic. On January&#160;12, 2007, US&#160;Airways Group
    assigned eight additional purchase options to Republic.
    US&#160;Airways Group purchased and took delivery of two Embraer
    190 aircraft in December 2006 and expects to take delivery of
    nine Embraer 190 aircraft in 2007 and 14 Embraer 190 aircraft in
    2008. The future commitments under the purchase agreement with
    Embraer an US&#160;Airways&#160;Group totals $661&#160;million
    as of December&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Bombardier
    Purchase Commitments</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On December&#160;14, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court approved a
    Global Settlement Letter between US&#160;Airways Group and
    Bombardier Inc., which had been executed by the parties on
    November&#160;10, 2006. The Global Settlement Letter amends the
    master purchase agreement dated as of May&#160;9, 2003, as
    amended, between US&#160;Airways Group and Bombardier. The
    Bankruptcy Court authorized the assumption of the master
    purchase agreement, as modified and amended by the Global
    Settlement Letter. The parties agreed to modify and amend the
    master purchase agreement to terminate all obligations of
    US&#160;Airways Group to purchase and take delivery of 42 firm
    aircraft remaining undelivered under the agreement, as well as
    the rights of US&#160;Airways Group to purchase and take
    delivery of 90 additional aircraft and options to take 94
    aircraft in the future. All obligations of Bombardier to
    manufacture and deliver these aircraft were also terminated. The
    master purchase agreement was amended to provide US&#160;Airways
    Group with the right to purchase Bombardier CRJ 200/700/900
    series aircraft from time to time during a period of five years.
    The Global Settlement Letter further provides that all
    pre-delivery payments held by Bombardier be returned to
    US&#160;Airways Group. Under the Global Settlement Letter, all
    claims of Bombardier asserted against US&#160;Airways Group and
    its subsidiaries in the Chapter&#160;11 cases were resolved and
    Bombardier was granted a total aggregate allowed general
    unsecured claim in the amount of $148&#160;million. The effect
    of distributions for general unsecured claims was reflected in
    US&#160;Airways&#146; financial statements upon emergence and
    will not have any further impact on the results of operations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Engine
    Maintenance Commitments</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with the merger, US&#160;Airways and AWA
    restructured their rate per engine hour agreements with General
    Electric Engine Services for overhaul maintenance services.
    Under the restructured agreements, the minimum monthly payment
    on account of accrued engine flight hours for both the
    US&#160;Airways and AWA agreements together will equal
    $3&#160;million as long as both agreements remain in effect or
    through October 2009.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    201
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(b)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Leases</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways leases certain aircraft, engines and ground
    equipment, in addition to the majority of its ground facilities
    and terminal space. As of December&#160;31, 2006,
    US&#160;Airways had 221 aircraft under operating leases, with
    remaining terms ranging from one month to approximately
    17&#160;years. Ground facilities include maintenance facilities
    and ticket and administrative offices. Public airports are
    utilized for flight operations under lease arrangements with the
    municipalities or agencies owning or controlling such airports.
    Substantially all leases provide that the lessee must pay taxes,
    maintenance, insurance and certain other operating expenses
    applicable to the leased property. Some leases also include
    renewal and purchase options.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, obligations under noncancelable
    operating leases for future minimum lease payments were as
    follows (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For the year ended December&#160;31, 2006, the three months
    ended December&#160;31, 2005, the nine months ended
    September&#160;30, 2005, and the year ended December&#160;31,
    2004, rental expense under operating leases was
    $775&#160;million, $180&#160;million, $532&#160;million, and
    $758&#160;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways also leases certain owned flight equipment to
    related parties (see Note&#160;10(b)) under noncancelable
    operating leases expiring in various years through the year
    2022. The future minimum rental receipts associated with these
    leases are: $78&#160;million in 2007, $78&#160;million in 2008,
    $78&#160;million 2009, $78&#160;million in 2010,
    $78&#160;million in 2011 and $616&#160;million thereafter. The
    following amounts relate to aircraft leased under such
    agreements as reflected in flight equipment as of
    December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005 (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
