</TR>
</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways has set up pass through trusts, also known as
    &#147;Enhanced Equipment Trust&#160;Certificates&#148; or
    &#147;EETC&#148;, covering the financing of 19 owned aircraft
    and 62 leased aircraft. These trusts are off-balance sheet
    entities, the primary purpose of which is to finance the
    acquisition of aircraft. Rather than finance each aircraft
    separately when such aircraft is purchased or delivered, these
    trusts allow US&#160;Airways to raise the financing for several
    aircraft at one time and place such funds in escrow pending the
    purchase or delivery of the relevant aircraft. The trusts are
    also structured to provide for certain credit enhancements, such
    as liquidity facilities to cover certain interest payments, that
    reduce the risks to the purchasers of the trust certificates
    and, as a result, reduce the cost of aircraft financing to
    US&#160;Airways.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Each trust covered a set amount of aircraft scheduled to be
    delivered within a specific period of time. At the time of each
    covered aircraft financing, the relevant trust used the funds in
    escrow to purchase equipment notes relating to the financed
    aircraft. The equipment notes were issued, at
    US&#160;Airways&#146; election, either by US&#160;Airways in
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    202
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    connection with a mortgage financing of the aircraft or by a
    separate owner trust in connection with a leveraged lease
    financing of the aircraft. In the case of a leveraged lease
    financing, the owner trust then leased the aircraft to
    US&#160;Airways. In both cases, the equipment notes are secured
    by a security interest in the aircraft. The pass through trust
    certificates are not direct obligations of, nor are they
    guaranteed by, US&#160;Airways Group or US&#160;Airways.
    However, in the case of mortgage financings, the equipment notes
    issued to the trusts are direct obligations of US&#160;Airways.
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, $615&#160;million associated with
    these mortgage financings is reflected as debt in the
    accompanying balance sheet.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition, neither US&#160;Airways Group nor US&#160;Airways
    guarantee or participate in any way in the residual value of the
    leased aircraft. All aircraft financed by these trusts are
    currently structured as leveraged lease financings, which are
    not reflected as debt on the balance sheets of either
    US&#160;Airways Group or US&#160;Airways. US&#160;Airways does
    not provide residual value guarantees under these lease
    arrangements. Each lease contains a purchase option that allows
    US&#160;Airways to purchase the aircraft at a fixed price, which
    at the inception of the lease approximated the aircraft&#146;s
    expected fair market value at the option date, near the end of
    the lease term.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    These leasing entities meet the criteria for variable interest
    entities. However, they do not meet the consolidation criteria
    under FIN&#160;46(R) because US&#160;Airways is not the primary
    beneficiary under these arrangements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(c)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Regional
    Jet Capacity Purchase Agreements</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways has entered into long-term capacity purchase
    agreements with certain regional jet operators and month to
    month agreements with US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned
    regional airline subsidiaries. The capacity purchase agreements
    provide that all revenues (passenger, mail and freight) go to
    US&#160;Airways. In return, US&#160;Airways agrees to pay
    predetermined fees to the regional airlines for operating an
    agreed number of aircraft, without regard to the number of
    passengers onboard. In addition, these agreements provide that
    certain variable costs, such as fuel and airport landing fees,
    will be reimbursed 100% by US&#160;Airways. US&#160;Airways
    controls marketing, scheduling, ticketing, pricing and seat
    inventories. The regional jet capacity purchase agreements have
    expirations from 2012 to 2020 and provide for optional
    extensions at US&#160;Airways&#146; discretion. The future
    minimum noncancelable commitments under the regional jet
    capacity purchase agreements are $1.03&#160;billion in 2007,
    $1.19&#160;billion in 2008, $1.25&#160;billion in 2009,
    $1.27&#160;billion in 2010, $1.30&#160;billion in 2011 and
    $7.28&#160;billion thereafter.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Certain entities with which US&#160;Airways has capacity
    purchase agreements are considered variable interest entities
    under FIN&#160;46(R). In connection with its restructuring and
    emergence from bankruptcy, US&#160;Airways contracted with Air
    Wisconsin, a related party, and Republic to purchase a
    significant portion of these companies&#146; regional jet
    capacity for a period of ten years. US&#160;Airways has
    determined that it is not the primary beneficiary of these
    variable interest entities, based on cash flow analyses.
    Additionally, US&#160;Airways has analyzed the arrangements with
    other carriers with which US&#160;Airways has long-term capacity
    purchase agreements and has concluded it is not required to
    consolidate any of the entities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">&#160;&#160;(d)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Legal
    Proceedings</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On September&#160;12, 2004, US&#160;Airways Group and its
    domestic subsidiaries (the &#147;Reorganized Debtors&#148;)
    filed voluntary petitions for relief under Chapter&#160;11 of
    the Bankruptcy Code in the United States Bankruptcy Court for
    the Eastern District of Virginia, Alexandria Division (Case Nos.
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">04-13819-SSM</FONT>
    through
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">03-13823-SSM)</FONT>
    (the &#147;2004 Bankruptcy&#148;). On September&#160;16, 2005,
    the Bankruptcy Court issued an order confirming the plan of
    reorganization submitted by the Reorganized Debtors and on
    September&#160;27, 2005, the Reorganized Debtors emerged from
    the 2004 Bankruptcy. The Bankruptcy Court&#146;s order
    confirming the plan included a provision called the plan
    injunction, which forever bars other parties from pursuing most
    claims against the Reorganized Debtors that arose prior to
    September&#160;27, 2005 in any forum other than the Bankruptcy
    Court. The great majority of these claims are pre-petition
    claims that, if paid out at all, will be paid out in common
    stock of the post-bankruptcy US&#160;Airways Group at a fraction
    of the actual claim amount.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    203
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On February&#160;26, 2004, a company called I.A.P. Intermodal,
    LLC filed suit against US&#160;Airways Group and its wholly
    owned airline subsidiaries in the United States District Court
    for the Eastern District of Texas alleging that the
    defendants&#146; computer scheduling system infringes upon three
    patents held by plaintiffs, all of which patents are entitled,
    &#147;Method to Schedule a Vehicle in Real-Time to Transport
    Freight and Passengers.&#148; Plaintiff seeks various injunctive
    relief as well as costs, fees and treble damages.
    US&#160;Airways Group and its subsidiaries were formally served
    with the complaint on June&#160;21, 2004. On the same date, the
    same plaintiff filed what US&#160;Airways Group believes to be
    substantially similar cases against nine other major airlines,
    including British Airways, Northwest Airlines Corporation,
    Korean Airlines Co., Ltd., Deutsche Lufthansa AG, Air France,
    Air Canada, Singapore Airlines Ltd., Delta Air Lines and
    Continental Airlines, Inc., and had filed a suit against AMR
    Group, Inc., the parent company of American Airlines, along with
    its airline subsidiaries, in December 2003. This action has been
    stayed as to US&#160;Airways Group and its wholly owned
    subsidiaries as a result of the 2004 Bankruptcy. In the
    meantime, several foreign airline defendants were dismissed from
    the case for reasons unique to their status as foreign
    operators, and the remaining defendants in September 2005
    obtained a ruling that there had been no infringement of any of
    I.A.P.&#146;s patents. In October 2005, I.A.P. entered into
    consent judgments with several defendants. I.A.P. appealed the
    judgment in favor of Continental Airlines and the AMR Group
    defendants, but the trial court&#146;s ruling was affirmed on
    November&#160;13, 2006. No further appeals have been taken.
    I.A.P. did not file any claims against US&#160;Airways Group or
    any of its subsidiaries in the 2004 Bankruptcy.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On January&#160;7, 2003, the Internal Revenue Service
    (&#147;IRS&#148;) issued a notice of proposed adjustment to
    US&#160;Airways Group proposing to disallow $573&#160;million of
    capital losses that US&#160;Airways Group sustained in the tax
    year 1999 on the sale of stock of USLM Corporation (the
    &#147;USLM matter&#148;). On February&#160;5, 2003, the IRS
    filed a proof of claim with the Bankruptcy Court in connection
    with the bankruptcy case filed on August&#160;11, 2002 (the
    &#147;2002 Bankruptcy&#148;) asserting the following claims
    against US&#160;Airways with respect to the USLM matter:
    (1)&#160;secured claims for U.S.&#160;federal income tax and
    interest of $1&#160;million; (2)&#160;unsecured priority claims
    for U.S.&#160;federal income tax of $68&#160;million and
    interest of $14&#160;million; and (3)&#160;an unsecured general
    claim for penalties of $25&#160;million. On May&#160;8, 2003,
    US&#160;Airways Group reached a tentative agreement with the IRS
    on the amount of U.S.&#160;federal income taxes, interest and
    penalties due subject to final approval from the Joint Committee
    on Taxation. By letter dated September&#160;11, 2003,
    US&#160;Airways Group was notified that the Joint Committee on
    Taxation had accepted the tentative agreement with the IRS,
    including a settlement of all federal income taxes through the
    end of 2002. Due to the 2004 Bankruptcy filing, which suspended
    payment of prepetition liabilities, final payment terms under
    the agreement have not been submitted to the Bankruptcy Court
    for approval. The IRS has submitted a proof of claim relating to
    the USLM matter in the 2004 Bankruptcy in the amount of
    approximately $31&#160;million, and on August&#160;2, 2005 the
    IRS filed a motion for relief from the automatic stay seeking to
    setoff against approximately $4&#160;million of tax refunds due
    to the Reorganized Debtors. On October&#160;20, 2005, the IRS
    filed an amended proof of claim reducing its claim in the USLM
    matter to $11&#160;million. On November&#160;3, 2005, the IRS
    filed an amended motion continuing to seek relief for the
    $4&#160;million setoff. US&#160;Airways and the IRS have reached
    an agreement to settle the USLM matter whereby the IRS would
    setoff approximately $4.5&#160;million of tax refunds and the
    IRS would be allowed an unsecured priority claim in the amount
    of approximately $6.5&#160;million, payable within 30&#160;days
    after the agreement is filed with the Bankruptcy Court. The
    agreement was filed with the Bankruptcy Court on
    February&#160;18, 2007 and the matter is now closed.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On February&#160;8, 2006, 103 flight attendants employed by the
    former MidAtlantic division of US&#160;Airways filed a complaint
    against the Association of Flight Attendants (&#147;AFA&#148;),
    AFA&#146;s international president Pat Friend and
    US&#160;Airways, alleging that defendants conspired to deceive
    plaintiffs into believing that MidAtlantic was a separate entity
    from US&#160;Airways in order to deprive them of the benefits
    they are due as US&#160;Airways flight attendants pursuant to
    the US&#160;Airways collective bargaining agreement.
    Plaintiffs&#146; claims against US&#160;Airways include breach
    of collective bargaining agreement, violation of the Railway
    Labor Act and racketeering under RICO. Plaintiffs&#146;
    complaint requests $400&#160;million in damages from
    US&#160;Airways and injunctive relief. The complaint was served
    on US&#160;Airways on July&#160;7, 2006. On November&#160;24,
    2006, Plaintiffs filed with the district court a notice of
    voluntary dismissal of US&#160;Airways from the litigation, and
    on November&#160;27, 2006, US&#160;Airways filed a notice
    withdrawing its
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    204
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    motion for sanctions. On December&#160;29, 2006, the district
    court entered an order dismissing US&#160;Airways from the
    litigation.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On October&#160;12, 2005, Bank of America, N.A., which is one of
    the issuing banks of the US&#160;Airways frequent flyer program
    credit card and which also acts as the processing bank for most
    airline ticket purchases paid for with credit cards, filed suit
    in the Delaware Chancery Court in New Castle County against
    US&#160;Airways, US&#160;Airways Group and AWA, alleging that
    US&#160;Airways breached its frequent flyer credit card contract
    with Bank of America by entering into a similar, competing
    agreement with Juniper and allowing Juniper to issue a
    US&#160;Airways frequent flyer credit card. Bank of America also
    alleges that US&#160;Airways Group and AWA induced these
    breaches. Bank of America seeks an order requiring
    US&#160;Airways to market the Bank of America card and prohibit
    Juniper from issuing a US&#160;Airways credit card, as well as
    unspecified damages. On October&#160;27, 2005, Juniper Bank, a
    subsidiary of Barclays PLC (&#147;Juniper&#148;), which was not
    originally a party to the lawsuit, sought and later received
    court permission to intervene as a defendant in the case and has
    made counterclaims against Bank of America. Juniper seeks an
    order declaring the validity of its new agreement to issue a
    US&#160;Airways frequent flyer credit card. On November&#160;3,
    2005, Bank of America filed a motion for partial summary
    judgment on the breach of contract claim against
    US&#160;Airways. After a series of procedural steps, Bank of
    America&#146;s motion, along with a cross-motion for summary
    judgment filed by Juniper, was heard in the Bankruptcy Court,
    where the case is now pending as an adversary proceeding. On
    January&#160;30, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court ruled that Bank of
    America was equitably estopped from pursuing its claims that
    US&#160;Airways breached its agreement with Bank of America by
    negotiating and entering into the agreement with Juniper. The
    Bankruptcy Court ruled in the alternative that US&#160;Airways
    did not breach its agreement with Bank of America to be the
    exclusive card issuer, but that US&#160;Airways had breached the
    &#147;no shop&#148; provision of the Bank of America agreement
    when US&#160;Airways negotiated with Juniper prior to reaching
    the Juniper agreement. Bank of America sought appeal of that
    ruling while it has continued to pursue certain administrative
    claims against US&#160;Airways in the Bankruptcy Court. The
    resolution of the final two claims that Bank of America made in
    the lawsuit, which are (i)&#160;that AWA tortiously interfered
    with the contractual relationship between US&#160;Airways and
    Bank of America and (ii)&#160;that US&#160;Airways Group and AWA
    tortiously interfered with Bank of America&#146;s right to
    future economic benefit under its agreement with
    US&#160;Airways, are dependent on the outcome of the pending
    appeal. Bank of America will pursue those two claims only if its
    appeal of the January&#160;30, 2006 order is ultimately
    successful. On July&#160;19, 2006, the Eastern District of
    Virginia affirmed the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s order in part,
    ruling that US&#160;Airways did not breach the exclusivity
    provisions of the contract. However, the Eastern District of
    Virginia reversed the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s decision on
    equitable estoppel and remanded the remainder of the case to the
    Bankruptcy Court to take further evidence. Bank of America and
    US&#160;Airways have each appealed the July&#160;19, 2006
    ruling. On January&#160;16, 2007, Bank of America amended its
    complaint to add additional breach of contract and tortious
    interference claims against US&#160;Airways and AWA, as well as
    claims against Juniper.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On February&#160;9, 2007, passengers Daphne Renard and Todd
    Robins filed a class action suit against US&#160;Airways in
    San&#160;Francisco Superior Court. The complaint alleges that
    US&#160;Airways breached its contract of carriage by charging
    additional fares and fees, after the purchase of tickets on the
    usairways.com website, for passengers under two years of age who
    travel as &#147;lap children,&#148; meaning that the child does
    not occupy his or her own seat but travels instead on the lap of
    an accompanying adult. The named plaintiffs allege that they
    purchased international tickets through the website for
    themselves and a lap child. Plaintiffs allege that after
    initially receiving an electronic confirmation that there would
    be no charge for the lap child, they were later charged an
    additional $242.50. The complaint alleges a class period from
    February&#160;9, 2002 to the present. US&#160;Airways has not
    yet been served with the lawsuit.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways is unable to estimate at this time the amount of
    loss or probable losses, if any, that might result from an
    adverse resolution of the proceedings discussed above, and
    currently is unable to predict whether the outcome of these
    proceedings will have a material adverse effect on its results
    of operations or financial condition. US&#160;Airways intends,
    however, to vigorously pursue all available defenses and claims
    in these matters.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    205
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">(e)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Guarantees
    and Indemnifications</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways guarantees the payment of principal and interest
    on certain special facility revenue bonds issued by
    municipalities to build or improve certain airport and
    maintenance facilities which are leased to US&#160;Airways.
    Under such leases, US&#160;Airways is required to make rental
    payments through 2023, sufficient to pay maturing principal and
    interest payments on the related bonds. As of December&#160;31,
    2006, the principal amount outstanding on these bonds was
    $74&#160;million. Remaining lease payments guaranteeing the
    principal and interest on these bonds will be $124&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways enters into real estate leases in substantially
    all cities that it serves. It is common in such commercial lease
    transactions for US&#160;Airways as the lessee to agree to
    indemnify the lessor and other related third parties for tort
    liabilities that arise out of or relate to the use or occupancy
    of the leased premises. In some cases, this indemnity extends to
    related liabilities arising from the negligence of the
    indemnified parties, but usually excludes any liabilities caused
    by their gross negligence or willful misconduct. Additionally,
    US&#160;Airways typically indemnifies such parties for any
    environmental liability that arises out of or relates to its use
    or occupancy of the leased premises.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In aircraft financing agreements, US&#160;Airways typically
    indemnifies the financing parties, trustees acting on their
    behalf and other related parties against liabilities that arise
    from the manufacture, design, ownership, financing, use,
    operation and maintenance of the aircraft and for tort
    liability, whether or not these liabilities arise out of or
    relate to the negligence of these indemnified parties, except
    for their gross negligence or willful misconduct. In aircraft
    financing transactions structured as leveraged leases,
    US&#160;Airways typically indemnifies the lessor with respect to
    adverse changes in U.S.&#160;tax laws.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways reviewed its long-term operating leases at a
    number of airports, including leases where US&#160;Airways is
    also the guarantor of the underlying debt. Such leases are
    typically with municipalities or other governmental entities.
    The arrangements are not required to be consolidated based on
    the provisions of FIN&#160;46(R).
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways, America West Holdings, AWA, and other
    subsidiaries of US&#160;Airways Group are all guarantors of the
    $1.25&#160;billion GE Loan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s 7%&#160;Senior Convertible Notes
    are fully and unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and severally
    and on a senior unsecured basis, by US&#160;Airways and AWA.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">(f)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Concentration
    of Credit Risk</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways invests available cash in money market
    securities of various banks, commercial paper and asset-backed
    securities of various financial institutions, other companies
    with high credit ratings and securities backed by the
    U.S.&#160;government.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, most of US&#160;Airways&#146;
    receivables related to tickets sold to individual passengers
    through the use of major credit cards or to tickets sold by
    other airlines and used by passengers on US&#160;Airways or its
    regional airline affiliates. These receivables are short-term,
    mostly being settled within seven days after sale. Bad debt
    losses, which have been minimal in the past, have been
    considered in establishing allowances for doubtful accounts.
    US&#160;Airways does not believe it is subject to any
    significant concentration of credit risk.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    206
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The net payable to US&#160;Airways Group consists of
    $1.1&#160;billion due to debt previously recorded at
    US&#160;Airways which was refinanced with proceeds from the GE
    Loan (see Note&#160;5). The remainder of the payable to
    US&#160;Airways Group is a result of funds provided and received
    from US&#160;Airways Group that arise in the normal course of
    business.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways recorded interest expense of $70&#160;million
    for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006, $6&#160;million for
    the three months ended December&#160;31, 2005, $1&#160;million
    for the nine months ended September&#160;30, 2005, and
    $2&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2004
    related to the above transactions and other transactions with
    the subsidiaries as described below. Interest is calculated at
    market rates, which are reset quarterly.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The net payable to and from AWA consists of amounts due to and
    from AWA relating to items such as debt extinguishment, merger
    related payments and receipts, and various other transactions
    that occur in the normal course of business that one airline
    settles on behalf of the other.
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways purchases all of the capacity (ASMs) generated
    by US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned regional airline
    subsidiaries at a rate per ASM that is periodically determined
    by US&#160;Airways and, concurrently, recognizes revenues that
    result primarily from passengers being carried by these
    affiliated companies. The rate per ASM that US&#160;Airways pays
    is based on estimates of the costs incurred to supply the
    capacity. US&#160;Airways recognized US&#160;Airways Express
    capacity purchase expense of $433&#160;million for the year
    ended December&#160;31, 2006, $96&#160;million for the three
    months ended December&#160;31, 2005, $306&#160;million for the
    nine months ended September&#160;30, 2005, and $472&#160;million
    for the year ended December&#160;31, 2004, related to this
    program.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways provides various services to these regional
    airlines including passenger handling, maintenance and catering.
    US&#160;Airways recognized other operating revenues of
    $96&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006,
    $22&#160;million for the three months ended December&#160;31,
    2005, $64&#160;million for the nine months ended
    September&#160;30, 2005, and $71&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2004 related to these services. These regional
    airlines also perform passenger and ground handling for
    US&#160;Airways at certain airports for which US&#160;Airways
    recognized other operating expenses of $145&#160;million for the
    year ended December&#160;31, 2006, $32&#160;million for the
    three months ended December&#160;31, 2005, $100&#160;million for
    the nine months ended September&#160;30, 2005, and
    $126&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2004,
    related to these expenses. US&#160;Airways also leases or
    subleases certain aircraft to these regional airline
    subsidiaries. US&#160;Airways recognized other operating
    revenues related to these arrangements of $80&#160;million for
    the year ended December&#160;31, 2006, $21&#160;million for the
    three months ended December&#160;31, 2005, $65&#160;million for
    the nine months ended September&#160;30, 2005, and
    $55&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways purchases a portion of its aviation fuel from
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s wholly owned subsidiary, MSC, which
    acts as a fuel wholesaler to US&#160;Airways in certain
    circumstances. US&#160;Airways&#146; aviation fuel purchases
    from MSC were $680 for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006,
    $120&#160;million for the three months ended December&#160;31,
    2005, $191&#160;million for the nine months ended
    September&#160;30, 2005, and $34&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2004. Effective July&#160;1, 2000, the
    activities of a certain division of MSC were transferred into
    US&#160;Airways and MSC began receiving a portion of its fuel
    inventory from US&#160;Airways.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways&#146; net payable to other US&#160;Airways Group
    wholly owned subsidiaries of $76&#160;million consists of a net
    receivable from America West Holdings of $1&#160;million and net
    payables to Piedmont of $24&#160;million, PSA of
    $12&#160;million, and MSC of $41&#160;million, respectively, at
    December&#160;31, 2006. At December&#160;31, 2005 the net
    payable to Piedmont, PSA and MSC was $19&#160;million,
    $12&#160;million, and $16&#160;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">(c)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">RSA</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of March&#160;31, 2003, at the time of emergence from
    US&#160;Airways&#146; first bankruptcy, Retirement Systems of
    Alabama Holdings LLC (&#147;RSA&#148;) held approximately 36.2%,
    on a fully-diluted basis, of US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s
    equity, had a voting interest of approximately 71.6% and was
    entitled to designate and vote to elect eight of
    15&#160;directors to US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s board of
    directors. Total amounts due to RSA at December&#160;31, 2004
    and 2003 included $54&#160;million and $73&#160;million,
    respectively, of the initial $100&#160;million at-risk amounts
    under the ATSB loan. Interest expense and interest payments on
    RSA&#146;s portion of the ATSB Loan was $4&#160;million for the
    nine months ended September&#160;30, 2005. Interest expense on
    RSA&#146;s portion of the ATSB Loan was $5&#160;million with
    interest payments of $5&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2004. In connection with US&#160;Airways&#146;
    emergence from bankruptcy and merger with America West Holdings
    on September&#160;27, 2005, any stock held by RSA and their
    board seats were cancelled. RSA no longer has the right to elect
    directors to the US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s board of directors.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">(d)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Shared
    Operating Expenses</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The operating expenses of US&#160;Airways reflect expenses for
    certain services shared with AWA, including technology and data
    processing services, corporate functions such as tax, legal,
    compliance, finance and operations, and the costs of the
    combined Dividend Miles frequent traveler program. These shared
    costs have been allocated based on US&#160;Airways&#146; and
    AWA&#146;s respective revenue passenger miles
    (&#147;RPMs&#148;). The operating expenses of
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways also reflect shared expenses incurred at more
    than 30 overlap airports where the operations of US&#160;Airways
    and AWA have been consolidated. These shared costs have been
    allocated based on US&#160;Airways&#146; and AWA&#146;s
    respective departures at those airports. Management believes
    that the methodologies underlying the allocation of these shared
    costs are reasonable. The following details the total corporate
    shared expenses and airport shared expenses allocated to
    US&#160;Airways and AWA that are included in operating expenses
    for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006 (in millions):
</DIV>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">11.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Stockholder&#146;s
    Equity and Dividend Restrictions</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group owns all of US&#160;Airways&#146;
    outstanding common stock, par value $1&#160;per share.
    US&#160;Airways&#146; board of directors has not authorized the
    payment of dividends on the common stock since 1988.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways, organized under the laws of the State of
    Delaware, is subject to Sections&#160;160 and 170 of the
    Delaware General Corporation Law with respect to the payment of
    dividends on or the repurchase or redemption of its capital
    stock. US&#160;Airways is restricted from engaging in any of
    these activities unless it maintains a capital surplus. In
    addition, US&#160;Airways may not pay dividends in accordance
    with provisions contained in the GE Loan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">12.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Nonoperating
    Income (Expenses)&#160;&#151; Other, Net</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2006 and 2005, US&#160;Airways recorded $11&#160;million and
    $4&#160;million, respectively, of derivative gains attributable
    to stock options in Sabre and warrants in a number of companies.
    On an ongoing basis, US&#160;Airways adjusts its balance sheet
    to reflect changes in the current fair market value of the stock
    options and warrants according to SFAS&#160;133.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">13.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Operating
    Segments and Related Disclosures</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group is managed as a single business unit that
    provides air transportation for passengers and cargo. This
    allows it to benefit from an integrated revenue pricing and
    route network that includes US&#160;Airways, AWA, Piedmont, PSA
    and third-party carriers that fly under capacity purchase
    agreements as part of US&#160;Airways Express. The flight
    equipment of all these carriers is combined to form one fleet
    that is deployed through a single route scheduling system. When
    making resource allocation decisions, the chief operating
    decision maker evaluates flight profitability data, which
    considers aircraft type and route economics, but gives no weight
    to the financial impact of the resource allocation decision on
    an individual carrier basis. The objective in making resource
    allocation decisions is to maximize consolidated financial
    results, not the individual results of US&#160;Airways, AWA,
    Piedmont and PSA.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Information concerning operating revenues in principal
    geographic areas is as follows (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways attributes operating revenues by geographic
    region based upon the origin and destination of each flight
    segment. US&#160;Airways&#146; tangible assets consist primarily
    of flight equipment, which are mobile across geographic markets
    and, therefore, have not been allocated.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">14.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Stock-based
    Compensation</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Predecessor Company recorded stock-based employee
    compensation in accordance with SFAS&#160;123 during the year
    ended December&#160;31, 2004 and during 2005 until the merger.
    Effective with the merger on September&#160;27, 2005,
    US&#160;Airways applied the provisions of APB&#160;25 and
    related interpretations. Effective January&#160;1, 2006,
    US&#160;Airways adopted SFAS&#160;123R, using the modified
    prospective transition method. Under the modified prospective
    transition method, compensation cost is recognized in the
    financial statements beginning with the effective date, based on
    the requirements of SFAS&#160;123R for all share-based payments
    granted after that date, and based on the requirements of
    SFAS&#160;123 for all unvested awards granted prior to the
    effective date of SFAS&#160;123R. Results for prior periods are
    not restated using the modified prospective transition method.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">(a)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Predecessor
    Company</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Upon confirmation of the Plan of Reorganization, existing shares
    of US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s common stock were cancelled. The
    Plan of Reorganization resulted in holders of US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s common stock and related equity securities
    receiving no distribution on account of their interest.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Prior to cancellation of the shares of US&#160;Airways
    Group&#146;s common stock upon emergence from bankruptcy on
    September&#160;27, 2005, there were 4,750,000&#160;shares of
    US&#160;Airways Group Class&#160;A Common Stock and 2,220,570
    each of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Class&#160;A-1</FONT>
    Warrants and shares of Class&#160;A Preferred Stock authorized
    to be granted to US&#160;Airways&#146; management. Through
    September&#160;27, 2005, 3,649,159&#160;shares of
    US&#160;Airways Group Class&#160;A Common Stock, 2,101,240 each
    of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Class&#160;A-1</FONT>
    Warrants and shares of Class&#160;A Preferred Stock, and 354,350
    options to purchase Class&#160;A Common Stock were granted to
    US&#160;Airways&#146; management. Grants of Class&#160;A Common
    Stock, stock options and warrants generally vested over four
    years. The Predecessor Company recorded compensation expense
    over the vesting period. The following table summarizes the
    activity of the Predecessor Company&#146;s stock options and
    warrants granted since emergence from the first bankruptcy
    through cancellation of those shares upon emergence from the
    second bankruptcy:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    There were no stock options or warrants granted during the nine
    months ended September&#160;30, 2005. The weighted average fair
    value of stock options and warrants granted during the year
    ended December&#160;31, 2004 was $0.80 and $2.70, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group did not grant any shares of restricted
    stock during the nine months ended September&#160;30, 2005.
    US&#160;Airways Group granted 835,160&#160;shares of restricted
    Class&#160;A Common Stock during the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2004. There were 1,683,674 non-vested shares
    of restricted stock outstanding immediately prior to
    cancellation upon emergence from the second bankruptcy on
    September&#160;27, 2005.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    210
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The weighted average fair value per share of US&#160;Airways
    Group Class&#160;A Common Stock grants was $1.87 in the year
    ended December&#160;31, 2004. In order to calculate the
    stock-based compensation for stock options and warrants using
    the fair value method provisions in SFAS&#160;123,
    US&#160;Airways used the Black-Scholes stock option-pricing
    model with the following weighted-average assumptions:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=hang1 -->

    &#151;

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways recognized compensation expense related to
    US&#160;Airways Group Class&#160;A Common Stock, stock option
    and stock warrant grants to US&#160;Airways employees of
    $11&#160;million and $50&#160;million for the nine months ended
    September&#160;30, 2005 and the year ended December&#160;31,
    2004, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">(b)&#160;&#160;</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Successor
    Company</FONT></I></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Effective with the merger on September&#160;27, 2005,
    US&#160;Airways applied the provisions of APB&#160;25 and
    related interpretations. Effective January&#160;1, 2006,
    US&#160;Airways Group adopted SFAS&#160;123R, using the modified
    prospective transition method.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Substantially all of America West Holdings&#146; and AWA&#146;s
    employee stock options outstanding at the time of the merger
    were fully vested in accordance with the change of control
    provisions of America West Holdings&#146; stock option plans and
    were converted into options of US&#160;Airways Group. Existing
    stock options of US&#160;Airways Group outstanding prior to the
    merger on September&#160;27, 2005 were cancelled as part of the
    plan of reorganization. Accordingly, as of January&#160;1, 2006,
    only unvested stock options, stock appreciation rights and
    restricted stock units granted subsequent to and in connection
    with the merger are subject to the transition provisions of
    SFAS&#160;123R. As part of the plan of reorganization, the
    Bankruptcy Court approved a new equity incentive plan, referred
    to as the 2005 Incentive Equity Plan (the &#147;2005 Incentive
    Plan&#148;). The 2005 Incentive Plan provides for the grant of
    incentive stock options, nonstatutory stock options, stock
    appreciation rights, stock purchase awards, stock bonus awards,
    stock unit awards, and other forms of equity compensation,
    collectively referred to as stock awards, as well as
    performance-based cash awards. Incentive stock options granted
    under the 2005 Incentive Plan are intended to qualify as
    &#147;incentive stock options&#148; within the meaning of
    Section&#160;422 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as
    amended. Nonstatutory stock options granted under the 2005
    Incentive Plan are not intended to qualify as incentive stock
    options under the Internal Revenue Code.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    A maximum of 12.5% of the fully-diluted shares (as of the
    completion of the merger) of US&#160;Airways Group common stock
    is available for issuance under the 2005 Incentive Plan,
    totaling 10,969,191&#160;shares. Any or all of these shares may
    be granted pursuant to incentive stock options. Shares of
    US&#160;Airways Group common stock issued under the 2005
    Incentive Plan may be unissued shares or reacquired shares,
    purchased on the open market or otherwise. At December&#160;31,
    2006, approximately 5.5&#160;million shares are available for
    grant under the 2005 Equity Incentive Plan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The number of shares of US&#160;Airways Group common stock
    available for issuance under the 2005 Incentive Plan will be
    reduced by (i)&#160;one share for each share of stock issued
    pursuant to a stock option or a stock appreciation right, and
    (ii)&#160;three shares for each share of stock issued pursuant
    to a stock purchase award, stock bonus award, stock unit award,
    and other full-value types of stock awards. Stock awards that
    are terminated, forfeited or repurchased will result in an
    increase in the share reserve of the 2005 Incentive Plan
    corresponding to the reduction originally made in respect of the
    award.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    211
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    If a stock award granted under the 2005 Incentive Plan or
    AWA&#146;s previous incentive plan (the &#147;2002 Incentive
    Plan&#148;) expires or otherwise terminates without being
    exercised in full, or if any shares of US&#160;Airways Group
    common stock issued pursuant to a stock award under the 2005
    Incentive Plan are forfeited to or repurchased by
    US&#160;Airways Group, including, but not limited to, any
    repurchase or forfeiture caused by the failure to meet a
    contingency or condition required for the vesting of such
    shares, then the shares of US&#160;Airways Group common stock
    not issued under that stock award, or forfeited to or
    repurchased by US&#160;Airways Group, will revert to and again
    become available for issuance under the 2005 Incentive Plan. If
    any shares subject to a stock award are not delivered to a
    participant because those shares are withheld for the payment of
    taxes or the stock award is exercised through a reduction of
    shares subject to the stock award (<I>i.e</I>., &#147;net
    exercised&#148;), the number of shares that are not delivered
    will remain available for issuance under the 2005 Incentive
    Plan. If the exercise price of any stock award is satisfied by
    tendering shares of US&#160;Airways Group common stock held by
    the participant, then the number of shares so tendered (whether
    by actual tender or by attestation of ownership) will remain
    available for issuance under the 2005 Incentive Plan. Shares of
    US&#160;Airways Group common stock subject to stock awards
    issued in substitution for previously outstanding awards assumed
    in connection with a merger, consolidation or similar
    transaction will not reduce the number of shares available for
    issuance under the 2005 Incentive Plan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s net income for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006 includes $35&#160;million of compensation
    costs related to share-based payments. Of the $35&#160;million
    recorded by US&#160;Airways Group, $12&#160;million was
    allocated to the financials of AWA and $23&#160;million was
    allocated to the financials of US&#160;Airways. Compensation
    expense of $4&#160;million, calculated using the provisions of
    APB&#160;25, was recorded for stock appreciation rights and
    restricted stock units granted to employees of US&#160;Airways
    Group in the fourth quarter of 2005. Of the $4&#160;million
    recorded by US&#160;Airways Group, $3&#160;million was allocated
    to the financials of AWA and $1&#160;million was allocated to
    the financials of US&#160;Airways. Upon adoption of
    SFAS&#160;123R, US&#160;Airways Group recorded a cumulative
    benefit from the accounting change of $1&#160;million, which
    reflects the impact of estimating future forfeitures for
    previously recognized compensation expense. Pursuant to
    APB&#160;25, stock compensation expense was not reduced for
    estimated future forfeitures, but instead was reversed upon
    actual forfeiture. No income tax effect related to share-based
    payments or cumulative effect has been recorded as the effects
    have been immediately offset by the recording of a valuation
    allowance through the same financial statement caption.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Restricted Stock Unit Awards</I>&#160;&#151; As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, US&#160;Airways Group has outstanding
    restricted stock unit awards (&#147;RSUs&#148;) with service
    conditions (vesting periods) and RSUs with service and
    performance conditions (vesting periods and obtaining a combined
    operating certificate for AWA and US&#160;Airways).
    SFAS&#160;123R requires that the grant-date fair value of RSUs
    be equal to the market price of the share on the date of grant
    if vesting is based on a service or a performance condition. The
    grant-date fair value of RSU awards that are subject to both a
    service and a performance condition are being expensed over the
    vesting period, as the performance condition is considered
    probable and the vesting periods of the awards are longer than
    the period allowed to meet the performance condition. Vesting
    periods for RSU awards range from two to four years. RSUs are
    classified as equity awards.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    212
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, there was $12&#160;million of
    total unrecognized compensation costs related to RSUs which will
    be allocated to AWA and US&#160;Airways. These costs are
    expected to be recognized over a weighted average period of
    1.1&#160;years. The total fair value of restricted stock awards
    vested during 2006 was $3&#160;million. No restricted stock
    vested during 2005 or 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Stock Options and Stock Appreciation Rights</I>&#160;&#151;
    Stock options and stock appreciation rights (&#147;SARs&#148;)
    are granted with an exercise price equal to the fair market
    value of US&#160;Airways Group common stock at the date of each
    grant, generally become exercisable over a three to four-year
    period and expire if unexercised at the end of ten years. Stock
    options and SARs are classified as equity awards. The exercise
    of SARs will be settled with the issuance of shares of
    US&#160;Airways Group&#146;s common stock.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    213
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">US&#160;Airways,
    Inc.</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes to the Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Stock option and SAR activity for the year ending
    December&#160;31, 2006 is as follows (stock options and SARs in
    thousands):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The fair value of stock options and SARs is determined at the
    grant date using a Black-Scholes option pricing model, which
    requires several assumptions. The risk-free interest rate is
    based on the U.S.&#160;Treasury yield curve in effect for the
    expected term of the stock option or SAR at the time of grant.
    The dividend yield is assumed to be zero since US&#160;Airways
    Group does not pay dividends and has no current plans to do so
    in the future. The volatility is based on the historical
    volatility of US&#160;Airways Group common stock over a time
    period equal to the expected term of the stock option or SAR.
    The expected life of stock options and SARs is based on the
    historical experience of US&#160;Airways Group.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The per share weighted-average grant-date fair value of stock
    options and SARs granted and the weighted-average assumptions
    used for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006, 2005, and 2004
    were as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=quadright -->
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=gutter -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, there was $24&#160;million of
    total unrecognized compensation costs related to stock options
    and SARs which will be allocated to AWA and US&#160;Airways.
    These costs are expected to be recognized over a weighted
    average period of 1.4&#160;years.
